text.wiki:
Nara (奈良市, Nara-shi, Japanese: [naꜜɾa]) is the capital city of Nara Prefecture, Japan. 
As of 1 April 2019, Nara has an estimated population of 359,666, making it the largest city in Nara Prefecture and sixth-largest in the Kansai region of Honshu. Nara is a core city located in the northern part of Nara Prefecture bordering the Kyoto Prefecture. 
Nara was the capital of Japan during the Nara period from 710 to 794 as the seat of the Emperor before the capital was moved to Kyoto. Nara is home to eight temples, shrines, and ruins, specifically Tōdai-ji, Saidai-ji, Kōfuku-ji, Kasuga Shrine, Gangō-ji, Yakushi-ji, Tōshōdai-ji, and the Heijō Palace, together with Kasugayama Primeval Forest, collectively form the Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 


== Etymology ==
By the Heian period, a variety of different characters had been used to represent the name Nara: 乃楽, 乃羅, 平, 平城, 名良, 奈良, 奈羅, 常, 那良, 那楽, 那羅, 楢, 諾良, 諾楽, 寧, 寧楽 and 儺羅.
A number of theories for the origin of the name "Nara" have been proposed, and some of the better-known ones are listed here. The second theory in the list, from the notable folklorist Kunio Yanagita (1875-1962), is most widely accepted at present.

The Nihon Shoki (The Chronicles of Japan, the second oldest book of classical Japanese history) suggests that "Nara" was derived from narasu (to flatten, to level). According to this account, in September in the tenth year of Emperor Sujin, "leading selected soldiers (the rebels) went forward, climbed Nara-yama (hills lying to the north of Heijō-kyō) and put them in order. Now the imperial forces gathered and flattened trees and plants. Therefore the mountain is called Nara-yama." Though the narrative itself is regarded as a folk etymology and few researchers regard it as historical, this is the oldest surviving suggestion, and is linguistically similar to the following theory by Yanagita.
"Flat land" theory (currently most widely accepted): In his 1936 study of placenames, the author Kunio Yanagita states that "the topographical feature of an area of relatively gentle gradient on the side of a mountain, which is called taira in eastern Japan and hae in the south of Kyushu, is called naru in the Chūgoku region and Shikoku (central Japan). This word gives rise to the verb narasu, adverb narashi, and adjective narushi." This is supported by entries in a dialect dictionary for nouns referring to flat areas: naru (found in Aida District, Okayama Prefecture and Ketaka District, Tottori Prefecture) and naro (found in Kōchi Prefecture); and also by an adjective narui which is not standard Japanese, but is found all across central Japan, with meanings of "gentle", "gently sloping", or "easy". Yanagita further comments that the way in which the fact that so many of these placenames are written using the character 平 ("flat"), or other characters in which it is an element, demonstrates the validity of this theory. Citing a 1795 document, Inaba-shi (因幡志) from the province of Inaba, the eastern part of modern Tottori, as indicating the reading naruji for the word 平地 (standard reading heichi, meaning "level/flat ground/land/country, a plain"), Yanagita suggests that naruji would have been used as a common noun there until the modern period. Of course, the fact that historically "Nara" was also written 平 or 平城 as above is further support for this theory.
The idea that Nara is derived from 楢 nara (Japanese for "oak, deciduous Quercus spp.") is the next most common opinion. This idea was suggested by a linguist, Yoshida Togo. This noun for the plant can be seen as early as in Man'yōshū (7-8th century) and Harima-no-kuni Fudoki (715). The latter book states the place name Narahara in Harima (around present-day Kasai)　derives from this nara tree, which might support Yoshida's theory. Note that the name of the nearby city of Kashihara (literally "live oak plain") contains a semantically similar morpheme (Japanese 橿 kashi "live oak, evergreen Quercus spp.").
Nara could be a loan word from Korean nara (나라 : country, nation, kingdom). This idea was put forward by a linguist Matsuoka Shizuo. Not much about the Old Korean language is known today, and the first written attestation of a word ancestral to Modern Korean nara is as late as the 15th century, such as in Yongbieocheonga (1447),  Wolinseokbo (月印釋譜. 1459), or Beophwagyeongeonhae (法華經諺解. 1463), and there is no evidence that proves the word already existed as far back as the 7th century. These 15th-century books used narah (나랗), an old form of nara in Korean, and its older form might be reconstructed *narak. American  linguist Christopher I. Beckwith infers the Korean narak derives from the late Middle Old Chinese 壌 (*nrak, earth), from early *narak, and has no connection with Goguryoic and Japanese na. (See also the next theory.) Kusuhara et al. also points out this hypothesis cannot account for the fact there are many places named Nara, Naru and Naro besides this Nara.
There is the idea that Nara is akin to Tungusic na. In some Tungusic languages such as Orok (and likely Goguryeo language), na means earth, land or the like. Some have speculated about a connection between these Tungusic words and Old Japanese nawi, an archaic and somewhat obscure word that appears in the verb phrases nawi furu and nawi yoru ('an earthquake occurs, to have an earthquake').The "Flat land" theory is adopted by Nihon Kokugo Daijiten (the largest dictionary of Japanese language), various dictionaries for place names, history books on Nara and the like today, and it is regarded as the most likely.


== History ==


=== Pre-Nara/Origins ===
There are a number of kofun in Nara, including Gosashi Kofun, Hishiage Kofun (ヒシアゲ古墳), Horaisan Kofun (宝来山古墳), Konabe Kofun (コナベ古墳), Saki Ishizukayama Kofun (佐紀石塚山古墳), Saki Misasagiyama Kofun (佐紀陵山古墳), and Uwanabe Kofun (ウワナベ古墳).
By decree of an edict on March 11, 708 AD, Empress Genmei ordered the court to relocate to the new capital, Nara. Once known as Heijō or Heijō-kyō, the city was established as Japan's first permanent capital in 710 CE; it was the seat of government until 784 CE, albeit with five year interruption, lasting from 741-5 CE. Heijō, as the ‘penultimate court’, however, was abandoned by the order of Emperor Kammu in 784 CE in favor of the temporary site of Nagaoka, and then Heian-kyō (Kyoto) which retained the status of capital for 1,100 years, until the Meiji Emperor made the final move to Edo in 1869 CE. This first relocation was due to the court's transformation from an imperial nobility to a force of metropolitan elites and new technique of dynastic shedding which had refashioned the relationship between court, nobility, and country. Moreover, the ancient capital lent its name to Nara period.As a reactionary expression to the political centralization of China, the city of Nara (Heijō) was modeled after the Tang capital at Chang’an. Nara was laid out on a grid—which was based upon the Handen system—whereby the city was divided by four great roads. Likewise, according to Chinese cosmology, the ruler's place was fixed like the pole star. By dominating the capital, the ruler brought heaven to earth. Thus, the south facing palace centered at the north, bisected the ancient city, instituting ‘Right Capital’ and ‘Left Capital’ zones. As Nara came to be the epicenter of Buddhist church and drawing pilgrimage site, the city plan incorporated various pre-Heijō and Heijō period temples, of which the Yakushiji and the Todaiji still stand.
Gallery
		


=== Politics ===
A number of scholars have characterized the Nara period as a time of penal and administrative legal order. The Taihō Code called for the establishment of administrative sects underneath the central government, and modeled many of the codes from the Chinese Tang dynasty. The code eventually disbanded, but its contents were largely preserved in the Yōrō Code of 718.Occupants of the throne during the period gradually shifted their focus from military preparation, to religious rites and institutions, in an attempt to strengthen their divine authority over the population.


=== Religion and Temples ===
Nanto RokushūWith the establishment of the new capital, Asuka-dera, the temple of the Soga clan, was relocated within Nara. The Emperor Shōmu ordered the construction of Tōdai-ji Temple (largest wooden building in the world) and the world's largest bronze Buddha statue. The temples of Nara, known collectively as the Nanto Shichi Daiji, remained spiritually significant even beyond the move of the political capital to Heian-kyō in 794, thus giving Nara a synonym of Nanto (南都 "The southern Capital").
On December 2, 724 AD, in order to increase the visual “magnificence” of the city, an edict was ordered by the government for the noblemen and the wealthy to renovate the roofs, pillars, and walls of their homes, although at that time this was unfeasible.Sightseeing in Nara city became popular in the Edo period, during which several visitor's maps of Nara were widely published. During the Meiji Period, the Kofukuji Temple lost some land and its monks were converted into Shinto priests, due to Buddhism being associated with the old shogunate.
Gallery
		
		
		
		
		


=== Modern Nara ===
Even though Nara was the capital of Japan from 710 to 794, it was not designated a city until 1 February, 1898. Nara city has developed from a town of commerce in the Edo and Meiji periods to a modern tourist city, due to its large number of historical temples, landmarks and national monuments. Nara was added to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in December 1998. The architecture of some shops, ryokans and art galleries has been adapted from traditional merchant houses.Nara holds traditional festivals every year, including the Neri-Kuyo Eshiki, a spring festival held in Todaiji temple for over 1,000 years; and the Kemari Festival, in which people wear costumes ranging across 700 years  and play traditional games).In 1909, Tatsuno Kingo designed the Nara Hotel, whose architecture combines  modern elements with traditional Japanese style.


== Geography ==
The city of Nara lies in the northern end of Nara Prefecture, directly bordering Kyoto Prefecture to its north.  The city is 22.22 kilometres (13.81 mi) from North to South, from East to West. As a result of the latest merger, effective April 1, 2005, that combined the villages of Tsuge and Tsukigase with the city of Nara, the city now borders Mie Prefecture directly to its east. The total area is 276.84 square kilometres (106.89 square miles).Nara city, as well as several important settlements (such as Kashihara, Yamatokōriyama, Tenri, Yamatotakada, Sakurai and Goze), are located in the Nara Basin. This makes it the most densely-populated region of Nara Prefecture.The downtown of Nara is on the east side of the ancient Heijō Palace site, occupying the northern part of what was called the Gekyō (外京), literally the outer capital area. Many of the public offices (e.g. the Municipal office, the Nara Prefectural government, the Nara Police headquarters, etc.) are located on Nijō-ōji (二条大路), while Nara branch offices of major nationwide banks are on Sanjō-ōji (三条大路), with both avenues running east–west.
The highest point in the city is at the peak of Kaigahira-yama at an altitude of 822.0 m (2,696.85 ft) (Tsugehayama-cho district), and the lowest is in Ikeda-cho district, with an altitude of 56.4 m (185.04 ft).

Murō-Akame-Aoyama Quasi-National Park
Yamato-Aogaki Quasi-National Park

Mount Wakakusa


=== Climate ===
The climate of Nara Prefecture is generally temperate, although there are notable differences between the north-western basin area and the rest of the prefecture which is more mountainous.
The basin area climate has an inland characteristic, as represented in the higher daily temperature variance, and the difference between summer and winter temperatures. Winter temperatures average approximately 3 to 5 °C (37 to 41 °F), and from 25 to 28 °C (77 to 82 °F) in the summer with highest readings reaching close to 35 °C (95 °F). There has not been a single year since 1990 with more than 10 days of snowfall recorded by Nara Local Meteorological Observatory.
The climate in the rest of the prefecture is that of higher elevations especially in the south, with  −5 °C (23 °F) being the extreme minimum in winter. Heavy rainfall is often observed in summer. The annual accumulated rainfall totals as much as 3,000 to 5,000 mm (118.11 to 196.85 in), which is among the heaviest in Japan and indeed in the world outside the equatorial zone.
Spring and fall temperatures are temperate and comfortable. The mountainous region of Yoshino has been long popular for viewing cherry blossoms in the spring. In autumn, the southern mountains are also a popular destination for viewing fall foliage.


== Cityscape ==


== Demographics ==
As of April 1, 2017, the city has an estimated population of 359,666 and a population density of 1,300 persons per km2. There were 160,242 households residing in Nara. The highest concentration of both households and population, respectively about 46,000 and 125,000, is found along the newer bedtown districts, along the Kintetsu line connecting to Osaka.
There were about 3,000 registered foreigners in the city, of which Koreans and Chinese are the two largest groups with about 1,200 and 800 people respectively.

== Deer in Nara ==
According to the legendary history of Kasuga Shrine, the god Takemikazuchi arrived in Nara on a white deer to guard the newly built capital of Heijō-kyō. Since then, the deer have been regarded as heavenly animals, protecting the city and the country.Tame sika deer (also known as spotted deer or Japanese deer) roam through the town, especially in Nara Park. In 2015, there were more than 1,200 sika deer in Nara. Snack vendors sell sika senbei (deer crackers) to visitors so they can feed the deer. Some deer have learned to bow in order to receive senbei from people.
Gallery
		
		
		


== Education ==
As of 2005, there are 16 high schools and 6 universities located in the city of Nara.


=== Universities ===

Nara Women's University is one of only two national women's universities in Japan. Nara Institute of Science and Technology is a graduate research university specializing in biological, information, and materials sciences.


=== Primary and secondary education ===


==== Public schools ====
Public elementary and junior high schools are operated by the city of Nara.
Public high schools are operated by the Nara Prefecture.


==== Private schools ====
Private high schools in Nara include the Tōdaiji Gakuen, a private school founded by the temple in 1926.


== Transportation ==

The main central station of Nara is Kintetsu Nara Station with JR Nara station some 500m west and much closer to Shin-Omiya station.


=== Rail ===
West Japan Railway Company
Kansai Main Line (Yamatoji Line): Narayama Station - Nara Station
Sakurai Line (Manyō-Mahoroba Line): Nara Station - Kyōbate Station - Obitoke Station
Kintetsu Railway
Nara Line: Tomio Station - Gakuen-mae Station - Ayameike Station - Yamato-Saidaiji Station - Shin-Ōmiya Station - Kintetsu Nara Station
Kyoto Line: Takanohara Station - Heijō Station - Yamato-Saidaiji Station
Kashihara Line: Yamato-Saidaiji Station - Amagatsuji Station - Nishinokyō Station
Keihanna Line: Gakken Nara-Tomigaoka Station

I played with dear in the park, feed the deer crackers, and ate ice cream. What's not to like about that.
small but beautiful city,it was so clean and lovely. you can see cute deer everywhere.if you can wake up soon and go outside for walking in the morning.....

Nara park isn’t far from the station and on a hot day a lot of it is under shade. The deer are very friendly and I was happy to see that the way people were interacting with them was ethical. You can buy the crackers for 150 JPY. The deer will ‘bow’ (some just do a head nod) for
Please respect them, and only feed them the ‘authorized’ biscuits. They are really cute if you treat them well and don’t chase them around as we saw children do today 😠

Deers. Lots and lots of deers. Please dont wear your best shoes and watch your steps as there are deer poop everywhere. The stink is unmistakable. Be careful while feeding the deers and do not tease them.
Deers can be quite aggressive when they know you’ve food on hand. Park has deer poo all over. Follow the pathway and it leads you to a huge temple with rich history.
I could get chilled and relaxed there, observing and feeding cute deers. I will definitely visit there again.

Was a pleasant walk around the park. Deer are interesting and very friendly. We had a cold Starbucks on the patio. Ross from the park.

We took a day trip from Kyoto to Nara. We loved feeding the deer, but you need to be careful around them. They can be a bit aggressive trying to get at the biscuits. You just have to not be scared and you will be fine. We also enjoyed the beautiful Temple and park grounds.

We loved Nara and Nara Park. Our 13 year old son was enamored with the deer and we loved how they bow for biscuits - amazing. Very scenic and lots of temples, gardens, and shrines to visit. We spent almost a full day here with a private guide and had an amazing time despite

The Nara Park is filled with deer, hundreds of them, and I did enjoy seeing them. However, with that being said, the experience at times seemed a little intimidating to me. Of course these animals are still wild, and were aggressive multiple times towards people during my visit.

Delightful clean park with plenty of deer roaming around to feed, it's just ashame about some the tourists letting their children run riot scaring the animals.

Beware while feeding the deer. They bite, push, and surround the person. The temple is good slight to see.

If you are visiting Osaka, make sure you put Nara on your itinerary. It’s very easy to get to, take a JR train will get you to Nara station, from there a short ride on bus will reach Nara park. Quite a big park that roam with heaps of deer and you would find vendor selling snack

Fascinating being surrounded by wild deer that remain tame enough to pat. They roam the park freely coercing visitors to feed them....many vendors selling not too cheap bags of biscuits for those willing to part with their money for a great photo feedding the deerr.

The park is a pretty nice place to stroll around and feed some bowing deer. We were expecting a small herd and smaller deer. But there are a ton of deer here and they are pretty big. Tame and calm too. And they love the biscuits. If you let them bow then give them a bit of

The deer are quite tame and comfortable around people... but are aggressive with food. Be sure to keep your hands visible to show them you don't have any food, or they'll pester you and pull at your cloths/bags.

We visited this park because we were going to Todaiji temple and I just fell in love with the deers. They sell cookies so you can feed them, they are not shy to ask for food and some of them even bowed for it. I will give this half a day.

Visited the famous Nara deers. Docile and only interested in humans with deer snack. Snacks are sold at fixed price by vendors at various points in the park.
Extremely beautiful park, lots of deer, people walk between them and tourits may also feed them offering special snacks.

The park has museums as well, but the deer seem to be the big draw. Suggestion: Try to go on a cooler day, and have comfortable walking shoes - it's a big place! Watch your clothing, maps, and purse, as the deer seem omnivorous!

We took the commuter train from Osaka to Nara station. Another 14 minutes walk , just follow the crowd , and you reach the park. So many places, temples and a museum to see, you should take as a minimum a half day. When you are there, meet the deers.

Always wary of attractions with animals but needn't have been here. The deer are truly free to wander around as they please, and there are plenty of fenced off areas they can go for some quiet time away from all the people. There is also plenty of fresh water on offer for them
A must see when you visit Nara. Be enthralled by the deers and the Buddha temple Best visited during cherry blossom season

Had a great time on our day trip to Nara from Kyoto. It was a short 45 minute ride from Kyoto Station using the JR line. No need to make seat reservations. Visited the temple which was nice but we didn’t bother paying to go in since we have been to so many temples already. We

Nice park, very clean and full of deers. There are people on the streets that sells the deers crackers, I think they know and from time to time they are a little aggressive if you don't give them the cracker.

Beautiful grounds and the deer are great fun. They can be really pushy so do make sure that your backpack or bag is fully zipped up. One actually used it's antlers to try to unhook my bag from my shoulder! If you hold your hands up in the air above you the deer will "bow"
What a great morning. The deer are everywhere! All very friendly and eager for a deer cracker. 150 yen for a pack which was reasonable. Beautiful surroundings.

Beautiful park with the deers. Get up close and personal and spend time with the deers. The park is massive and the deers are confined. They are freely roaming around the park and tourist can feed them with the crackers that are being sold in the park for a very small amount.

Visited recently to take in the Golden Buddha and the deer around the temple and park. Beautiful place and the temple was awesome. The deer are friendly (particularly if you have food) but very entertaining in there own way. A great way to spend a few hours.
This park is famous for its deer. I heard they have been around for hundreds of years. They learned to bow for the food, which is very interesting!

The park and surrounding area is lovely. The deers are very friendly so if you are scared of animals this place may not be for you . Only buy the deer wafers if you want to feed them, break them in half to make them last longer. Bow to the 🦌 it will bow back to you.

Deers found in every corner of the park! They will not hesitate to look to you for crackers, even to the extent of nudging you or even biting you. At least they would be 'polite' about it by giving the standard Nara deer bow. Which makes it hard to resist giving them the treat.

A visit to Japan wouldn’t be complete without feeding the deer in Nara. The "deer cookies" are sold throughout the park and can be fed to the deer. You have to raise your hand with the cookie first, wait for them to bow, and then feed it. They are so adorable when they bow!

It is unusual to get so close to a wild animal. But years of being hand fed by tourists have made them very docile. They are every where, and so is their poop! So be careful where you tread. Plenty of vendors selling food for the deer. Plenty of photo opportunities.

Love all the deer walking around. Easy to buy crackers to feed them. They can get aggressive if you done give them the crackers, but one of the coolest experience!

The park is very nice and designed to host a lot of tourists. The deer are friendly and welcoming especially when you feed them with specific deer crackers. The signs can be improved.

Deers were very cute and gentle. Weather was good, Nice place for a walk. You can buy deer feed for 150yen yo feed the deers. You can also walk through the park to the todaiji temple.

I visited Nara as a day trip from Kyoto. It's about an hour by train. This is a nice park to have a walk in spring. The deer in the park are an attraction. It's fun to watch. Search for the quieter places to escape the crowds.

Really easy to get here for a day trip from Kyoto. A lot of walking involved, but well worth it to get to see the giant Buddha in that beautiful temple. Other temples and a gorgeous little garden on the way, plus of course, the almost tame deer.

The main attraction here is definitely the deers. When you feed them with crackers, they bow you after that. So sweet. You can walk around the park and feed the deers as often as you want. Some of them behave better than others. The park itself is nice, with lovely picture

My wife and I were here on a Gate1 tour, with Optional Excursion to Nara Park. If you are in a hurry, most likely you can see everything within 2-3 hours. As with most attractions in Japan, very well organized (and of course, extremely clean!). We enjoyed seeing the deer and

Went on a weekday afternoon. A pretty decent walk from the train station. Fun to feed the deer, they were quite tame in the evening. Maybe they were full from all the other tourists feeding them throughout the day.

Managed to cover all the 3 shrines and the deers in Nara within 2 hours upon arriving in Nara. In Japan, everything is well organized and nearby. A day trip is sufficient for those wanting to see the deer

Nice place for relax and watching deers and feed them with rice crackers which you can buy on every corner. So you can relax and rest before you will continue to enjoying beauty of Nara. Please just really don't feed the deers with anything else or you can harm this beautiful

The deer at Nara park roam around freely and seek food from visitors. It can get very busy in Nara but still worthwhile checking out these deer.

Nara is an amazing city, probably the nicest in Japan. Over 1.000 deers are walking on the streets and in the park and you can feed them or play with them. The temple is amazing and the entire atmosphere is really great.

A fun place to walk around. The deer are an added bonus. For a price you get these wafers that you feed the deer and they will come feed from your hands. Keep in mind that these are still wild animals and treat them with respect. We noticed a few people tease them with the
nice place to relax, pet friendly deer, feed them and take a strall towards the Todaiji temple. lots of photo opportunities

You can spend the day in Nara. There are so many deers - not just in the park but around the whole area in the lead up to the temple. You can buy crackers for 150 Yen and the deers will not leave you alone if they know you have food. Best to break them in half so they last

Quite an experience feeding the deers. The deers are lovely and polite. Fun to try to take a wefie with them!

It is easy to get to Nara from either Kyoto or Osaka, and it is another must do site along with Arashiyama. Tour the UNESCO world heritage sites, yes, multiple. Take a walk off the beaten path either in Nara Park or to the deeper shrines. The tranquility is another world from

The deer were so cute! If you have some food (you can buy deer crackers for ¥150, but we were also given some acorns by a lovely old man on a bicycle!), they will literally mug you! It was so funny - they don't hurt, but they will nip you (they kept biting my butt!). If you have

These are WILD ANIMALS first and foremost. If you do plan on getting the deer crackers (deer feed sold at every corner of every road and junction in the park), be ready to be a deer magnet - they will come from far and wide to get the cracker out of your hand. We find the deer
Nice litte park in Nara - a good option for a relaxed, cheap day out. You can see the deer, buy deer 'cookies' to feed them, take some lovely photos amongst the cherry blossoms, or just chill out.
Really cute to have lot of deer’s all around you. They are little aggressive so be careful with food and your bags. Apart from that they really are very cute.
This is a nice area to go for a walk. There are lots of deer- you can buy crackers to feed them and most of them are well behaved!

I know deers prefer to stay in the wild even if they are easy prey for fierce animals. But Nara is unique, deers roam freely sometimes they gently bonk your bags for cookies. Only feed them sold JPY150 cookies from vendors. I also had my takoyaki here which is so scrumptious.

History, scenery, wildlife, fresh air and exercise - a perfect day out. The deer are more friendly than we imagined possible, especially if you buy the special cookies to feed them. We caught the end of the blossom season which made the day even more special.

This place is pretty cool, deer feeding is a must, if you bow at them they will bow back to you. But be careful, if they think you have food and you turn your back on them, they will bite you on the bum.
All those deer r free to walk around U can even see some of them r walking on the road with car driving behind them Interesting U can also buy some biscuit to feed them What an interesting experience

The park is beautiful and the deer roam freely. But be aware that they can be aggressive, especially if you have any food. Also be sure to watch where you walk or your shoes may be covered in something unpleasant.

The park is very pretty and very big. There are free roaming deer everywhere. The deer are friendly and bow if you bow to them. Please respect the deer and don't tease them with food like I saw some people doing. Yes, they will chase after you if you have food readily available.
Beautiful park with wild deers that would eat from your hand. Food vendors and ponds. Just be careful because they will eat your clothes :)
Highly recommend if you have extra time to play with Deer, there are also cultural place to visit such as shrines and temples.

Day trip on catch from Osaka after visiting Kyoto. The park itself is quite large with many deer roaming freely. They will come to you if you are feeding them with food which can be bought from the stall. The deer do bow when receiving food. There is a large wooden temple in the
Definitely must visit park. Wild deer so tame. Snacks on sale at park for feeding.deer do bow if u bow and feed them.be cautious some deer can be aggressive.

Nara park is a beautiful park that houses 1200 deer throughout. They have learnt to bow to receive the special deer crackers you can feed them. However some a pushy and will bite at your jacket if you don’t pay them attention.

We went to Nara to see the deer after seeing online recommendations and also the recommendations of friends. It was fun to see the deer roaming so closely around Nara and to see them 'bowing'. We enjoyed the gardens - really really enjoyed the Isuien and Yoshiken Garden more!

Like others report if you can wake up early and based inTokyo get there by 8:15am to enjoy deer feeding. 150Yen will get you the special Deer Senebi crackers and they can be bought all over the park at the same price. Arrive at Kintetsu station, it’s right on the doorstep of

As you approach Nara Park, you can see as baby deers roaming the park as people. They are pretty harmless and some may pose for pictures with you but if you have a deer biscuit in hand, they will love you!! The deer biscuits are 150 Yen and available along the park by street

Saw so many people feeding any old thing to the deer. If you must then buy the silly deer biscuits but don’t feed them your sandwich or your map. They are completely habituated to people and don’t understand what’s good for them. Just think. What is a deer supposed to eat??
This park is very nice, deer are everywhere. And there are more than you can imagine. You can buy food to give them but they will start following you. They also poop all over so watch your steps.

The buildings are breathtaking and the scale of the park, the Buddhas, temple, pagodas is stunning, but particularly during cherry blossom season it is a tourist zoo. It’s still very enjoyable to visit and you can get good clear views of everything, but if I go again I would

It was a perfect day at Nara. A bit difficult to get there via Osaka since the trains are all confusing. It was nice and sunny outside and there were SOOOOOO many deer! You can get crackers for them for like 5 USD. And it's more than enough to feed them. An amazing
Nice day out in Nara. The deer are fun for every age. All hotspots of Nara are within 20 mins walking distance. Come in spring when the cherry trees are in bloom!
Lovely park , very relaxing walk among the temples and the deer who do anything for a biscuit! Very relaxing.

It is a nice walk thru the park with lots of deer that love human beings for the food they get. They have also been trained to bow, a sign that they are requesting food. Stone lanterns line the path - very large number of these heavy sculptures!

We visited here from Kyoto by train and was worth the effort. We arrived early which was a good thing as it was very busy by the time we left just after 1pm.

The park is very nice with deers everywhere bit it is crowded. There some spectacular trees, the walk around the park and temple is very easy. The park is clean and well maintained. It was a wonderful visit even with the crowd.

An experience you should not miss. The park is just amazing. The local government is so helpful with a lot of free facilities and information points.

It's a great place to visit all year round. Purchase some senbei for the deer and you are gold. Would advise to stay away from the more aggressive male deers though, they tend to bite at your belongings if you taunt them with food.

Yes, if you have time in kyoto then its worth taking the train to Nara to see, feed and touch some of the hundred deers running freely in this huge park. The park has some temples and cherryblossom trees also. There is no entrance free to this park. The deers are cute and you

We weren't actually here to feed the deers. However, it was fun seeing them and added to the ambience of the place. The park itself is nothing spectacular.

a wonderful natural place! unfortunately when we were there the trees have not yet bloomed, but still a beautiful place! we can only imagine how beautiful it is when everything is pink! Absolutely great attraction are deer at the same way that you can feed bought cookies!

The place is worth visiting period. So manny memories from the few hours that we spent there the first day, I will go back tomorrow to watch the rest but it was already worth it.

The park is big with the does roaming free, they are very used to be near people, you can feed by hand, there are some old buildings and museums that are worth visiting, you won't be disappointed.

We have been here twice over 9 years, this time with our young boys that loved it as much as us, especially with the deer everywhere and being able to pet and feed them!

Incredible... I advise all the visitors to japan to visit nara park❤❤ Don't forget to visit owls cafe ❤❤❤ Deer, temples, traditional shops , owls cafe ......etc

This place is awesome 😎

It's a bit of a busy place, but fun experience feeding the deer. Would recommend if your in Osaka, its a short train ride.
Best place to visit. A lots of deer in entire of this area. Good place to walking and eating

As others have probably mentioned many times. This is a great park with numerous temples and museums. Deer are just roaming around bathing in sunlight. They will only approach you if you have crackers. They do bow to you periodically …

An overall brilliant area with many things to see and do, it’s also central to a lot of good locations in Nara. Nara is definitely worth a couple days visit but if you can only fit in one day, Nara Park is a great place to start.
Big park with lots of deer.  Side streets have shops with food and trinkets.  Definitely fun for the whole family!
One of my favorite experience in Japan. Beautiful and big park, a lot of deers everywhere and there is also a temple to see. Plan a whole afternoon there if you like animals!
I enjoy walking to the park. It took 30 mins from the nearest train station by foot by along the way you can enjoy the city. I witnessed a deer crossing the street on the zebra cross.
Heaps of fun. Some of the deer can get quite cantankerous so you definitley have to hold your ground but it's such an amazing experience.

The deer park of Nara... I spent so much time there. If you are a good walker you can walk around the entire park and the few temples behind in about two hours. But it will take more time if you spend a lot of time patting the heads of the …
A peaceful place full of nature and servants that you can exclusively feed with the cookies that are sold there for 200 yen
Such an amazing place. Some deers are aggressive but it’s fun to feed them and took a picture with them.
A lovely park to explore with family, just watch out for screaming tourists terrorising the deer. Give yourself plenty of time to explore the area.

Not for the faint of heart! These semi-wild deers are highly intelligent and ready to consume (read steal) your deer-cookies that you can buy at various locations around the park! Show the palms of both of your hands to signal that you don’t have any crackers!
10/10 I'm a (at the time of writing this) a 24 year old man who has never felt more like a Disney Princess. This is a must see. Please train down, fly down, take a taxi, anyway you can!

I really enjoyed the park area. The deer were fun and friendly, though some were forceful about getting their food. The crackers to feed the deer are cheap. The park itself is lovely, do watch out for deer droppings though!
Absolutely loved visiting the park and surrounds. The deer are hilarious, but also very greedy! Keep your snacks and deer crackers hidden!

Wow...just wow. So many Deer, it's a must place to visit. Try going week days, crowds can be overwhelming.
The Deer have learned to bow for treats, give it a try, bow then they will :)
Nice big park setting also, very relaxing visiting the nearby tramples with their endless lanterns paving the way.

text.wiki:
Tōdai-ji (東大寺, Eastern Great Temple) is a Buddhist temple complex that was once one of the powerful Seven Great Temples, located in the city of Nara, Japan. Though it was originally founded in the year 738 CE, Todai-ji was not opened until the year 752 CE. Its Great Buddha Hall (大仏殿 Daibutsuden) houses the world's largest bronze statue of the Buddha Vairocana, known in Japanese as Daibutsu (大仏). The temple also serves as the Japanese headquarters of the Kegon school of Buddhism. The temple is a listed UNESCO World Heritage Site as one of the "Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara", together with seven other sites including temples, shrines and places in the city of Nara.


== History ==


=== Origins ===

The beginning of building a temple where the Kinshōsen-ji complex sits today can be dated to 728 CE, when Emperor Shōmu established Kinshōsen-ji (金鐘山寺) as an appeasement for Prince Motoi (ja:基王), his first son with his Fujiwara clan consort Kōmyōshi. Prince Motoi died a year after his birth.
During the Tenpyō era, Japan suffered from a series of disasters and epidemics. It was after experiencing these problems that Emperor Shōmu issued an edict in 741 to promote the construction of provincial temples throughout the nation. Later in 743 during the Tenpyō era the Emperor commissioned the Daibutsu to be built in 743. Tōdai-ji (still Kinshōsen-ji at the time) was appointed as the provincial temple of Yamato Province and the head of all the provincial temples. With the alleged coup d'état by Nagaya in 729, a major outbreak of smallpox around 735–737, worsened by several consecutive years of poor crops, followed by a rebellion led by Fujiwara no Hirotsugu in 740, the country was in a chaotic situation. Emperor Shōmu had been forced to move the capital four times, indicating a certain level of instability during this period.


=== Role in early Japanese Buddhism ===
According to legend, the monk Gyōki went to Ise Grand Shrine to reconcile Shinto with Buddhism. He spent seven days and nights reciting sutras until the oracle declared Vairocana Buddha compatible with worship of the sun goddess Amaterasu.
Under the Ritsuryō system of government in the Nara period, Buddhism was heavily regulated by the state through the Sōgō (僧綱, Office of Priestly Affairs). During this time, Tōdai-ji served as the central administrative temple for the provincial temples and for the six Buddhist schools in Japan at the time: the Hossō, Kegon, Jōjitsu, Sanron, Ritsu and Kusha. Letters dating from this time also show that all six Buddhist schools had offices at Tōdai-ji, complete with administrators, shrines and their own library.

Japanese Buddhism during this time still maintained the lineage of the Vinaya and all officially licensed monks were required to take their ordination under the Vinaya at Tōdai-ji.  In 754 CE, ordination was given by Ganjin, who arrived in Japan after traveling over 12 years and six attempts of crossing the sea from China, to Empress Kōken, former Emperor Shōmu and others. Later Buddhist monks, including Kūkai and Saichō received their ordination here as well. During Kūkai's administration of the Sōgō, additional ordination ceremonies were added to Tōdai-ji, including the ordination of the Bodhisattva Precepts from the Brahma Net Sutra and the esoteric Precepts, or Samaya, from Kukai's own newly established Shingon school of Buddhism. Kūkai added an Abhiseka Hall to use for initiating monks of the six Nara schools into the esoteric teachings. by 829 CE.


=== Decline ===
As the center of power in Japanese Buddhism shifted away from Nara to Mount Hiei and the Tendai sect, and when the capital of Japan moved to Kamakura, Tōdai-ji's role in maintaining authority declined. In later generations, the Vinaya lineage also died out, despite repeated attempts to revive it; thus no more ordination ceremonies take place at Tōdai-ji.


== Architecture ==


=== Initial construction ===

In 743, Emperor Shōmu issued a law stating that the people should become directly involved with the establishment of new Buddhist temples throughout Japan. The Emperor believed that such piety would inspire Buddha to protect his country from further disaster. Gyōki, with his pupils, traveled the provinces asking for donations. According to records kept by Tōdai-ji, more than 2,600,000 people in total helped construct the Great Buddha and its Hall; contributing rice, wood, metal, cloth, or labor; with 350,000 working directly on the statue's construction. The 16 m (52 ft) high statue was built through eight castings over three years, the head and neck being cast together as a separate element. The making of the statue was started first in Shigaraki. After enduring multiple fires and earthquakes, the construction was eventually resumed in Nara in 745, and the Buddha was finally completed in 751. A year later, in 752, the eye-opening ceremony was held with an attendance of 10,000 monks and 4,000 dancers to celebrate the completion of the Buddha. The Indian priest Bodhisena performed the eye-opening for Emperor Shōmu. The project cost Japan greatly, as the statue used much of Japan's bronze and relied entirely on imported gold.  48 lacquered cinnabar pillars, 1.5 m in diameter and 30 m long, support the blue tiled roof of the Daibutsu-den.Maps that include some of the original structures of Todai-ji are rare, though some still exist today. Some of these structures include, the two pagodas, the library, lecture hall, refectory, and the monk's quarters located behind the main hall. Todai-ji functioned not only as a place of worship and Buddhist practice, but as a place of higher learning and study. Much of what contemporaries now know about the original layout of the temple comes from the writings of monks who lived and studied there.
The original complex contained two 100 m pagodas, making them some of the tallest structures at the time. They were located on either side of the complex, one on the western (西塔) and one on the eastern side (東塔). The pagodas themselves were surrounded by a walled courtyard with four gates. These were destroyed by an earthquake. One of the sōrin finials survived and is standing at the spot where one of the pagodas used to stand.
The Shōsōin was its storehouse, and now contains many artifacts from the Tenpyō period of Japanese history.


=== Reconstructions post-Nara Period ===

 
The Great Buddha Hall (Daibutsuden) has been rebuilt twice after fire. The current building was finished in 1709, and although immense—57 metres (187 ft) long, 50 metres (160 ft) wide and 49 metres (161 ft) high—it is actually 30% smaller than its predecessor, being reduced from 11 to 7 bays wide due to lack of funds. Until 1998, it was the world's largest wooden building. It has been surpassed by modern structures, such as the Japanese baseball stadium 'Odate Jukai Dome', amongst others. The Great Buddha statue has been recast several times for various reasons, including earthquake damage. The current hands of the statue were made in the Momoyama Period (1568–1615), and the head was made in the Edo period (1615–1867).
The existing Nandaimon (Great South Gate) was constructed at the end of the 12th century based on Daibutsuyō style, after the original gate was destroyed by a typhoon during the Heian period. The dancing figures of the Nio, the two 8.5-metre-tall (28 ft) guardians at the Nandaimon, were built at around the same time by Unkei, Kaikei and their workshop members. The Nio are an A-un pair known as Ungyo, which by tradition has a facial expression with a closed mouth, and Agyo, which has an open mouthed expression. The two figures were closely evaluated and extensively restored by a team of art conservators between 1988 and 1993. Until then, these sculptures had never before been moved from the niches in which they were originally installed. This complex preservation project, costing $4.7 million, involved a restoration team of 15 experts from the National Treasure Repairing Institute in Kyoto.


=== Dimensions of the Daibutsu ===
The temple gives the following dimensions for the statue:
Height: 14.98 m (49 ft 2 in)
Face: 5.33 m (17 ft 6 in)
Eyes: 1.02 m (3 ft 4 in)
Nose: 0.5 m (1 ft 8 in)
Ears: 2.54 m (8 ft 4 in)The statue's shoulders are 28 meters across and there are 960 six curls atop its head.  The Birushana Buddha's golden halo is 27 m (87 ft) in diameter with 16 images each 2.4 m (8 ft) tall.Recently, using x-rays, a human tooth, along with pearls, mirrors, swords, and jewels were discovered inside of 
the knee of the Great Buddha; these are believed to be the relics of Emperor Shomu.The statue weighs 500 tonnes (550 short tons).


== Temple precincts and gardens ==
 
Various buildings of the Tōdai-ji have been incorporated within the overall aesthetic intention of the gardens' design.  Adjacent villas are today considered part of Tōdai-ji.  Some of these structures are now open to the public.
Over the centuries, the buildings and gardens have evolved together as to become an integral part of an organic and living temple community.
The Tōdai-ji Culture Center opened on October 10, 2011, comprising a museum to exhibit the many sculptures and other treasures enshrined in the various temple halls, along with a library and research centre, storage facility, and auditorium.


== Japanese national treasures at Todai-ji ==

The architectural master-works are classified as:


== Major historical events ==

728: Kinshōsen-ji, the forerunner of Tōdai-ji, is established as a gesture of appeasement for the troubled spirit of Prince Motoi.
741: Emperor Shōmu calls for nationwide establishment of provincial temples, and Kinshōsen-ji appointed as the head provincial temple of Yamato.
743: The Emperor commands that a very large Buddha image statue shall be built—the Daibutsu or Great Buddha—and initial work is begun at Shigaraki-no-miya.
745: The capital returns to Heijō-kyō, construction of the Great Buddha resumes in Nara. Usage of the name Tōdai-ji appears on record.
752: The Eye-opening Ceremony celebrating the completion of the Great Buddha held.
855: The head of the great statue of the Buddha Vairocana suddenly fell to the ground; and gifts from the pious throughout the empire were collected to create another, more well-seated head for the restored Daibutsu.


== In popular culture ==
Matsuo Bashō refers to the Great Buddha statue in a haiku (1689-1670):
初雪や /  いつ大仏 /  の柱立.
"First snow!/ When Buddha’s great statue/ pillar-erection"
And,
"First snow and / there stands the great Buddha / a pillar of strength"Tōdai-ji has been used as a location in several Japanese films and television dramas. It was also used in the 1950s John Wayne movie The Barbarian and the Geisha when Nandaimon, the Great South Gate, doubled as a city's gates.
On May 20, 1994, the international music festival The Great Music Experience was held at Tōdai-ji, supported by UNESCO. Performers included the Tokyo New Philharmonic Orchestra, X Japan, INXS, Jon Bon Jovi, Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan, Tomoyasu Hotei, Roger Taylor, classic Japanese drummers, and a Buddhist monk choir. This event, organized by British producer Tony Hollingsworth, was simultaneously broadcast in 55 countries on May 22 and 23, 1994.
The 2007 animation series Mononoke (モノノ怪), which is a spin-off of the 2006 horror anthology series Ayakashi: Samurai Horror Tales, references the Tōdai-ji, particularly the treasure room Shōsōin, in Episodes 8 and 9.


== International Outreach ==
Following the April 2019 fire that damaged the spire of another UNESCO World Heritage Site, the Cathedral of Notre Dame in Paris, Japanese authorities declared plans to expand fire prevention measures at several historic locations including Todai-ji in Nara, partly by hiring new, younger employees in a context where temple and shrine staff are aging.  Custodians of Todaiji temple also installed a donation box, stating “Let’s Rebuild Notre Dame Cathedral”, in the hallway behind the Great Buddha statue.  In June 2019, a sign next to the box, in Japanese and English, explained why Todai-ji, as headquarters of the Kegon sect of Buddhism, was soliciting funds in this way. The English version declared, “Todai-ji temple has been reconstructed every time it burned down by big fires thanks to the significant effort of many people.  We sincerely express our deepest sympathy for the tragedy that hit the Notre-Dame de Paris. Going beyond the creed, we would like to ask everyone for your support to reconstruct the cathedral.”

The enormity of this temple must be experienced. We happened upon a drumming performance that was so great. Truly a must on your travels in Japan.

Beautiful temple well worth the entry fee. It's busy but it doesn't really detract from the experience. Photography is allowed inside and there is a hole you can crawl through inside for good luck. Lots of information in English to explain what is what.

Nice place to visit for a wee walk and quiet reflection.easy to get to from Kyoto grounds full of wild deer, that you can pet and photograph.
Far too many people but this is a must see attraction. The size, age, atmosphere is mind-blowing. Get there early before the crowds

The sheer size of the temple is a sight to behold! One could only imagine the effort put into the construction.
Gorgeous huge Buddha in the largest wooden building in the world does not disappoint. Go early to avoid the rush and chaos of the crowds.

We left Kyoto for Nara as soon as the rush hour was over, but the train was heaving. The same goes for Nara and the Todai-Ji temple. It was a week day as well. Bus loads of tourists. But it was worth it as the temple is impressive. We could see why it was so popular. Suggest one
This place is amazing, it’s huge. Largest wooden structure in the world. Huge Buddha. Very large crowds but this is a must place to see!

The 800 yr old Buddha within the temple is magnificent! Definitely must see. The temple grounds are well kept and beautiful.

This is a must see if you’re in Osaka, Kyoto or Nara. It is one of the most impressive temples in terms of its size. An imposing wooden structure housing the worlds largest bronze Buddha statue. Not to be missed!

Easy access from the train station. Just get the bus day pass. 600 yen entrance and I recommend the audio talk which explains the statues and grounds etc. A very old monument rich in history, the biggest wooden structure in the world! Just a good visit really- not too big!

Very large and impressive Eden temple which contains many statues including a giant Buddha. Quite a long walk to reach it and there are hundreds of free roaming deer in the park. These look cute and can be very friendly.

This is the oldest and largest wooden structure surviving and looking at the massive joints, one cannot but marvel at the skills of the builders. The Budhha is magnificent as well as the accompanying Bodhistva and other figures.

Really amazing place with beautiful statues of buddha and others. Whole place is really great and I recommend to visit this place.

the budha statue is amazing and there are other nice statues, it's definitely wirth the train ride from Kyoto

It's hard to describe the scale of the temple and Buddha. It's truly something that should be seen in person as pictures don't do it justice. Gets very busy as there are several tour buses that stop here.
The biggeat wood builduing in the world that houses one of the biggest buddhas in Japan, beautiful gardens and deers all over the property

It takes a lot to impress me but this place does. The grandeur of the building overwhelms while peaceful. You might think you've seen all of the temples you need to see but you're wrong. This is a must.

Largest wooden structure, housing largest bronze statue of Buddha. Over 1300 years old. Reasonably priced entry fee considering the significance of the site. Deer roaming freely in park near site is an added bonus.

Can be quite busy as it's one of the main attractions. Lovely approach through the park with all of the deer.
We enjoyed our visit here. The huge Buddha was unique and beautiful. Its worth a visit to experience this place. Wasn't too busy the day we went.

Fantastic temple experience. We received a free guided tour in English from a lovely volunteer. Probably my favourite temple visit in Japan.

Must visit for all tourists. It costs 600 yen to visit the Buddha Hall and an extra 400 yen for the museum. Recommend coming around 4pm to view the sunset scene. Note that this place closes at 5pm though.
Been there multiple times, everytime was a greater experience than the previous. An amazing temple, a bit too crowded at times, but if you can get past that and enjoy it, it's a must see spot.

Very impressed with the building. Have to see it in you own eye. Not planned to enter initially, but was attracted by it when arrived by the entrance.
No photo could ever do justice to how amazing Todai-ji Temple is in person. It has been the highlight of our entire Japan experience.

Generally I make it a point to visit any temple/shrine in japan if I’m nearby. So during my visit to Nara park I popped by. Personally, I felt a sense of awe when arrived at the temple. It’s not the most majestic of buildings, but perhaps the surroundings blending in with the

We took a day off Kyōto to go to Nara and we were not disappointed. Todai-ji Temple has amazing ancient buildings with massive Buddha inside. On top you get to walk around semi-wild dears. Don’t miss it!

Biggest Buddha I've ever seen!! Unfortunately it's covered by a big wooden building so you can't really see it from the outside but I guess the want to preserve it or something 🤔🤔🤔

Need to walk some distant through Nara Park before arriving at Nandaimon Gate of Tōdaiji and Todaiji Temple. Some souvenir shops to get great souvenirs from Nara. See deers and more deers.

was the visit to Nara, and in particular, Toda-ji Temple. Its beautiful. The Buddha Statue, the other statues in the hall, etc - amazing! it was also fun watching people wriggling their way through Buddha's Nostril!

Took the train from Kyoto to Nara and walked up to the temple. Big grounds and full of tourists and school groups when we were there We had a short 10 minute introduction to it by one of the volunteer guides at the entrance. Obviously the main attraction is the big Buddha but

It’s amazing, doesn’t even look real, it was an amazing sight. There’s the whole history behind why it was made and why the hand was done like that etc. We went at an extremely busy time unfortunately so we followed the crowd and didn’t have much time to take in the full view.
This temple is imposing and has some beautiful statues besides the huge gold Buddha. the grounds a beautifully manicured.

Todai-ji Temple should be regarded as the landmark of Nara because the world's largest bronze buddha was placed inside the huge timber structure. The temple was easily accessible either by walking from the train station or take the local bus there. However the spot was normally
The most famous temple in Nara, Typical japanese temple in a very nice area near Nara park. Good spot for pics but don't expect to be alone there

WOW what an amazing place. The massive statues are enormous and just brilliant to view. the work they put into these. a very interesting place and a must to visit allow a couple of hours. easy walking and good for children of all ages.
Beautiful and interesting. Temples, shrines and grounds. This should be your top priority in Nara. GO.
We came with little knowledge of the region but we were pleased we stopped by, we would recommend it to all even just to see

My partner and I visited Todai-ji temple on the 15th of Oct- a Monday. Despite this it was incredibly busy, people were everywhere, we went fairly early in the morning. It was a nice, unique shrine, seeing the large bronze budda was amazing. I preferred other shrines in the are
Nara is a lovely city and Todai-ji temple is definitely worth visiting. It can get a little crowded at times so come early.

Our main goal for Nara was really just the deers. I just htough we could drop by the temple and take a look see. It was a really good experience since it was our first temple experience in Japan. There were stamps that you can collect at each temple you go to and this was out

Must visit when you step in Nara. If you don’t want to walk , you can take a bus from Nara Kintetsu station ( check with station master- direction ) and it will drop you in front of temple. Walking from station to temple should be around 15mins. Inside and Outside of temple

Located at Nara, Todai-ji is a Buddhist Temple Complex, constructed in 728 AD. The massive 15 meter Buddha is the largest bronze statue of Buddha, flanked by two Bodhisattvas. A walk around reveals several smaller Buddhist statues. At one corner is a pillar with a hole in its

An easy day trip from Kyoto, we exited the train station and followed the crowd up a major road, full of shops and restaurants, then made a left at the stoplight, to pass through the giant gate and into the temple to see the Daibutsu, (Great Buddha). It really is amazing

It is worth the walk from Nara station and moving around the deers gathering in front of the temple. The Buddha statue is awesome. Avoid holding the deer crackers in your hands as deers will rush at you.

Todai-ji is a balance of temple and tourist attraction but is well worth it. While the main hall is worth seeing for the Daibatsu, venture further up the mountain to the see some amazing views of Nara.

Probably the most important and impressive shrine in Japan and is a must for tourists. The meditating Buddha gives a wonderful sense of calm and peace.

This temple is one of the highlights of a visit to Nara and should be included in your itinerary. Although it gets quite busy, there's still enough space that it doesn't feel uncomfortably crowded. Worth paying the entrance fee to see the Buddhas inside.

Very big and huge temple with a humongous campus and a very beautiful statue. Some deers are roaming around . And place was very crowded if you want to click some snaps with deers better to go to Nark park. This place you can reach by taking bus from station
At this temple there is much more to see than in most temples in Japan. The temple is impressive and inside you can find more large statues. Access with a wheelchair is probably very hard.

Basically this temple is the largest wooden temple in Japan sheltering the largest bronze Buddha. Its beautiful and you can't really appreciate the size until you see it in person. Very crowded with school parties when we visited and that did detract a bit.

Beautiful and impressive. There's wheelchair/stroller access round the back as well (which also takes you away from the crowds as you enter, but you get into the main hall and the crowds are there again). Definitely worth a visit. Depending on which direction you come from,

This place gives you the goosebumps because its huge and beautifully preserved. It reminisces classical Tang dynasty architecture, apparently. If you have elderly visitors do be careful with those rather steep climbs to the temple and the uneven cobblestone pavements. The

Go go go. You may think it’s all a touristy hype but that’s one big wooden temple with a fairly overwhelming sized Buddha statue/ sculpture. There is an entry fee and there’s lots of people as well. Try and go very early if you can to skip the crowds..

Situated in Nara park this temple was awesome. Everything about it is on the large size and the Buddha is enormous. Lovely walk around the area and an interesting archaeological dig nearby. The deer aren't allowed in the temple, thank goodness!

A large temple in the mountains within Nara Deer Park, Todai-ji Temple is in an outstanding location. The view from the main building is simply breathtaking. We got a goshuin here - if you are a tourist in Japan, I highly recommend a goshuincho, and the goshuincho here and at
This was fantastic to visit. There was a great deal of history and sculptures to admire within this building.

This was a fun day, scenic train trip from Osaka, enjoyable walk from the station with heaps of little shops and places to eat. Sika deer everywhere leading up to the temple. It was actually fun to watch people trying to feed them. Breathtaking temple with a giant Buddha inside.

Todaiji temple is located in the Nara park, and surrounded with nature all around. What amazes me is the giany Buddha’s inside which will mesmerize you.
I was amazed. Stunning, from the statues to the building. If your in the Nara area, this is a must. The walk to the structure itself is great since the roads are full of deer.

Large Buddha figure in an huge impressive wooden temple. The building itself is worth a visit, although the large statues, partly golden, are the actually famous sight. In the nearby park, you can see and feed crowds of friendly dears.

Amazing and beautiful temple. Deer heaven, thousands of them are moving around. Must bring camera. You can buy some food for deer, they are very friendly but once you show the food, they may be bit excited, better to be aware. The view of temple, the big Budha statue inside is

We went to Todai-ji Temple 45 minutes before closing. There were not that many people there. The temple looks amazing from the outside. The big budah on the inside the temple is the most interesting part though. Seeing the statue and walking to it gave me that strange feeling

An absolutely beautiful temple! The whole temple is huge compared to others we visited. The grounds are lovely to. We went part of a tour guide so heard about the history of the temple. There is a small shop inside the temple that sells cute little gifts.

Well, you have to go here if you go to Nara. Todai-ji is a Buddhist temple complex in Nara and that includes the Great Buddha Hall (Daibutsuden) which houses the world's largest bronze Buddha statue. Everything...the statues, wooden structures, etc. is truly impressive.
The temple is insane, it’s so large, the Buddha inside is huge as well. If you’re in Nara this temple is a must see. Very impressive.

This is one of the must see attractions in Nara, allegedly the biggest Buddha in the world. Built in the 8th century. Needless to say all tourists visiting the town will go here at some point. Best if you can avoid the Chinese holidays

Was nice to see. But there are definitely better places in Nara to explore for nature lovers! Historical and architectural point of few I can ensure- it was a very special experience. Especially the exterior of the temple..
We’ve been to so many temples on our trip that I’m a bit Templed out but glad we came to see this. The size of the wooden building and Buddha statues are impressive!
This temple is located in the Nara park. Very impressive the big statues you can see inside the temple. If you came in Nara you can't miss this

Glad that we made an effort to come to Nara since this is really a unique place, The temple has a huge Buddha statue with the Great Buddha Hall. There are a lot of deers wonder around the temple freely. If you are afraid of deers then avoid this place.

The temple is amazing and the statues are the same but being an engineer I was impressed by the wooden structure. Entering the temple you can easily forget that it is made of wood, it's huge and well worth the visit and entrance fee.
Worth a visit to see this massive wooden temple. We went at 8am before most of the crowds but would advise going at 7:30am when it opens to get ahead of the school tours too. Well worth a look.
A must see when visiting Japan. Packed full of tourists and Japanese school kids. Be careful of the deers roaming the site as they do bite.

This is a not to miss temple visit. Paying 1000 Yen which includes the entrance fee together with todaji museum.You get to know in year 700 , this temple was built . Magnificent Buddha statue and old craving by the artist. The museum shown those Buddhist scripts in Chinese

Everything is kept to the highest standard. Our guide on the walking tour was very knowledgeable. The grounds are incredible and can't miss the deer. They are friendly, maybe too friendly sometimes. Do check out the surrounding gardens and other temples. All are worth it.
This was an interesting place to visit and see the largest Buddha and the other items in this venue. It is worth your time to put on your list of things to see.

Very nice temple to visit!! You can find the biggest bronze buddha here! It is impressive to see it since it is inside the temple. When you go to the gift shop, you can find a pillar. In this pillar, there is a hole with the size of the nostril of the buddha. It appears that if

The big bronze Buddah is breathtaking and you simply have to see and experience the magnitude. Really worth a trip from Osaka or Kyoto... but our recommendation is actually to stay in Nara for one night. Consider the guesthouse Naramachi!

The sheer size of this indoor Buddha is impressive, the temple is also very large to be able to accommodate this giantic Buddha. Beyond the size of the Buddha, there is nothing that would consider extraordinary.
Great Japanese architecture and its history. Constructed with timber and iron. It’s beautiful and a must see when you visit the Nara deer park. A small fee apply.

We didn't pay to go inside the main area of the temple, and instead choose to wander around the free areas (we are backpackers on a tight budget). Just wandering around the exterior of this temple gave us a great feel for how magnificent it is.

It’s huge. 600 yen entry fee. Shops inside selling various Buddhist or deer related things. There are deer in the surrounding area which are very cute and friendly.

After walking through the Nara deer park, you'll find this temple. It was quite crowded mid day and we wasn't disappointed. The place was clean and well maintained. Very touristy but not to be missed!

I’ve been countless times and Todaiji is always the MUST SEE place anytime friends visit Japan. There are currently renovations to the north side of the main structure so that part of the building is covered.

The temple and the Buddha are very impressive, huge monuments, highly recommend to visit. As everywhere, inside the temple is a large souvenir shop that doesn't quite add to the flair. Contrary to many reviews here saying the deer (of which there are 1,200 roaming around) are
Full of history and wonderful pics to be taken. Very touristy but you cannot afford to miss it . Enjoy!

It truly impressive. The biggest standing wood construction in the world, this temple is the most impressive thing I saw in Japan. There are a lot of tourists so you miss probably the feeling that it is a temple and not just a touristic attraction but it is good anyway. After

I thought the Nandai-mon gate was impressive then I saw the Daibutsu-den Hall (which is supposed to be one of the biggest wooden buildings in the world). It was incredible, I thought it was even more amazing than the Great Buddha who lives inside. A must see.

Have seen many large Buddha statues, so it wasn't the first time that I was seeing one, But the outside structure where the Buddha is housed and the entire experience is well worth the effort if you have a day (or even 5 hours to spare if you are in Kyoto).
Well.. There is a huge statue of Buddah. And a temple. Thats it. Cool and all but do not expect more than that.
The most impressive temple I've seen in Japan. The temple itself looks pretty, but it's what's inside that is awesome: three gigantic Buddha and two statues of two guardian deities.

Loved going in, so much respect shown to the buddhism religion. There is also a hole that kids crawl through and if you can fit through then you will receive good luck. I managed to fit through even though I'm was 19

Impressive wooden Buddhist temple. It houses a 50 foot bronze statue of Buddha. It is from 750. Just after the entrance into the complex there is a manned table- and they offer a free 15 minute guided tour. We found out guide helpful in explaining the history of the complex.

Amazingly beautiful temple in Nara. It is worth the walk among deers and the hundreds of tourists to see this temple.
This place cost 600 Yen. The museum is under maintenance. The view is spectacular, never seen a temple so huge before!
This was so nice. Huge temple combined with the park outside. Beautiful grounds to walk around and take pictures. Absolutely stunning Buddha.
I got chance to visit this temple during my trip to Nara. It's a great place. Very beautiful and well organized.

Traveling in July during the 2018 heat wave was challenging, but this temple was a must. Honestly did not think I could take another step, but seeing the temple from a distance clinched the deal. Absolutely gorgeous with a 49 foot Buddha.

It's one of the most famous plapce to visit in Nara city. Usually you need to pay to get in, but I think it's free on August 15th.

located in the Nara park, where the entrance of the temple shows like a fantastic work of art by its size, and within the temple is located the great Buddha (magnificent) .....

The temple and of course the bowing deer are lovely but the site is very crowded. If you go here, make sure you go to a smaller temple, too, in order to appreciate the quiet spirituality of the place.
Very beautiful but to many people!!! It’s was too much for me and the atmosphere was completely destroyed

One of my favourite places during my visit to Japan. I would definitely recommend to have a day visit to Nara

Even without paying to go in you can admire the beauty and impressive scale of this building. Definitely worth a visit.
And the 49 foot gilt bronze Great Buddha cast in 749 makes it the oldest & largest of its kind in the world.
One of thw biggest and impressive attraction in Japan. It is in the Nara Park surrounded by deers. Enjoy the walk and see this great temple.

Great temple, can only be seen in person to appreciate it. You probably won't when you are there but you will 2 months from visiting and be like 'that was pretty special.'

The Great Buddha (Daibutsu) of Nara is definitely something worth visiting when in the area. It’s size is remarkable as is the structure around it. Also, the park with its deer makes for a pleasant stroll. It is quite crowded, though.

Still can't believe that the whole thing is made mainly of wood, and the supports are just sitting on rocks.

Wow! This was one of my favorite temples in all of Japan, thanks to the massive Buddha statue inside a massive wooden building. Breathtaking!

Todaiji is a popular tourist spot among those that go to Nara. There are many domestic deer around, and places to buy souvenirs. The sights were amazing, and for anyone interested in religion, I suggest this destination.

No photos can do justice to how big the building and daibutsu are in real life. I accidentally got there the very minute they opened (which I think is 7:30am) and I'm very glad I did. No crowds, nobody was around, and I got to quietly walk around the area practically by myself.

Amazing structure of the temple . Need to pay to enter. This place is famous if you mentioned Nara to travellers

Unbelievable structure and a must see. 600¥ per adult entry. Well worth every penny. Make sure to visit here.
Our goodwill guides took us here and it was great to have someone providing information along the way. Big Buddha is huge!

This is a grand place with amazing statues. Can be a bit crowded at peak times but it is worth a visit for this unique experience. Recommended :)
Largest wooden hall in the world. An amazing site. So much better than we had expected. Even after total “temple overdose”, this was really worth the trip.
The Buddha is so much bigger than i imagined. Pictures can't capture its size right. Statues on sides are amazing too!!
It is located in Nara, which also well known as world heritage sites in all Japan. Surrounding with many beautiful seeing.
Visited yesterday with my husband. Stunning temple. Huge Buddhas lovingly kept in pristine condition.
