text.wiki:
Heijō Palace (平城宮, Heijō-kyū) was the imperial residence in the Japanese capital city Heijō-kyō (today's Nara), during most of the Nara period. The palace, which served as the imperial residence and the administrative centre of for most of the Nara period from 710 to 794 AD, was located at the north-central location of the city in accordance with the Chinese models used for the design of the capital.
The palace consisted of a large rectangular walled enclosure (the daidairi), which contained several ceremonial and administrative buildings including the government ministries. Inside this enclosure was the separately walled residential compound of the emperor or the Inner Palace. In addition to the emperor's living quarters, the Inner Palace contained the residences of the imperial consorts, as well as certain official and ceremonial buildings more closely linked to the person of the emperor.
The original role of the palace was to manifest the centralised government model adopted by Japan from China in the 7th century—the Daijō-kan and its subsidiary Eight Ministries.  The palace was designed to provide an appropriate setting for the emperor's residence, the conduct of great affairs of state, and the accompanying ceremonies.
After the capital was moved to Heian, the palace structures were either moved there or suffered several fires and other disasters and disappeared. The site was built over for agriculture that almost no trace of it remained, however the location was still known. Excavations started in the 1970s and large-scale reconstruction based on contemporary literary sources and excavations starting in the 2000s.
The excavated remains of the palace, and the surrounding area, was established as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1998 along with a number of other buildings and area, as the "Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara."


== History ==

One year after Empress Genmei's succession to the Chrysanthemum Throne in Keiun 4 (707 AD), a rescript was issued deciding on the move from Fujiwara-kyo near Asuka towards the northern edge of the Nara basin. In Wadō 3 (710 AD), the new capital was officially established, but the completion of the palace had to wait further. The new capital city's name was written Heijō (平城) but also pronounced Nara at the time.
The city, and the palace grounds, was based largely on Chang'an (present-day Xi'an), the capital of China during the Tang dynasty, which was contemporary to the time when Nara was capital. Chang'an was in turn, like many ancient east Asian cities, based on a complex system of beliefs & laws of geomancy. This dictated the grid system of streets, as well as the necessity for spiritually protective shrines or temples to be placed at particular cardinal directions around the city. The city area measured six kilometres from east to west and five kilometres from north to south.
In accordance with this system, the palace was placed at the northern end, on an extended line from Suzaku Street, the main thoroughfare running north-south straight through the centre of the city. The street ended at the Suzaku Gate, and the rest of the palace buildings were then placed beyond to the north of this gate. The primary buildings of the palace compound were the Daigoku-den, where governmental affairs were conducted, the Chōdō-in where formal ceremonies were held, the Dairi, the emperor's residence, and offices for various administrative agencies.
The Nara period covers 75 years from 710-784 AD. Emperor Shōmu moved the capital to other places such as Kuni-kyo and Shigaraki-kyo in the period between 740-745 AD. The imperial buildings and governmental offices were drastically transformed around this period. In the later Nara period, the audience hall was erected in the eastern part, at the south side of the imperial domicile. This is called the latter audience hall. A number of buildings in the imperial domicile and the governmental offices were replaced and renovated several times. This was probably not due to the repair of the old buildings but due to another reason.
When the capital was moved to Heian-kyō (now called Kyoto), Nara's Imperial Palace was simply abandoned. Over the ensuing centuries, the ravages of time and the elements slowly destroyed the buildings, until by the beginning of the Kamakura Period in the late 12th century there was practically nothing left above ground. However, those sections that lay underground were preserved, and re-discovered by modern archaeologists.While the site was designated Special Historical Site by the Agency for Cultural Affairs in 1952, archaeological efforts headed by the National Research Institute for Cultural Properties, such as excavations are continuing since 1959. The Suzaku Gate and East Palace Garden have been restored and opened to the public in 1998. The Takenaka Corporation was mainly responsible for the reconstruction.Heijō Palace was the main event site of Commemorative events of the 1300th anniversary of Nara Heijō-kyō Capital (Japanese:平城遷都1300年祭) in 2010, and the First Daigokuden(第一次大極殿) was restored for the occasion. In commemorative events of the 1300th anniversary, a variety of seasonal events were held throughout Nara Prefecture.


== Structures ==


=== Suzaku Gate ===

The main entrance to the capital through the Suzaku Avenue was the Rajō Gate (羅城門, Rajōmon). The main avenue was approximately 75 metres wide and extended north for 3.7 kilometres up to the Suzaku Gate (朱雀門, Suzakumon). The name "Suzaku" derives from the Chinese name for the legendary bird which acted as a southern guardian. The palace was surrounded by great earthen walls and had twelve gates, with the Suzaku Gate as largest gate and the main entrance. The southern open spaces was part of the avenue, and the Nijō-ōji (the second great street) approximately 37 metres wide was extending in the east-west direction in front of the gate.
The gate measured 25 metres in width and 10 metres in depth, with 22 metres in height. Built on a platform, the gate was probably a two-storied structure, conspicuously larger than the other gates of the palace. The open space to the front was used for ceremonies such as New Year celebrations. It was reconstructed in 1998.


=== Second Street and Mibu Gate ===
The Second Street was a major thoroughfare running east-west along the southern side of the palace precinct. Around 35 metres in width, it was second only to Suzaku Avenue in size. The Suzaku Gate, which was the main gate, together with the Mibu Gate to its east and the Wakainukai Gate to its west, all opened onto this avenue.
In the latter half of the Nara period, the Great Hall of State and the Halls of State compound that comprised the centre  of politics shifted to the eastern sector of the precinct. The Mibu Gate served in effect as the main gate to the palace.
The area immediately to the south of the Second street is known to have been used for state offices and detached residences located outside the palace grounds, and was thus a district rivaling the palace itself in importance.


=== Greater Palace ===
The daidairi was a walled rectangular area extending from north to south between the first and second major east-west avenues and from west to east between the north-south avenues.
The three main structures within the Greater Palace were the Official Compound (朝堂院, Chōdō-in) and the Inner Palace (内裏, Dairi).


=== Chōdō-in ===
The Chōdō-in was a rectangular walled enclosure situated directly to the north of the Suzaku Gate in the centre of the southern wall of the Greater Palace. It was based on Chinese models and followed Chinese architectural styles, and archaeological evidence from earlier capitals shows that this building complex was present in earlier palaces and had a remarkably stable design from the 7th century onwards.


=== Former audience hall ===

The Great Hall of State (大極殿, Daigokuden) was the most important state building in the palace. It was facing south at the northern end of the compound. It was the largest building, measuring 44 metres in width and 20 metres in depth, with a height of 27 metres. The hall was thought to have been a two-storey Chinese-style structure with a hipped and gabled roof, and an open front façade having no doors.
No data directly indicating the audience hall's true appearance have survived. For the reconstruction, locations of the pillars were inferred through reference to the building's remains at Kuni-kyō, to where it had been relocated. For the upper part of the building, research was conducted on the main hall of Hōryū-ji, the eastern pagoda of Yakushi-ji, and other buildings that survived from the Nara period. The depiction of the Heian Palace audience hall depicted in the Nenchu gyoji emaki (Illustrated scroll of annual events and ceremonies) was also consulted.
The reconstruction was started in 2001 and completed in 2010. For the reconstruction, Japanese cypress wood was used. The building's pillars and beams were painted in vermilion, the walls in white, the roof with ceramic tiles. The upper part of the interior of the hall was painted with symbols of the Chinese zodiac such as the Tiger, the Horse and the Ox alongside the walls, and floral pattern on the ceiling. The paintings were executed by the renowned painter Atsushi Uemura based on designs from the Nara period.


==== Takamikura ====
In the middle of the audience hall was the emperor's throne, called Takamikura (高御座). This was an important item that symbolised the imperial office, and at state events such as the enthronement and New Year's Day ceremonies the emperor proceeded to the audience hall and took his seat on the throne. Nobles lined up in the inner court south of the hall and paid their respect.
With no records of the construction or design of the Takamikura of the Nara period, the details are unknown. The reconstructed model of the Takamikura was made after experts consulted various literature and historical materials, and based on the throne in the Kyoto Imperial Palace which dates to the Taishō era. Details of the design and patterns were created by referring to materials such as the treasure of the Shōsōin repository.


=== Office of Foods ===
This area, stretching northward from the centrally located Great Hall of State, is believed to have been the site of the Office of Foods. This office stocked foods other than the rice that was paid as tax, and was in charge of providing meals for state banquets and rituals held in the palace.
Surrounding a large well, itself provided with a roof and from which numerous eating utensils have been excavated, stood a group of buildings used as offices and storehouses. The first inscribed wooden tablet recovered from the palace site was found in 1961 in a rubbish pit belonging to this office.


=== Latter audience hall ===
The latter audience hall dates to the time after the capital was re-established after the relocation from Shigaraki.
Traces of the platforms of the latter audience hall and the eastern state halls had remained by the Meiji era, which led to the discovery of the site by Sekino Tadashi, a researcher of architecture history. Tanada Kajuro, a local gardener, worked on a public movement for protection of the site.
The area on the north side of the latter audience hall is the site of the imperial domicile.


=== Imperial Domicile ===
The emperor and empress lived, worked and received visitors in the imperial domicile section. It was surrounded by a roofed walkway, divided lengthwise by an earthen wall. The Office of the Court Ladies was also located here.
Inside the imperial domicile was a stone-paved area containing a large well, which remains were found in 1973. The well was lined with a solid cedar tube carved from a log 1.7 metres in diameter. The water from this well was probably for the exclusive use of the emperor and empress. The site was reburied and the wall was reconstructed with new materials as an outdoor exhibit.


=== Office of the Imperial Household ===
In this section to the east of the imperial domicile, is what is thought to have been the Office of the Imperial Household (宮内省, Kunai-shō). It was surrounded by an earthen wall, 90 metres in length to the north and south and 50 metres wide from east to west. Six buildings stood in this compound. The main one was roofed with tiles, the others with cypress bark.
The building were reconstructed in accordance with the findings of the archaeological excavations, following the Nara period construction techniques.


=== East Palace Garden ===

Archaeological excavations uncovered remains of a large garden in the southeast corner of the palace in 1967. This was named "East Palace Garden" (Tōin Teien) because the neighbouring area is considered to be the site of the East Palace.
Within the area measuring 80 metres from east to west and 100 metres from north to south. Several buildings were located around a curvilinear pond. In the vicinity of the site, Empress Shōtoku had the "Jewelled Hall of the East Palace" constructed, in which banquets were held.
The excavations revealed that the garden was originally built in the Chinese style of the early Nara period, and modified in a Japanese style of the late Nara period. The garden was reconstructed in 1998.


== Museum ==
The Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties has conducted research and investigation of the site on a continual basis since 1959. The Nara Palace Site Museum exhibits the results of the excavations. It consists of galleries for the palace and its administrative offices, artifacts, archaeological science, and special exhibitions.


== Transport ==
It takes 15 or 20 minutes to walk from Yamato-Saidaiji Station to Heijō Palace. And between May and August in 2010, the free shuttle bus runs between Yamato-Saidaiji Station, JR Nara Station and Heijō Palace every 10 or 15 minutes.


== See also ==

text.wiki:
Kasuga Grand Shrine (春日大社, Kasuga-taisha) is a Shinto shrine in Nara, Nara Prefecture, Japan. It is the shrine of the Fujiwara family, established in 768 CE and rebuilt several times over the centuries.  The interior is famous for its many bronze lanterns, as well as the many stone lanterns that lead up the shrine.
The architectural style Kasuga-zukuri takes its name from Kasuga Shrine's honden (sanctuary).
Kasuga Shrine, and the Kasugayama Primeval Forest near it, are registered as a UNESCO World Heritage Site as part of the "Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara".
The path to Kasuga Shrine passes through a deer park. In the park, deer are able to roam freely and are believed to be sacred messengers of the Shinto gods that inhabit the shrine and surrounding mountainous terrain. Kasuga Shrine and the deer have been featured in several paintings and works of art of the Nambokucho Period.  Over three thousand stone lanterns line the way. The Man'yo Botanical Garden is adjacent to the shrine.


== History ==


=== Origin ===
The birth of this shrine, according to legend, began when the first kami of Kasuga-taisha, Takemikazuchi, rode on the back of a white deer to the top of Mount Mikasa in 768 CE. This kami is said to have traveled from the Kashima Jingu Shrine in order to protect Nara.  The shrine location first received favor from the Imperial government in the Heian period as a result of the power from the Fujiwara family as well as Empress Shōtoku.From 1871 through 1946, Kasuga Shrine was officially designated one of the Kanpei-taisha (官幣大社), meaning that it stood in the first rank of government supported shrines.


== Religious significance ==
The four main kami enshrined here are Ame no koyane, Himegami, Futsunushi no mikoto, and Takemikazuchi no mikoto. Though these are the primary divine beings of Kasuga taisha, they are often grouped together as a syncretic, combined deity known as Kasuga Daimyōjin. Kasuga Daimyōjin is composed of five divine beings and each consists of a Buddhist deity and Shinto kami counterpart. The fifth deity, Ame no oshikumone, was added much later and is said to be the divine child of Ame no koyane and Himegami. The importance of the multifaceted kami was that it became a template for future worshipers who wanted to combine several deities to pray to at once.


== Architecture ==
The architectural style of Kasuga-taisha comes from the name of its main hall (honden) known as Kasuga-zukuri. The shrine complex is protected by four cloisters and contains a main sanctuary, treasure house, several different halls, and large gates. One beautiful aspect of this shrine is the many wisteria trees known as "Sunazuri-no-Fuji" that bloom in late April and early May. This shrine is also home to over 3,000 lanterns which are made of either stone or bronze. An entire hall is devoted to them which is Fujinami-no-ya Hall but the lanterns are only lit during the Setsubun Mantoro and Chugen Mantoro festivals.
The four main kami each have a shrine devoted to them which are all in the same architectural style. They are characterized by sloping gabled roofs, a rectangular structure, katsuogi (decorative logs), and chigi (forked roof structures). The first hall established is dedicated to Takemikazuchi no mikoto, the second to Futsunushi no mikoto, the third to Amenokoyane no mikoto, and the final hall is attributed to the consort, Himegami. Several auxiliary shrines lie outside the main sanctuary that are dedicated to lesser kami. One is allotted to Tsunofuri no kami, that is commonly known as Tsubakimoto Jinja Shrine or Kayabusa Myojin. Kasenomiya Jinja Shrine is attributed to Shinatsuhiko no mikoto and Shinatsuhime who are kami of the winds. Wakamiya Jinja Shrine, created in 1135 CE, is one of the more prominent auxiliary shrines because it houses the kogami, or offspring kami called Ame no Oshikumono no mikoto. The primary worship here revolves around vengeful gods and the dead and is the location of the Kasuga Wakamiya festival.
The Treasure House at this shrine contains hundreds national treasures as well as about many other cultural properties, most of which are from the Heian period. Some of the most noteworthy items that reside here are ornate taiko drums used in gagaku from the Kamakura period, arrows with crystal whistles from the Heian period, and bronze mirrors of the Heian and Nanboku-cho periods.


== Festivals ==
During the festivals of Setsubun Mantoro (February 3) and Chugen Mantoro (August 14–15), three thousand shrine lanterns are all lit at once. The Setsubun Mantoro refers to the celebration of the seasonal shift from winter to spring while the Chugen Mantoro relates to the transition of summer to fall. They both takes place in order to celebrate the Obon and Setsubun holidays in Japanese culture. At Kasuga Grand shrine, people are seen writing and attaching their wishes, or ema, to the lanterns before lighting them during both festivals. Additionally, it is said that tossing dried beans at these times will ward off bad luck in the future.March 13 is the Kasuga Matsuri, a local festival which features the dances of gagaku and bugaku. Shinto women perform traditional Japanese Yamato-mai dances that date back to the Heian and Nara periods. This festival also holds a horse celebration which consists of a parade through the streets by a "sacred" horse. One will see people dressed in traditional costumes of the Heian to Edo periods and can experience authentic kagura dance displays with dengaku music.
The Kasuga Wakamiya Festival takes place at the Wakamiya Jinja shrine from December 15 to 18th each year. The main goal of this gathering was to ward off disease while promoting new growth for the spring. Like Kasuga Matsuri, attendants can see kagura performances along with a procession in traditional attire.


== Kasugayama Primeval Forest ==
Kasugayama Primeval Forest is primeval forest of about 250 hectares (620 acres) near the summit of Kasugayama (498 metres (1,634 ft)), and contains 175 kinds of trees, 60 bird types, and 1,180 species of insects. In this area adjacent to Kasuga Grand Shrine, hunting and logging have been prohibited since 841 CE. Because Kasugayama has long been tied to Kasuga Grand Shrine worship, it is regarded as a sacred hill. The forest backdrop of the Kasuga Grand Shrine's buildings today has been unchanged since the Nara period.

Kasuga Taisha looks magical, especially in rainy weather: I was there twice, and both times it was rainy there. During such weather there is not so many people visiting, as they probably does not want to go there from Todai-Ji temple (10 minutes walking distance) so it is

This shrine is famous for their thousand lantern. Very beautiful shrine complex and can also experience lantern in the dark room. Outside the shrine there are huge area. You should allocate a lot of time if you want to explore the whole area.

This is a much visited shrine for the Japanese people, I was here on the weekend following New Year and the queues were substantial. Much writing and hanging up of wishes, so a glimpse into what makes a culture tick.

This is reached by taking along walk or a short trek through the forested areas of Nara. there are local buses which also go there. Cars are difficult to park there. Kasuga Taisha is Nara's most celebrated shrine. It was established at the same time as the capital and is

The shrine itself was attractive, and the forest trail to the shrine was even more attractive. Deers roam around the forest and on the trail so you’d see lots of them on the way. They were accustomed to the pilgrims. Once you get to the shrine there is a reception for visitors

When we went to Kashuga Taisha, we didn’t have much expectations and only went there as it showed on Google’s list of “things to do in Nara”. However I’d say now if there was only thing you could do in Nara apart from feeding the deers, go to Kasuga Taisha. It is slightly far

This temple is not on everyone's list, but it's situation surrounded by forest makes it special. The complex is easily reached in the South East of Nara Park, only maybe 15 minutes walk from Todaiji Temple if you're coming from the North along paths through the forest. However,
It was a good stroll after a heavy breakfast and family time enjoying the scenery and deers along the way. Among the best temples and not to miss.

This shrine is situated close to Todaiji-Temple. Since this shrine is the head quater of over 1000 shrines all oll over Japan. Very fortunately a wedding ceremoney (Japanese style) was held at the shrine when I visited there. This shrine was first built in 768. This is also a

To my mind by far the most interesting religious complex in the city's huge park area. There is lots to see and the winding paths through the forest leading to the shrine area, with their hundreds of stone lanterns, are an attraction in themselves. Allow an hour at least and
Wonder temple and even more fascinating graveyard adjoining the temple and a terrific, deer filled, path on the way to the temple.

The pathway leading to Kasuga Grand Shrine was nice with stone lanterns on both sides. It formed nice photo-backdrops for pictures while on the way with deers having their food near the lanterns. Entrance fee to the Grand Shrine was necessary. Worth to view the internal part

Following the trumpeting of the Deer at 10.00 we were escorted to the Kasuga Taisha Shrine. Fortunately, our Japanese friend could translate during our guided tour around the shrine. What is remarkable are the hundreds of stone lanterns outside and bronze ones inside. Well kept

Unluckily, when We visit the temple, there is a ceremony happened in the main hall so that we can’t go inside to have a walk. There are many light stands made by stone along the road. If you like calligraphy, a lady sitting in the counter to write calligraphy for visitors with a
About a 20 minute walk through the deer park across from Todai Ji but uphill all the way Worth the effort to see this World Heritage site and feed the deer Allow a good two hours

To me the Shinto shrines are the coolest religious places in Japan. Along with Fushimi Inari this was the best religious place in Japan. The walk up to it is magical surrounded by forest, stone lanterns and of course, deer. The temple itself is not very large but worth the
Beautiful. Very tranquil and relaxing to walk. Well suited to anyone who enjoys photography the area lends itself to the camera with interesting old trees and structures and contrasts.
4* Kasuga Taisha Shrine Shinto shrine Walking path flanked by 3000 stone and bronze lanterns Deer are around

This shrine was lovely, it’s free but there’s more to see for a small additional fee. The room with lanterns were my favourite. We took the bus here from the train station (the tourist information centre at the train station is very helpful). You will also see deer on your way
Basically one small courtyard and a special room you have to pay entrance to see. I was more impressed by the park than the shrine itself.

Hopefully by now you have read our two preceding reviews of our temple trek? If not, just pop back and have a look, we'll wait. Righto, good to see you back, here we go! In our last instalment we reviewed the Nara Park deer and we were heading out of the park to the Sth

What we liked best was the mystical feeling of the deers in the woods besides moss covered stone lanterns. There were few tourists. There were priests or similar women dresses in traditional white and red clothing. You can get goshuin here. We didn't see the dark room that other

As you walk through the Ni-no Torii you are immediately flanked on both sides of the path by moss covered stone lanterns---with Sika Deer intermittently poking their heads out with the hope that you have purchased some rice crackers to feed them. You walk up a gravel path with
It's a nice one to go to if you're in the area especially with the dark room lit up with lanterns. The area is scenic.

This place is absolutely stunning! The lanterns in the dark room are so beautiful and it is such a calm place. You can hear the forest and the sound of the lanterns in the wind. Even though there were many tourists in the park, the shrine was really quiet and such a beautiful

Disclaimer. If you or anyone you are visiting with is disabled, this probably won't be a place you'll enjoy. It's a bit of a trek from the Nara Deer Park up to the point where the thumbnail photo was taken. There's an incline walk and quite a few stairs with relatively few
I’ve never seen so many lamps in my life. Stone lamps, wooden lamps, metal lamps, several hundreds of lamps! Extremely beautiful and picturesque, highly recommendable!

Nara is a place that should be visited many many times...and each time the experience is unforgettable. We went to Nara from the Namba station in Osaka, on a leisurely JR rain ride. At Nara station, we went to the Visitor's Information Center where very helpful and pleasant

I could tell from the other reviews that this was exactly the sort of place I would love . But it totally surpassed my expectations . It is a magic place in the hills with lots of mossy stone pagodas on the hillside with deer peeking through. The shrine itself has wonderful

The Kaduga Shrine is a beautiful secluded holy site at the far end of Nara Park from the city centre. It's a good long walk but worth the trip. It is shaded by the trees and has many ornate gateways, carved stones and shrines within it. The Avenue of lanterns leading up to it is

This place is so beautiful, especially the hanging lanterns surrounded the shrine, very unique architecture and buildings. We took a train from Kyoto then take a bus to Nara park to get to the shrine - a long walk from the bus stop, but definitely worth a trip.
This shrine lies at he foot of a deeply forested hill. Pathways are lined with hundreds of lanterns, with many hundreds more in the shrine itself. There are several sub shrines around the main hall.
Nice place to visit if only to go into the darkened room full of lamps which was a lovely place to take some different photos.

Slight Uphill walk WILL struggle if unfit. Worth it if you want to see a beautiful shrine, docile deer scattered along the path. 600 yen fee to get in Get some good photos here as situated in a lot of trees and greenery

Mount Mikasa overlooks the bright vermillion colours and roofs of cypress bark of these remarkable buildings, Founded in 768, the inner sanctum comprises four separate shrines, adorned by a thousand bronze hanging lanterns. A number of smaller shrines are located throughout

Kasuga Taisha is one of the most famous shrines in Japan. If you like deers, then this place is right for you. Most of their charms have deer insignia on it. Also, the surrounding areas are breathtakingly beautiful. Truly a kino shrine. I was there almost the entire day
It is very beautiful Shrine, i already visited Shrine ini Korea. But this one in Japan is better. The view you see makes you feel better

This shrine is lovely; it contains many beautiful hanging metal lanterns and is surrounded by a multitude of large standing mossy stone lanterns. It is situated in a shady forest with many deer wandering around. Don't miss it.

As it is a shrine, the grounds are always open. I highly recommend going early, especially in summer before it gets too hot. At around 7am or 8am, there are just a few dog walkers or joggers, and you can enjoy the shrine grounds in silence. I was lucky enough to see and hear the
We didn't enter the shrine for lack of time. However, the walk to the shrine with stone lanterns is beautiful and relaxing. And there are the deer to entertain us!
I think this goes for all shrines/temples in Nara. There are absolutely stunning. This shrine with its beautiful colour and lanterns is amazing. Definitely worth a visit.
It's very cute to visit. Different from all other temples. It's one of the only two temples we saw in nara

This shrine has stone lanterns all the way up to the shrine as well as hanging lanterns. They are lit twice a year. That would be spectacular to see. There are lots of deer roaming around amid the stone lanterns. We only had an hour to view but it was enough time.

I think if I had to choose the most amazing attraction in Nara, for me it would be the Kasuga Shrine. Walking up to the Shrine is already quite amazing, with 100ders of stone lanterns in a "Harry Potter like" forest. When you enter the main shrine, the vermillion colour and the
We got here just as it was closing, but walked around the forest to the different areas. It was beautiful and I would recommend checking it out!

This is a beautiful temple, with many stone and bronze lanterns around the whole temple. However, the temple is separated into different parts and you will have to pay to enter the different areas. This is the temple where you can get your fortune by purchase a beautiful made
Go early to find no tourist around and hear the monks chanting. It was a good morning there each room has a pretty view and the path is well design so you can visit all the areas.

If visitng the Todjai-ji temple, this shrine must be included as part of your trip to Nara. Sadly, an ongoing ceremony (assumed to be a funeral given the sombre music and general mood) prevented any internal visit but the outside grounds and hundreds of stone lanterns proved to

This shrine is located at Nara, about 15 minutes slow walk from Todaiji. Before the ou enter the shrine, the paths are lined with numerous stone lanterns that were donated to the shrine. Upon entering the shrine, you'll see many beautiful ancient bronze and gold-plated lanterns

I wish I could say something more positive about the Kasuga Shrine but I am afraid I did not find it particularly memorable. I visited a lot of temples and shrines on an 11 day trip to Japan and some stand out because they were particularly stunning or novel in some way whilst
absolutely gorgeous place, you will also see some deers walking around. and the line of lanterns are so beautiful ... its vibrant, also there's a really huge old sacred tree inside. feels sarene

Beautiful place of 4 Kami (spirits/deities). Very annoyed with the tourists teasing the poor deers for selfies. Not just one nationality but a couple of nationalities. The deer is considered a sacred animal of the Kami. That is not a petting zoo. Those are wild animals.

This is actually a complex of shrines and covers a much larger area than most people realize. The grand shrine itself is plenty impressive, and the shady path leading up to is lined densely with stone lanterns with the famous Nara deers on the path and in the woods behind the

Kasuga Grand Shrine is the greatest shrine in Nara. There are 15 little shrines in this Grand Shrine area. It is worthy to hike around them. It's so beautiful and you will enjoy the peaceful atmospere in the forest.

It was a very nice 15 minute walk uphill through Nara park from the main road. It was very shady in the park and you feel very peaceful. You would also see lots of stone lanterns on both sides of the path, which was very unique. The shrine has a bright orange exterior and was
Very crowded once the tour group arrive. You will be unable to take good pictures of the very nice shrine.

Unfortunately, when we visited the Shrine, they were preparing for the year end ceremony and the last steps to the main shrine were shielded off. But I liked the greenery and nature, including the roaming deer in the compound.

Located within the shady recesses of deer-filled Nara Park, this shrine is a god-send if you are starting to suffer shrine fatigue on your Japanese travels. It has a unique layout and a labrynthine visitor route that gives a point of difference to the "normal" shrine visit where

I took a bus from the Nara JR Station directly to the car park located just below this remarkable shrine. Here there is a museum and a huge car park full of tourist buses as well as local buses that run in a schedule. To get to the shrine means a 10 minute walk up the hill

Another amazing UNESCO Heritage site to visit in Nara. Nara is easily accessible via train either from Kyoto or from Osaka. Enjoy the free running deers and also this Kasuga Taisha shrine. Beautiful view, leisure walk. You will not regret it.

Another beautiful Shinto shrine with the vermillion tori gates, to ward off evil. This complex has 100's of stone and bronze lanterns which have been donated by worshippers since 8th century. At certain times of the year, on specific occasions, all these lanterns are lit, must

We visited this site s part our our tour with Celebrity cruises. It is a very serene and beautiful place, although the day we were there it was quite busy. The stone lanterns line the pathway up to the shrine and are hauntingly beautiful. There is also the odd deer or to
This place is a must ! It’s beautiful. The lanterns are incredible. Do not miss this. One of my highlights in Japan

It felt like a long walk uphill to get to this shrine and when we did get there we were a bit disappointed with what there was to see. The shrine does have both Goshuin and free stamps for your notebook available. If I had my time again, I would probably skip this.

Kasuga Grand Shrine is another nice shrine in Nara. You need to walk along the pathway with tall trees and stone lanterns on both sides. The environment is quiet and peaceful with less crowds of visitor. If you want to enter the inner part of the shrine, you need to pay the

My partner and I visited Nara on the 15th of Oct '18. This was one of my favourite shrine/temples out of all the ones I visited during the month I spent in Japan. The walk to the shrine itsself was beautiful, the deer in this area were friendly and charming- less pushy than

Kasuga Shrine is a gorgeous place to visit. The vermillion and green of the shrine and lanterns is quite beautiful but the walk to the shrine, through the forrest along a path lined with lanterns is what really makes the visit.

This shrine is another of the recommended places to visit in Nara. We walked there from Todai-ji temple, and took the opportunity to interact with the numerous deer along the way. It's a nice walk there along a tree lined path. The shrine itself was quite crowded and seemed like
This is quite a huge shrine but I find it a bit too touristy. As a result, I didn't pay the extra 500 yen to enter the inner shrine. Perhaps you should check out the inner shrine.
This is a nice shrine filled with lanterns. But also have a good look along the roads when you walk to this shrine. All along these roads you can find bigger and smaller stone lanterns.

It was raining which made the walk to the shrine less fun than it should have been but I was interested to see all the different stone lanterns. Paid 500 yen to get into the inner shrine which was well worth it. More lanterns, quieter and a special area where they had a

Chanced to see this place while roaming around Nara park and I am so glad we decided to visit. Its involves a little uphill climb but quite manageable for someone like me with average fitness. Not for the elderly with mobility issues though. The place is stacked with lanterns

There is quite a hustle bustle walking up to this temple. Even within the premises there is a lot of people (I went during high tourist time of the year ) Pay the small entry fee and go inside to see the 1000 lanterns. Even more there is a little dark room with so many

It's a bit of a hike up though the park but for the UNESCO status and the crowds going there, I might have ignored it. Stone lanterns line the route and the local deer, always hungry for food from a tourist are everywhere. Pass a few of the minor temples, then go through the

Walking through the deer garden (there are real deer in there) up to the shrine is a more relaxed walk. The shrine itself is nice, pay the entrance fee to see the inner shrine, well worth it, specially the lantern room.

We walked through the Nara deer park up to this temple at 5pm on a clear autumn day. Many of the crowd had gone home after their day trips from Kyoto. As we approached the temple up the stone lantern lined path, everyone else was leaving as it had ‘closed’. It was getting dark

Wonderful shrine! It was our last shrine of our Japan trip. We completed our goshuin book in this shrine and we were happy because the stamp has a deer on it which represents Nara completely ♡. We were surprised to see the amount of lamps and it was beautiful to see the contrast

The path leading to the shrine is lined with stone lanterns, and many more nestled in the woods. The main shrine is recently renovated. The color of the shrine is in vivid orange red. There are many bronze/metal lanterns hanging along the wall of the buildings. This is a great

Lovely walk through the wooded area of Nara Park to get to this shrine. The shrine is very impressive and incredibly peaceful - although it is popular with tourists, somehow it still seems to give off a peaceful feel.

Kasuga Grand Shrine is a must whilst in Nara. Many different areas at the shrine the dark room with all the lantens lite up and many beautiful walk ways in brilliant red. Crowd's were small on the day so getting some great pictures was easy.

Kasuga is a smaller shrine with a lot of lanterns along the walk way to the shrine, It is within the Nara deer park, I must admit i was probably at this stage all shrined out as we had been to so many i didnt appreciate its beauty until i got home a looked at my photos. Worth a
Walking up to this area is fantastic, as you can see the hundreds of stone statues where lanterns are placed. The temple itself can be admired in part without entering, and there are deer all about.
The shrine is famous for its 3000 stone lanterns that line its approaches & bronze lanterns that hang from its buildings that are only lit twice a year during festivals in February & August.

Our tour made a short stop here and it was worth getting of the bus for, there are almost three thousand lanterns (2/3 stone, 1/3 brass) on the grounds. The stone lanterns are along the path leading to the temple and make for some beautiful pictures, especially if a deer walks

Our tour spent a half hour at this "Lantern Shrine" The walk to the shrine is bordered by many moss covered stone lanterns. There are more bronze lanterns at the shrine proper. Our guide told us that they are all lit twice a year during lantern festivals in February and August.

A beautiful, but not distinctive shrine. If you have visited other characteristic shrines in Japan, such as Heian Shrine (平安神宮) , Tsurugaoka Hachimangu (鶴岡八幡宮), Nikko Toshogu (日光東照宮), ......etc, this one can be skipped. The must-visit temples in Nara, in my opinion,

This was our 3rd place we visited in Nara Park. It also had the least number of visitors during our visit compared to the other 2 temples. The path leading to the shrine was lined with hundreds of concrete lanterns of various shapes and sizes. When we arrived at the shrine,

Architecture, style, color, stone and bronze lanterns, and history are some of the aspects that make a visit here worthwhile. This is Nara's most celebrated shrine dating back to the Nara Period (710-794 AD) and the Heian Period (794-1185 AD). Plenty of smaller shrines exist in
How i love this temple with thousands of stone lanterns situated from entrance to the interior of the temple! :) it looks exactly like in the anime! Enjoy walking around despite the deer poo.

There is not much to see from the front view outside the ticketing entrance. I paid 500 yen (worth it) to enter the walking path, which is quite long though some paths are in circles. The lines of lanterns are marvelous to view at if you appreciate the different ways they are

There are so many old lanterns on the way up to this temple set in beautiful parklands and of course surrounded by deer. You can choose whether to visit just the front part of the temple or pay 500Y pp and go further in where there are many ornate metal lamps some of which are

We reached the shrine via a lesser used path directly from Todai-ji Temple and then departed through Deer Park where all the stone lanterns are situated. The first thing you notice is how clean, bright and colorful the shrine complex is. The other distinguishing feature is the
This place is nearby nara park, whereby it surrounding of alot of historical heritage architecture. Better wear sport shoes when you visit Nara.

This Shrine contains hundreds if not thousands of lanterns. The path is lined on both sides with stone lanterns that are covered in moss and are stunning in their beauty. Deer roam around and peek out between the huge lanterns. It is unlike anything I have ever seen. You could
Even in broad daylight it’s easy to see that lanterns are the dominant symbol of the shrine. To get the full effect, visit in the evening when the lanterns are lit.

We visited Kasuga shrine in the evening, just before the closing time, with no crowd around, and it was truly magical experience! Red shrine buildings were framed with rows of lanterns of different size, shape and color. Plus, wisteria was in bloom! There are also a pitch dark
Many lanterns in this Shrine. Beautiful, the walk is a bit uphill, about 1.5 km walk from the street.

The collection of lanterns on the grounds is awesome. There is also 800-year old wisteria. The walk in is a bit uphill but not strenuous. The lanterns are left to age on their own so they are covered with moss, grass, or worn. Unique in presentation. Lovely in its own

Kasuga Grand Shrine is a Shinto shrine in the city of Nara. It is established in 768 CE. The path to Kasuga Shrine passes through Deer Park, in which deer can roam freely and are believed to be sacred messengers of the Shinto gods that inhabit the shrine and surrounding

Possibly my favorite out of all the shrines I visited over two weeks in Japan. The walk fro Todai-ji was beautiful and peaceful and the whole of Kasuga Taisha was absolutely gorgeous. There were some signs in English explaining the history of some of the trees, gardens, and sub

So many lanterns, with deer peeking out between them up to the shrine. However, having waited until later in the day, they offered only goshuin on pre-stamped paper and the additional walking pathways (which did cost money but apparently had nice wisteria) were already closed.
What a beautiful shrine and so well preserved M.D. looked after. It is an absolute must visit when in Nara

After visiting Todai-ji Temple, we went up to Kasuga Grand Shrine. Lots of stone lanterns on both sides of the pathway leading to the Shrine were very impressive. The forest with high trees and the groups of deer were roaming around were targets for photo-taking. If you want

We visited the temple after Todai-ji Temple, it is part of the big Nara Park area. The wide path is lined with many many stone lanterns (Kasuga), quite impressive. Lots of deer roaming around the area, as the forest is on either side. Really nice place to relax and stroll.
If you like Kasugas then this is the spot... many hundreds of them line the route to the temple its very impressive.... well worth a visit
You can see a lot of this site without paying the extra 500 yen. However there are some good things to see if you pay the admission. This includes a beautiful lantern room.

While walk toward the temple, you come across plenty of light stand that guide you to the temple. However, except the red building structure and some lovely lanterns, there are no much to see. I don't event border to pay for entering the temple. Maybe, the temple will be lovely

This is the main shrine in Nara and a very important one in Japan. You approach along an avenue lined with stone lanterns and much frequented by deer. I found them less aggressive here, so it is a good place to feed them. This whole area is cool and wooded and peaceful. The

Getting here by bus is pretty easy. They have one that goes on a round trip back to the JR station. We came right after it rained so it was pretty cold and wet. But the ground was surprisingly not muddy. It was a bit slippery though because of the rocks. The way there is pretty

this temple full of laterns. it is a kind of donation from people visiting there. you can write your names on it and do your blessing. there is a dark room filled up with light up laterns. a special experience. simple set up but beautiful.
Kasuga Taisu is a very beautiful temple located near the Nara Park. This temple's interior and exterior design and decorations are wonderful, really worth seeing.

This is a nice walk from the start of the park. It's worth seeing and makes for a great loop. When we went they were maintaining the zen gardens which was nice to see. They give out a cool deer goshuin too.
Great shrine. Walk through the park with surrounding trees and deer wandering around. Need a bit walking and there is some slope though.
Within Nara Park, this Shrine can be walk around within 45 minutes. It offers a glimpse of the shogun history and how religion plays an important part in their way of lives. Worth a visit!

One of the main sites in Nara. Medium sized square Shinto Temple complex to the southeast of Nara Park. There is a museum/carpark nearby from where you can catch a bus back to the station. Of course the colours are spectacular as are all the lanterns hanging in rows. There is

I think i love almost all shinto shrines. The shrine surounded by tall trees, there are vermilion torii and lanterns and everything seems mythical to me. We visit this place in afternoon and sun started to set down and everything so quiet. It just beautiful.

We liked especially the road coming to the shrine, surrounded by beautiful forest and many deers. However, it is sad to see plastic trash by the road and deer tried to bite it. We picked up the trash and had to walk almost 2 km as no trash bin around. Would it be helpful if

This shrine I want to characterize as the Shrine of the Lanterns, which can be found all over. I find that it lacks upkeep, even though you could also say that this way its original character is preserved best.
Peaceful shrine and lovely grounds. The path towards the shrine itself is worth being its own tourist attraction with wild deers along the way.

We commenced our exploration into Nara Park from Kintetsu Nara metro station. We started quite early in the morning but by the time, we reached Kasuga Grand Shrine it was almost late evening and the sky was turning dark. I was attracted by the vermilion columns of the temple

I toured a bit in the area and would make this one of my top two places to see if you were short on time. I didn't see another shrine like it across my many visits to shrines in Nara and in Kyoto because of the huge number of lantern holders that were strewn across the entire
It was so far the best shrine we visited in Nara. Very peaceful at noon so we could find a bit of peace here while wandering around. Highly recommend!
The Kasuga Shrine contains many light lanterns and very beautiful old trees. Very nice place to visit in Nara.

After visiting the humble abode of Shiga Naoya we headed out to Kasuga Taisha. We used a short cut access path that was a bit strange because all you see are towering trees barely penetrated by sunlight. I was only relieved by the end of the trail when I saw the convergence of

From the moment you start approaching the Shrine, you already start feeling amazed by the ancient atmosphere of the stone lanterns. It is a beautiful shrine with hundreds of lanterns and a dark room filled with mirrors that will leave you breathless.

A very brightly coloured shrine with a lot of small shops selling traditional Japanese good luck charms. The shrine has a relatively narrow pathway with quite a lot of up and down stairs which were tough for some of our elder group members .

Kasuganocho is one of the smaller shrines in town, but well worth it. As you walk up the pathway to the deer shrine you will see the historic stone carved lanterns along with red maple trees if you choose to come in the fall. A short walk leads you to the main shrine with the
My wife and I visited this place as part of our Tour of Nara Park. We have found from our 2 weeks in Japan, that most of the Japanese people are deeply religious.
Kasuga shrine is, by itself, not very large object. But park / approach and hundred of stone lanterns, in combination with the beauty of this shrine are, without doubt, must see.

It was built when earlier in history when Nara became the capitol of Japan. The shrine grounds is huge and lined with many stone lanterns given by worshipers during the years. They also have other hanging lanterns. The lanterns are lit twice a year. Many buildings to see,

A shrine (temple) located in a forrest with hundreds of old stone lanterns an hundreds of very tame deer. One of the best places to visit in Nara. It is worth to take a local bus from Nara railway station and walk the last part of the route through the forest.

It’s a short trek up a small hill to reach the temple. The trek itself is already pretty zen, with all the old stone lanterns along the way. When you get to the temple, there’s a fee to go into the “special area”, which we passed because it was raining and we wanted to return

This shrine was well worth visiting as the path winds its way through the forest in Nara Park, with smaller shrines on each side. The path was very busy as locals wandered up the hill to the shrine. After passing through a torii gate you will eventually come to the most

A beautiful shrine to visit while in Nara! I was lucky enough to be going with my host family while staying in Japan who were able to explain some of the processes in the shrine and help us view it respectfully. The first part of the shrine is the middle gate and the hall (the

Kasuga Taisha is worth the detour! In 768 four deities were invited to dwell here and now over 2200 rituals are performed annually. The shrine is unique and beautiful and serene, even with tourists meandering through its walkways adorned by hanging golden lanterns. I loved
Plan you day in Nara sensibly because there are many attractions to visit and this is definitely one of them! Take many pics and feel lucky and grateful for the opportunity of visiting such a place!

Not very impressed, but it was a nice building and the walk towards the shrine had many cool lanterns. Try to walk to the right after you've seen the shrine and you'll see other temples with a whole different feeling, much more calm compared to the hectic Kasuga shrine with all
Just off the park, the shrine is one of the most ancient in Japan. Besides the lanterns this shrine also has very clean restrooms which the overrun Buda Temple lacks. Plan to do your business here.

This Shinto temple is a great addition to the hike to Nigasudo and presents a comparison with this being a Shinto shrine. The entrance cost is well worth getting into the inner pathways of the shrine including a darkened hallway with hundreds of lanterns simulating what it would

It seems like everywhere you turn there is a shrine or temple - and nearly all of them are worth a visit! The Kasuga Grand Shrine is no exception. Definitely make sure this is on your list of shrines to see in Nara!

Kasuga grand shrine is located in Nara area and should be part of your itineraries while in Nara. The temple is very nicely designed and also has quite nice view. The pictures that I attached can clearly explained why.

You need at least 3 hours here to fully explore the surrounding forest. Well worth it. There are plenty of wild deer in the complex and you could easily spend hours just feeding them and getting them to bow.

This shrine is a bit of a walk (it's located in a different area to some of the other main temples in Nara Park), but the lanterns are lovely and it's worth a look.

Great Shrine in the Nara complex..lovely architecture and beautiful gardens and lanterns.. worth a visit.. little deer wandering around also
it's a nice place but another of the many shrines in Japan, so nothing new. the walk there and back through the park is a nice one

Live everything in Nara park, this temple is so beautiful. The stone lanterns are the main attraction, there are so many of them. Also the canfor tree is very impressive. Can get crowded so visit early.

Located within a forest, this temple complex is beautiful. Wonderful for wondering around and slowly taking in the beauty of the buildings and landscape.

there are many good temples to look at in the park whether the cost to see the laterns is worth it i am not sure, we only walked around and could see many of the key features from outside.

A Japanese couple recommended this shrine and it did not disappoint. The beautiful colours and architecture is very special and offers a lovely contrast to the giant Buddha.

This is a wonderful Shinto shrine that is both beautiful and peaceful. I could spend hours here just being.

text.quote: Serene classical Japanese garden on a quiet river with a wooden teahouse & striking autumn blooms.
trip: This garden is situated between Kofukuji Temple and Todaiji Temple (both World Heritages). There is a house with glass doors which were made by hands; therefore the glass planes are not flat and smooth. The garden shows different colors depending on each season.

This was a beautiful find in Nara - it's far away from the crowds and so very peaceful and quiet. We visited when the autumn colours were glorious - beautiful hues of yellow, orange and red. It's free for international tourists - just show some ID!
First, foreigners get a free pass. Second, not overly crowded. Peaceful, lovely rest houses oozed with ambience and charm. Not much colour yet, nor flowers but the mosses were in good form.
Really lovely visit. Near other attractions. And free. No reason not to go. Nice little brochure, too.

This was a great introduction to Japanese gardens for me. I was happy to find that this garden is free if you show a foreign passport, and it ended up being one of the best gardens I saw in my time in Japan! The three segments are all beautiful, and the tea house set the perfect

Most people come to Nara to see deer. I am not so much into animals, as I am peaceful and relaxing experiences. I had Isuien garden on my list to visit and just my luck, it was closed on the day I went to Nara. I discovered this garden right next door and went. For some odd

We went into this garden as it was free, as opposed to Isui-en garden. You have to show ID. Not sure why??? Strange. It was not so big; however still consists of three parts: The Moss Garden, The Pond Garden, The Tea Ceremony Garden. It was really beautiful and peaceful, well
Very beautiful, free for foreigners. The counter staff will ask you where did you get info about this place. Best part is less crowds and no deer stink.

I had read on a blog to visit the gardens and I'm so glad we did! It's off from the main road and away from Nara park which was actually a blessing. I'm assuming people either don't know about it or only care to see the touristy things. It's free for international travelers as

This was my favorite place in all of Nara. If you like crowds, go to the other major cites in Nara. There are crowds aplenty. If you want a place of serenity and beauty come to this garden. Most westerners, including myself, are not skilled at looking at Japanese gardens. But
Beautiful and well maintained garden. Water, stones, little bridges – all incorporated into landscape so you can relax and enjoy the nature.

Beautiful but quite small Formal garden with pond, moss and flower areas with many orchids in flower. A peaceful retreat after the deer park! And as overseas visitors we had free entry on showing our passports. Highly recommend.

We visited this garden on April 9. It is next to the Isuien garden. Only Japanese visitors have to pay an entrance fee. If you are a foreign visitor make sure that you have your ID with you. Show it at the ticket office and you can visit for free. It is not a big garden, but it

This is a true gift of the people of Nara to foreigners such as myself. No fee if you show your passport. It is far less crowded than its neighboring garden, though not as extravagant. Very peaceful, though, with a chance to walk around without constantly running into other

This was an unexpected delight. We were heading to the Isuien Garden, which was literally next door and found these gardens. It is free entry for foreigners with proof of ID. It was just sooo beautiful - tranquil, peaceful and beautiful. The garden comprised of 3 areas but

If you show your passeport, the entrance is free! (Otherwise, I think it costs 250¥) Very calm place, right next to Nara park. Almost no tourists inside, it was to calm compared to Nara park which was crowded with tourists… Give it a try! Estimated time inside this garden: 15 to

If you are a foreigner, take a passport! Entrance for foreigners is for free if you have a passport with you! Beautiful garden! very nice lady at the entrance! be sure to come and see and take beautiful pictures!

Unexpected visit to this lovely garden. I was headed to Isuien Gardens (literally next door) and found the entrance to Yoshikien Gardens. Free for foreigners to enter with ID. The garden is comprised of three areas with slightly different themes in each. Beautiful even without

Came here on a Tuesday (today) was open. While the garden is a standard japanese garden wuth 3 levels (stone, moss and flower), which is pretty as per any old japanese garden, the lady who was admitting guests at the entrance was very unfriendly to me and my family, just coz we

The garden is open until 17 and the last entry is at 16.30. As we were approaching the garden entrance at 16.28 or so we saw the lady hanging out the "closed" sign already. A little later, when we tried to enter, I showed the lady at the entrance my phone showing exactly 16.30,
I think this garden is much better than nearby Isuien Garden. It is managed by the Nara Prefecture. It has lovely restful aspects to it. It’s free for foreigners.

Spacious and beautiful garden near Isuien and Todaiji, entry is free for foreign visitors. So, everything is there for a nice stroll! In winter you can enjoy mossy rocky landscape and camellia flowers)

This surprisingly spacious garden is not as well known as the Isuien close by; there were only a few visitors the Sunday afternoon we visited although it is free for foreigners (bring your passports - they will check individually). Very serene place, but I thought the place was

This beautiful garden is simple and serene. For visitors to Japan from other countries, there is no entry fee. Simply show your ID. I have visited in spring and autumn. Both seasons are lovely in this quiet garden.

This is not a particularly well publicised garden but it was one of our favourites during our holiday in Japan. The style does not follow a strict typical Japanese style, it had less emphasis on heavily clipped topiary and a greater variety of planting for year round interest.

As you enter the Nara Park you will walk past the entrance to this beautiful garden. It is easy to miss, so look for it. Entrance is free for foreigners, but even with a fee you should go and have a look. A lovely designed garden with a few structures, easy to do in less than an

I thought this was a lovely Japanese style garden, with three gardens you could visit. If international visitors show a passport than it is free entry. It was beautiful with the autumn leaves and not too crowded. I would recommend it.
There are top garden destinations in Japan to go to, But if you dont have time to go to each, in Yoshikien, you will bea able to have a feel of: pond garde, moss garde and tea house garden.

We stumbled across this place along the lines of after visiting the nearby Todaiji Temple. It's free for foreigners (just have to show your passport). The three gardens are well kept and worth the 20 minute stroll. Definately worth the stop on your way through.

A nice garden in Nara, after visiting the temples and shrines and see all the deers is a good idea to stop at this garden, enjoy the peace and quiet of the place. The garden has 3 areas, the Moss Garden, the Flower Garden and the Pond Garden. Also has a Japanese style house and

I visited this garden during a recent stay in Nara. It is just next to Isuien, making it easy to stop at both on one trip. In addition, admission to this garden is free if you are a foreigner. The garden itself is lovely and peaceful and while a bit smaller than the neighboring
Nice beautiful garden and free for foreigners. not a huge garden, but delightful nonetheless. At a reasonable pace, would take about half an hour. Right next door to isuien gardens.

So peaceful, well taken care of and just beautiful. Clearly shows the beauty of the area, the wonderful care the people give to this place, and why so many visit it. You could find a spot to just yourself and hang out.
We stumbled upon this free entry hidden garden as the isui-en was closed and it would have been a shame to miss the small garden.

Came here looking for Isui-en (next door) and entered because it is free for foreigners! It was such a pleasant surprise. There is a lot of variety in the garden (walking paths and ponds) and is also a decent size so you can walk around peacefully with no crowds. If you are

We were looking for somewhere quiet and peaceful to sit and relax after visiting the Deer Park and temple at Nara. This garden is immediately adjacent to the Isuien Garden and near the bus stop to the JR station. Entrance is free to international guests on production of a

Yoshikien gardens are right next door to Isuien Garden. Entrance is free from memory. There are various levels with different plants/planting styles e.g. the moss garden, the flower garden etc. Lovely to wander through and you'll probably have it mostly to yourself.

We found this amazing place by pure accident. Took a wrong turn when returning from the nearby temple to get to the Nara train station. Well worth a visit if you are in the area. The gardens are beautiful, it is a great change of pace from the normal hustle and bustle that is

We stayed over 2 nights in Kyoto, and it was decided to do a day trip to Nara. On my personal itinerary for Nara, I had also wanted to visit Isuien Garden, and by chance we came across Yoshikien which was adjacent. This surprisingly small albeit quaint Garden was worth the hour

The location was beside the Isuien Garden and near the Todaiji Temple. Foreigner tourist may enter the garden for free. The park was nice with some plants and local architecture buildings. To walk around the park need less than 1 hour. Very good place to relax and enjoying

Yoshikien Garden (吉城園) is right next to Isuien Garden (依水園). You have to pay Y650 for entry to Isuien Garden but it's free entry for foreigners to Yoshikien Garden. We went through the underpass to get to the garden from Kofukuji temple. Upon entry, there is the pond garden.

When I visited Nara, I was told by the official of tourist information centre that I should visit Yoshikien Garden as it is very beautiful. Moreover, it is free for foreigners. I visited the place in the morning by 11 a.m. It was third week of November and fall season was in
Both gardens (there's another garden next door: Isui-en) are very lovely and have great views! We enjoyed them more than famous garden of Kenrokuen in Kanazawa).

Whilst it's neighbouring garden is a bit larger we found Yoshikien gardens to be a more serene experience. Some how a little bit more relaxed yet very beautiful. It is obviously looked after with much love. A bonus is that it is free for foreign visitors. We showed our drivers

As always, every garden I have visited in Japan has the same ambiance that will make you feel at peace. We went here and found out that we don't have to pay entrance fee (because we are tourist-not local people). It's not a big garden, but you don't want to leave this place
This is a wonderful example of a traditional Japanese garden. Every view is designed like a painting and different parts of the garden evoke aspects of nature.
A lovely and peaceful place for a stroll and to take pictures of this beautiful place inmnersed in the Japanese nature.
We liked this better than the next door Isuien Garden and it was free with foreign ID. One of these gardens would be enogh in my opinion and I would chosse this one.

If you want to take a break from the hustle and buatle of people in Nara Park, then I would recommend this place. A small but peaceful and pretty garden to walk around or just take a load off. Also it is free for non Japanese visitors.

This garden is not a large one but it's definitely very pretty and calm. As all japanese gardens it's very well kept. You may find toilets there too, even if not the cleanest at least for japanese standard.

This is a lovely garden and beautifully kept. Infact there are three distinct gardens within it, i.e. the Japanese styled garden with a pond and a small observation hill overlooking it, a serene moss garden and lastly a flower garden at the back. We took an early bus from

We stumbled upon this garden and the free price tag was a warm welcome after a morning of digging into pockets to pay around Nara. This is a beautiful garden, it was peaceful and quiet. Such care and attention to detail.

Indeed, as described on one of the website, it's a fine garden. The whole place is very well maintained and taken care of. Of course, you can see much now, except all greens. But it is recommended to visit during November where you can see spectacular maple trees!

We visited this because it is free for foreigners, otherwise I don't think it would be worth paying for it. Nice garden, but nothing spectacular. If you have to pay, go right next door to see an amazing garden

Even during the Golden Week holiday we could escape the crowds. May really is a spectacular time - so green! And before the heat sets in. Free entry for foreigners makes this a great option. Just as nice as the more famous Isuien next door.
Free visit of these gardens for oversea tourist. Garden is beautiful and quiet even if it is 5 minutes walk from the big Buddha.

From the gentle and informative welcome to the abundance of wonderful flowers this small garden is testament to someone's aesthetic sensibilities. It needs time and gentle strolling. Everywhere there is beauty in the tiniest stone or fragment of moss. Please don't miss it and

Even though Winter, with no flowers or foliage, this garden is lovely with moss and water features. A couple of small huts added to the timelessness. Tranquil just to stroll along the paths in the misty rain.

We stumbled across this while we were heading elsewhere. When we saw that it was free for foreigners (like us Aussies) we knew there was no reason not to stop and have a look. Fantastic walking path that flowed through the gardens, with photo opportunities at every turn. Set

Although we visited this garden in winter, it's still a very worthwhile garden to visit. The moss gardens are beautiful and it's easy to walk around. We took a taxi from JR Nara, ¥1040. Very handy to Nara Park and all it's attractions. Free entrance for foreigners.

This garden's autumnal beauty was on show when we visited in November. We were so very impressed. The thought, design and labour that had gone into it, is a credit to those involved. The different 'rooms' are delightful. It is well presented and a must, if you like gardens and

This amazing garden is a hidden treasure in Nara it is next to the Isui-en garden but they are 2 separate gardens.Both are situated near Nara park.Make sure you take your passport as the entry is free for foreign visitors. You walk through the entrance into an amazing pool

This garden is immediately next door to Isui-en garden (a magnificent traditional Japanese garden). They are both worth visiting if you are in the area. Yoshikien is much smaller but offers a moss garden, pond garden and garden of tea ceremony flowers.

Small pretty garden. Not stunning but worth a short visit en route to temples as free for non Japanese. Right next door to isui-en garden which looked beautiful but is expensive at 900y but means you can peek through the mesh fence for nothing!

Yoshikien is a small and beautiful garden with its entrance just to the right of Isuien garden (also worth visiting, much bigger and a fee). With your identity card or passport you will get free entry as a foreigner. It is a serene and beautiful garden that you should not miss

This is right next to Isuien garden and has three sections to stroll in. Foreigners are free of charge. It's extremely pretty with lovely water features and a nice moss garden. The walk is a loop, so it's easy to spend 45 minutes here exploring. There are some rocky steps so

Very nice garden next to Isuein. It's free for foreigners and is worth the twenty minutes to wander around. Much quieter and less busy than its neighbor, and it has three different sections. Would recommend a visit to both, start with this one though.
This garden is fairly small but nice and pretty and peaceful. It's free to visit if you're foreign so worth a look in. There is a pond section, mossy section and flower section.

Very nice garden! Free admission if you are from another country. The gardens and houses were really nice to see. The last garden didn't have any blooms but she let us know that and it was in August. The moss garden was nice. For something free it was great and somewhere you
Free for foreigners, beautiful moss garden! Right next to isuien garden. For me, this garden was cozier, quieter and more peaceful. Go in!

If I gave a five star rating to Isuien Garden, then this one only deserves 4 stars. For most people it is probably not worth visiting both gardens, especially if you are dragging nagging children along with you, and this one is unquestionably the less expensive of the two.

After a very warm welcome by a friendly lady, speaking fluent English (not too common in Japan ) we spent a wonderful time in this beautiful garden. It's better kept than it's neighbor and has lots of places to sit down and calmly enjoy. After all, that's what gardens are
Saw many butterflies spiders and lizards and were able to get many great shots. Free for tourists with passport and English speaking front desk.
This garden is a bit hidden off the main road. However, it is a nice and quite place. The garden is very beautiful. The entrance is free for foreigners.

Free to foreigners, this garden is absolutely lovely. It was not busy at all when we went. We saw, maybe 4 other people there. A very nice place to relax and take your time. I didn't visit the garden next door, but this one was amazing. There was no need to go to the other

Nice alternative to isuien because it's free to foreigners instead of 900 yen. From what I can tell very similar although smaller. Don't think it would be necessary to go to both. Go here on your way to todai.

It is a beautiful garden, especially the part with pond and the moss garden. Nicely shaped, beautiful colours of green, and for free for foreign tourists. So, definitely recommend to visit - it is for 20 minutes, but worth it.

The garden entry is free for foreign tourists. There are 3 main gardens and all are beautiful, perhaps not as manicured as the Isui-en garden next door. Lovely place to sit in peace and enjoy the beauty of nature.

There were three separate parts to this garden - the pond garden, moss garden, and flower garden. Every turn in the path revealed a new and tranquil scene. The sound of water was always there as well. Also, it was free to foreigners - a first for us.

I'm not too good on planning trips so this was a wonderful surprise on the walk to the Todaiji temple. The garden has numerous stone paths, a pavilion and a beautiful teahouse. It was gorgeous even in the rain. top tip: take insect repellent. There are mosquitoes and a sign

This free to tourists (show passport) moss garden with a traditional tea house and ponds is situated to one side of Nara Park and next to the more elaborate pay to enter Isuien garden. We spent a quiet half hour here on our bicycle ride around Nara Park – it is well laid out

Next door to the more frequented Isuien garden (900¥ entrance fee), this garden is smaller but well worth a visit : split in 3 gardens, the Pond, Moss and Tea gardens, the nicest may be the first one. During my visit early June, the monsoon rain had not yet arrived which may be
perhaps not very spectectular, this is a nice garden worth a visit (and free for foreigners) - we found the moss garden very interesting- didn't even know such thing exists

Yoshikien Garden is located very near Nara Park, Isuien Garden, and Todaiji. The free entry for foreigners attracted my attention. It is a quiet and quaint garden compared to Isuien next door, but it still offers enough lush greenery and flowers to provide a sense of tranquility

Stopped by this lovely garden and it was one of the best we saw in Japan. Free for international guests. Great landscape design and a beautiful tea house. Skip the garden next door that requires a payment and check this out instead. Totally worth it.

I walked by this place after leaving Isuien right next door and being slightly disappointed (it was an overcast afternoon on a winter day), and saw a sign that said "free to foreigners". I had some time to kill and thought, why not? It was a nice surprise. I took many pictures

beautiful garden with less visitors to find some peace in the humble jumble or Nara. I can highly recommend to take a rest here and enjoy the traditional living house and beautiful garden beside its big and expensive brother. This is maybe the only place where you will find

Such a warm welcome from a lovely old lady and as we are international visitors we got to visit for free. Those are the positives! Unless you are bored and in desperation of something to pass time I would give this place a miss. Very poorly maintained its like visiting an

Recently on a trip to Nara my parents and I had a few hours to do some sightseeing. Yoshikien wasn't on our list to see, but as the next door neighbors were taking the day off, and as it was free to international visitors, we popped in. Let me preface this by saying we also

It's amazing how the other tourists always skip the gardens. There were so many people at Tennoji, we just expected the gardens to be a madhouse also. The place is so serene and has a lot of history. These gardens are hundreds of years old and immaculately maintained.

We were on our way to Isuien and came across this garden located just right next door. When we saw a sign that says free admission for foreign tourists, we decided to give it a go. To our surprise, the garden far exceeded our expectation. It was really quiet and peaceful with

Located just next door to Isuien Gardens, entrance is free to foreign visitors. While not very large, it does offer three pretty gardens - the pond garden, the moss garden and flower garden. There were only a few other visitors when we were there, so it was nice to be able to

Is a lovely garden with free entrance for foreigners . A place to be surrounded with the feel of fall. Walking distance from my stay from ryokan Mitsumae. Next to this beautiful garden is isuien garden,
This garden is right next to Isuien garden. Entrance is free for foreigners. There were no other people when we went here so it was very quiet and peaceful. Autumn colors are beautiful.

Though a small garden, right next door to the Isuien, the Yoshikien is a must visit. It is free to foreign tourists (need to show your passport), and has three beautiful gardens in its premises - the moss garden, the flower garden and the tea garden. Lovely on a cold morning

This park is small, but well worth a visit. Its beautiful and quiet. We had the whole place to ourselves and just sat and watched over the well kept gardens and ponds. Please, make sure to visit this little wonder! It's better than the big Park next door!
really nice garden and if you show your passport at the entrance you will get free entry, really well laid out and maintained gardens well worth a visit

google: A beautiful Japanese garden. As soon as we arrived, we were offered a complimentary tour. Our guide, Kobe, explained the history for the garden and gave more details about Nara. It was a genuinely wonderful experience I’ll treasure for a lifetime.

.there are 3 types of garden within, I'd say this takes about 30mins
