text.wiki:
Nara (奈良市, Nara-shi, Japanese: [naꜜɾa]) is the capital city of Nara Prefecture, Japan. 
As of 1 April 2019, Nara has an estimated population of 359,666, making it the largest city in Nara Prefecture and sixth-largest in the Kansai region of Honshu. Nara is a core city located in the northern part of Nara Prefecture bordering the Kyoto Prefecture. 
Nara was the capital of Japan during the Nara period from 710 to 794 as the seat of the Emperor before the capital was moved to Kyoto. Nara is home to eight temples, shrines, and ruins, specifically Tōdai-ji, Saidai-ji, Kōfuku-ji, Kasuga Shrine, Gangō-ji, Yakushi-ji, Tōshōdai-ji, and the Heijō Palace, together with Kasugayama Primeval Forest, collectively form the Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 


== Etymology ==
By the Heian period, a variety of different characters had been used to represent the name Nara: 乃楽, 乃羅, 平, 平城, 名良, 奈良, 奈羅, 常, 那良, 那楽, 那羅, 楢, 諾良, 諾楽, 寧, 寧楽 and 儺羅.
A number of theories for the origin of the name "Nara" have been proposed, and some of the better-known ones are listed here. The second theory in the list, from the notable folklorist Kunio Yanagita (1875-1962), is most widely accepted at present.

The Nihon Shoki (The Chronicles of Japan, the second oldest book of classical Japanese history) suggests that "Nara" was derived from narasu (to flatten, to level). According to this account, in September in the tenth year of Emperor Sujin, "leading selected soldiers (the rebels) went forward, climbed Nara-yama (hills lying to the north of Heijō-kyō) and put them in order. Now the imperial forces gathered and flattened trees and plants. Therefore the mountain is called Nara-yama." Though the narrative itself is regarded as a folk etymology and few researchers regard it as historical, this is the oldest surviving suggestion, and is linguistically similar to the following theory by Yanagita.
"Flat land" theory (currently most widely accepted): In his 1936 study of placenames, the author Kunio Yanagita states that "the topographical feature of an area of relatively gentle gradient on the side of a mountain, which is called taira in eastern Japan and hae in the south of Kyushu, is called naru in the Chūgoku region and Shikoku (central Japan). This word gives rise to the verb narasu, adverb narashi, and adjective narushi." This is supported by entries in a dialect dictionary for nouns referring to flat areas: naru (found in Aida District, Okayama Prefecture and Ketaka District, Tottori Prefecture) and naro (found in Kōchi Prefecture); and also by an adjective narui which is not standard Japanese, but is found all across central Japan, with meanings of "gentle", "gently sloping", or "easy". Yanagita further comments that the way in which the fact that so many of these placenames are written using the character 平 ("flat"), or other characters in which it is an element, demonstrates the validity of this theory. Citing a 1795 document, Inaba-shi (因幡志) from the province of Inaba, the eastern part of modern Tottori, as indicating the reading naruji for the word 平地 (standard reading heichi, meaning "level/flat ground/land/country, a plain"), Yanagita suggests that naruji would have been used as a common noun there until the modern period. Of course, the fact that historically "Nara" was also written 平 or 平城 as above is further support for this theory.
The idea that Nara is derived from 楢 nara (Japanese for "oak, deciduous Quercus spp.") is the next most common opinion. This idea was suggested by a linguist, Yoshida Togo. This noun for the plant can be seen as early as in Man'yōshū (7-8th century) and Harima-no-kuni Fudoki (715). The latter book states the place name Narahara in Harima (around present-day Kasai)　derives from this nara tree, which might support Yoshida's theory. Note that the name of the nearby city of Kashihara (literally "live oak plain") contains a semantically similar morpheme (Japanese 橿 kashi "live oak, evergreen Quercus spp.").
Nara could be a loan word from Korean nara (나라 : country, nation, kingdom). This idea was put forward by a linguist Matsuoka Shizuo. Not much about the Old Korean language is known today, and the first written attestation of a word ancestral to Modern Korean nara is as late as the 15th century, such as in Yongbieocheonga (1447),  Wolinseokbo (月印釋譜. 1459), or Beophwagyeongeonhae (法華經諺解. 1463), and there is no evidence that proves the word already existed as far back as the 7th century. These 15th-century books used narah (나랗), an old form of nara in Korean, and its older form might be reconstructed *narak. American  linguist Christopher I. Beckwith infers the Korean narak derives from the late Middle Old Chinese 壌 (*nrak, earth), from early *narak, and has no connection with Goguryoic and Japanese na. (See also the next theory.) Kusuhara et al. also points out this hypothesis cannot account for the fact there are many places named Nara, Naru and Naro besides this Nara.
There is the idea that Nara is akin to Tungusic na. In some Tungusic languages such as Orok (and likely Goguryeo language), na means earth, land or the like. Some have speculated about a connection between these Tungusic words and Old Japanese nawi, an archaic and somewhat obscure word that appears in the verb phrases nawi furu and nawi yoru ('an earthquake occurs, to have an earthquake').The "Flat land" theory is adopted by Nihon Kokugo Daijiten (the largest dictionary of Japanese language), various dictionaries for place names, history books on Nara and the like today, and it is regarded as the most likely.


== History ==


=== Pre-Nara/Origins ===
There are a number of kofun in Nara, including Gosashi Kofun, Hishiage Kofun (ヒシアゲ古墳), Horaisan Kofun (宝来山古墳), Konabe Kofun (コナベ古墳), Saki Ishizukayama Kofun (佐紀石塚山古墳), Saki Misasagiyama Kofun (佐紀陵山古墳), and Uwanabe Kofun (ウワナベ古墳).
By decree of an edict on March 11, 708 AD, Empress Genmei ordered the court to relocate to the new capital, Nara. Once known as Heijō or Heijō-kyō, the city was established as Japan's first permanent capital in 710 CE; it was the seat of government until 784 CE, albeit with five year interruption, lasting from 741-5 CE. Heijō, as the ‘penultimate court’, however, was abandoned by the order of Emperor Kammu in 784 CE in favor of the temporary site of Nagaoka, and then Heian-kyō (Kyoto) which retained the status of capital for 1,100 years, until the Meiji Emperor made the final move to Edo in 1869 CE. This first relocation was due to the court's transformation from an imperial nobility to a force of metropolitan elites and new technique of dynastic shedding which had refashioned the relationship between court, nobility, and country. Moreover, the ancient capital lent its name to Nara period.As a reactionary expression to the political centralization of China, the city of Nara (Heijō) was modeled after the Tang capital at Chang’an. Nara was laid out on a grid—which was based upon the Handen system—whereby the city was divided by four great roads. Likewise, according to Chinese cosmology, the ruler's place was fixed like the pole star. By dominating the capital, the ruler brought heaven to earth. Thus, the south facing palace centered at the north, bisected the ancient city, instituting ‘Right Capital’ and ‘Left Capital’ zones. As Nara came to be the epicenter of Buddhist church and drawing pilgrimage site, the city plan incorporated various pre-Heijō and Heijō period temples, of which the Yakushiji and the Todaiji still stand.
Gallery
		


=== Politics ===
A number of scholars have characterized the Nara period as a time of penal and administrative legal order. The Taihō Code called for the establishment of administrative sects underneath the central government, and modeled many of the codes from the Chinese Tang dynasty. The code eventually disbanded, but its contents were largely preserved in the Yōrō Code of 718.Occupants of the throne during the period gradually shifted their focus from military preparation, to religious rites and institutions, in an attempt to strengthen their divine authority over the population.


=== Religion and Temples ===
Nanto RokushūWith the establishment of the new capital, Asuka-dera, the temple of the Soga clan, was relocated within Nara. The Emperor Shōmu ordered the construction of Tōdai-ji Temple (largest wooden building in the world) and the world's largest bronze Buddha statue. The temples of Nara, known collectively as the Nanto Shichi Daiji, remained spiritually significant even beyond the move of the political capital to Heian-kyō in 794, thus giving Nara a synonym of Nanto (南都 "The southern Capital").
On December 2, 724 AD, in order to increase the visual “magnificence” of the city, an edict was ordered by the government for the noblemen and the wealthy to renovate the roofs, pillars, and walls of their homes, although at that time this was unfeasible.Sightseeing in Nara city became popular in the Edo period, during which several visitor's maps of Nara were widely published. During the Meiji Period, the Kofukuji Temple lost some land and its monks were converted into Shinto priests, due to Buddhism being associated with the old shogunate.
Gallery
		
		
		
		
		


=== Modern Nara ===
Even though Nara was the capital of Japan from 710 to 794, it was not designated a city until 1 February, 1898. Nara city has developed from a town of commerce in the Edo and Meiji periods to a modern tourist city, due to its large number of historical temples, landmarks and national monuments. Nara was added to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in December 1998. The architecture of some shops, ryokans and art galleries has been adapted from traditional merchant houses.Nara holds traditional festivals every year, including the Neri-Kuyo Eshiki, a spring festival held in Todaiji temple for over 1,000 years; and the Kemari Festival, in which people wear costumes ranging across 700 years  and play traditional games).In 1909, Tatsuno Kingo designed the Nara Hotel, whose architecture combines  modern elements with traditional Japanese style.


== Geography ==
The city of Nara lies in the northern end of Nara Prefecture, directly bordering Kyoto Prefecture to its north.  The city is 22.22 kilometres (13.81 mi) from North to South, from East to West. As a result of the latest merger, effective April 1, 2005, that combined the villages of Tsuge and Tsukigase with the city of Nara, the city now borders Mie Prefecture directly to its east. The total area is 276.84 square kilometres (106.89 square miles).Nara city, as well as several important settlements (such as Kashihara, Yamatokōriyama, Tenri, Yamatotakada, Sakurai and Goze), are located in the Nara Basin. This makes it the most densely-populated region of Nara Prefecture.The downtown of Nara is on the east side of the ancient Heijō Palace site, occupying the northern part of what was called the Gekyō (外京), literally the outer capital area. Many of the public offices (e.g. the Municipal office, the Nara Prefectural government, the Nara Police headquarters, etc.) are located on Nijō-ōji (二条大路), while Nara branch offices of major nationwide banks are on Sanjō-ōji (三条大路), with both avenues running east–west.
The highest point in the city is at the peak of Kaigahira-yama at an altitude of 822.0 m (2,696.85 ft) (Tsugehayama-cho district), and the lowest is in Ikeda-cho district, with an altitude of 56.4 m (185.04 ft).

=== Climate ===
The climate of Nara Prefecture is generally temperate, although there are notable differences between the north-western basin area and the rest of the prefecture which is more mountainous.
The basin area climate has an inland characteristic, as represented in the higher daily temperature variance, and the difference between summer and winter temperatures. Winter temperatures average approximately 3 to 5 °C (37 to 41 °F), and from 25 to 28 °C (77 to 82 °F) in the summer with highest readings reaching close to 35 °C (95 °F). There has not been a single year since 1990 with more than 10 days of snowfall recorded by Nara Local Meteorological Observatory.
The climate in the rest of the prefecture is that of higher elevations especially in the south, with  −5 °C (23 °F) being the extreme minimum in winter. Heavy rainfall is often observed in summer. The annual accumulated rainfall totals as much as 3,000 to 5,000 mm (118.11 to 196.85 in), which is among the heaviest in Japan and indeed in the world outside the equatorial zone.
Spring and fall temperatures are temperate and comfortable. The mountainous region of Yoshino has been long popular for viewing cherry blossoms in the spring. In autumn, the southern mountains are also a popular destination for viewing fall foliage.


== Cityscape ==


== Demographics ==
As of April 1, 2017, the city has an estimated population of 359,666 and a population density of 1,300 persons per km2. There were 160,242 households residing in Nara. The highest concentration of both households and population, respectively about 46,000 and 125,000, is found along the newer bedtown districts, along the Kintetsu line connecting to Osaka.
There were about 3,000 registered foreigners in the city, of which Koreans and Chinese are the two largest groups with about 1,200 and 800 people respectively.

== Deer in Nara ==
According to the legendary history of Kasuga Shrine, the god Takemikazuchi arrived in Nara on a white deer to guard the newly built capital of Heijō-kyō. Since then, the deer have been regarded as heavenly animals, protecting the city and the country.Tame sika deer (also known as spotted deer or Japanese deer) roam through the town, especially in Nara Park. In 2015, there were more than 1,200 sika deer in Nara. Snack vendors sell sika senbei (deer crackers) to visitors so they can feed the deer. Some deer have learned to bow in order to receive senbei from people.
Gallery
		
		
		


== Education ==
As of 2005, there are 16 high schools and 6 universities located in the city of Nara.


=== Universities ===

Nara Women's University is one of only two national women's universities in Japan. Nara Institute of Science and Technology is a graduate research university specializing in biological, information, and materials sciences.


=== Primary and secondary education ===


==== Public schools ====
Public elementary and junior high schools are operated by the city of Nara.
Public high schools are operated by the Nara Prefecture.


==== Private schools ====
Private high schools in Nara include the Tōdaiji Gakuen, a private school founded by the temple in 1926.


== Transportation ==

The main central station of Nara is Kintetsu Nara Station with JR Nara station some 500m west and much closer to Shin-Omiya station.


=== Rail ===
West Japan Railway Company

Really impressive pagoda and surrounding area. There's plenty to see on a day trip to Nara from Kyoto.

text.wiki:
Nara (奈良市, Nara-shi, Japanese: [naꜜɾa]) is the capital city of Nara Prefecture, Japan. 
As of 1 April 2019, Nara has an estimated population of 359,666, making it the largest city in Nara Prefecture and sixth-largest in the Kansai region of Honshu. Nara is a core city located in the northern part of Nara Prefecture bordering the Kyoto Prefecture. 
Nara was the capital of Japan during the Nara period from 710 to 794 as the seat of the Emperor before the capital was moved to Kyoto. Nara is home to eight temples, shrines, and ruins, specifically Tōdai-ji, Saidai-ji, Kōfuku-ji, Kasuga Shrine, Gangō-ji, Yakushi-ji, Tōshōdai-ji, and the Heijō Palace, together with Kasugayama Primeval Forest, collectively form the Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 


== Etymology ==
By the Heian period, a variety of different characters had been used to represent the name Nara: 乃楽, 乃羅, 平, 平城, 名良, 奈良, 奈羅, 常, 那良, 那楽, 那羅, 楢, 諾良, 諾楽, 寧, 寧楽 and 儺羅.
A number of theories for the origin of the name "Nara" have been proposed, and some of the better-known ones are listed here. The second theory in the list, from the notable folklorist Kunio Yanagita (1875-1962), is most widely accepted at present.

The Nihon Shoki (The Chronicles of Japan, the second oldest book of classical Japanese history) suggests that "Nara" was derived from narasu (to flatten, to level). According to this account, in September in the tenth year of Emperor Sujin, "leading selected soldiers (the rebels) went forward, climbed Nara-yama (hills lying to the north of Heijō-kyō) and put them in order. Now the imperial forces gathered and flattened trees and plants. Therefore the mountain is called Nara-yama." Though the narrative itself is regarded as a folk etymology and few researchers regard it as historical, this is the oldest surviving suggestion, and is linguistically similar to the following theory by Yanagita.
"Flat land" theory (currently most widely accepted): In his 1936 study of placenames, the author Kunio Yanagita states that "the topographical feature of an area of relatively gentle gradient on the side of a mountain, which is called taira in eastern Japan and hae in the south of Kyushu, is called naru in the Chūgoku region and Shikoku (central Japan). This word gives rise to the verb narasu, adverb narashi, and adjective narushi." This is supported by entries in a dialect dictionary for nouns referring to flat areas: naru (found in Aida District, Okayama Prefecture and Ketaka District, Tottori Prefecture) and naro (found in Kōchi Prefecture); and also by an adjective narui which is not standard Japanese, but is found all across central Japan, with meanings of "gentle", "gently sloping", or "easy". Yanagita further comments that the way in which the fact that so many of these placenames are written using the character 平 ("flat"), or other characters in which it is an element, demonstrates the validity of this theory. Citing a 1795 document, Inaba-shi (因幡志) from the province of Inaba, the eastern part of modern Tottori, as indicating the reading naruji for the word 平地 (standard reading heichi, meaning "level/flat ground/land/country, a plain"), Yanagita suggests that naruji would have been used as a common noun there until the modern period. Of course, the fact that historically "Nara" was also written 平 or 平城 as above is further support for this theory.
The idea that Nara is derived from 楢 nara (Japanese for "oak, deciduous Quercus spp.") is the next most common opinion. This idea was suggested by a linguist, Yoshida Togo. This noun for the plant can be seen as early as in Man'yōshū (7-8th century) and Harima-no-kuni Fudoki (715). The latter book states the place name Narahara in Harima (around present-day Kasai)　derives from this nara tree, which might support Yoshida's theory. Note that the name of the nearby city of Kashihara (literally "live oak plain") contains a semantically similar morpheme (Japanese 橿 kashi "live oak, evergreen Quercus spp.").
Nara could be a loan word from Korean nara (나라 : country, nation, kingdom). This idea was put forward by a linguist Matsuoka Shizuo. Not much about the Old Korean language is known today, and the first written attestation of a word ancestral to Modern Korean nara is as late as the 15th century, such as in Yongbieocheonga (1447),  Wolinseokbo (月印釋譜. 1459), or Beophwagyeongeonhae (法華經諺解. 1463), and there is no evidence that proves the word already existed as far back as the 7th century. These 15th-century books used narah (나랗), an old form of nara in Korean, and its older form might be reconstructed *narak. American  linguist Christopher I. Beckwith infers the Korean narak derives from the late Middle Old Chinese 壌 (*nrak, earth), from early *narak, and has no connection with Goguryoic and Japanese na. (See also the next theory.) Kusuhara et al. also points out this hypothesis cannot account for the fact there are many places named Nara, Naru and Naro besides this Nara.
There is the idea that Nara is akin to Tungusic na. In some Tungusic languages such as Orok (and likely Goguryeo language), na means earth, land or the like. Some have speculated about a connection between these Tungusic words and Old Japanese nawi, an archaic and somewhat obscure word that appears in the verb phrases nawi furu and nawi yoru ('an earthquake occurs, to have an earthquake').The "Flat land" theory is adopted by Nihon Kokugo Daijiten (the largest dictionary of Japanese language), various dictionaries for place names, history books on Nara and the like today, and it is regarded as the most likely.


== History ==


=== Pre-Nara/Origins ===
There are a number of kofun in Nara, including Gosashi Kofun, Hishiage Kofun (ヒシアゲ古墳), Horaisan Kofun (宝来山古墳), Konabe Kofun (コナベ古墳), Saki Ishizukayama Kofun (佐紀石塚山古墳), Saki Misasagiyama Kofun (佐紀陵山古墳), and Uwanabe Kofun (ウワナベ古墳).
By decree of an edict on March 11, 708 AD, Empress Genmei ordered the court to relocate to the new capital, Nara. Once known as Heijō or Heijō-kyō, the city was established as Japan's first permanent capital in 710 CE; it was the seat of government until 784 CE, albeit with five year interruption, lasting from 741-5 CE. Heijō, as the ‘penultimate court’, however, was abandoned by the order of Emperor Kammu in 784 CE in favor of the temporary site of Nagaoka, and then Heian-kyō (Kyoto) which retained the status of capital for 1,100 years, until the Meiji Emperor made the final move to Edo in 1869 CE. This first relocation was due to the court's transformation from an imperial nobility to a force of metropolitan elites and new technique of dynastic shedding which had refashioned the relationship between court, nobility, and country. Moreover, the ancient capital lent its name to Nara period.As a reactionary expression to the political centralization of China, the city of Nara (Heijō) was modeled after the Tang capital at Chang’an. Nara was laid out on a grid—which was based upon the Handen system—whereby the city was divided by four great roads. Likewise, according to Chinese cosmology, the ruler's place was fixed like the pole star. By dominating the capital, the ruler brought heaven to earth. Thus, the south facing palace centered at the north, bisected the ancient city, instituting ‘Right Capital’ and ‘Left Capital’ zones. As Nara came to be the epicenter of Buddhist church and drawing pilgrimage site, the city plan incorporated various pre-Heijō and Heijō period temples, of which the Yakushiji and the Todaiji still stand.
Gallery
		


=== Politics ===
A number of scholars have characterized the Nara period as a time of penal and administrative legal order. The Taihō Code called for the establishment of administrative sects underneath the central government, and modeled many of the codes from the Chinese Tang dynasty. The code eventually disbanded, but its contents were largely preserved in the Yōrō Code of 718.Occupants of the throne during the period gradually shifted their focus from military preparation, to religious rites and institutions, in an attempt to strengthen their divine authority over the population.


=== Religion and Temples ===
Nanto RokushūWith the establishment of the new capital, Asuka-dera, the temple of the Soga clan, was relocated within Nara. The Emperor Shōmu ordered the construction of Tōdai-ji Temple (largest wooden building in the world) and the world's largest bronze Buddha statue. The temples of Nara, known collectively as the Nanto Shichi Daiji, remained spiritually significant even beyond the move of the political capital to Heian-kyō in 794, thus giving Nara a synonym of Nanto (南都 "The southern Capital").
On December 2, 724 AD, in order to increase the visual “magnificence” of the city, an edict was ordered by the government for the noblemen and the wealthy to renovate the roofs, pillars, and walls of their homes, although at that time this was unfeasible.Sightseeing in Nara city became popular in the Edo period, during which several visitor's maps of Nara were widely published. During the Meiji Period, the Kofukuji Temple lost some land and its monks were converted into Shinto priests, due to Buddhism being associated with the old shogunate.
Gallery
		
		
		
		
		


=== Modern Nara ===
Even though Nara was the capital of Japan from 710 to 794, it was not designated a city until 1 February, 1898. Nara city has developed from a town of commerce in the Edo and Meiji periods to a modern tourist city, due to its large number of historical temples, landmarks and national monuments. Nara was added to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in December 1998. The architecture of some shops, ryokans and art galleries has been adapted from traditional merchant houses.Nara holds traditional festivals every year, including the Neri-Kuyo Eshiki, a spring festival held in Todaiji temple for over 1,000 years; and the Kemari Festival, in which people wear costumes ranging across 700 years  and play traditional games).In 1909, Tatsuno Kingo designed the Nara Hotel, whose architecture combines  modern elements with traditional Japanese style.


== Geography ==
The city of Nara lies in the northern end of Nara Prefecture, directly bordering Kyoto Prefecture to its north.  The city is 22.22 kilometres (13.81 mi) from North to South, from East to West. As a result of the latest merger, effective April 1, 2005, that combined the villages of Tsuge and Tsukigase with the city of Nara, the city now borders Mie Prefecture directly to its east. The total area is 276.84 square kilometres (106.89 square miles).Nara city, as well as several important settlements (such as Kashihara, Yamatokōriyama, Tenri, Yamatotakada, Sakurai and Goze), are located in the Nara Basin. This makes it the most densely-populated region of Nara Prefecture.The downtown of Nara is on the east side of the ancient Heijō Palace site, occupying the northern part of what was called the Gekyō (外京), literally the outer capital area. Many of the public offices (e.g. the Municipal office, the Nara Prefectural government, the Nara Police headquarters, etc.) are located on Nijō-ōji (二条大路), while Nara branch offices of major nationwide banks are on Sanjō-ōji (三条大路), with both avenues running east–west.
The highest point in the city is at the peak of Kaigahira-yama at an altitude of 822.0 m (2,696.85 ft) (Tsugehayama-cho district), and the lowest is in Ikeda-cho district, with an altitude of 56.4 m (185.04 ft).

=== Climate ===
The climate of Nara Prefecture is generally temperate, although there are notable differences between the north-western basin area and the rest of the prefecture which is more mountainous.
The basin area climate has an inland characteristic, as represented in the higher daily temperature variance, and the difference between summer and winter temperatures. Winter temperatures average approximately 3 to 5 °C (37 to 41 °F), and from 25 to 28 °C (77 to 82 °F) in the summer with highest readings reaching close to 35 °C (95 °F). There has not been a single year since 1990 with more than 10 days of snowfall recorded by Nara Local Meteorological Observatory.
The climate in the rest of the prefecture is that of higher elevations especially in the south, with  −5 °C (23 °F) being the extreme minimum in winter. Heavy rainfall is often observed in summer. The annual accumulated rainfall totals as much as 3,000 to 5,000 mm (118.11 to 196.85 in), which is among the heaviest in Japan and indeed in the world outside the equatorial zone.
Spring and fall temperatures are temperate and comfortable. The mountainous region of Yoshino has been long popular for viewing cherry blossoms in the spring. In autumn, the southern mountains are also a popular destination for viewing fall foliage.


== Cityscape ==


== Demographics ==
As of April 1, 2017, the city has an estimated population of 359,666 and a population density of 1,300 persons per km2. There were 160,242 households residing in Nara. The highest concentration of both households and population, respectively about 46,000 and 125,000, is found along the newer bedtown districts, along the Kintetsu line connecting to Osaka.
There were about 3,000 registered foreigners in the city, of which Koreans and Chinese are the two largest groups with about 1,200 and 800 people respectively.

== Deer in Nara ==
According to the legendary history of Kasuga Shrine, the god Takemikazuchi arrived in Nara on a white deer to guard the newly built capital of Heijō-kyō. Since then, the deer have been regarded as heavenly animals, protecting the city and the country.Tame sika deer (also known as spotted deer or Japanese deer) roam through the town, especially in Nara Park. In 2015, there were more than 1,200 sika deer in Nara. Snack vendors sell sika senbei (deer crackers) to visitors so they can feed the deer. Some deer have learned to bow in order to receive senbei from people.
Gallery
		
		
		


== Education ==
As of 2005, there are 16 high schools and 6 universities located in the city of Nara.


=== Universities ===

Nara Women's University is one of only two national women's universities in Japan. Nara Institute of Science and Technology is a graduate research university specializing in biological, information, and materials sciences.


=== Primary and secondary education ===


==== Public schools ====
Public elementary and junior high schools are operated by the city of Nara.
Public high schools are operated by the Nara Prefecture.


==== Private schools ====
Private high schools in Nara include the Tōdaiji Gakuen, a private school founded by the temple in 1926.


== Transportation ==

The main central station of Nara is Kintetsu Nara Station with JR Nara station some 500m west and much closer to Shin-Omiya station.


=== Rail ===

Plan of Todaiji
text.quote: Hilltop hall, part of Tōdai-ji Buddhist temple, with sweeping views of Nara from its balcony.
trip: The Nigatsu-do temple is one further milestone along the beautiful park of temples and shrines in Nara. It is located not too far behind te Todaji shrine and offers a beautiful view on the complex, due to its elevated location on a small hill nearby. The area is rather calm and
There is a descent flight of stairs to climb to get to this temple but it is worth the view. The view from the balcony is across the Nara Park and to the city.
We didn't get in so I can't say anything about the inside. But from the outside, it's quite impressive with its large columns. You have great views of the city
Beautiful hike up to see all of Nara. We were there during one of the festival in early March and saw they light large torches and run across the temple. It was amazing!
Had to hiked using the stairs. Tiring but totally worth it. Beautiful building with panoramic view from the top.

Temple is close by the Todaiji temple, uphill. Nigatsu-dō or Second Month Hall as named after Shuni-e ceremony that is held in the second lunar month. Original temple from 9th century burnt during the ceremony and current building is from 1669. Temple offers nice view to the
Part of the Todaiji complex, but deserves a special mention. The main temple is designed in such a way that it overlooks the city, gives a great vibe to the place. A must do.

This hall and temple is named after the month of February (Sangatsudo Temple next door is the March Hall ) and apparently it is famous for fireworks in February. It sits at the back of the Todaiji Temple up the steps and the hill.There is also a great view from this point.

It was worth dropping by although it was a bit way far. It was quieter with lesser crowd. The architecture of the building was beautiful. The lanterns were also beautiful and one could have a better view of Nara up here.

Nigatsu-do Hall or "Hall of the Second Month" is part of the Todai-ji Temple complex---which also includes the Great Buddha Hall (Daibutsuden), the Belfry and the Great South Gate (Nandaimon). It offers some beautiful views and is a nice respite from the crowds you will find
Quieter area not too many tourists but worth the visit just for the view and the serenity. there is a small restaurant you can grab something to eat at pretty basic but again away from the crowds.

Not far away from the famous Todaiji-Temple lays this temple. Up there you have a nice view and you can also drink a tea. The little hike up it’s worth it, because the building and everything around looks very nice and like the title also says it’s not so crowded like the

This was one of my favorite temples during my visit in Japan. The buildings are simple beautiful, the place is surrounded by deer (that come and go freely) and once you get to the top, you can see the whole city. Simple amazing! Don’t miss it!

This temple is probably one of my most favorite temples in Japan. Even when compared to Todaiji. Take for instance, the fact that you can see the entire city of Nara from this place and it's free admission. It's a beautiful temple, designed like kind of an eyrie on the side of a

We walked slightly away from Todaiji to this lovely shrine. There are several pathways leading to this shrine located slightly above a hill. So, one has to walk up a bit of stairs to reach this place or walk up a slope along the side of the field to reach it. One can have a
A nice temple with a view of the surroundings from the large wooden balcony. Less crowded than some. Worth the walk up.

We came here at the suggestion of our taxi driver, and it was so worth it! We were in Nara from Kyoto to look at the deer park. After many days of hiking/touristing, our feet were really sore, so we decided to take a taxi-- it's up hill from the train station to the park. Our
Beautiful temple on the hill providing visitors with an amazing view over the city. The dark woods, large veranda and suspended lanterns make this temple a nice to visit.
Nigatsudo is a part of Todaiji. Take a back corridor from the Buddha Hall. It's a very nice path to take. Great view of Nara from the top level of Nigatsudo.

While utterly beautiful, Todai-ji Temple is populated beyond belief, but Nigatsu-do is an opportunity to experience a more tranquil temple viewing in Nara. Up some stairs and a little tricky to find the route from Todai-ji, you will be graced with a stunning piece of

To visit this temple you really need to know which way to reach it. When exiting the Todaiji Temple just head left through a large vermilion colored torii gate along the edge of the park and take the left fork in the road. You will arrive at a number of interesting old wooden
I came across this temple after passing through the Nandaimon Gate of Tōdaiji. There is a flight of stairs which lead you up to the temple. You would have quite a nice view from the temple.

As I approached the temple, I felt like I was in a movie. It's built into/on the side of a high hill and quite inspiring. It did convey a sense of spirituality and peace. Much less tourist than the other busy temples like Todai Ji. Perhaps that's what gave it that lovely

I love this temple which is located on a hill. Ni-gatsu means "second-month" or February in Japanese. It's not too far from Todai-ji. When you arrive you climb around 70 steps to get to the top where the Hall is located. From the balcony you can see a panoramic view of Nara
Such a beautiful temple to visit at night. It feels quite magical/mysterious compared to the other nearby and more famous temples.
From the veranda, you can see beautiful town and sunset. The place is a little away from the Nara station but it is worth to visit. 東大寺からさらに歩く必要がありますが、その価値ありの境内からの長めです。平和を感じられて大好きな場所です！

This temple is deep inside the park therefore making it very quiet and calm since most tourists don't make it that far into the park. The view from the top is very nice during the morning, but can be very hot and blinding during the afternoon so bring sunglasses.

As you walk around the park , not far from the main temple and museum is a path way leading up from the lake through the trees and takes you to an area with more temples/shrines. this temple The Nigatsu-do is a large complex and has some really old statues and there are some

A much quieter stop as compared to Todai-ji. This temple is not huge but nice and peaceful, the view at the top is breathtaking. I did the following half- to one-day itinerary: Nara Station --> Take the yellow bus to Todai-ji Temple --> Walk to Nigatsu-do (have some ramen in a
You have a take a deeper walk from the Nara park to go into this temple. Rich culture and history. There is a shop selling green tea ice cream - nice

One of my best memories from the wonderful city of Nara! The outer galleries decorated with lanterns offer superb views. Besides, nearby there is a charming wooden rest hall where you can have free hot green tea while contemplating Buddhist paintings or chatting with other
The view of Daibutuden complex of Todaiji temple is very nice. Ａ wooden stair corridor to and from Nigatudo and view of the Nara city is fabulous.
Nice temple area with a nice few overlooking the park area and lots of details at this nice temple, Just lovely!
Nice view of Nara from the top of the temple and entrance is free which is nice. Go on up and bang the bell!!

This is behind the main hall of Todaiji where the big buddha sits. It is really much quieter than the main hall as most people visit Todaiji just to see the big buddha. In my opinion, this is also worth taking a look.
To be fair my review is a bit biased since I was here for the fire festival but it was cool and fun. I am not sure I would do it again but definitely a fun experience.

Todaiji was very crowded the day I visited, but Nigatsudo hall was still rather peaceful. I imagine it would be amazing at dusk. There was some minor construction taking place on the grounds when I visited in February 2017 which I found a little annoying. Definately worth a

Nice temple that not many tourists would walk all the way up. Not far but wondering really why? Peaceful surely. Nice resting point with self-service tea too. Just need to wash up afterwards. Love it.
This building was situated neatly behind the Main Hall and since most people leave after seeing the Big Buddha, you'll have it all to yourself. Great photo opportunities! Don't miss it!

Walk up the temple, you will get a nice view to the city. The place is clean with deer walking about. You can touch and feed them. Unique experience; especially when you have kids with you. They will enjoy it.

The walk up to this temple is half the fun. Many ways to get to the top. Climbing all the way up the stairs to the balcony of the main building gives a nice view of the city. All of it is very atmospheric and well worth the hike. No admission is charged. One can then proceed on

we found free parking just around the corner of the temple hall (although it's located near Nara Park and belongs to Todai-ji). The admission is free. Something different to other buildings are the stone steles. The hall is up on a hill and you have a great view over Nara from
I'm surprised it's #6 in Nara, the view is average, the temple is ordinary, 50m before there are stunning statues inside Hokke-dō temple, must see!

Nigatsudo is 5 minutes' hike from Todaiji but worth the detour. I'd even argue it's better than Todaiji. While not as high and impressive Nigatsudo has something of Kyoto Kyomizudera; built half on stilts you have a panorama. From the exit of Todaiji, follow the steps up past

Got the pleasure to visit this famous Hall at night! It was through a special tour with the Nara Park Hotel! It is cool since no one was around, the quiet ambiance and history it represented was awesome! One of the highlights of my trip!

Nigatsu-do and Sangatsu-do temples are a bit of an uphill walk from Todai-ji Temple. They are attractive, but modest compared to other temples on the park grounds (and in Japan generally). They are worth a visit but if you're tired, hot and cranky, your energy might be better

Just a short walk after Todaiji temple to here. Passed by the Great bell to reach here on a slight slope hill. When you reached here, you would forget about your fatigue as the place is so calm, serene & beautiful. Its a different structure from temple as there are a lot of
Nagatsu-do, which is a part of Todaiji temple, is well known for its Omizutori ceremony. From the platform, like that of Kiyomizudera in Kyoto, you can enjoy a nice view.

If you come the Nara park make sure you take the effort to come here. The views are stunning the building is pretty and not to many people around. Peace in an area where there are lots of things happening, could have just sat and watched the day go by.

Even though this might not be the most popular place to visit in a park that is full of amazing places, it's a great, contemplative spot to sit and watch the sun go down. Just to the left of the Daibutsu hall (when you stand in its steps), it's a great spot to decompress as the
After visiting Todaiji, we walked uphill to Nigatsu-do. The temple is impressive and the views are beautiful. It I was a quick and nice visit.

Made our way all the way there so we felt like we had to visit. It was expensive and we didn't stay long. The nearby Toshodaiji Temple is a much better visit.

I am only putting 4 stars because one of the towers was under renovation and completely covered which took away some of the splendor of this temple.

The temple site is a bit of a ride from the train station in Nara but well worth the time and effort. We visited in June 2018 and although some of it was covered for restoration the overall experience was excellent. As you go through the site it peals back like a picture book.

Very impressive and worth the visit all the way just to see this. On par with Taj Mahal in terms of majesty

I followed the advice in Alan Booth's 'Collins Illustrated Guide to Japan' and found it sound. You can then walk to Toshodaiji temple. Both temples are quiet and peaceful unlike the more famous Todaiji temple where one is assaulted by the crowds and too many deer.

things to view are seperated in east, south, north and west. but still management as the places around is not that big. there is a huge renovation works going on. pls check the time table before you go

text.quote: This replica of a traditional merchant townhouse with wooden lattice exterior includes a gift shop.
trip: It's a free attraction, and fascinating to see how homes were once constructed--the literature was very helpful. We were actually walking between Harushika Brewery and Gango-Ji Temple in Naramachi when we came across this home. If you combine it with other temples in this

Wonderful old temple at Gangoji on the Yamanobe no Michi trail. They serve somen noodles here. And there are two poetry monuments, both of which are profiled in "Precious Stones," a delightful book about the old trail and its poetry monuments. Highly recommended.

We stumbled upon this delightful house and enjoyed wandering through. It was a little insight into the traditional housing and courtyard garden. A lovely woman welcomed us in and offered an English description of the house as we left she gave us an origami “gift”- so sweet.
We stumbled upon this while exploring the old town area.This was free and is self-guided. It's beautiful and simple.
I stumbled upon this while looking for some temples and shrines. This remained open when some of the temples and shrines were closed. This was free and is self-guided. It's beautiful and simple.

This was a bit difficult to find but if you are seeing Gangoji Temple, you are very close. The neighborhood has narrow, winding streets and old, traditional houses and shops. People were very friendly and helpful in our search. Admission is free. Very enlightening. It is

This is a must see if you want to experience Japanese culture. It's a traditional Japanese house and see how people would have lived back in the days. It's also free entry, when we walked in there was a lovely lady who introduced us to the house and when we let she gave us each
An opportunity to walk through a restored traditional house, to get a sense of how life & living was structured in Nara-machi. Peaceful, well organised, practical, beautiful living.

This beautiful and well preserved traditional house, located in the peaceful Nara-Machi area is well worth a visit. I particularly liked the little courtyard/garden in the middle of the building. Such great use of space here.

A lovely traditional house to visit. Gives visitors an insight into the traditional house and lives of the Japanese. It is free. Definitely a must-visit. Does not require much time, but do drop by for some photo-taking. The lady looking after the place even showed us how to

This little museum demonstrates what a traditional machi-ya in Nara would look like. Visited on a rainy day and there was only me inside. The only staff (receptionist) gave me tour inside the house and demonstrated how to operate a traditional Japanese front door. Free admission.

The attraction is free. You an walk through this traditional Japanese house, with a lovely interior garden, a nook like loft and all the different features to a Japanese home. We had two 10-year old girls and they enjoyed exploring all the nooks. You should make this the

This very old house in Naramachi is worth seeking out as it is simply gorgeous. Beautifully restored to allow you to see how a rich person lived in this area. Not easy to find but if you are wandering around the area you will stumble across it. The courtyard garden is to die for
We had a difficulty locating the house. it was a pretty sight though and interesting to understand the architecture in the olden days.

We chanced upon this while walking around Naramachi and end up spending about 45 mins going through each corner of the Machiya. The staff-in-attendance was very helpful and explains a lot of the details of the house to us, and demonstrating the use of some of the kitchen

This place is quite hard to spot, we got lost around Nara machi before reaching here. There nothing much to see here, it's just a very traditional Japanese house and has a really beautiful zen garden.

I had some trouble finding this place. Also keep in mind that this place closed around 5, and it's not very easy to get here if you are coming back from the main park. I came here after visiting todaji and the rest of the Nara park so it was a very long walk. This place is
If you are wandering round Nara then put this on your itinerary. Run by the city council and with free entrance it shows you a traditional urban townhouse and is open 9 to 5 but closed on Mondays.

This is a well preserved old house in old Nara. It is very beautiful and shows you how the urban class in medieval Japan used to live. Very small but functional rooms. Free of charge and quite near the train station. A must visit for architecture or anthropology buffs.

Lovely house filled with history, it truly takes you back in the samurai time...the surroundings are also great to visit...lots of traditional crafts, Tea brewery, Japanese antiquity..etc I would highly recommend this place, it's a short walk from the station...A must do!!

From most of the other reviews I have seen they are describing the city of Nara itself, and not specifically the "old city" Naramachi which is located 5km to the south about 10min walk from koriyama station (the next JR line from Nara station). Here is the location of Koriyama

The old city of Nara, Nara michi is a wonderful stroll any time of day. Early in the morning it is so quiet and still. In the later part of the day, wonderful little shops are open. Most of the buildings are very old low slung wooden slatted. Some really nice renovations and

Bandung in Japan? that was i fell when i was visiting this city. Bandung is a little city in West Java, Indonesia. Similar nuance with Bandung, Nara is small and traditional yet beautiful city. You might go around on foot.

This house used to be a merchant house and has been conserved in a pristine condition. Admission is free and you can take your time to look around the traditional layout with authentic furnishings. There is even a beautiful zen garden at the back of the house with a small water

From Kintetsu nara station it took 1o min walk,short distance . a district is called naramachi that a taxi driver advise us to go around. a hot day hiding ourselves under shadows we took around the district where we could traditional clothing ,papers,hemp products,

I spent one day in Nara from Osaka. I found this city really charming and unique for the deers you can find all around the city. They are quite quiet and domesticated. I did a route around Nara, visiting several Temples and everything was on foot, immersing in the most
Liked all here, buildings, historical perspective, deer roaming free everywhere, climate that day, lunch, all!

We loved our day in Nara. The city is beautiful, green and leafy and nestled in the mountains. We were delighted to discover that the tourist information agency offers free English speaking student guides to escort us around Nara. We had a lovely young woman show is all the

Even though Nara is a compact city, as opposed to Kyoto. Taking time, as we did, is an added bonus to capture the essence of this city. My husband and I spent a week in Nara and enjoyed every bit of it. Sure, one can do a superficial tour of this ancient city. However, it is in

This is a beautiful city an hour away from Kyoto by train. It is naturistic, full of temples and full of bambis (deers). Definately worth a visit if you are in this side of the country. Half a day is good for this place.

Nara is a great place to explore from Osaka with a easy JR ride from Namba station .. Lots of temples and the famous indoor buddha and dear park .. Been twice and enjoyed both times very much nice Japanese foods as well Well worth visiting it whilst in Kansai

My wife and I visited old Nara, the ancient capital of Japan, in October 2013 on a day trip from Kyoto. We travelled by Japan Rail local train from Kyoto station (a trip of only around 45 minutes), which was free as we had JR Rail Passes. This is a quaint area of heritage timber

Naramachi, who mean Nara Town, is the former merchant district just south-ouest of Nara Park, you can see some well preserved traditional residential buildings and warehouses. Boutiques, shops, cafes....etc with nice coton curtains in the open door. Many of those buildings were

with our original plan, just saw the sign while walking sanjodori st, checked on the map, only a short detour, so paid a visit, surprise, only walked about 5 min, felt back into past. most of visitors make a day trip from kyoto or osaka to nara, but we will make sure have a

Yes, Nara is unique and definitely worth spending more than a day. I only managed to spend two nights here. I wish I could spare more time. There is direct airport bus from Nara to Osaka Airport. So, you could make it your last stop before departing from Osaka Airport. The deer
It's fun to walk through these old streets and see the old houses and the ones people have renovated into beautiful modern homes. The area is dotted with small, peaceful and pretty little temples.

Visit to the lattice house is free and at the counter you can get an English brochure describing the place. There are two floors and it even has it's own little private garden in the center. You get to see what houses look like back then. A tatami room with a brazier for boiling

We visited Nara just for a day from Osaka, but after the excellent Nara-Machi walking tour, would like to stay overnight on our next visit. Nara-Machi is a warren full of intriguing, ancient shops and houses. It's also dotted with places specialising in tofu cuisine, soba and

My husband and I didn't have nearly enough time in Nara. For a city, albeit it small it maintains a lovely neighborhood feel. A fellow traveler in Koyasan told us it's a big deer park, I couldn't help but roll my eyes and think oh no let's hope it is more. It is and delightfully

Most guidebooks recommend a day or two in Nara. What a mistake that is! The first time I went was on a bus tour from Kyoto -- and I enjoyed it very much, I could see that it was a beautiful and olld fashioned town from the tile roofs and the wood houses and the beautiful

My extended family visited Naramachi as part of our day trip to Nara (from Osaka). We had spent the morning at Nara Park, had lunch and walked to Naramachi. It was an interesting area with lots of old traditional houses. In particular, we visited Koshi-no-ie Residence
This city is look memorable to me because of simple and it has a sense of ancient history of buddha start here, in Japan.

This is a historic home (or a reconstruction of one) in the Naramachi district of Nara. A guide book convinced us to take a stroll through Naramachi, which we did after visiting the main temples in Nara Park. (We were going to use this house as the southernmost point of our

text.quote: Covered shopping arcade featuring casual eateries & retailers for souvenirs, clothing & housewares.
trip: The shopping street downtown would be a "must see" tourist spot for visitors. There were roll of souvenir shops and restaurants where you could stroll around or take a rest after touring the tourist spots in Nara. By the way, this shopping street was all covered and suitable
Higashimuki Shopping Street was an interesting covered stret near the Nara Park and adjacent to the Kitetsu Nara Station that has a number of restaurants and souvenir shops and worth a visit.

The feel of Higashimuki on compariason to Mochiidono is quite different. It is brighter, busier and the retailers and resuraunts felt more appealing to us, especialy to the Little One. She was getting more opinionated at this point of the trip! We did a quick wander up
A long indoor shopping street with stores and restaurants. A good way to see a lot of little stores and restaurants.

A gallery of shops of various qualities from the really very cheap one to the slightly more quality one. There are also some interesting little restaurants. It is located halfway between the station and the deer park. It's great if you find a rainy day to spend some time

What can I say it's okay nothing special. Usual assortment of Japanese souvenirs / shops. I think it is the best in the area. There is a variety of restaurants but again nothing special or extraordinary for Japan. But if you are in Nara, I don't think you have too much of a

This covered shopping street connects the Kintetsu-Nara train station at one end and the Nakatanido (mochi pounding shop) at the other end. There are plenty of souvenir shops, fruit/veg stands, restaurants on this main shopping street. You can also buy some persimmon leaf

This street is another shopping street as others say however the key is that it links undercover Kintetsu station to Nakantaidou Mochi maker on Sanjo dori and the 3 story pagoda. On the other end through a short walk is Nara park. So the street is a great passageway between

We came to this street since the restaurant we wanted to eat at was located here, so before and after filling our bellies we took a look at shops. We particularly liked a shop in which everything cost 100 yen, we spent a lot of time there and bought several gifts. As mentioned,

What I'm quickly learning whilst on my trip to Japan that these types of streets seem to be everywhere. Very narrow full of quirky restaurants and shops. I just find all the bits on offer interesting.
This is one of the main shopping street in older part of Nara. There are lots of shops and restaurants on this street right off Kintetsu Nara Station.
It’s undercover, busy with people and stacked with shops and restaurants. A good place to hang around on a rainy day.
There are many shops and restaurants on the Higashimuki Shopping Street. With the added bonus of being very close to the train station, temples and the Deer Park

I entered this arcade shopping street by taking a small lane down from the Kofuku-ji Temple. The street is like so many others that can be found all over Japan with some nice looking restaurants, souvenir shops, cafes and general stores as well as street food stores. The street

A covered arcade in Nara, which is well worth the visit. There's a Daiso hundred yen shop here that is jam packed with bargains you never knew you needed. Good place for rice paper and origami paper, etc.
You will probably pass by this place either before or after you visited the Nara park. It is a long stretch of shops and restaurants where I took a walk and had my lunch after my visit to Nara park.
If you pass in Nara it's impossible to not see this street. It's a commercial street like many other with shops and restaurants... nothing special.
More unique shop[s and restaurants. Mochi making shop with fresh mochis was pretty amazing. Not as large as other cities which is exactly why we liked it.

The shopping street was not included in our itinerary that day. All of us were focused on the sites inside Nara park. The deer, gardens, temples, museums and everything else. It's only on the way back to the train station that we received a message to go and taste a mochi place
We saw some roof covered shopping streets in Japan but this was the one we liked most. Lots of different little shops and restaurants where you can easily spend one or two hours when you visit Nara.

This covered shopping arcade close to Nara Park. You can find all kinds of arts and craft shops, stores selling clothes and accessories both modern and traditional, and souvenir shops selling tea, rice crackers, stuffed deer toys, and traditional confectionery. Many of the shops

Great place to get your souvenirs. It is very busy and a huge mix of people. Here you can get the more traditional Japanese gifts rather than tat. Can get very warm on a nice day as the streets very narrow.
Covered shopping area good for rainy days. Found some nice souvenir shops and there is Daiso on this street, where everything is 108 yen and not of bad quality either.
We searched for a meal place and a shopping, but we could not find any attractive shops other than that of 'Nara-pickles'.
The covered shopping street is near to the JR Station. There are many souvenir shops and restaurants there to facilitate visitors while traveling in Nara. Recommended.
Great for Pokemon Raids when the wife is shopping. A lot of food, gadgets, drinks and just great to walk when it is bad weather
Good street to enjoy less crowds and find a decent restaurant under some cover. Less shops but definitely worth popping into for lunch or dinner especially if it is raining.
very convenience place just next to the station. many attractions there for shopping and eating. i try the fresh made tempura shop there. they made the tempura in front of you. good to try

A good place to wander and browse local shops. You will find everything you need here, from food and drink to tourist gifts. This is a good place to visit when you need a change from Nara's historic parks, to escape the hot sun or the rain!
Small shopping street, less crowded and not touristy compared to places like Shinsaibashi. Eateries and shop selling snaks, souvenirs, dried sea food can be found here.
Hubby and I fully enjoyed walking the streets of Nara, especially this market place. Let your nose follow the trail to yummy baked goods or lunch time restaurants.

Go for the restaurants that don't advertise in English for the best experience! Also in late afternoon/evening the streets are very calm with mostly locals and no huge tourist crowds! They also play Attack on Titan theme music on the intercoms which our group found hilarious and

I walked past this Higashimuki Shopping Street for a number of occasions. I came from Osaka, alighted at Kintetsu Nara metro station and decided to safe keep my luggage bags first at our hostel before touring Nara Park. I told my wife to hang around the Daisho shop while I

This is the street right next to the Kintetsu Nara Station. Full of restaurants and shops, it is a shopaholic haven. There are a number of souvenirs specific for the Nara area which we highly recommend (deer themed presents, sweets and kit kats for that area). Higashimuki
The street was right beside the Nara Station. I visited this street before get the train to find some souvenirs. There were also some restaurants, pharmacies, hotels and convenience stores.

A great place to stroll around, lots of shops and restaurants so a good place to eat at reasonable prices. Located next to the railway station so very convenient if arriving by train, and close to a number of good tourist sites including Nara Deer Park and Todaiji temple -
lots of see when walking through this arcade - plenty of café/restaurants and shopping not to mention people watching while having a coffee!!

This street is literally outside Kintetsunara station so you really couldn't miss it. Limited dining options and if we weren't starving, we would have probably skip it. Surprisingly, we found an affordable small restaurant which serves surprisingly yummy omu rice. The best part

This short shopping street is just next to the Nara station & provides tourists with a decent place for dining options & some shopping. There aren't very much dining options though ,but at the other end of this street - there are other dining options on the main road.

This is a little walking side street covered by a glass canopy and featuring numerous shops and restaurants. It was a break from the sun for us on our way back to the JR Station from the deer park and a chance to get something to eat. It's nothing to compare to Namba in Osaka,
Mostly touristy shortcut through town that is covered so good on a rainy or hot day. LGK Craft good place for beer tasting and Trattoria Piano good for cappuchino and panna cotta.

The shopping street should either be your first stop to Nara Park or vice versa your last stop after sightseeing all tourist spots in Nara. There were many restaurants and souvenir shops where you could purchase your gifts back home. By the way, there was a shop named Daiso

Nothing special bout this shopping street, especially the first part. The restaurants are too expensive for what they offer, and the shops do not offer great stuff. The southern part is a little bit more original...
Popped through these shops in the early evening with a map form Oak Hostel Nara. Found a fab place to eat homemade Udon noodles and a delicious hot pot. Lots of choices for shopping and eating

We were here on Nov 2016. We came here after visited Nara Park. A very nice shopping street. We can found mini market, restaurants, cafe, souvenir shops,local food stalls, drug store etc. We spent 2 hours here.
many cute shops with friendly staff. traditional and modern gifts and kick knacks. perfect to pick up some items for memories of Nara/Japan

Found this shopping street on the way back from Todaiji temple to JR Nara station. Nice shopping street, a lot of food, drug stores and souvenir shops. Finally I found the deer doll made in Japan at this area. Most of the souvenirs at Todaiji temple are made in China 😂 There

Plenty of small places to shop or eat at for this style of mall. We ate at a sushi restaurant near the entrance where the dishes float on a boat. And had coffee and green tea dessert at a cafe as well. Worth popping in.

My son wanted to go a bow to the deers in Nara Park as he had seen it on the net, but there is so much more to experience. The tourists nature of the main shopping roads is different from Namba and Osaka city. We also went to see the toy museum an excellent hands on and free!

Similar to other cities of Japan, Higashimuki Shopping Street is a covered shopping avenue that provides shopping and eating opportunities for tourists after long visits to the nearby sightseeing spots. The place is particularly useful during rainy or cold days. Worth to visit

This place one of the must sees in Nara. Its not nearly as big and diverse in its offering as the ones in the Gion area of Kyoto, but its a great place to find your special type of eatery, under cover from cold, wind rain or heat.
If you haven't been to Tokyo or Kyoto or Osaka, you might find this street interesting and worth your while. But it's second rate all the way and only useful to get out of the rain.
You can find plenty of stores for shopping and eating in this shopping street. The shopping area is covered with cute overhead and decorations. Great place for mingling with the locals.
If you are in Nara this shopping street is worth the walk. Our kids enjoyed it too. Lots of local goods.
After visiting the park we sampled the shops. Straightforward tourist fare in the first block, but go farther south to get to the more authentic local shops.

This shopping alley cuts across Sanjadori street in the center of town and stretches some 200 meters in both directions – the walkway is covered so not affected by rain – lots of shopping (with some bargains) and dotted with plenty of restaurants and drinking spots – – worth a
It is just a shopping arcade and nothing else. But if you have enough time, you can also take a look.

The Higashimuki Shopping Street in Nara is very nice. Quite small in comparaison of other shopping street of Japan such as Kyoto or Osaka, but in a way it's good because we find products easier to find and it's less crowded. It's clean as always in Japan. You will find many

Restaurants (Tonkatsu, Kakinoha, Soba, Udon, and seafood; including Italian), Fast-food Chains (McDonalds), Tea and Accessories, Souvenirs, Wholesale Candy shops, clothing and more. Recommended as a first or last stop during your trip to Nara, it will take some time to visit all
We enjoyed this market street area. There seemed to be products for sale that were just a little different o those we'd seen elsewhere and it was less crowded than at Kyoto.

We almost didn't make it to the main deer park/temple area because we had to walk down this street to get there! Where do I begin? Hand made glass figures, stonework, items made from deer antler, woodwork (some very intricately detailed), dinnerware, cutlery, fine fabrics. Ohh,

Passed through here in the evening while having a look around our hotel. Spent only maybe 35mins walking through the whole thing. Bought some kiwi fruit from a lovely lady who threw in some apples with the deal because we were students!

My boyfriend and I passed through here on our way to Deer Park and Todaiji Temple. We rented bikes at the Nara train station and what should've taken 15 mins to ride over to the park, took us well over two hours because we took a detour through this shopping area. It feels
Very close to Nara station. Tablo socks can be found here with Nada famous preserved food. Tradition Japanese souvenir and close to the park with a small lake. Casual walk in Mara.

Beautiful covered street full of souvenir shops, confectionery shops, boutiques etc. Everything Japanese. Can be found outside Kintetsu Nara Station when you exit on the right just past Gyoki Bosatsu Square fountain. Spent an hour of happy shopping/browsing.

The end closer to the kintetsu station is more for tourists. As you walk towards along away from the station, there are more interesting boutiques range from leather goods, clothing, arts and crafts restaurants where you will find more locals :) I can spend hours there!

Covered shopping arcade with loads of restaurants and souvenir shops; shops for locals too including clothing stores, pharmacy, convenience store and, of course, a 100 yen store. We walked through very early in the morning, before most of the stores were open in order to get to

This seems to be the main food street in Nara. However, we hired a guide from Narawalk which brought us to the smaller side streets and interesting local places to visit. Both for shopping and for local food.
google:
Food, clothes, music, books, deers, there's everything you may want in this shopping street. It's not as long as Kobe's shopping street, but it's just as enjoyable.
If you are on your way to the Nara Park feel free to have a walk in there, it's pretty nice even if you don't buy anything.
Various shops and restaurants along the walkway. You can't get tired🤭
Lots of great shops and restaurants. Unique items as well as gifts for every price range.
Make sure thatvyou visit the fresh made mochi and sembe shop at the end ofvghe arcade it is the best i have eaten in the 25 years that i have lived in Japan

Nice place to go shopping and eat. Buy some strawberries in a fruit shop there and it was super nice and sweet. Many other foods too. And also, many souvenir, especially deer keychain or doll, since Nara is famous for its deer. Super nice place.
It's convenient.  Right be train station. Covered top shipping street.
Lovely place that is lively in the evening/night as well!

Cool area for tourists. Has some souvenir shops and mostly foods and snack. It is walking distance from train station. We took train from Kyoto and paid 640 Yen per person . It took 48 minutes to reach to this beautiful town. Market is a …

Shopping street with a lot of shops selling a variety of things. It's a nice last stop after visiting Nara Park. Everything here is quite obviously touristy and also expensive though. It was, like most famous spots here, extremely crowded. Nice respite from the weather though.

Absolutely love it.. Gd choices of restaurants, fruits but dont expect too much of shopping.. Probably about half the size of kuromon Market. One thing that stood out for me is the feeling of being transported back in time.
Incredible shopping area, get the cheese cake if you want a treat.
Simple shopping street you'll never get lost. Has sufficient of stores that will definitely help carve the shopping appetite.
Nice place but many closed places when we visited.
Big shopping mall, good all-round stores and lots of places to eat!
Do get the persimmon there if u can. Its sweet and fresh ñ crunchy
Shop a number of items here. Cheaper than Kyoto and Osaka in general. But close early as 7pm on Saturday have less than 50 percent of shop still open.
Crowded shopping street and lead straight to the most famous Mochi making shop in Nakanidou
Excellent place for kitchen ware shopping. Many things to see.
Clean and good food
Lots to see and shop. Good location for tourists.
Out door shopping for street foods in Osaka.
Great place as always - check the side alleys and second floor levels for sneaky food and souvenir shops that are both tasty and of better value than the main strip
Many dining choices but expect waiting time.
This is a very likely street with a lot of shops and attractions. Great for touring
Fun some relief here from the heat and humidity. Lovely presented shops and great restaurants.
The place has alot of stuff to buy and good to eat. Unfortunately Almost half the shops were closed when we visit (around 5pm)
So many shops here. Good place to find food and shop. Might get very crowded on a weekend
Good place for eat
Lots of good food, must try the tempura place
Only had lunch here in Il Paris. Lovely roce bown with steak, etc and a drink. All reasonably priced by Japanese standards. Staff very friendly and helpful with limited English
Such a variety of shops. Wide spaces and it is also covered! Watch out for the traffic lights as it is a partial shared space with traffic.
The food is nice and price not expensive
Cool shopping place in Nara. Busy with shoppers and tourists.
Love this beautiful  town,full of good finds vety peaceful place ,nice environment,picturesque sceneries,definitely will come back again
A short walk after visiting the dear park.. wasnt too bad
Very interesting variety of shops and food outlets
Nice place for walking around
I miss this place, a lot of stuff to see, exciting stuff hahaha
Great place to visit. Numerous shops and plenty restaurants.
A Must eat Tendon in Nara
Great place for a bite and shopping.
Nice place for all your shopping!
You can buy second hand books here. Quite a number of shops.

This street is filled with restaurant that can cater to every of your taste
Most of the restaurants located here are crowded because of it's proximity with Nara park
Lots of tourist

This is a small shopping mall as you come out from Nara Station, to your right. 
There is a fountain in front of it. 
It is not busy and most people come here after visiting Nara Park. 
There is a large Daiso (100 yen shop) with varieties of goods. 
There are also many food outlets.
Some nice restaurants and shops. If you are in Nara, it's worth a wander.
Lots of nice shops and restaurants!
Must try mochi
Not so big shopping street but many restaurants and shops. You can find souvenirs for your family.
Ok. very crowdy
The shopping here is nice but the food is better! If you’re looking for something special to buy for friends and loved ones, this is not the place.
little bit cold here than osaka
So cool
Basic necessities, variety of food available
Nice area for dining
Very good.
good price and good food

It's a wonderland of food and shopping.
