text.wiki:
Nara (奈良市, Nara-shi, Japanese: [naꜜɾa]) is the capital city of Nara Prefecture, Japan. 
As of 1 April 2019, Nara has an estimated population of 359,666, making it the largest city in Nara Prefecture and sixth-largest in the Kansai region of Honshu. Nara is a core city located in the northern part of Nara Prefecture bordering the Kyoto Prefecture. 
Nara was the capital of Japan during the Nara period from 710 to 794 as the seat of the Emperor before the capital was moved to Kyoto. Nara is home to eight temples, shrines, and ruins, specifically Tōdai-ji, Saidai-ji, Kōfuku-ji, Kasuga Shrine, Gangō-ji, Yakushi-ji, Tōshōdai-ji, and the Heijō Palace, together with Kasugayama Primeval Forest, collectively form the Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 


== Etymology ==
By the Heian period, a variety of different characters had been used to represent the name Nara: 乃楽, 乃羅, 平, 平城, 名良, 奈良, 奈羅, 常, 那良, 那楽, 那羅, 楢, 諾良, 諾楽, 寧, 寧楽 and 儺羅.
A number of theories for the origin of the name "Nara" have been proposed, and some of the better-known ones are listed here. The second theory in the list, from the notable folklorist Kunio Yanagita (1875-1962), is most widely accepted at present.

The Nihon Shoki (The Chronicles of Japan, the second oldest book of classical Japanese history) suggests that "Nara" was derived from narasu (to flatten, to level). According to this account, in September in the tenth year of Emperor Sujin, "leading selected soldiers (the rebels) went forward, climbed Nara-yama (hills lying to the north of Heijō-kyō) and put them in order. Now the imperial forces gathered and flattened trees and plants. Therefore the mountain is called Nara-yama." Though the narrative itself is regarded as a folk etymology and few researchers regard it as historical, this is the oldest surviving suggestion, and is linguistically similar to the following theory by Yanagita.
"Flat land" theory (currently most widely accepted): In his 1936 study of placenames, the author Kunio Yanagita states that "the topographical feature of an area of relatively gentle gradient on the side of a mountain, which is called taira in eastern Japan and hae in the south of Kyushu, is called naru in the Chūgoku region and Shikoku (central Japan). This word gives rise to the verb narasu, adverb narashi, and adjective narushi." This is supported by entries in a dialect dictionary for nouns referring to flat areas: naru (found in Aida District, Okayama Prefecture and Ketaka District, Tottori Prefecture) and naro (found in Kōchi Prefecture); and also by an adjective narui which is not standard Japanese, but is found all across central Japan, with meanings of "gentle", "gently sloping", or "easy". Yanagita further comments that the way in which the fact that so many of these placenames are written using the character 平 ("flat"), or other characters in which it is an element, demonstrates the validity of this theory. Citing a 1795 document, Inaba-shi (因幡志) from the province of Inaba, the eastern part of modern Tottori, as indicating the reading naruji for the word 平地 (standard reading heichi, meaning "level/flat ground/land/country, a plain"), Yanagita suggests that naruji would have been used as a common noun there until the modern period. Of course, the fact that historically "Nara" was also written 平 or 平城 as above is further support for this theory.
The idea that Nara is derived from 楢 nara (Japanese for "oak, deciduous Quercus spp.") is the next most common opinion. This idea was suggested by a linguist, Yoshida Togo. This noun for the plant can be seen as early as in Man'yōshū (7-8th century) and Harima-no-kuni Fudoki (715). The latter book states the place name Narahara in Harima (around present-day Kasai)　derives from this nara tree, which might support Yoshida's theory. Note that the name of the nearby city of Kashihara (literally "live oak plain") contains a semantically similar morpheme (Japanese 橿 kashi "live oak, evergreen Quercus spp.").
Nara could be a loan word from Korean nara (나라 : country, nation, kingdom). This idea was put forward by a linguist Matsuoka Shizuo. Not much about the Old Korean language is known today, and the first written attestation of a word ancestral to Modern Korean nara is as late as the 15th century, such as in Yongbieocheonga (1447),  Wolinseokbo (月印釋譜. 1459), or Beophwagyeongeonhae (法華經諺解. 1463), and there is no evidence that proves the word already existed as far back as the 7th century. These 15th-century books used narah (나랗), an old form of nara in Korean, and its older form might be reconstructed *narak. American  linguist Christopher I. Beckwith infers the Korean narak derives from the late Middle Old Chinese 壌 (*nrak, earth), from early *narak, and has no connection with Goguryoic and Japanese na. (See also the next theory.) Kusuhara et al. also points out this hypothesis cannot account for the fact there are many places named Nara, Naru and Naro besides this Nara.
There is the idea that Nara is akin to Tungusic na. In some Tungusic languages such as Orok (and likely Goguryeo language), na means earth, land or the like. Some have speculated about a connection between these Tungusic words and Old Japanese nawi, an archaic and somewhat obscure word that appears in the verb phrases nawi furu and nawi yoru ('an earthquake occurs, to have an earthquake').The "Flat land" theory is adopted by Nihon Kokugo Daijiten (the largest dictionary of Japanese language), various dictionaries for place names, history books on Nara and the like today, and it is regarded as the most likely.


== History ==


=== Pre-Nara/Origins ===
There are a number of kofun in Nara, including Gosashi Kofun, Hishiage Kofun (ヒシアゲ古墳), Horaisan Kofun (宝来山古墳), Konabe Kofun (コナベ古墳), Saki Ishizukayama Kofun (佐紀石塚山古墳), Saki Misasagiyama Kofun (佐紀陵山古墳), and Uwanabe Kofun (ウワナベ古墳).
By decree of an edict on March 11, 708 AD, Empress Genmei ordered the court to relocate to the new capital, Nara. Once known as Heijō or Heijō-kyō, the city was established as Japan's first permanent capital in 710 CE; it was the seat of government until 784 CE, albeit with five year interruption, lasting from 741-5 CE. Heijō, as the ‘penultimate court’, however, was abandoned by the order of Emperor Kammu in 784 CE in favor of the temporary site of Nagaoka, and then Heian-kyō (Kyoto) which retained the status of capital for 1,100 years, until the Meiji Emperor made the final move to Edo in 1869 CE. This first relocation was due to the court's transformation from an imperial nobility to a force of metropolitan elites and new technique of dynastic shedding which had refashioned the relationship between court, nobility, and country. Moreover, the ancient capital lent its name to Nara period.As a reactionary expression to the political centralization of China, the city of Nara (Heijō) was modeled after the Tang capital at Chang’an. Nara was laid out on a grid—which was based upon the Handen system—whereby the city was divided by four great roads. Likewise, according to Chinese cosmology, the ruler's place was fixed like the pole star. By dominating the capital, the ruler brought heaven to earth. Thus, the south facing palace centered at the north, bisected the ancient city, instituting ‘Right Capital’ and ‘Left Capital’ zones. As Nara came to be the epicenter of Buddhist church and drawing pilgrimage site, the city plan incorporated various pre-Heijō and Heijō period temples, of which the Yakushiji and the Todaiji still stand.
Gallery
		


=== Politics ===
A number of scholars have characterized the Nara period as a time of penal and administrative legal order. The Taihō Code called for the establishment of administrative sects underneath the central government, and modeled many of the codes from the Chinese Tang dynasty. The code eventually disbanded, but its contents were largely preserved in the Yōrō Code of 718.Occupants of the throne during the period gradually shifted their focus from military preparation, to religious rites and institutions, in an attempt to strengthen their divine authority over the population.


=== Religion and Temples ===
Nanto RokushūWith the establishment of the new capital, Asuka-dera, the temple of the Soga clan, was relocated within Nara. The Emperor Shōmu ordered the construction of Tōdai-ji Temple (largest wooden building in the world) and the world's largest bronze Buddha statue. The temples of Nara, known collectively as the Nanto Shichi Daiji, remained spiritually significant even beyond the move of the political capital to Heian-kyō in 794, thus giving Nara a synonym of Nanto (南都 "The southern Capital").
On December 2, 724 AD, in order to increase the visual “magnificence” of the city, an edict was ordered by the government for the noblemen and the wealthy to renovate the roofs, pillars, and walls of their homes, although at that time this was unfeasible.Sightseeing in Nara city became popular in the Edo period, during which several visitor's maps of Nara were widely published. During the Meiji Period, the Kofukuji Temple lost some land and its monks were converted into Shinto priests, due to Buddhism being associated with the old shogunate.
Gallery
		
		
		
		
		


=== Modern Nara ===
Even though Nara was the capital of Japan from 710 to 794, it was not designated a city until 1 February, 1898. Nara city has developed from a town of commerce in the Edo and Meiji periods to a modern tourist city, due to its large number of historical temples, landmarks and national monuments. Nara was added to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in December 1998. The architecture of some shops, ryokans and art galleries has been adapted from traditional merchant houses.Nara holds traditional festivals every year, including the Neri-Kuyo Eshiki, a spring festival held in Todaiji temple for over 1,000 years; and the Kemari Festival, in which people wear costumes ranging across 700 years  and play traditional games).In 1909, Tatsuno Kingo designed the Nara Hotel, whose architecture combines  modern elements with traditional Japanese style.


== Geography ==
The city of Nara lies in the northern end of Nara Prefecture, directly bordering Kyoto Prefecture to its north.  The city is 22.22 kilometres (13.81 mi) from North to South, from East to West. As a result of the latest merger, effective April 1, 2005, that combined the villages of Tsuge and Tsukigase with the city of Nara, the city now borders Mie Prefecture directly to its east. The total area is 276.84 square kilometres (106.89 square miles).Nara city, as well as several important settlements (such as Kashihara, Yamatokōriyama, Tenri, Yamatotakada, Sakurai and Goze), are located in the Nara Basin. This makes it the most densely-populated region of Nara Prefecture.The downtown of Nara is on the east side of the ancient Heijō Palace site, occupying the northern part of what was called the Gekyō (外京), literally the outer capital area. Many of the public offices (e.g. the Municipal office, the Nara Prefectural government, the Nara Police headquarters, etc.) are located on Nijō-ōji (二条大路), while Nara branch offices of major nationwide banks are on Sanjō-ōji (三条大路), with both avenues running east–west.
The highest point in the city is at the peak of Kaigahira-yama at an altitude of 822.0 m (2,696.85 ft) (Tsugehayama-cho district), and the lowest is in Ikeda-cho district, with an altitude of 56.4 m (185.04 ft).
Nara Basin
Murō-Akame-Aoyama Quasi-National Park
Yamato-Aogaki Quasi-National Park
Kasugayama Primeval Forest
Sarusawa Pond (猿沢池)
Mount Wakakusa


=== Climate ===
The climate of Nara Prefecture is generally temperate, although there are notable differences between the north-western basin area and the rest of the prefecture which is more mountainous.
The basin area climate has an inland characteristic, as represented in the higher daily temperature variance, and the difference between summer and winter temperatures. Winter temperatures average approximately 3 to 5 °C (37 to 41 °F), and from 25 to 28 °C (77 to 82 °F) in the summer with highest readings reaching close to 35 °C (95 °F). There has not been a single year since 1990 with more than 10 days of snowfall recorded by Nara Local Meteorological Observatory.
The climate in the rest of the prefecture is that of higher elevations especially in the south, with  −5 °C (23 °F) being the extreme minimum in winter. Heavy rainfall is often observed in summer. The annual accumulated rainfall totals as much as 3,000 to 5,000 mm (118.11 to 196.85 in), which is among the heaviest in Japan and indeed in the world outside the equatorial zone.
Spring and fall temperatures are temperate and comfortable. The mountainous region of Yoshino has been long popular for viewing cherry blossoms in the spring. In autumn, the southern mountains are also a popular destination for viewing fall foliage.


== Cityscape ==


== Demographics ==
As of April 1, 2017, the city has an estimated population of 359,666 and a population density of 1,300 persons per km2. There were 160,242 households residing in Nara. The highest concentration of both households and population, respectively about 46,000 and 125,000, is found along the newer bedtown districts, along the Kintetsu line connecting to Osaka.
There were about 3,000 registered foreigners in the city, of which Koreans and Chinese are the two largest groups with about 1,200 and 800 people respectively.

== Deer in Nara ==
According to the legendary history of Kasuga Shrine, the god Takemikazuchi arrived in Nara on a white deer to guard the newly built capital of Heijō-kyō. Since then, the deer have been regarded as heavenly animals, protecting the city and the country.Tame sika deer (also known as spotted deer or Japanese deer) roam through the town, especially in Nara Park. In 2015, there were more than 1,200 sika deer in Nara. Snack vendors sell sika senbei (deer crackers) to visitors so they can feed the deer. Some deer have learned to bow in order to receive senbei from people.
Gallery
		
		
		


== Education ==
As of 2005, there are 16 high schools and 6 universities located in the city of Nara.


=== Universities ===

Nara Women's University is one of only two national women's universities in Japan. Nara Institute of Science and Technology is a graduate research university specializing in biological, information, and materials sciences.


=== Primary and secondary education ===


==== Public schools ====
Public elementary and junior high schools are operated by the city of Nara.
Public high schools are operated by the Nara Prefecture.


==== Private schools ====
Private high schools in Nara include the Tōdaiji Gakuen, a private school founded by the temple in 1926.


== Transportation ==

The main central station of Nara is Kintetsu Nara Station with JR Nara station some 500m west and much closer to Shin-Omiya station.


=== Rail ===

trip: We did a daytrip to Nara. Besides Nara park with lots of deers you can also check this temple with vast gate.

This massive gateway easily transmits its historic message 'don't mess with me' and leads to another, almost as impressive gateway. Lots of wildlife - friendly tourists and agressive deer (one of which ate our map). On the town side of the gate there are plenty of restaurants

The 8 meter high wooden gate at the pathway to Todai-ji Temple was constructed between 1199 -1203. It was very impressive and you would admire the construction method thereat while crossing this gate.

This large wooden gate guards the access towards Todaji Temple. It was built 1199-1203 in Daibutsu style. It has five main column areas and double roof, supported by 18 pillars. The gate is 25 meters tall, making it largest temple gate in Japan.

This impressive wooden gate, the largest entrance to any temple in Japan was built in 1199 and replace the original built in the Nara Period at the time of the construction of the Todaiji Temple. The original was destroyed in a typhoon. It is an impressive wooden structure and a

Nandaimon (Great South Gate) is the main entrance of Todaiji Temple which has a height of more than 8 meters. Made of large, huge wood, this gate has 3 doors of the same size. On the left and right side of this gate are placed two giant statues of Protective God called

The South Gate absolutely towers above you as you approach the sumptuous Todai-ji temple. It is beautiful but also looks very authentic and untouched. The scale of it is amazing and really ought not to be missed.
The vertical pillars consist of one tree each, and are absolutely HUGE. Each one would require 2 long-armed men to encircle it. The trees must have been hundreds of years old.
Yup, it’s a big gate. Walk through this onto your real destination right past it. The gate has some neat sculptures in it, and is worth seeing. You won’t need to stay more than 15 minutes.
And that's about it. I questioned why they would make it so massive in the first place. When you see what lies behind it you will understand.
Passing through this grand gate is probably the best way to make your way to the wonderful Todai-ji Temple.

It is majestic and guarded by mobs of Sika deer wanting their tribute. For me, that was definitely an added interest, just be advised they can be very aggressive. If you want a good experience with deer it is better to wake up early and go to the woods in Nara park where animals
This is a great wooden gate with lots of deer around it. You walk through it on the way to the great Buddha hall. The paint is all chipping off though!
The entrance to Todaji-ji temple is grand with these historical gates and enormous fierce looking statues at guarding them. What an entrance!!!
very picturesque, especially with the cute deers walking around. its a huge wooden structure and best and grand way to walk in to the temple area
This is the best way to approach the temple as it makes for a suitably grand entrance. Lots of deer around too, so pay attention - one head butted me from behind which was a bit of a shock!

The huge Great South Gate together with the statues are located in front of the Todai-ji Temple. It was really impressive and visitors need to pass through the gate prior to access to the main temple.

This is the enormous entrance gate which you have to pass through to access the Todai-ji temple. Constructed out of wood it's an impressive structure and worth a stop to admire it when visiting the temple.

Great South Gate is a large timber gate leading to Todaiji Temple. There are two Guardian Kings on both sides of the gate to guard the area or to protect the visitors. A nice photo-stop for travelers but you need to be aware of the groups of Nara deers chasing for food nearby.

This gate is nice and impressive and leads to the Todaiji Temple from. There are 2 statues one on each side guardinf the gate. You will see them as you enter the gate. There are lots of deers roaming around the area as well.

text.wiki:
Kōriyama Castle (郡山城, Kōriyama-jō) was a Japanese castle in what is now the city of Yamatokōriyama, Nara Prefecture, Japan. The Sengoku daimyō Tsutsui Junkei started construction of the castle, and Toyotomi Hidenaga made it his residence. In the Edo period, it became the headquarters of the Kōriyama Domain. During this time it was held by members of the Mizuno, Okudaira Matsudaira, Honda, Fujii Matsudaira, and Yanagisawa clans.
Today, many walls and moats are preserved in a public park in the city. The Yanagisawa Shrine stands on the grounds. The Castle was listed as one of　the Continued Top 100 Japanese Castles in 2017.


== Photographs ==

		
		
		


== Access ==
The nearest station is Kintetsu-Kōriyama.


== Sources ==
This article incorporates material from the articles 郡山城 (大和国) (Kōriyama-jō (Yamato no Kuni)) and 郡山藩 (Kōriyama-han) in the Japanese Wikipedia, retrieved on May 4, 2008.


== References ==

text.wiki:
Akishino-dera (秋篠寺) is a Buddhist temple in Nara, Japan. Founded in the eighth century, its Kamakura-period Hondō is a National Treasure.


== History ==
The Shoku Nihongi of 797 places the origins of the temple in Hōki 11 (780), while the Legends of Akishino-dera (秋篠寺縁起) of 1139 ascribes it to the vows of Emperor Kōnin and Emperor Kammu and names its founder as Zenjū Daitoku (善珠大徳), younger brother of Emperor Shōmu. The Records of the Kōfuku-ji Kanmu (輿福寺官務牒疏) of 1441 dates its foundation instead to 776. Excavated Nara-period tiles corroborate an eighth-century foundation date. Like other major temples of the period, Akishino-dera had two pagodas, as well as a Kondō. According to the Legends, a fire in June 1135 destroyed most of the temple. Two hundred and fifty-five ofuda, dating from 1327 to 1524, cast light on later years.


== Buildings ==
The five by four bay National Treasure Hondō, with a raised platform, earthen floor, tiled hipped roof, and slightly narrower intercolumniation at each end, epitomises the Wayō style. Built on the site of the former lecture hall, it is a Kamakura-period rebuild in somewhat archaizing style. Inside, a raised altar platform is backed by an internal wall that spans three bays. The Hondō was dismantled for repair and reconstruction in 1899.


== Treasures ==
Statues designated Important Cultural Properties include a Yakushi Triad, Gigeiten (伎芸天) (traditional identification), Taishakuten, and Jizō Bosatsu, in the Hondō; Daigensui Myōō (大元帥明王) in the Daigendō; Bonten, Kudatsu Bosatsu (traditional identification), and hollow dry-lacquer fragments, kept at Nara National Museum; Jizō Bosatsu, kept at Kyoto National Museum; and Jūichimen Kannon, kept at Tokyo National Museum. The dry-lacquer heads of Gigeiten and Bonten, along with the heads of Kudatsu Bosatsu and Taishakuten, date from the Nara period and are joined to bodies of the Kamakura period; the hollow dry-lacquer fragments similarly date from the Nara period, while the images flanking the Yakushi, along with the two Jizō and Jūichimen Kannon, are from the Heian period, Daigensui Myōō is from the Kamakura period, and the Yakushi dates from the Muromachi period. Other treasures include a set of five standing Godariki Bosatsu (五大力菩薩); a waniguchi (鰐口) dating to Shōan 3 (1301) that has been designated a Prefectural Cultural Property; and a painting of Daigensui Myōō dating from the Nanboku-chō period and seven Muromachi-period fragments of ema with images of horses, designated Municipal Cultural Properties.

		
		


== See also ==
List of National Treasures of Japan (temples)
List of National Treasures of Japan (sculptures)
Shichidō garan
For an explanation of terms concerning Japanese Buddhism, Japanese Buddhist art, and Japanese Buddhist temple architecture, see the Glossary of Japanese Buddhism.


== References ==

text.wiki:
Nara (奈良市, Nara-shi, Japanese: [naꜜɾa]) is the capital city of Nara Prefecture, Japan. 
As of 1 April 2019, Nara has an estimated population of 359,666, making it the largest city in Nara Prefecture and sixth-largest in the Kansai region of Honshu. Nara is a core city located in the northern part of Nara Prefecture bordering the Kyoto Prefecture. 
Nara was the capital of Japan during the Nara period from 710 to 794 as the seat of the Emperor before the capital was moved to Kyoto. Nara is home to eight temples, shrines, and ruins, specifically Tōdai-ji, Saidai-ji, Kōfuku-ji, Kasuga Shrine, Gangō-ji, Yakushi-ji, Tōshōdai-ji, and the Heijō Palace, together with Kasugayama Primeval Forest, collectively form the Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 


== Etymology ==
By the Heian period, a variety of different characters had been used to represent the name Nara: 乃楽, 乃羅, 平, 平城, 名良, 奈良, 奈羅, 常, 那良, 那楽, 那羅, 楢, 諾良, 諾楽, 寧, 寧楽 and 儺羅.
A number of theories for the origin of the name "Nara" have been proposed, and some of the better-known ones are listed here. The second theory in the list, from the notable folklorist Kunio Yanagita (1875-1962), is most widely accepted at present.

The Nihon Shoki (The Chronicles of Japan, the second oldest book of classical Japanese history) suggests that "Nara" was derived from narasu (to flatten, to level). According to this account, in September in the tenth year of Emperor Sujin, "leading selected soldiers (the rebels) went forward, climbed Nara-yama (hills lying to the north of Heijō-kyō) and put them in order. Now the imperial forces gathered and flattened trees and plants. Therefore the mountain is called Nara-yama." Though the narrative itself is regarded as a folk etymology and few researchers regard it as historical, this is the oldest surviving suggestion, and is linguistically similar to the following theory by Yanagita.
"Flat land" theory (currently most widely accepted): In his 1936 study of placenames, the author Kunio Yanagita states that "the topographical feature of an area of relatively gentle gradient on the side of a mountain, which is called taira in eastern Japan and hae in the south of Kyushu, is called naru in the Chūgoku region and Shikoku (central Japan). This word gives rise to the verb narasu, adverb narashi, and adjective narushi." This is supported by entries in a dialect dictionary for nouns referring to flat areas: naru (found in Aida District, Okayama Prefecture and Ketaka District, Tottori Prefecture) and naro (found in Kōchi Prefecture); and also by an adjective narui which is not standard Japanese, but is found all across central Japan, with meanings of "gentle", "gently sloping", or "easy". Yanagita further comments that the way in which the fact that so many of these placenames are written using the character 平 ("flat"), or other characters in which it is an element, demonstrates the validity of this theory. Citing a 1795 document, Inaba-shi (因幡志) from the province of Inaba, the eastern part of modern Tottori, as indicating the reading naruji for the word 平地 (standard reading heichi, meaning "level/flat ground/land/country, a plain"), Yanagita suggests that naruji would have been used as a common noun there until the modern period. Of course, the fact that historically "Nara" was also written 平 or 平城 as above is further support for this theory.
The idea that Nara is derived from 楢 nara (Japanese for "oak, deciduous Quercus spp.") is the next most common opinion. This idea was suggested by a linguist, Yoshida Togo. This noun for the plant can be seen as early as in Man'yōshū (7-8th century) and Harima-no-kuni Fudoki (715). The latter book states the place name Narahara in Harima (around present-day Kasai)　derives from this nara tree, which might support Yoshida's theory. Note that the name of the nearby city of Kashihara (literally "live oak plain") contains a semantically similar morpheme (Japanese 橿 kashi "live oak, evergreen Quercus spp.").
Nara could be a loan word from Korean nara (나라 : country, nation, kingdom). This idea was put forward by a linguist Matsuoka Shizuo. Not much about the Old Korean language is known today, and the first written attestation of a word ancestral to Modern Korean nara is as late as the 15th century, such as in Yongbieocheonga (1447),  Wolinseokbo (月印釋譜. 1459), or Beophwagyeongeonhae (法華經諺解. 1463), and there is no evidence that proves the word already existed as far back as the 7th century. These 15th-century books used narah (나랗), an old form of nara in Korean, and its older form might be reconstructed *narak. American  linguist Christopher I. Beckwith infers the Korean narak derives from the late Middle Old Chinese 壌 (*nrak, earth), from early *narak, and has no connection with Goguryoic and Japanese na. (See also the next theory.) Kusuhara et al. also points out this hypothesis cannot account for the fact there are many places named Nara, Naru and Naro besides this Nara.
There is the idea that Nara is akin to Tungusic na. In some Tungusic languages such as Orok (and likely Goguryeo language), na means earth, land or the like. Some have speculated about a connection between these Tungusic words and Old Japanese nawi, an archaic and somewhat obscure word that appears in the verb phrases nawi furu and nawi yoru ('an earthquake occurs, to have an earthquake').The "Flat land" theory is adopted by Nihon Kokugo Daijiten (the largest dictionary of Japanese language), various dictionaries for place names, history books on Nara and the like today, and it is regarded as the most likely.


== History ==


=== Pre-Nara/Origins ===
There are a number of kofun in Nara, including Gosashi Kofun, Hishiage Kofun (ヒシアゲ古墳), Horaisan Kofun (宝来山古墳), Konabe Kofun (コナベ古墳), Saki Ishizukayama Kofun (佐紀石塚山古墳), Saki Misasagiyama Kofun (佐紀陵山古墳), and Uwanabe Kofun (ウワナベ古墳).
By decree of an edict on March 11, 708 AD, Empress Genmei ordered the court to relocate to the new capital, Nara. Once known as Heijō or Heijō-kyō, the city was established as Japan's first permanent capital in 710 CE; it was the seat of government until 784 CE, albeit with five year interruption, lasting from 741-5 CE. Heijō, as the ‘penultimate court’, however, was abandoned by the order of Emperor Kammu in 784 CE in favor of the temporary site of Nagaoka, and then Heian-kyō (Kyoto) which retained the status of capital for 1,100 years, until the Meiji Emperor made the final move to Edo in 1869 CE. This first relocation was due to the court's transformation from an imperial nobility to a force of metropolitan elites and new technique of dynastic shedding which had refashioned the relationship between court, nobility, and country. Moreover, the ancient capital lent its name to Nara period.As a reactionary expression to the political centralization of China, the city of Nara (Heijō) was modeled after the Tang capital at Chang’an. Nara was laid out on a grid—which was based upon the Handen system—whereby the city was divided by four great roads. Likewise, according to Chinese cosmology, the ruler's place was fixed like the pole star. By dominating the capital, the ruler brought heaven to earth. Thus, the south facing palace centered at the north, bisected the ancient city, instituting ‘Right Capital’ and ‘Left Capital’ zones. As Nara came to be the epicenter of Buddhist church and drawing pilgrimage site, the city plan incorporated various pre-Heijō and Heijō period temples, of which the Yakushiji and the Todaiji still stand.
Gallery
		


=== Politics ===
A number of scholars have characterized the Nara period as a time of penal and administrative legal order. The Taihō Code called for the establishment of administrative sects underneath the central government, and modeled many of the codes from the Chinese Tang dynasty. The code eventually disbanded, but its contents were largely preserved in the Yōrō Code of 718.Occupants of the throne during the period gradually shifted their focus from military preparation, to religious rites and institutions, in an attempt to strengthen their divine authority over the population.


=== Religion and Temples ===
Nanto RokushūWith the establishment of the new capital, Asuka-dera, the temple of the Soga clan, was relocated within Nara. The Emperor Shōmu ordered the construction of Tōdai-ji Temple (largest wooden building in the world) and the world's largest bronze Buddha statue. The temples of Nara, known collectively as the Nanto Shichi Daiji, remained spiritually significant even beyond the move of the political capital to Heian-kyō in 794, thus giving Nara a synonym of Nanto (南都 "The southern Capital").
On December 2, 724 AD, in order to increase the visual “magnificence” of the city, an edict was ordered by the government for the noblemen and the wealthy to renovate the roofs, pillars, and walls of their homes, although at that time this was unfeasible.Sightseeing in Nara city became popular in the Edo period, during which several visitor's maps of Nara were widely published. During the Meiji Period, the Kofukuji Temple lost some land and its monks were converted into Shinto priests, due to Buddhism being associated with the old shogunate.
Gallery
		
		
		
		
		


=== Modern Nara ===
Even though Nara was the capital of Japan from 710 to 794, it was not designated a city until 1 February, 1898. Nara city has developed from a town of commerce in the Edo and Meiji periods to a modern tourist city, due to its large number of historical temples, landmarks and national monuments. Nara was added to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in December 1998. The architecture of some shops, ryokans and art galleries has been adapted from traditional merchant houses.Nara holds traditional festivals every year, including the Neri-Kuyo Eshiki, a spring festival held in Todaiji temple for over 1,000 years; and the Kemari Festival, in which people wear costumes ranging across 700 years  and play traditional games).In 1909, Tatsuno Kingo designed the Nara Hotel, whose architecture combines  modern elements with traditional Japanese style.


== Geography ==
The city of Nara lies in the northern end of Nara Prefecture, directly bordering Kyoto Prefecture to its north.  The city is 22.22 kilometres (13.81 mi) from North to South, from East to West. As a result of the latest merger, effective April 1, 2005, that combined the villages of Tsuge and Tsukigase with the city of Nara, the city now borders Mie Prefecture directly to its east. The total area is 276.84 square kilometres (106.89 square miles).Nara city, as well as several important settlements (such as Kashihara, Yamatokōriyama, Tenri, Yamatotakada, Sakurai and Goze), are located in the Nara Basin. This makes it the most densely-populated region of Nara Prefecture.The downtown of Nara is on the east side of the ancient Heijō Palace site, occupying the northern part of what was called the Gekyō (外京), literally the outer capital area. Many of the public offices (e.g. the Municipal office, the Nara Prefectural government, the Nara Police headquarters, etc.) are located on Nijō-ōji (二条大路), while Nara branch offices of major nationwide banks are on Sanjō-ōji (三条大路), with both avenues running east–west.
The highest point in the city is at the peak of Kaigahira-yama at an altitude of 822.0 m (2,696.85 ft) (Tsugehayama-cho district), and the lowest is in Ikeda-cho district, with an altitude of 56.4 m (185.04 ft).
Nara Basin
Murō-Akame-Aoyama Quasi-National Park
Yamato-Aogaki Quasi-National Park
Kasugayama Primeval Forest
Sarusawa Pond (猿沢池)
Mount Wakakusa


=== Climate ===
The climate of Nara Prefecture is generally temperate, although there are notable differences between the north-western basin area and the rest of the prefecture which is more mountainous.
The basin area climate has an inland characteristic, as represented in the higher daily temperature variance, and the difference between summer and winter temperatures. Winter temperatures average approximately 3 to 5 °C (37 to 41 °F), and from 25 to 28 °C (77 to 82 °F) in the summer with highest readings reaching close to 35 °C (95 °F). There has not been a single year since 1990 with more than 10 days of snowfall recorded by Nara Local Meteorological Observatory.
The climate in the rest of the prefecture is that of higher elevations especially in the south, with  −5 °C (23 °F) being the extreme minimum in winter. Heavy rainfall is often observed in summer. The annual accumulated rainfall totals as much as 3,000 to 5,000 mm (118.11 to 196.85 in), which is among the heaviest in Japan and indeed in the world outside the equatorial zone.
Spring and fall temperatures are temperate and comfortable. The mountainous region of Yoshino has been long popular for viewing cherry blossoms in the spring. In autumn, the southern mountains are also a popular destination for viewing fall foliage.


== Cityscape ==


== Demographics ==
As of April 1, 2017, the city has an estimated population of 359,666 and a population density of 1,300 persons per km2. There were 160,242 households residing in Nara. The highest concentration of both households and population, respectively about 46,000 and 125,000, is found along the newer bedtown districts, along the Kintetsu line connecting to Osaka.
There were about 3,000 registered foreigners in the city, of which Koreans and Chinese are the two largest groups with about 1,200 and 800 people respectively.

== Deer in Nara ==
According to the legendary history of Kasuga Shrine, the god Takemikazuchi arrived in Nara on a white deer to guard the newly built capital of Heijō-kyō. Since then, the deer have been regarded as heavenly animals, protecting the city and the country.Tame sika deer (also known as spotted deer or Japanese deer) roam through the town, especially in Nara Park. In 2015, there were more than 1,200 sika deer in Nara. Snack vendors sell sika senbei (deer crackers) to visitors so they can feed the deer. Some deer have learned to bow in order to receive senbei from people.
Gallery
		
		
		


== Education ==
As of 2005, there are 16 high schools and 6 universities located in the city of Nara.


=== Universities ===

Nara Women's University is one of only two national women's universities in Japan. Nara Institute of Science and Technology is a graduate research university specializing in biological, information, and materials sciences.


=== Primary and secondary education ===


==== Public schools ====
Public elementary and junior high schools are operated by the city of Nara.
Public high schools are operated by the Nara Prefecture.


==== Private schools ====
Private high schools in Nara include the Tōdaiji Gakuen, a private school founded by the temple in 1926.


== Transportation ==

The main central station of Nara is Kintetsu Nara Station with JR Nara station some 500m west and much closer to Shin-Omiya station.


=== Rail ===
West Japan Railway Company
Kansai Main Line (Yamatoji Line): Narayama Station - Nara Station
Sakurai Line (Manyō-Mahoroba Line): Nara Station - Kyōbate Station - Obitoke Station
Kintetsu Railway
Nara Line: Tomio Station - Gakuen-mae Station - Ayameike Station - Yamato-Saidaiji Station - Shin-Ōmiya Station - Kintetsu Nara Station
Kyoto Line: Takanohara Station - Heijō Station - Yamato-Saidaiji Station
Kashihara Line: Yamato-Saidaiji Station - Amagatsuji Station - Nishinokyō Station
Keihanna Line: Gakken Nara-Tomigaoka Station

text.quote: Sizable collection of ancient Chinese bronze wares, mirrors & seals, along with Korean pottery.
trip: A large garden, as Japanese gardens go, and divided into an "outer" and "inner" side. The garden and associated tea ceremony huts have been popular with Urasenke masters, and rich merchants entertaining artists of the day. I found it rather generic, definitely not worth the

Situated between World Heritage sites of Kofukuji Temple and Todaiji Temple in Nara Park is a typical Japanese garden. During an extensive trip where you'll be visiting the gardens in Kanazawa, Okayama and various castle grounds, Isuien is not a necessary garden to see. It is of
Wonderful garden, secluded with different zones, better than some of the paying gardens we visited. The mosses are wonderful, and so were the momiji.

This garden is situated between Kofukuji Temple and Todaiji Temple (both are World Heritages) In Nara Prefecture. This garden has chactereistics of two different types of gardens in Edo Era and the Meiji Era. This garden represents a typical Japanese garden.The garden is a
This is a beautiful garden. It encapsulates much of what is important in Japanese garden design. Please do not miss it. Well worth a visit.

It's a small garden but has some nice views. Also, next to their entrance gate, on the right, is another garden which you can enter freely when you show your passport. visit them both and you have a nice 1,5 hour.

I used to go to Nara when I was on business trips to Japan. The city is great to escape the full-on insanity of Osaka, and this garden was my favourite place to come to. Returning as a tourist confirmed that my memories were not faulty. This is a truly special place. Every view
Beautiful, tranquil gardens. A great window into the Japanese world. Totally great way to spend an hour or two.

This garden lived up to its expectations. A nice break from the crowds at the big Buddha temple. There are friendly docents that give history. We spent 1 hour taking pictures and walking the stone and dirt paths, over small bridges and stone paths that cross the scenic

We went to the garden and thought the prices was a little steep. Went to museum that was included and that was nice. As we entered the park a lady said goodbye to a gang and then introduced herself to us as our guide. She was knowledgeable and it was just only us on the tour. No

We were passing it and decided to go in but there is an entrance fee. not many people go to see the garden at least when we were there in July. It is beautiful but again if we were not in area.. it is not worth a special trip

Budget travelers beware! You may have to shell out a little more than you're comfortable with for this attraction, but I honestly believe you won't regret it. If you're especially interested in scenery, fantastic views and gardens then there's no way you'll regret coming here.

Like many Japanese gardens, this one is full of beautiful views and it’s quite big. We had a lovely experience because we were shown the place with a private guide (it was included with our ticket and there was nobody else visiting that day at that time). He explained to us the

There are actually two gardens here one in the back and one in the front. Each represents a different style. We went in May 2019 and there was a ¥900 entrance fee. It takes about 1 hour to power through the gardens. The museums is relatively small, so you can skip it to save
What a beautiful garden this is and well worth the admission fee. We were lucky to have an excellent guide to tell us the history of the garden.
The garden is a nice break from the crowds and offers free English speaking guides. It is not a big garden but offers some very pretty photo spots and is well worth a look if you are in the area.

After we saw another Japanese style gardens in Japan I think that this place is nice to visit but definitely not worth a 900 yen that included the fee for the museum(that you have to pay even if you don’t want to enter). I think Yoshiki-en garden(a few minutes walking) is nice
After the crowds in the park, including multiple school tours, this garden offered a welcome respite.

We visited this garden on April 9. It is next to the Yoshiki-en garden. With the ticket you can visit the little art museum next to the ticket office. The garden has two parts: the front garden is compact and the back garden has a big pound, some cascades and little quiet places.

Isuien Garden is a beautiful traditional Japanese garden, tucked into a quiet corner of Nara’s streets. The entrance booth is manned by a polite old lady who spoke English and told us that it was free for tourists, which was a pleasant surprise as we were already getting ready
We were disappointed by the size and amount of fauna. Maybe it was the time of year. Don’t spend the 900 yen. It only takes 10 min to walk slowly around.
A pretty Japanese garden with tea houses. Some peace from the nearby crowds. The museum is also worth a look.

This was a lovely garden but I felt the Yoshikien garden, which is right next door, was more beautiful and better for a photographer. If you are pushed for time - seeing the Yoshikien garden is definitely the one to choose. Nonetheless we thoroughly enjoyed walking around this
This garden is a calmed oasis near Nara Park. The place has a museum, several tea houses and a beautiful garden.
If you like Japanese landscape gardens with occasional views of nearby temples and the hills around Nara come here.

It is certainly a lovely garden. But having been to many other gardens in Japan, I am not quite sure if its really that special and if it deserves to be quite pricier to visit than most other gardens in Japan. Still, worth visiting if you like gardens, and it doesnt get very

Almost impossible to find..but when we eventually did it was worth the struggle. A beautiful peaceful place to while away a morning. Plenty of areas where you can just sit and contemplate. You should take id with you if you're planning a visit.otheewise you can't go in!

beautiful garden! one of many nearby! we highly recommend going there a little earlier when there are not so many tourists! the opportunity to take beautiful photos! admirable how beautiful it is all there preserved
Lovely gardens however at 900 yen it is one of the most expensive sites I visited on my whole trip. Peaceful setting and nice views. Just hard to justify the cost.

It was an adequate garden, though nothing was in full bloom at the time of visit. I have definitely seen better. For such a small garden, it was pretty overpriced at 900 yen. I mean, even the entrance to Todai-ji was 600 yen only! Student discount is very small, you still have

Manicured garden with attention to even the leaves that felt. I would cover the pipe that probably creates the small creek on the top, just not to break the illusion, but overall te place is just pretty in steroids.
A typical but stunning Japanese Garden with wonderful views of the mountain. Small and compact, quick and easy to visit.

This garden is slightly off the beaten track (from JR Nara to Todaiji). However, do note that the admission is rather expensive at ¥900. The garden is well maintained and beautiful, giving you a typical Japanese Zen feeling. Be sure to spend some time here during your trip to

We paid 800 yen or so to enter these private gardens. We took advantage of the volunteer English guide who explained a bit about the gardens. Her English was not too advanced to answer detailed questions though. The gardens are a must see and do. A definite tranquil escape from

My initial response to the entry price was that it was too expensive but with the personal guide it really was a great experience. Despite it being Winter I still saw many features. The guide pointed out many things that I would have walked past. it was an enriching experience.

Very beautiful garden in every season! Even in winter, it offered us some charming views. Besides, there is an atmospheric tea house with traditional desserts and matcha) Besides, Yoshikien garden is just a few steps away, and it’s free for foreign visitors!

The Isuien garden is stunning and a nice peaceful break from the crowds in Nara Park. We were given a small guided tour where we were told about the history of the garden and Japanese tea ceremony. Our guide was lovely and very informative.

This was the first Stop in lonely planets walking tour and we are so glad we decided to do it. For 900yen we got a wonderful little tour and explanation of the Japanese garden style, the Isuien’s unique details and the general Japanese tea ceremony. We then wandered the tranquil

We visited the Garden after visiting the Deer Park. A walkable distance from the park (via the underpass). We paid ¥900 per adult for the entrance fee which included a free ticket to a small pottery museum next to the Garden. It was a beautiful Japanese garden with many photo

I tripped on this and am glad I did. Really nicely laid out and i was lucky to have some fall colors. It isn't large so you're not rushed going through it. A small museum which i did not go in. the gardens took up what allocated time i had.

Family initially didn't want to pay the entrance fee of 900 yen, but came out feeling that this was one of the highlights in Nara. The concept of 'borrowing scenery' is in full display in the Garden. I think I enjoyed it more than the Nara deers, for the autumn colours.

On our arrival at the Isuien Garden we were approached by a delightful older man, Hiroyuki, who offered to take us on a tour of the garden. He is retired from work, and provides his services as a volunteer. His tour was informative and gave us a perspective of the garden and
We loved this garden. It is beautiful and very calm and relaxing. It was nice to also get entry into the museum.
If you only ever visit one Japanese style garden during your visit to Japan, make it this one. Interesting plants, features, watercourses, tea houses. Yeah, it's got the lot. Very enjoyable!

This is near Nara Park so going here will not take you much time. I am stressed from work and so is my husband so our time here was well spent for meditation and good talk. This is not the best Japanese Garden however still is beautiful. And if you ever wanted a snack, they

I spent several hours enjoying this garden during a recent stay in Nara. The grounds were lovely and very peaceful. The leaves were just beginning to turn, which added to the beauty of the place. I visited soon after it opened and it was not crowded. I also went to the small

Beautiful place, but here's the thing, maybe it's just me. right next door is the smaller Yoshikien gardens. So for me, after a while, that's a lot of garden to see. If I had done one but not the other, I think I would have been fine. Naturally the 2 are not the same. And I am

We visited Isuien shortyl before it closed. It was a rainy day, there were not many people in the garden, probably because the entry fee was on the higher side. Totally worth it tough, the garden is amazing and very well maintained. One of my favourite gardens in Japan.
One of the most beautiful and peaceful gardens I’ve seen after Kyoto... very impressive places to discover. I would highly suggest everyone to enjoy the nature there.. a must see garden in Nara!

The entry fee to this garden is 900 yen. It entitles you to a free guided tour of the garden as well as entry to the museum. Some people might shun away because of the cost of the entry fee, however, I do feel that this place is a must do in Nara. The garden is so beautiful and

I loved these gardens - really peacful and very well kept, it is a bit pricey but they offer free tours of the garden which are done by volunteers who are very well informed about the whole area. If you want somewhere to get social media pictures or family snaps then this place

The gardens were pleasant but much smaller than I was expecting. Also the museum was also small and not very interesting especially for non-Japanese speakers. At ¥900, I thought it was very expensive especially compared to the other main sights in Nara.
This is the best park. There is a breathtaking view in the park that I cant stop thinking about. Quiet and not as crowded as the rest of the city. I would really like to come back in spring or fall.

With a reduced rate for foreigners, if you like Japanese gardens this one is better than the neighboring Yoshiki-en garden. It's about half an hour to wander around and enjoy the ambience. There are several tea houses in the gardens and I believe you can book in for a ceremony.
This is a hidden gem, uncrowded, quiet, a must see. Step away from the crowds to this peaceful oasis.

Even on a June Sunday with Todai-ji and the surrounding parks so overrun with crowds the deer had given up hassling for food, Isuien was a peaceful oasis, with barely a sound creeping in from outside, and just a few dozen people strolling the grounds. The gardens here are

Perhaps because it requires an entrance fee, this garden is untarnished by the touristy crowds outside. For the ¥900 I was offered a free English guide around the garden which I learnt a lot from about Japanese landscaping and culture. The garden is quintessentially Japanese
Went on a visit to Nara, very peaceful and beautiful. One of my favorite parks in Japan. Not crowded so you could take your time wandering around. Lovely visit

What a lovely garden to sit and relax in total calmness. You can walk round and it is very quiet and serene. There is a tea room where you can get tea or lunch and sit looking out over the garden. The garden covers nearly three acres. There are two strolling around the pond

A friend recommended that we visit Isuien Garden during our visit to Nara. We are glad we did! Such a peaceful garden away from the busy and noisy shrines/ temples. The entrance fee is 900 yen for adults, pricey but I think worth it.
After walking Nara Park and Toda-ji temple the Tea House at the Isuien Garden is a nice break. Nice view , green tea ice cream $520 yen.

The garden was nice but not 900 yen nice. Having been to others on our trip so far for half the price if less it didn't compare yet was more expensive. Real shame. If money is no object please go in as it is very pretty. There is a free garden next door (for foreign

This is an exquisite jewel of a garden. The texture of the land, water and plants is in perfect balance. We were there in the first week in April on a comfortable sunny day – and it was glorious to walk around this garden - beautiful colors. There is a free garden next door,

This is an exquisite garden which is a traditional Japanese walking garden. The entry fee of 900 yen is good value as this also included a tour of the garden from an expert guide. Probably the best garden that we visited in Japan.

I felt the entrance fee was higher than usual (Yen 900 if I recall correctly) but when I think back about my day in Nara the garden was a big factor in making the whole trip so much more worthwhile. I visited. It is not so popular by name, but google map is helpful to locate it,

Amazing garden. One of the best I have been to in Japan. I went on a rainy day so the setting made for a great experience. The water was so still at times it made a perfect reflection. Just sat there for what seemed like hours.
Another beautiful, well manicured and structured Japane garden and this one free to foreigners. Men were removing fallen petals from the moss. A relaxing stroll in an area of great beauty.
Visited this as park of a trip to Nara. The landscape of the garden is prettt and definitely worth a visit as part of Nara trip.

It is located next to a public garden free for tourist. After visiting the free garden, this garden seems a bit expensive. However, we are very glad that we went there. It is a private Japanese garden with beautiful landscape and is big. Because of the fee, it is rather

There are two different styles of japanese gardens in Nara right next door to each other and both are worth visiting - Isuien was my favourite as there was a lovely lake/river there and varying examples of japanese gardening around it. The sun was out and we found ourselves in

We could see how these gardens would be beautiful in season but we visited in winter and they were dry and brown. On the way out we ran into a man working at the gardens who told us in spring the cherry blossoms are beautiful to see, in summer everything is green and flowering
Very noce little jewel at the foot of the majestuous todai - jo temple. The garden is manicured as well as the tea house and other buildings inside. Really woth the tour!

The Isuien Garden was one of my must visit place in Nara. I visited it in November during the maple color reached its peak, it was so beautiful and peaceful. There were not many visitors probably because the entrance fee is quite expensive (900 yen). There is Yoshikien garden

We made our way from the train station past all the tourists to Isuien Gardens. At the entrance, we were very fortunate to be met by an EGG (Nara YMCA English Goodwill Guide) who offered to guide us through the garden. This turned into one of the highlights of our trip. We had

We visited the garden during winter-time. The main garden was closed but we were allowed into a smaller segment. Foreign visitors get to enter for free. Not the best time to visit a garden during winter but the place still exudes serenity. Quite scenic despite bare trees.

Passby the place while walking towards Nara park , the free entrance entice me to check the place out . Nice place to slowly explore the place within 20mins, not many visitors as it is slightly off the main road to Nara park .

While the Deer Park in Nara boasts the most friendly animals. Isuien Gardens provides a tranquil serenity in a busy city setting. We were fortunate to meet a docent at the entrance who explained the gardens layout, intricacies and meaning. He provided a great background history

If you travel to Nara please don't miss this beautiful garden with it's beautiful colours, streams, stepping stones and ponds with the most amazing reflections. If you can, get one of the garden guides to show you around, they are a mine of information about the garden layout

We were in for some diversity after a string of temples, so we paid to visit the garden, which was advertised with splendid photographs through town. We were not disappointed. If we would have had more time we might have tried the tea ceremony, but the garden with tea houses
I visited under the rain, and it did not lose its enchantment. Don't miss also the next door YOSHIKIEN Garden

The front garden is beautifully landscaped and it gradually becomes less designed as you move through the back garden to the outer edges. The autumn colours of the Acers and Enkianthus were stunning as they were reflected in the ponds. The various tea houses were well

This is a beautiful garden, expertly looked after - we watched the gardening team pruning trees - fascinating to watch how they determine shape etc. Lovely meandering paths and ponds with quite a variety of plants.

Garden was beautiful and quiet. Not many tourists, due to entry fee I guess, so we got to really enjoy our visit. We had one of the free guides, he was funny and spoke very good English. His explanation of all the symbols and the design principles behind the garden made the

This is the most scenic garden we visited in Japan. In November it glows with red leaves of Enkianthus and Japanese Maples. It has dynamic topography on nearly three acres encompassing two ponds, islands, water wheel and waterfall. One can enjoy lunch at the Tea house and stroll
Beautiful and relaxing park for walking and admiring the view over the mountains and the greenery. Calm and pretty. You can also have tea in the tea house in the park.

This garden has all the expected features of a traditional Japanese garden: pond and rills, clipped maples, stepping stones, lanterns and teahouses. It was lovely even in the rain. Watch out for the stones with cord wrapping - they mean no entry! We didn't go in the small

The garden is beautiful and its entrance fee miraculously deters the crowds that would ruin it. It was particularly appreciated as Nara's main sites are overrun by visitors. The museum was dull - specialising in seals, as in company seals, it was not well enough displayed to be
Beautiful traditional japanese garden, in two parts. We were offered a free tour from a volunteer who was practicing his English and it was great to learn from and converse with him.
We did enjoy this garden but somehow it left us a bit flat. We liked the next door, smaller, and more dramatic Yoshikien garden which also was free with foreign ID (passport...) better.

Beautiful garden built around a tea house and of course a few minutes walk from the temple which is the largest wooden structure in the world. We were unfortunate in that it was very cloudy but on a sunny day would be magnificent. Adjacent to it is a small museum which was

big thanks to tsutomu from nara ymca english goodwill tours,met by accident at nara rail station and given a free 5 hour walking tour of nara,visited most of the sights including Isuien Garden, one of the best days i had in japan. would visit again in spring or autumn though,as

We were greeted by a volunteer who gave us a quick 10 min intro to the garden which was great! The whole garden is so pretty and tranquil, i preferred this to some of the bigger more "commercialised" gardens we saw in other parts of Japan.

I still cannot believe I paid ¥900 to visit this small, mediocre garden, which looks quite neglected. They are certainly not using this high entrance fee for the maintenance of the park. Quite frankly, it would not deserve a visit even if it were a free entrance. Major

Isuien garden is one of the most beautiful example of Japanese gardening art. Entrance fee a little bit higher than usual temple or museum entrance fees, however it is a place which offers to enjoy tea time in a real japanese garden :)

An absolutely beautiful garden, something I would like to see during all four season changes. Lovely piece of history and nurture of the centuries. A must visit spot during your time in Nara. This was my highlight this trip.
We went during Summer and it was so green and beautiful! Free guides are available. It's hard to find. You'll have to walk between a long walkways with a yellow wall and brown wall.
If you're visiting Nara Park you will almost certainly wander through or past Isui-en Garden. It is attractive but would not be worth a special trip itself.
it's a small and lovely garden to walk around, definetly worth paying the small entrance fee. also around great place to enjoy a cup of green tea.

We chose to go to this garden before the deer city and arrived at 10am. The garden entrance was 900yen each and got you entrance to the garden and the museum next door. Arriving at 10 was perfect as we missed all of the tour groups and pretty much walked around with a volenteer

A relatively small and peaceful garden with lots to enjoy - particularly borrowed scenery and ponds. Surprisingly not that busy and highly recommend as a quick and easy visit on the way from train/centre to Todaji. The little museum which is included in ticket is only so/so
My wife and I found this garden to be between ok and nice, certainly not worth the 1200 yen each for entry. Save your money and your legs getting there.

This is a beautiful garden (s) for a peaceful stroll with the mountain in the background. If you are a gardener yourself you will certainly take away many ideas with you. You will find a few welcome moments of peace if you just sit a while and soak it all in.
A beautiful, tranquil zen garden definitely worth a detour for a quiet wander. Lovely moss patchworks.

Both the garden and the museum that comes with the entrance fee were quite disappointing. Having visited a number of Japanese gardens already, Isuien appeared to be somewhat neglected, which detracts from the beautiful landscaping. The Yoshiki-en garden next door was better

We loved strolling through this Japanese garden! So many special zen places! The garden was spectacular in the late spring but I have seen pictures of it in the fall when it is just as remarkable. A must see if you are visiting Nara and very close to Nara Park.

Must say, this was the best surprise of the day. It was raining a little, so we decided to stay for a minute. And it was wonderful. We struck the wooden gong for service and ordered two large beers while our baby crawled across the floor. It was more expensive than other gardens

We visited Isuien Garden in January and it was a cold day but the garden warmed our hearts and we soon forgot how cold the day was as we viewed this amazing example of a Japanese garden. Fortunately because of the time of year there were few people around and we had the whole
It's well organised and full of beautifully trimmed trees and plants. Water, moss, pebbles. It's quintessentially Japanese. Take your time here whatever you do.

round the corner from the Great Buddha we were greeted by a volunteer guide who offered to take us around. this is a borrowed garden with views of the surrounding mountains and temple visible through the trees. pretty ponds and teahouse
A Japanese Garden, really well-maintained. Visit in different seasons to enjoy the different feel, as the foliage changes colors. Relaxing and calm atmosphere.

The garden was one of my favourite gardens that I visited on my trip to Japan. It's only a short walk from the Todai-ji and though relatively small in size, is definitely worth a visit. There is also a small museum opposite the gardens which you can skip if you are short on
One of the most iconic landscape of Japan, this garden represent all the beauty you can find in Japan. It is a must visit if you come to Nara.

The Isuien Garden is about 10 minutes walking distance west of the Nandaimon Gate of the Todai-ji temple and covers nearly 3 acres. The garden is a combination of front garden- built in 1670's by Kiyosumi Dosei and back garden - designed by Seki Tojiro in early 20th century.
We visited this garden 3 years ago and wanted to visit again. BUT, the garden is closed to the public whilst reconstruction is done. Visit Yoshikien next door which is free to foreigners.

It is one of the most beautiful gardens (especially when the leaves turn red) we have seen on out trip, very tranquil. Isuien garden is located West of the Nandaimon Gate of the Todai-ji temple. The front garden is designed in the Edo period and the back garden is designed in

There are reasons why this is classified as one of the country's most beautiful gardens. This private garden can be visited but at cost of 900 yen. In my opinion, it is worth the money. For the few that have rated this a poor attraction, it is apparent that they have missed

It is the most tranquil place we've been on this trip. There aren't a bus load of tourist like in other attractions. You can spend time taking in the sights in the back and front gardens. Its well worth the 900Yen entrance fee

Nice small Japanese garden for couple of hours. The guide explained us about the small buildings or place where tea ceremony is done. This was a private garden earlier now available for public. Many places to take a perfect photo especially during autumn. Good place to visit if

These gardens are well worth the 900 yen to gain entrance. They are tranquil and in the late fall the colours are beautiful. The waterfalls are peaceful. I would skip the museum but the Isuien Garden is a good way to start your visit to Nara.

You imagine a Japanese garden in the fall and then you get lucky and visit Japan during peak fall season. It's a gardener and a photographer's paradise - there's a fabulous photo op at every turn. I know many people come to Japan to see cherry blossoms in the spring but it is

Isuien is a gem of a garden. Every which way you turn, there is something beautiful and interesting to see. The garden is wonderfully sculpted, and the autumn colours are stunning. We had a photograph of a whole backdrop of red maple leaves. The garden path is well-marked, with

Two minutes after deciding not to pay $18 for two of us to view another garden, we found Isuien-free to International tourists. It was absolutely stunning. The flowers were not in bloom up in the floral garden, but we were there in peak leaf changing season in a bit of rain in

We went to Japan for the autumn leaves photography and we were not disappointed our expectations were exceeded.This garden was amazing not many tourist in the garden during our visit. They are sometimes shut on Tuesdays so check at tourist office before you go. Cost expensive

Don't go home from Nara if you haven't visit this place. This Garden is simply breathtaking. The garden is very beautiful and peaceful. There's a café shop that overlooks the garden wherein you can order coffee, tea or even beer and appreciate the beauty and peacefulness of
If you want to see a truly beautiful Japanese garden don't miss this one There is a free garden next door called the Japanese garden it is worth seeing both Also there are free guides very helpful
Isuien Garden is a beautiful garden well worth its entrance fee. It is a rather large garden and also has a teahouse / restaurant at its premises. Take your time in strolling around.

This was probably the loveliest garden we visited in our two weeks in Japan. It's a strolling garden that uses 'borrowed sceney' ie elements outside the garden as part of the view. There are ponds and streams, moss gardens and little shrines and tea houses. We were lucky enough

Here is one of those gardening gems for which Japan is so rightly famous. This garden and the similar once next to it (free entry) are themselves alone worth the trip to Nara. The extremely detailed use of all the natural elements to create such beauty and harmony is
A very nice example of old Japanese garden. We were lucky to visit it in Autumn when trees are colorful. It worth a visit.

This garden is the one place you must visit if you go to Nara. Very beautiful, quiet, and large enough to wander around for a good hour. Entrance fee is ¥900, also including the museum (not much to see though).

This was the highlight of our day trip to Nara. Todaiji is a must see of course, but was very crowded. This on the other hand was pretty, quiet and serene. There's an area with a few benches where one can sit and enjoy the scenery and atmosphere for a bit. Highly recommended.

There are many gardens and parks throughout Japan and this puts them all to shame. An absolutely beautiful stroll, I had a free tour guide tell me about the front and back garden so that helped add to experience. It was gorgeous when I went with some of the trees turning to red
Isuien Garden is a must-see if you're in Nara. It's the only walking garden in Nara and it's beautifully preserved. They charge an admission fee of about 900JPY but the scenery is worth it.

A very large and well-known garden in Nara. A visit requires a couple of hours to complete what is essentially a loop track to appreciate the multiple features here that include tea houses, picturesque bridges over water features and lovely ponds. A visit in November, which
Great garden which will look stunning in autumn. Enjoyed a lovely stroll through the garden. Filled with small patches of moss, delightful!

My great regret is that I visited at the start of October rather than towards the end of October. The leaves on a few of the trees were just starting to turn, but I could see it would be spectacular when the leaves are changing fully. It's a very pretty and charming garden,
Really lovely quiet garden with windy paths and good views. It's free for foreigners and the lady at the reception was polite.

We happened upon this garden on a day trip to Nara. Much of the park was swarmed with people (and deer), so this garden was a welcome break from the crowds. Well worth the $8 fee (810 yen since the museum was closed that day). The garden was well-kept and had small signs with

We had just had an interesting trip to the impressive big golden buddha after dodging deer in the park (as an aside, they are fine - not a problem, and it is quite funny watching them cross the zebra crossing, obeying the lights)! It was a hot day and this lovely garden with its

The front garden was built in the 1670s by a wealthy cloth merchant whilst the rear section was built in the 20th century in order to allow tea ceremonies. Both have the perfect sense of harmony and with the mountains and Todaiji temple as a backdrop they are superb and very
If you are tight on time, go to yoshiki en garden next door. It's free for foreigners (show passport) instead of y900 here. It's smaller but similar.

I love Japanese gardens, so this was a must for me to visit. In your ticket, there is a guide included who walks you through the garden, tells you its history and also some information about plants, garden architecture and carps. I very much enjoyed.

The beautiful, manicured gardens are not large but are a great place to escape the crowds, sit and have a few moments of peace. They are also cool, even on a hot, steamy day. The museum is very small and does not house much of great interest. If you are on a strict budget,

Compare to the Great Buddha of Todaiji temple and over crowded photo shooting with deers in Nara park, this is the place where one can enjoy the peace and atmosphere of Zen. One can enjoy tasty ice-cream in the tea house overlooking the garden. For ones who has difficulties to
We were completely charmed by this elegant and refined garden. We learned a lot from an EGG (English Goodwill Guide) who talked about the history, design, and plants.
Very beautiful gardens within walking distance from Nara Park. Not free but worth seeing. Earlier in the morning right when the open is usually best to avoid mosquitos.

A tranquil garden close to highways and residences. Masterful creation of separate spaces, each with the sound of water and beautiful vistas. Entrance fee (about $10) also includes a small museum with a lovely collection of celadon ceramics (mostly Korean).

This was quite a nice garden, and on the way to Todaiji temple. Beautiful and peaceful but not necessarily unique or the best among Japanese gardens. Not a must see for the admission price of 900 yen, which is on the high side compared to other attractions.

We spent about an hour here after walking about 15 minutes from Nara Park. There were hardly visitor when we were there so we strolled leisurely around the garden. It was tranquil and quite beautiful. If you have an extra hour, it is worth the time to visit Isuien Garden.
Definitely worth a visit, this was one of the most beautiful settings in Japan. There were no crowds and it is a peaceful, lovely and historical garden.
More intimate than the larger public gardens. Lovely layout and planting with good borrowed landscape of the buildings in Nara park such as Nandai-mon gate, and the surrounding hills.

A beautiful and quiet Japanese garden with two ponds, nicely trimmed trees and thatched roofs buildings serving as tea houses or old rest houses. You can have a Japanese tea in the tea house while admiring the landscape sitting on tatami mats. The many maple trees make it

We were walking from Gangoji Temple to Todaiji Temple and happened to pass the entrance to this garden. We were looking for somewhere to rest in some quiet away from the crowds in Nara that day - so we popped into the garden. It was beautiful. Well landscaped and quiet. Far
This was a beautiful traditional garden in the heart of Nara. It was not very crowded because of the entrance fee. If you are a fan of gardens, then you will want to see this.

We had just visited the Temple and Buddha in Nara, which was absolutely packed with school trips. We had decided to seek out this garden. We were almost put off by the 900 yen entrance fee, but were glad we weren't. Compared to the crowds in the park and the temple, this was
Glorious 400 year old garden that is an absolute delight. The entry price is steep at 900 yen but it was the most perfect example of a Japanese garden that we saw on our trip.

We visited this garden early in the morning on our side trip to Nara. The price is a bit steep (900 yen for adults), but I think it was worth the price. The garden was absolutely stunning, and there were very few other visitors (most likely due to the steep price). If you want

Isuien is a nice Japanese Garden close to the Todai-ji Temple in Nara. There are 2 parts of the garden, one made in Edo period (17th century) and the other made in Meiji period (19th century). The entrance fee is a little bit expensive(900 yen), but it's worth visiting this

It is without doubt a beautiful garden. The attached museum is not really worth wasting time on. You can see part of it already by taking a tea in the neighbouring tea house without paying the entrance fee. There is another free garden yoshiki-en just beside it. I actually liked

We were apprehensive in paying the 900 yen entrance fee, but the tourist information center staff told us this is "the most highly rated garden in all of Japan by tourists". It's underwhelming, and even if it was free - the time isn't worth it if you're doing a day trip from

Very high entrance fee as they only sell a combo ticket with the next door shocker of a museum. The gardens are nice and some decent pictures can be taken, but it is very small and not in any way worth the money.
