The entrance fee was surprisingly high (900 yen, but that day the inside museum was closed so only 810 yen, still very expensive), so my expectations rose drastically. The garden couldn't reach them because it's true that it is quite nice but I didn't feel the awe I longed for.
Nice, quiet and scenic garden but nowhere near stunning. Nothing special about this garden especially given the entrance fee required (¥820). However, it might be more scenic during late autumn.
Although there is an entrance fee, it is worth paying it. There are some volunteers who explain the history of the gardens. It is a peaceful and wonderful place.

One reviewer complained about the entrance fee. I think it's fair, and it certainly keeps the numbers down which means those that pay and enter have a relatively peaceful garden to enjoy. Wonderful colour when we were there in April, and lots of good photos taken.
It was really peaceful and relaxing, the garden is beautiful. I wish I could visit it again. Worth it!
Stopped here on the way to Nara Park and temple area. We were greeted and offered a free Guide to show us around the gardens. The area is beautifully kept and peaceful

The entrance fee to this garden is 900Yen per adult. It is not value for money and the plants and landscape there is not that great. There are sign board all over stating please do not step on the moses. Quite annoying. There is a garden next door which is free to tourist.

Don't skip this one, it was the highlight of our Nara visit to see the two gardens.It is also very quiet in there even though Tennoji was packed with people. You can sit in peace and harmony and take in the scenery. The amount of detail within the gardens is a marvel to behold-

This zen garden was fun to visit and very beautiful. We were guided around it by a volunteer who spoke surprisingly good English so were able to learn more specific reasons for its current design. I highly recommend you ask about that. It is small though and can probably be in

I was so surprised seeing how peaceful and calm Nara was, not many tourist at all BUT the scenery ommgg so beautiful it does not lose to Kyoto at all! when i first step into Isuien garden i was just mesmerised seeing how well and beautiful they maintained the garden...the autumn

It's a beautiful garden. What can I say. I visited the garden on Oct of 2015, Thursday morning. There were 4 people in the garden besides me when I visited. There was a volunteer guide who spoke English who gave me a private tour and explained to me things that I'd never

Unfortunately it was raining the day I went to see the Isuien Garden but that didn't take away from how beautiful and breathtaking this garden is. Seeing the trees turning brown, red and yellow was a beautiful sight! The walking paths give you opportunities to take perfect

Most landscape in Japan is awe-inspiring but the beauty of the Isuien is that if you visit it first thing in the morning, you might be one of the few people there and enjoy the lovely landscape in solitude. A must visit in Nara!

Less crowded than the other attractions of Nara even on a Sunday morning. Not so easy to find so ask a policeman to find the left hand turn off the main street. Very peaceful walk to get there. BTW there is wonderful free garden next door to the right. free to any non-Japanese,

This is a lovely garden to look at before you hit the big temples! There were free English speaking guides to talk to you about the history of the place, and they take your photo with your camera! About the only pics I'm in! It costs to get in, but you also get to visit the
when we visited the gardens were really quiet, most toruists only get to see the bronze buddha so this is a ideal get away from the crowds location, lovely place to rest

This garden is a hidden gem in Nara Park. It is such a beautiful garden, but there was hardly anyone there. I suppose most people visit the major attractions first. We visited this spot on our second day and were rewarded with the visit. The adjoining Neiraku Art Museum included
Quite a large garden, lots to explore, very peaceful and a good contrast to the busyness of the Toshodaiji complex.
the entire garden is superbly landscaped! great picture opportunity! lots of flowers and very serene!
A lovely garden situated just at the fringe of Nara Park. It has a nice pond and one can take lots of pictures with Todai-ji Temple as the background.

Out of all the sites we've visited, Isuien garden is my favourite. It has such a beautiful layout besides just the main garden view. Well worth also walking along all the other small paths throughout the garden. This should be on everyones list to visit in Nara! Entry fee is a

Walking distance from Toda-ji Temple, this garden is well worth a visit. Most tourists visiting nearby Today-ji bypass this in their rush. That's good news for the traveller with more time to enjoy the garden. There's a museum on site that is also well worth a visit. Local

It was so peaceful to walk in this garden with such a beautiful view that was feast for your eyes. Everything is carefully maintained but the effort was not too apparent and it gave natural feel to this place. I was there in the beginning of autumn so the leaves have started to

This was our first stop on our trip to Nara. What a lovely garden it is! There were stunning vistas, with some leaves just beginning to change. There was a lovely pond with stepping stones to one side of a small island and a stone bridge to the other side. This was a more open

We found this little gem very enchanting and just beautiful. Way better than eg the famous Okayama garden. Isuien has it all, a pond, waterfall, tea house and more. With 3000 jpy a bit expensive especially for a family of 4. If you are not a garden fanatic , visit the free
Located Near Nara park you find this garden. Decorated in Japanese style two small ponds form the center. Quiet and peaceful to stay here for a while

This was my second time here and the garden is impeccable with fantastic landscaping. Every area was well thought out, picturesque, and breathtaking. Take the free English speaking guide tour and learn about the long rich history of this garden. The guide shared interesting

Beautiful garden, a bit small and there are nicer gardens elsewhere in Japan but if you are in Nara for a day and have time then it is worth going. Next door there is another garden and is free for foreigners.

This garden offers a peaceful moment of rest between the visits to the temples, there are very beautiful views, great for nice pictures, you can walk around or just sit and enjoy the silence and the view. Not particularly interest in the nearby museum.

One of the gardens you can visit in Nara park. We were lucky that there are a couple of very nice Japanese elderly who offered to gave us a tour of the garden, which made us fully appreciate the design and the history of the place.

We found this place recommended in the guidebook. It was quite tricky to find, and we almost gave up at one point... We were very glad we didn't. It was our favourite spot in Nara, tranquil, spiritual and painstakingly well maintained. Not as popular as the main attractions, but
We were here on a hot day in summer. A little disappointed that there wasn't much blooming, but still worth a 30 minute walk through to get away from the world.

The best Japanese Garden we have seen in this trip, we have been to Osaka, Nara, Kobe, Kyoto, Tokyo, this Isuien Garden has all the Japanese tea Garden feature in one. It is not easy to find Isuien, it is so close to Todaiji Temple, but no signs to direct you, have to ask

Really don't understand why this garden is rated so high, there are way better gardens in the Kansai area. Maybe because we visited in June, but still, in the fall or spring other places would be prettier too. Anyways, I thought the Manyo/Shinen Botanical garden was more

This was one of the most beautiful gardens we saw on our trip - and we saw a lot of gardens! It is not a huge garden but big enough to spend maybe up to an hour wandering around. There are two large ponds, front and back with fabulous landscaping, trees, shrubs, rock features

My wife and two sons visited back in April. We spent around an hour here before going over towards Todai-Ji. The garden is beautiful and picturesque. We were fortunate enough to have a tour guide show us around (free of charge and refused to take payment!) and he was very
I had a very nice experience with volunteer tour guide Hideyuki-san. He gave a great tour and very kind person! Thanks a lot!

This garden can be easily done in half an hour. Its very close to nara deer park so we decided to stop by. It may be small but it is stunningly beautiful. yes the 900Y fee is steep but the work that goes into this garden does make it worth it.
I wouldn't understand somebody who doesn't like this garden. Quintessential Japanese garden. Perfection.

If you want to visit a typical Japanese garden you should definitely visit Isuien Garden. The entrance fee is quite expensive with 900 Yen but worth. You can see all the tree mountains around Nara from this Garden. You should sit down for a moment and enjoy the view and the
Gardeners work hard but don't overwork the garden; weeds are kept down but the other plants are allowed to grow just a bit wild. It makes for a really lovely result.
A nice Japanese garden. Small and interesting. Not more. if you are here, do not miss it. This is not the main attraction in Nara park.

I could only give this 3 stars since it certainly is a beautiful and peaceful garden, in a land full of beautiful and peaceful gardens. Not as impressive as a place like Shukkein in Hiroshima. Full of tea houses around the lake, I would have given a higher rating if not for the

It is a private garden and has some very beautiful scenes. Great if you are a photography lover. Not sure it worth the money of 900 yen. But, it does offer a museum to watch and a locker to put your bags while you watch the park, FREE!

Not to be missed, especially if you've enjoyed some of the Kyoto gardens. Down the hill from Todaiji. In terms of must sees, I rank this just below the Kofukuji and Todaiji treasure houses (medieval Buddhist wooden sculptures) and above the Kasuga jina and certainly the Nara
This is a very cute little garden located a five minute walk from Todaji temple. You could spend thirty minutes walking around it. There is also the possibility to partake in a tea ceremony there.
Start your Nara tour from this garden. There is another garden located next to this one. Nara park and todaijji temple are just meters away from this garden

This garden is quite a long walk from the main area, but can be combined with a trip to the Todeji. We arrived at 4.30pm just in time for the last entry, but to be honest 30 minutes was enough to walk round the garden as it is small. The little museum was closed so get there
Definitely one of the most beautiful garden I have ever seen -- and Japanese gardens are beautiful in general anyway. I simply couldn't believe how amazing it is. A definite must.

I visited in April in the rain and the cherry blossoms were out. It was lovely. I would like to see it a few weeks later when the azaleas are blooming. You must see this garden and have tea in the tea house!

With Cherry Blossoms in full bloom, this traditional Japanese garden provided a lovely atmosphere for a stroll and a break from the crowds of Nara park. The beautifully delicate landscaping is interesting to explore and neat surprises are all around. Highly recommended.
trying to kill a few hours in the rain we found this little gem..take advantage of the free guides.. yes really free not a scam….you learn so much from them

I stumbled across Isuien Garden while walking through Nara on my way to Todai-ji. The entrance fee was for both the museum and the garden, and while I was not very impressed by the museum, the garden definitely made up for it! The garden was extremely serene and fairly secluded.
This is what a Japanese garden should be. It is immaculately kept and most refined and delicate, with some lovely detail at every turn. Well worth a visit.

My husband and I spent the day in Nara today which was a welcome adventure away from Kyoto (which has been quite dissapointing). We visited Isuien Garden as part of a guided free tour by a lovely man Tetsuo who works for the NPO Nara Guide Club. Even though today's temperature

Very nice garden, in Nara park. Very quiet and relaxing, to rest a bit from the crowds visiting the rest of places. The ticket is a bit expensive (900 ¥) but includes the museum with some beautiful art from XVII and XVIII century

There was only 2 other people there when I visited. The entrance was quite expensive at 900Y but this included a free guided tour (in excellent english) and the small museum next door. Wonderfully manicured garden...and great example of thatched Japanese buildings
We enjoyed exploring this traditional Japanese garden, which although in January was still quite lovely.

This garden is the quintessential, gorgeous, immaculate Japanese garden. It has everything you would want in a Japanese garden: calm, serene spots; lovely vistas; some historical structures; contemplative scenery; beautiful plants and trees; and, water features. The scale is
Entry fee is 900 yen (adults) 500 yen (teenager) for both garden and museum. It is not stressful to walk around in this medium size garden but not much flowers blooming as it is winter.

November is a great time to visit since the foliage changes color now! Excepted for one cherry tree that is blossoming in Oct-nov (also now), get to the back of the property to find it. Worthwhile noting: volunteers from the YMCA offer free guided tours. Today Mrs. Yasuko did a
A traditional Japanese style garden. Great for a pleasant stroll away from the crowds, with numerous attractive spots for photographs.
An awe inspiring garden with an awe inspiring backcloth of the mountains. Well worth setting aside time to sit, admire, walk and think.

This garden is a perfect break from the bustle of the crowds and tourists in Nara. Entry is slightly expensive but is also next to Yoshikien Garden which has free entry, so in reality you might be paying for both. Very manicured and carefully planned layout with a wonderful

Very beautiful garden, but I think it's expensive compared to other gardens. If you like nature, I'm sure you're gonna live it! I went about 4pm, so there were shadow in some places. I think it would be even better going about noon.
After the crowds of the Todaiji temple this garden provides a tranquil break. A compact location but with lovely vistas and colours

Well with a visit to be away from the crowds. The price is on the high side and the museum a waste of time. But I would happily pay again. Also I would recommend visiting in the morning as the light will be best for photos

Seems a steep price to stroll a garden path off the beaten path. Nevertheless, garden affectionatos will beat a path to this gem worth at least a nine dollar fifty cent toll. ( caveat, handicapped access highly difficult )

Typical Japanese garden worth a visit to let your mind come to rest when you stroll through. Next to this garden there is another (free) garden which is also worth while

Not sure it is worth all the hype. Very nicely groomed, 2 ponds, but not sure what differentiates it from other gardens.

This garden itself is worth a visit to Nara. Not so easy to find, but if you have a map and GPS, it is not hard. There is an admission fee but worth it. When you enter the garden, you are presented with a stunning view already. Every few steps you take, you find a different
Do visit sanshu restaurant for lunch when you're nearby. It's abit more pricy but you get to sit back, relax and enjoy the stunning view in the hut while sipping on tea.
…where you would like to be lost for the rest of your life, - but at least reserve two or three hours for a visit, especially if you are a keen photographer

Isuen Garden is a wonderfull place to be to tank energy and enjoy nature. I loved the entrence and loved waking arround the garden and each corder has someting to show: the river, the pond, the hill and even the fine restaurant is worth see

The garden was absolutely silent and we had the whole place to ourselves, to wonder around past the streams, pond and mossy areas. A really great place to wander and enjoy the spring weather, and a great opportunity to take some photos with no other tourists in the picture.
This is one of the most beautiful garden that we have seen in Japan, not so much crowd, very peaceful, and stunning landscape. Great colors in Autumn.

Isuien Garden is absolutely beautiful, especially the rear garden, where you can see Mount Wakakusayama and part of Todaiji in the background. We were there on Saturday during cherry blossom season and we still had the garden largely to ourselves. It was so peaceful to walk

This garden is paradise. We came here after visiting the busy Tōdai-ji with thousands of other tourists right around the corner. And here - silence. We have been almost alone in this wonderful place with it's lakes and beautiful pavilions. A must see for everyone visiting Nara!

Peaceful, and lots to see in the garden. Its a good place to get away from the crowded spots in Nara. While I do feel that it is like most Japanese gardens, there are certain areas that differ from the rest such as moss gardens, places that seem like forests from fairy tales, a
Partitioned in several areas this very old garden has breathtaking spots and a nice view on the Todaiji temple. One of Nara's main attractions and not to be missed.
it's the best garden I have ever seen or step my foot into! Beautiful is a small word to describe this garden! It's an experience!

This is a lovely garden, very peaceful and easy on the eyes. You can get around the garden in less than one hour, but try to allow more time and relax - you will enjoy the experience much more. It is so easy to get distracted in Nara as there are so many attractions; this is

We didn't expect to see such a lovely formal garden in Nara. We were there in mid-October, and there were a few trees that had already begun to turn. It would be spectacular in mid-Nov. The adjoining museum of ancient artifacts is worth a short visit as well.

My husband now says that when he needs to think of a happy place this (and the other beautiful place place next door) are where he's thinking of.... Can not help make anyone feel like there is nothing wrong with the world! Beautiful tranquil place.

In this oasis of tranquility you're constantly surrounded by magnificent nature incl. various ponds, stone paths, pavilions and gardens, etc. Trees and flowers blossoming during Sakura left me stunned and the atmosphere was very special indeed. Close proximity to Nara Park made

We really enjoyed this garden as well as Yoshikien garden which is right next door. Both gardens are worth a visit. Isuien was very scenic and had great opportunities for getting pictures of and exploring a true Japanese garden. It's an easy walk from Nara park nearby.

Well worth a visit. My kids had fun crossing the little bridges and walking on the stones over the streams. Beautiful, serene garden.
I had expected to be bigger but when you walk around you will love it. Just relax next to the tea house and enjoy the view. the entry fee is 650 including entry to the museum.

Its a small garden, but is manicured with trees, plants- all well placed. It is bordered by what I call a Forest-hill which emits a nice pine forestry scent. There is a private garden with a pond towards the end, to which you may enter for a fee. Not a must to see Isuien, but

This garden was probably my favorite of the many gardens we visited in Japan. Something about the view looking from the teahouse over the pond to the trees and hills, there is not an unpleasant thing in sight. Everything seemed so balanced and lovely from that view point.

For nature lovers and get the chance to see a real Japanese garden. Very pretty and close to it there another one, smaller, and free. I went to the botanic garden too and well not worth a visit. The Isuien is much better.

From the outside the gardens look very unimpressive..as are the front part of the gardens once you enter. So much so that I felt ripped off when we entered the front garden. However, then you walk around to the back/main garden and are simply stunned by the near perfect view
Ok, 600 yen cover charge seems high for a small garden, but the garden is peaceful and just another 'I'd like to have a garden like this at home'.
The Yoshikien Gardens next door are free to people with a foreign passport and are lovely. Save yourself a bit of money.

First we visited the neighboring garden, which was wonderful (and free!). Then we came to Isuien Garden, which costs 600 yen. We debated... and entered, and didn't regret it one bit. 'Twas a lovely garden, built to take advantage of the surrounding hillside, while at the same

google: Beautiful Zen garden.  It is rather small but we still spent an hour taking in the scenery around 2 ponds, bridges, stepping stone paths and several small tea houses. Admission is 900 yen per person but we felt it was money well spent. Entry is from a street right outside of Nara Park.
Well worth visiting if you like gardens.  A tour guide was available to explain some of the design thinking.
Very peaceful and good place to relax the mind. For photography is very recommended

text.quote: This rebuilt 8th-century temple serves as the primary temple for the Buzan sect of Shingon Buddhism.
trip: what a peaceful place ！ I have been there with my wife. Weather was bad but we enjoyed a lot. Highly Recommending.

We made a stop in this little town only because we wanted to see the temple, it was really worth going there... the cherry trees were in full blossom, the way to go to the temple, going up the stairs was really nice, we loved the atmosphere of the place.
朝早く訪れました。紅葉が綺麗に色付いていて、参拝客も少なく、ゆっくりと紅葉を楽しむ事が出来ました。特に内舞台から望む紅葉、五重の塔は美しいです。 We visited there early in the morning.Colored leaves were beautiful,quiet and peace.

It was one of my favourite temples which I visited in Japan. It was much more quiet then other places in Nara or Kyoto. Thanks to it mountainous location it has special feeling about it. Especially when Buddhist monks starting chanting prayers. I would recommend it to anyone
I've seen many beautiful temples, but this one has an amazing view of the town and the sea. The Hydrangea path is gorgeous.

Please pay a visit to this temple if you would like to explore more of Nara. Is much less crowded compare to those temples in Nara or Kyoto. Visited in spring and although passed the cherry blossom peak season, is still lovely. If is a raining day, the scene just pop.

『雨でも寺院内を巡りその魅力を感じられる場所』として紹介いただいた寺院ですが、それ以上の神秘的な雰囲気が感じられる寺院だと思います。境内の多くの建物が木造で、中には百年以上の歴史が刻まれたものもあり、触れるだけでも、その歴史の積み重ねを感じられるでしょう。 山腹の崖に建造されただけに、本堂の舞台からの眺めは絶景です。紅葉の名所でもあり、境内が朱や黄に色鮮やかに染まりますが、雨の日はその上に霧が発生し、幻想的な風景を作り上げます。
My only wish is to have visited here on a cooler day. The reward of the beauty of this temple and its surroundings is worth the effort that is required to walk from the train station to here.

This event used to do on 14th.feb. you can watch evils and a fire-pole performance that day only.

After viewing a video (Title: "Nara: Tranquil temples and bountiful blooms "), I have decided to visit Hasedera (長谷寺)—one of the famous flowers temples in Nara area. From the stock images on Google, Hasedera seems to look even better with blooming flowers in the springtime. For

I strongly recommend you to visit this temple during Peony Festival (end of April ~ beginning of May), when the site is turned into a mountain of peonies. It is absolutely enchanting! You can forget everyday life and plunge into nature.

Famous for ith flowers throughtout the year, especially for the peonies, hydrengeas and cherry blossoms. I love the sight from the terrace of the main hall. Magnificent view, much more impressive than from famous Kiyomizu temple in Kyoto!

Amazing literally get off the bus front the station, about 15minutes and straight away you can see Deer crossing the road lying in the grass next to the road. Such a wonderful sight. We found a place a five minute walk from where we got off that sold deer cookies for 150yen then
Beware while feeding the deer. They bite, push, and surround the person. The temple is good slight to see.

From the JR Nara station, it's about a 30 min walk to the park. As you enter through the park gate, you begin to see deer all around. There are biscuit vendors throughout the park selling a pack for 150Y. It is advised not to feed the deer any other types of outside foods

If you are visiting Osaka, make sure you put Nara on your itinerary. It’s very easy to get to, take a JR train will get you to Nara station, from there a short ride on bus will reach Nara park. Quite a big park that roam with heaps of deer and you would find vendor selling snack

Nara Park offers a nature encounter unlike any other in Japan. Hundreds of deer, regarded as messengers of the gods in the Shinto religion, roam freely in the park. Being able to interact with them is almost like a spiritual experience. The deer are tame and affectionate, and

Fascinating being surrounded by wild deer that remain tame enough to pat. They roam the park freely coercing visitors to feed them....many vendors selling not too cheap bags of biscuits for those willing to part with their money for a great photo feedding the deerr.

The park is a pretty nice place to stroll around and feed some bowing deer. We were expecting a small herd and smaller deer. But there are a ton of deer here and they are pretty big. Tame and calm too. And they love the biscuits. If you let them bow then give them a bit of

The day in Nara Park was my favorite day of my Japan trip. Where else in the world can you wander around feeding deer that will bow to you? Nara was very easy to get to from Osaka and was ~40 min to travel to. We didn’t have the JR Pass but you can take the local lines. Once you

The deer are quite tame and comfortable around people... but are aggressive with food. Be sure to keep your hands visible to show them you don't have any food, or they'll pester you and pull at your cloths/bags.

Nara Park is quite a surprise. You don't have to even set foot inside the park to see deer streaming out. It's quite a sight. There are many vendors selling special deer biscuits for 150 yen. I think it's that price everywhere around the park. The deer in the park are actually

We visited this park because we were going to Todaiji temple and I just fell in love with the deers. They sell cookies so you can feed them, they are not shy to ask for food and some of them even bowed for it. I will give this half a day.

We couldn't decide whether to visit the deer park while in Japan, but we decided to get up early and go! It was worth it in the end, but highly recommend getting there early because by 10-11am the place is flooded with tourists and the deer don't seem as happy. We arrived by
Visited the famous Nara deers. Docile and only interested in humans with deer snack. Snacks are sold at fixed price by vendors at various points in the park.
Extremely beautiful park, lots of deer, people walk between them and tourits may also feed them offering special snacks.

The big attraction are the deers in the Nara Park, almost 1200 of them spread over the natural surroundings of the Nara Park. As one starts walking from the parking area to the Buddha temple, one can find all the deers around. One can buy crackers for 150 jpy each packet (has

The park has museums as well, but the deer seem to be the big draw. Suggestion: Try to go on a cooler day, and have comfortable walking shoes - it's a big place! Watch your clothing, maps, and purse, as the deer seem omnivorous!

First time saw this place with many deer’s and they are friendly . If you want to feed them you can buy some crackers for them . Nearby restaurant was serving eel bento and ramen o try one ramen noodles here. I came here with the bus from train station consider here is

We can pet the deers, feed them with deer biscuit and leaves and also take photo with them. Kids love it too(some are afraid though). My 6 year old daughter said it’s the Japan trip highlight after Disneyland. But somehow many deers look unhealthy and thin. It’s also very

We took the commuter train from Osaka to Nara station. Another 14 minutes walk , just follow the crowd , and you reach the park. So many places, temples and a museum to see, you should take as a minimum a half day. When you are there, meet the deers.

Always wary of attractions with animals but needn't have been here. The deer are truly free to wander around as they please, and there are plenty of fenced off areas they can go for some quiet time away from all the people. There is also plenty of fresh water on offer for them
A must see when you visit Nara. Be enthralled by the deers and the Buddha temple Best visited during cherry blossom season

Had a great time on our day trip to Nara from Kyoto. It was a short 45 minute ride from Kyoto Station using the JR line. No need to make seat reservations. Visited the temple which was nice but we didn’t bother paying to go in since we have been to so many temples already. We

There are lots of deer here. They are cute, friendly, and are fun to feed. You can buy cookies to feed the deer (vendors all around sell them). If you want to feel like a superhero, feed the deer early in the day (but watch out they may want to eat all your cookies). Later in

Nara park is full of small deers who mingle weith the tourists in the anticiaption of being fed with deer crackers being sold there at a cost of 150 Yen. The deer are very sweet but should be trated with some respect and can get a bit "pushy " if they think you have some

The main feature of the park is a heavy population of deer that have learned to beg for food and when approached right, will bow for food. However, they also leave their droppings everywhere and can charge tourists, grab items you did not intend to give them, etc. Overall, a

Park Nara boasts one of the densest concentrations of UNESCO world heritage sites in the world. There are the main sites of Nara here: Todaiji temple, Kofuku-JI temple and Kasuga Shrine. However, not that remains in the memory, and a huge number of deer, of which there are more

Nice park, very clean and full of deers. There are people on the streets that sells the deers crackers, I think they know and from time to time they are a little aggressive if you don't give them the cracker.

Beautiful grounds and the deer are great fun. They can be really pushy so do make sure that your backpack or bag is fully zipped up. One actually used it's antlers to try to unhook my bag from my shoulder! If you hold your hands up in the air above you the deer will "bow"
What a great morning. The deer are everywhere! All very friendly and eager for a deer cracker. 150 yen for a pack which was reasonable. Beautiful surroundings.

This is a very large park area with deer everywhere. Gardens and Temples make for nice walks although the large Todajii temple area is busy. There are deer everywhere but beware they can be aggressive going after food. You can buy small packs of crackers for 150yen but as soon

You can see the deers almost as soon as you steal out of the train station. They don’t only stay inside the park, but they also cross the streets and wonder around the city. The park itself is very beautiful, with different temples and things to see. If you decide to buy the

Nara Park isn’t difficult to miss. Whenever one mentions Nara, one thinks of deer. Legend has it that the deer are offspring of a sacred white deer from Kashima Shrine and are messengers of the gods. There are signs throughout the Park advising that the deer are to be fed

It's always a pleasure to watch animals allowed to roam free. No cages, just the freedom to wander, graze, look around and not be alarmed by human company. Nara Deer Park is one such haven. One can spend the entire day in this beautifully maintained nature park, bow to the deer

Beautiful park with the deers. Get up close and personal and spend time with the deers. The park is massive and the deers are confined. They are freely roaming around the park and tourist can feed them with the crackers that are being sold in the park for a very small amount.

Walking near, feeding and taking pictures with the deer was amazing. Yes, the deer do bow before you feed them their cookie! The deer cookies can be bought from vendors around the park. It can be busy, but there are lots of deer around! It is important to note to feed them a

Visited recently to take in the Golden Buddha and the deer around the temple and park. Beautiful place and the temple was awesome. The deer are friendly (particularly if you have food) but very entertaining in there own way. A great way to spend a few hours.
This park is famous for its deer. I heard they have been around for hundreds of years. They learned to bow for the food, which is very interesting!

The park and surrounding area is lovely. The deers are very friendly so if you are scared of animals this place may not be for you . Only buy the deer wafers if you want to feed them, break them in half to make them last longer. Bow to the 🦌 it will bow back to you.

Easy train ride from osaka (or kyoto) for a day trip. Love the deer, and they are everywhere. If you want to get away from the crowds go further up. We loved feeding the deer (and yes they can get very aggressive once they know you have food). If that distresses you, dont buy

Deers found in every corner of the park! They will not hesitate to look to you for crackers, even to the extent of nudging you or even biting you. At least they would be 'polite' about it by giving the standard Nara deer bow. Which makes it hard to resist giving them the treat.

A visit to Japan wouldn’t be complete without feeding the deer in Nara. The "deer cookies" are sold throughout the park and can be fed to the deer. You have to raise your hand with the cookie first, wait for them to bow, and then feed it. They are so adorable when they bow!

It is unusual to get so close to a wild animal. But years of being hand fed by tourists have made them very docile. They are every where, and so is their poop! So be careful where you tread. Plenty of vendors selling food for the deer. Plenty of photo opportunities.

I admit at first glance it’s nice being so close to the animals, that are walking around freely, and to take pictures and videos. However, this aw-effect starts to wear off very quickly and you start to see the negative aspects. 1) the fur of the deer does look unhealthy. This
Love all the deer walking around. Easy to buy crackers to feed them. They can get aggressive if you done give them the crackers, but one of the coolest experience!

Had an absolute blast feeding the deer here. First warning: the deer here are not shy. On the contrary, they can get quite aggressive. (parents of kids please take note!) Once they know you have food, they'll shove you, nip at your pants, push their noses into your hands, and
The park is very nice and designed to host a lot of tourists. The deer are friendly and welcoming especially when you feed them with specific deer crackers. The signs can be improved.

We Enjoyed feeding and petting the deers but, the deer tend to be aggressive and they poke your behind begging for more cookies. We were lucky to see the wisteria in full bloom. ¥500 entrance fee was worth it. The deers were roaming freelt.

This is a huge and lovely park, with a great museum and several separate UNESCO sites worth a visit. It's also home to the quasi-tame sacred deer; the deer run the place, and most of the cit near the park, and can get pretty feisty when they think you've got food, to the point
Deers were very cute and gentle. Weather was good, Nice place for a walk. You can buy deer feed for 150yen yo feed the deers. You can also walk through the park to the todaiji temple.

I visited Nara as a day trip from Kyoto. It's about an hour by train. This is a nice park to have a walk in spring. The deer in the park are an attraction. It's fun to watch. Search for the quieter places to escape the crowds.

Awesomely fun place for young and old. By the time we reached Nara, we had seen many deer. Nara's deer has a history of more than 1000 years. They are known as the Oracles, loved and protected. Nara's mascots are deer. There are about 1,200 wild deer in Nara Park. They are very

The main attraction of Nara are the deer roaming the park grounds freely instead of caged or in an enclosure. People can feed the deer with biscuits and take pictures up close. The novelty wears off quite easily though and you notice the negative aspects such as deer poop lying

As soon as you get off the bus you’ll want to buy biscuits and feed the deer. Don’t. Get walking up hill and it gets quieter about 20 minutes in. Go all the way up and we found some younger, less aggressive deer who were more than happy to wait for the biscuits. The views from

Really easy to get here for a day trip from Kyoto. A lot of walking involved, but well worth it to get to see the giant Buddha in that beautiful temple. Other temples and a gorgeous little garden on the way, plus of course, the almost tame deer.

This park's nearest station is Kintetsu-Nara Station. From the station, it is about 10 to 15 mins walk till you hit the inner park. There are a lot of deers roaming around freely for you to feed. Along the path from the station, there will be some vendors selling the biscuits

Great day trip and worth a visit purely for the todeji and deer park. No where else have I seen deer so tame and willing to come near and interact with humans. If you now and choose the right temperment of deer you’re bound to get a good shot! For example some of the deer at the

There's a lot of cute deers! Nuff' said right? You just need 2-3 hours looking around the area, play with the deers, go to the Big Buddha temple just 10 mins walk away. It was a very simple place to visit, you don't need to rush for anything and it makes it so relaxing to

So this was a visit to allow my 2.5year old to enjoy the company of the deers but the deers nearer to the train station on the way to the park are definitely conditioned to be way more aggressive than they should be. The term gentle deer didn’t go so well with my kid when a deer

The main attraction here is definitely the deers. When you feed them with crackers, they bow you after that. So sweet. You can walk around the park and feed the deers as often as you want. Some of them behave better than others. The park itself is nice, with lovely picture

it was really a good experience for my family specially my kids to have a close encounter with the deers at the Nara park. We fed the deer and they were very tame. you can buy and feed the deer with the deer senbei at 150jpy You can touch them and have photo with them without

My wife and I were here on a Gate1 tour, with Optional Excursion to Nara Park. If you are in a hurry, most likely you can see everything within 2-3 hours. As with most attractions in Japan, very well organized (and of course, extremely clean!). We enjoyed seeing the deer and

Went on a weekday afternoon. A pretty decent walk from the train station. Fun to feed the deer, they were quite tame in the evening. Maybe they were full from all the other tourists feeding them throughout the day.

Managed to cover all the 3 shrines and the deers in Nara within 2 hours upon arriving in Nara. In Japan, everything is well organized and nearby. A day trip is sufficient for those wanting to see the deer

If you really feel lonely in Nara and want to do some socializing, the deer of the Nara Park would welcome you among their midst. Beautiful park that engulfs within its premises shrines, temples, gardens, and deer. If it is a short stay in Nara, do spend a full day at the park.

Nice place for relax and watching deers and feed them with rice crackers which you can buy on every corner. So you can relax and rest before you will continue to enjoying beauty of Nara. Please just really don't feed the deers with anything else or you can harm this beautiful

The deer at Nara park roam around freely and seek food from visitors. It can get very busy in Nara but still worthwhile checking out these deer.

Nara is an amazing city, probably the nicest in Japan. Over 1.000 deers are walking on the streets and in the park and you can feed them or play with them. The temple is amazing and the entire atmosphere is really great.

This place is amazing! Not only does it have beautiful historical temples for the adults to see, but all the deers also kept my 2 young kids entertained. They had great fun feeding those deers. Be careful of the males, they get aggressive. This is not to be missed when you

A fun place to walk around. The deer are an added bonus. For a price you get these wafers that you feed the deer and they will come feed from your hands. Keep in mind that these are still wild animals and treat them with respect. We noticed a few people tease them with the
nice place to relax, pet friendly deer, feed them and take a strall towards the Todaiji temple. lots of photo opportunities

This is a must-do if you’re in Nara. The park itself doesn’t actually feel that big when you’re walking around it so that might contribute to it feeling very busy. There are lots of little stalls within the park selling deer crackers for 150 yen for around 8 crackers.

You can spend the day in Nara. There are so many deers - not just in the park but around the whole area in the lead up to the temple. You can buy crackers for 150 Yen and the deers will not leave you alone if they know you have food. Best to break them in half so they last

I do think that it is a great place for all ages since the deer are usually friendly, but I does warn that they are wild animals and they can attack on some occasions. The people there do sell you special deer crackers to feed the deer with and if you to the deer nod the deer

This is one of those places that can easily be one of the most cherished memories of Japan or quickly forgotten. It all depends when you go. If you go during the day, rush hour, evening... I don't think you will be very much impressed. The secret to this place, to have a magical
Quite an experience feeding the deers. The deers are lovely and polite. Fun to try to take a wefie with them!

It is easy to get to Nara from either Kyoto or Osaka, and it is another must do site along with Arashiyama. Tour the UNESCO world heritage sites, yes, multiple. Take a walk off the beaten path either in Nara Park or to the deeper shrines. The tranquility is another world from

This was at the top of my list once we booked our Kyoto trip. It's about an hour train from Kyoto, so it is a bit of a trek, but it's worth it (FYI - it's also about in hour from Osaka so you can also use that as your jumping point). Once you get to Nara station, the park is

The deer were so cute! If you have some food (you can buy deer crackers for ¥150, but we were also given some acorns by a lovely old man on a bicycle!), they will literally mug you! It was so funny - they don't hurt, but they will nip you (they kept biting my butt!). If you have

These are WILD ANIMALS first and foremost. If you do plan on getting the deer crackers (deer feed sold at every corner of every road and junction in the park), be ready to be a deer magnet - they will come from far and wide to get the cracker out of your hand. We find the deer
Nice litte park in Nara - a good option for a relaxed, cheap day out. You can see the deer, buy deer 'cookies' to feed them, take some lovely photos amongst the cherry blossoms, or just chill out.
Really cute to have lot of deer’s all around you. They are little aggressive so be careful with food and your bags. Apart from that they really are very cute.
This is a nice area to go for a walk. There are lots of deer- you can buy crackers to feed them and most of them are well behaved!

The park houses many shrines and temples as well as many interesting sights.the closest part of the park to the 2 stations is reached from eat street. This closest section has the most deer as they are being fed by hordes of tourists all day long. further into the park you will

I know deers prefer to stay in the wild even if they are easy prey for fierce animals. But Nara is unique, deers roam freely sometimes they gently bonk your bags for cookies. Only feed them sold JPY150 cookies from vendors. I also had my takoyaki here which is so scrumptious.

History, scenery, wildlife, fresh air and exercise - a perfect day out. The deer are more friendly than we imagined possible, especially if you buy the special cookies to feed them. We caught the end of the blossom season which made the day even more special.

This place is pretty cool, deer feeding is a must, if you bow at them they will bow back to you. But be careful, if they think you have food and you turn your back on them, they will bite you on the bum.
All those deer r free to walk around U can even see some of them r walking on the road with car driving behind them Interesting U can also buy some biscuit to feed them What an interesting experience

The park is beautiful and the deer roam freely. But be aware that they can be aggressive, especially if you have any food. Also be sure to watch where you walk or your shoes may be covered in something unpleasant.

The park is very pretty and very big. There are free roaming deer everywhere. The deer are friendly and bow if you bow to them. Please respect the deer and don't tease them with food like I saw some people doing. Yes, they will chase after you if you have food readily available.
Beautiful park with wild deers that would eat from your hand. Food vendors and ponds. Just be careful because they will eat your clothes :)
Highly recommend if you have extra time to play with Deer, there are also cultural place to visit such as shrines and temples.

I would highly recommend doing a tour to Nara. It's a massive place and apparently has 80 shrines/temples, but the main reason we went was for the deer. There are hundreds roaming around everywhere, and are just so chilled and friendly. When we visited, unfortunately there was a

Day trip on catch from Osaka after visiting Kyoto. The park itself is quite large with many deer roaming freely. They will come to you if you are feeding them with food which can be bought from the stall. The deer do bow when receiving food. There is a large wooden temple in the
Definitely must visit park. Wild deer so tame. Snacks on sale at park for feeding.deer do bow if u bow and feed them.be cautious some deer can be aggressive.

Nara park is a beautiful park that houses 1200 deer throughout. They have learnt to bow to receive the special deer crackers you can feed them. However some a pushy and will bite at your jacket if you don’t pay them attention.

We went to Nara to see the deer after seeing online recommendations and also the recommendations of friends. It was fun to see the deer roaming so closely around Nara and to see them 'bowing'. We enjoyed the gardens - really really enjoyed the Isuien and Yoshiken Garden more!

Like others report if you can wake up early and based inTokyo get there by 8:15am to enjoy deer feeding. 150Yen will get you the special Deer Senebi crackers and they can be bought all over the park at the same price. Arrive at Kintetsu station, it’s right on the doorstep of

As you approach Nara Park, you can see as baby deers roaming the park as people. They are pretty harmless and some may pose for pictures with you but if you have a deer biscuit in hand, they will love you!! The deer biscuits are 150 Yen and available along the park by street

Saw so many people feeding any old thing to the deer. If you must then buy the silly deer biscuits but don’t feed them your sandwich or your map. They are completely habituated to people and don’t understand what’s good for them. Just think. What is a deer supposed to eat??
This park is very nice, deer are everywhere. And there are more than you can imagine. You can buy food to give them but they will start following you. They also poop all over so watch your steps.

The buildings are breathtaking and the scale of the park, the Buddhas, temple, pagodas is stunning, but particularly during cherry blossom season it is a tourist zoo. It’s still very enjoyable to visit and you can get good clear views of everything, but if I go again I would

It was a perfect day at Nara. A bit difficult to get there via Osaka since the trains are all confusing. It was nice and sunny outside and there were SOOOOOO many deer! You can get crackers for them for like 5 USD. And it's more than enough to feed them. An amazing
Nice day out in Nara. The deer are fun for every age. All hotspots of Nara are within 20 mins walking distance. Come in spring when the cherry trees are in bloom!
Lovely park , very relaxing walk among the temples and the deer who do anything for a biscuit! Very relaxing.

We visited Nara park in March, the weather was so good and it was such a warm day, which definitely helped. It was so much fun to walk around and get to spend some time with the deer - watching them bow politely and getting to feed them biscuits (you can buy these at the park

It is a nice walk thru the park with lots of deer that love human beings for the food they get. They have also been trained to bow, a sign that they are requesting food. Stone lanterns line the path - very large number of these heavy sculptures!

When visiting Nara Japan, the Nara Park is a place that visitors will pass through en-route to Isuien Garden, Todaiji and Kasuga Shine. You'll see many deer roaming around the park, on the pathways, and sometimes on the less-busy roads. Multiple vendors can be seen at the park
We visited here from Kyoto by train and was worth the effort. We arrived early which was a good thing as it was very busy by the time we left just after 1pm.

The park is very nice with deers everywhere bit it is crowded. There some spectacular trees, the walk around the park and temple is very easy. The park is clean and well maintained. It was a wonderful visit even with the crowd.

There are a lot of deers here, and some may be quite aggressive, so don't attract too many deers at once, and don't tease them with the deer senbei. Don't feed them with food other than the sika senbei sold inside the park. (These are sold for only 150 yen, so just buy and
An experience you should not miss. The park is just amazing. The local government is so helpful with a lot of free facilities and information points.

It's a great place to visit all year round. Purchase some senbei for the deer and you are gold. Would advise to stay away from the more aggressive male deers though, they tend to bite at your belongings if you taunt them with food.

Yes, if you have time in kyoto then its worth taking the train to Nara to see, feed and touch some of the hundred deers running freely in this huge park. The park has some temples and cherryblossom trees also. There is no entrance free to this park. The deers are cute and you

We went here on our way to temples and shrines. There are deer everywhere. You buy special cookies for 150 yen to feed them. If they see you have cookies they can get a little aggressive. You are supposed to just go ahead and feed the ones close to you and not try and chose. The

The Nara deer are all over the park and around the temples around the park. They are quite docile and it’s good fun feeding them with the special snacks sold by vendors around the park and temples. Some of the deer also know how to bow to receive the snacks!

If you’re in Osaka or Kyōto you definitely have to take the 30-60min train to nara! Take a walk from the station to the deers. It’s really nice to see and get close to the mostly free animals. Buy some deer crackers and feed them! But be careful 😉
We weren't actually here to feed the deers. However, it was fun seeing them and added to the ambience of the place. The park itself is nothing spectacular.

The scenery was great, sakura were beautiful! However, lots of very noisy tourists. It was so annoying we decided to leave early. Be sure to check Yoshikien Garden, which is right next to Nara Park: free for foreigners, and much more calm than Nara Park!

Do hide the deer biscuits once you had purchased them cos the deers will finish them up within seconds 😭 Do save some further up for cuter deers which are less aggressive and in exchange for better photos

A great park - busy though. The deer really do bow to you and are very happy to be stroked - especially when you have the 'deer biscuits' that you can buy from vendors there. They can smell them a mile off!
There are tons of people and the deer are completely tame. They run up to you if they think you have food. It could be a nice place to walk around but beware of the crowds.

Soo many deer around and a first time seeing them not afraid people, coming up so close in the open. You start feeding one, they all gather and start to surround you and headbutt you for food. Its quite hilarious seeing kids getting surrounded soo fast.

a wonderful natural place! unfortunately when we were there the trees have not yet bloomed, but still a beautiful place! we can only imagine how beautiful it is when everything is pink! Absolutely great attraction are deer at the same way that you can feed bought cookies!
It's one of highlights in my home town of Nara. Feed the deer and they'll chase you for sometime. It's a great place to see cherry blossom in spring and autumn colors in fall.

The place is worth visiting period. So manny memories from the few hours that we spent there the first day, I will go back tomorrow to watch the rest but it was already worth it.

Me and my partner really enjoyed our trip to Nara Park. Famously to feed the deer, and as well as visiting the various temples. We didn’t expect for there to be a big market on too, which was a plus so we could buy some street food (yakitori, takoyaki etc)

We have been here twice over 9 years, this time with our young boys that loved it as much as us, especially with the deer everywhere and being able to pet and feed them!

text.wiki:
The Shōsō-in (正倉院) is the treasure house that belongs to Tōdai-ji in Nara, Nara, Japan. The building is in the azekura log-cabin style, with a raised floor. It lies to the northwest of the Daibutsuden (which houses the Great Buddha). The Shōsō-in houses artifacts connected to Emperor Shōmu (701–756) and Empress Kōmyō (701–760), as well as arts and crafts of the Tempyō period of Japanese history.


== History ==

The construction of the Tōdai-ji Buddhist temple complex was ordained by Emperor Shōmu as part of a national project of Buddhist temple construction. During the Tempyō period, the years during which Emperor Shōmu reigned, multiple disasters struck Japan as well as political uproar and epidemics. Because of these reasons Emperor Shōmu launched a project of provincial temples. The Tōdai-ji was appointed as the head temple of these provincial temples. Emperor Shōmu was a strong supporter of Buddhism and he thought it would strengthen his central authority as well.  The origin of Tōdai-ji's Shōsō-in repository itself dates back to 756, when Empress Kōmyō dedicated over 600 items to the Great Buddha at Tōdai-ji to express her love for her lost husband, Emperor Shōmu, who died 49 days earlier. Her donation was made over five times across several years, then stored at the Shōsō-in. During the Heian period, a large number of treasures, consisting of items and instruments used in important Buddhist services were transferred from a different warehouse called the Kensakuin to the Tōdai-ji.
After the Meiji Restoration, it came under the administration of the national government, and since World War II has been under the administration of the Imperial Household Agency. It is on the UNESCO register of World Heritage Sites as one of the Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara. It is also a National Treasure of Japan.


== Building ==

The building is in the Azekura Zukuri log-cabin style, with a floor raised to about 2.5 m takayuka-shiki (高床式).  This is an architectural style that was mainly used for the construction of granaries and storehouses. Some distinctive features of this building style are the triangular, wooden beams that come together in the corners, as well as the fact that it was assembled without using any bolts nor nails. This could be slightly surprising for its height of 14 m, width of 33 m and depth of about 9.3 m. However, it was a logical and smart step. As a result of assembling the storehouse without bolts or nails, the structure became very flexible and able to withstand earthquakes, a phenomenon of nature that Japan was already well acquainted with during Nara period. The Shōsō-in is also the only building to survive the Siege of Nara in the Heian period. The exact construction date is unclear, but construction works probably started soon after the empress's bequest in AD 756 and definitely were finished before AD 759, when the bequest items storage lists were complete.


== Preservation of the artefacts ==
Since the Shōsō-in was to be a repository for (valuable) objects, it was constructed quite ingeniously to create a natural climate regulation system. This natural climate regulation system was created by elevating the floor to a height of 2.7 m. This made circulation of air underneath the building possible and protected the structure against humidity at the same time. In addition to this, during the first few decennia after its construction, the triangular beams of the Japanese cypress might have functioned as a natural regulator of humidity and temperature.
The artefacts themselves were stored away in chests made from Cedar wood that's known for its durability. These chests were 90–110 cm long, 60–70 cm wide and 40–50 cm high. Not only the building itself but also these chests were elevated from the ground. All these adjustments made it possible to preserve the treasures in perfect state.


== Treasures ==
The Shōsō-in today holds around 9,000 items, excluding items that are yet to be classified. The treasures that were donated by Empress Kōmyō were stored in the Hoku Sō, the Northern part of the Shōsōin. From the very beginning, this part of the Shōsō-in has been sealed by the imperial family. One was permitted to enter only with explicit permission of the imperial family.
While 95 % of the items of the collection are remainders from the 8th century and of domestic production, like art or documents, there is also a variety of items originating in Tang China, India, Iran, Greece, Rome and Egypt.
Although these collections are not open to the public, selections are shown at Nara National Museum once a year in autumn.
The objects and treasures that have been stored in the Shōsō-in can be divided into the following categories.

Furniture Chōdo Hin (調度品)
Games Yūgi gu (遊戯具)
Music instruments Gakki (楽器)
Clothing and accessories  Fukushoku (復職)
Weaponry Buji (武事)
Buddhist objects Butsugu (仏具)Apart from these objects for everyday use, pieces of writing (shoseki) have also been preserved in the Shōsō-in. These pieces of writing can provide detailed stories about Nara period's society, social life, the population, social, cultural and economical activities.


== Silk collection ==
Since 1994, the Imperial Household Agency's Office of the Shoso-in Treasure House, which is responsible for the administration of the repository, has been producing exact reproduction of ancient Nara textiles. Apart from the appearance and colour, care has been given to reproduce the production and weaving style. The silk is donated each year by Empress Michiko, who personally runs the Momijiyama Imperial Cocoonery at Tokyo Imperial Palace.


== See also ==
The Kamakura Museum of National Treasures designed to resemble the Shōsō-in, also holds a fine collection of Japanese art and sculpture.
For an explanation of terms concerning Japanese Buddhism, Japanese Buddhist art, and Japanese Buddhist temple architecture, see the Glossary of Japanese Buddhism.
Kura (storehouse)


== References ==


== External links ==
Imperial Household Agency page for Shōsōin (in Japanese)
Imperial Household Agency page for Shōsōin (in English)
Shosoin Tanabetsu Mokuroku (List of Shosoin Solid Objects)
Guide to Shosoin research (Nara period written documents of the scriptorium)
text.quote: This raised building with a log-cabin appearance was built in the 700s to store treasures.
trip: Spent a couple of hours here. Unfortunately, I could not enjoy the outdoors too much as the day was rainy. Inside the temple is a large Buddha. I visited with my parents and spent about 1.5 hours there, inside the temple and visiting some of the shopping stalls.
Perhaps one of the most beautiful fully bloomed cherry blossom trees I have seen in Japan is on the left of this entryway.

This UNESCO cultural heritage is an architectural gem that has withstood over 1000 years. Impressive wooden structures and Buddha statutes. You are greeted by hundreds of Sika deers on the entrance path to the temple grounds. There are lots of cherry trees in the temple grounds

The great Buddha hall was incredible, very historic and just nice to watch. You will also see many deers from Nara park

Beautiful temple! Seeing the giant Buddha was a wonderful experience. Be warned though, it will be SUPER packed!

The temple and grounds are magnificent, but inside you'll see a huge buddha and two further golden buddhas, plus huge wooden carved warriors. Well worth visiting.

An immense Temple with incredibly tall statues of beauty surrounded by a garden setting inhabited by surprisingly tame, and approachable, deer. But the statues are huge and beautiful.

This is my favorite temple in Nara. It is located next to the Nara Park and you will appreciate that this temple was built ages ago. The giant buddha is amazing! This is a must see!

One of the more impressive temples visited in Japan with plenty of added extras providing additional information on the structure and history. Some interactive displays also adding interest. Very popular though so don't expect to have it to yourself.

This temple is massive, very easy to find, even after a deer ate my map on the way. Busy as this is the main tourist attraction in town but easy to get around. The gigantic Buddha statue is a must see. After your visit make sure you stroll around in Nara park, entertain yourself
This Buddhist temple is a must. Only had a very short time so missed visiting the museum. The deer in Nara are just amazing
Such an interesting place, crowded but you can see everything well. Excellent 10 minute English guide.

Todai-ji Temple was our main destination on a quick day trip to Nara, while on the way from Kyoto to Osaka. We took a taxi from Nara Station, then walked towards the temple. We first walked through the giant Nandaimon Gate and saw the temple in the distance. As we got closer,
Nara was a wonderful experience. Walking to the shrine, all the Bambi's around us, the big Buddha, all were wonderful to see. Nara is certainly worth a stop@
The temple was amazing, beautiful & so huge! Some people did not go inside to have a closer view, i think it was worth every penny!

This temple is huge and then you walk in and see the Big Buddha, impressive. Loved hearing the facts regarding this temple from our tour guide. I thought the deer were kinda annoying, they were everywhere.
A fifteen minute walk from the Kintetsu line station in Nara through the deer park Worth the effort to see one of the largest Buddha's in Japan

beautiful park around, nice street food and and market next too, with the tokyo tower on the back ground.

Todai-ji is a very special place of worship and should be treated as one! We went on another reconnaissance trip to Todai-ji Temple before a school tour. We were blown away by the sheer number of people visiting, compared to when we first arrived 15 years ago! Unfortunately
One of the most impressive temples I have seen, a wonderful all wooden structure (allegedly one of the largest in the world) in a beautiful setting.

It (temple) is not only the largest wood structure in the world but there is something magical in this huge (15 m) Great Buddha statue. Certainly must see in Nara. You can find English speaking volunteer guide there who will provide 20 min intro to this place.

This is an awe inspiring temple. The place was very crowded but did not detract from the serenity and splendour of the venue. Need a good hour to experience and reflect on the temple and the surroundings.

This is a fantastic temple and the enormous Buddha is just breathtaking. Allow an hour or so as there is a fair bit of walking to the temple, especially if you combine the visit with Nara Park.

A very impressive sight, well worth the entrance fee. Take the opportunity to have a free guide who will take you to the temple and explain the history. The buda is the biggest in the world and is truly impressive.

Visited in the late morning/early afternoon as part of my independent tour of Nara. Beautiful Buddhas in the enormous temple. Fairly crowded and felt somewhat herded along however, you can spend time looking at the treasures the temple holds. Exterior is packed with people

Beautiful temple, with free guide provided to explain history of Buddhism in Japan and symbology. The Buddha can be seen from all angles which is interesting as light reflects off of it.
Amazing Buddhist temple in the middle of Nara park. It’s the biggest building made of wood, and inside there is a 15m tall bronze statue of Buddha! Really amazing!

One of the biggest temple I've seen. A must see place if you travel to Nara. The lovely deers will also add to the amazing experience.
An inspiring site with the enormous Buddha and beautiful temple buildings. A must see in Nara. It’s only an hour from Kyoto by train which runs frequently.

Not what I expected. The building is incredible, as are the statues. Amazing to think this was built centuries ago. Really awe inspiring to think built by hand without modern mechanisation. As previously mentioned watch the deer they are so accustomed to people they are fearless

Another breath-taking wonder in Japan. It is worth the time to visit and experience all the beautiful temples and sites.

4* Tōdai-ji Temple Buddhist Huge Buddha flanked by soldiers Bell tower Deer all over the place; concessions to feed them; watch out for the deer sh*t; deer also may snip at you p.s. the deer sometimes eat plastic wrappers or paper; need to be watchful
Visit Nara as a side trip from Kyoto to see the Todai-ji Temple, said to be the largest wooden structure in Japan originally constructed in 752 as the main Buddhist Temple in Japan.
Breathtaking! Worth the trip and the small entrance fee. Words can not describe the beauty this temple beholds. A must see!
It was big, grand and beautiful. Lots of tourists and also local school children but the line was moving fast.
Todaiiji has a beautiful idol of lying Buddha. We saw deer 🦌 in the surround areas. It was little rainy weather which made the whole space feel fresh and new.
There is a massive buddha statue inside and the whole compound is majestic. Worth visiting more than the usual shrines in the area.

Amazing temple with the giant Buddha astonishing your view. Deers gathering around in a magical place
It was nice with about 5 huge statues. The place is nice and can be easily reached while walking in nara park.

Superb place.Loved the statues and the history all over the place.So much to learn there if you want to learn about Japan
Amazing Buddhist temple. Largest wooden structure in the world houses Japan’s largest Buddha. The grounds are very impressive. And you will walk around many deer on your way in thru Deer Park.

if you are in the area it is definitely worth it visit I would not necessary come all the way to Nara just for it but it was worth it as we were in Nara anyways

This was one of the highlights of the trip so far. An amazing building for its architecture but also pure brilliance of construction. It’s huge. Set in lovely gardens and surroundings even at one of the busiest times of the year it still didn’t feel too crowded.

you can visit temple from 7:30 to 17:00. you must pay entrance fee for visiting inside the temple but you can visit and take great photo in outside of temple free.
Totally impressive place. Everything is enormous, the wooden temple, the Buddha, the amount of people... Beautiful place!

Just go and see! Beautiful and sacred place, this pne should be visited when in Japan. Daibutsu is amazing and the deer are very kawaii.

I visited as a part of a day trip to Nara. The Buddha is beautiful and impressive in size. The setting is lovely.

My third time visiting and always a sight to behold. Deers roam freely nd are known to be messengers from Heaven. Do show your palms to the deers should they look to you for food. This signals that you do not have any to feed them. Feed deers only with the deer biscuits bought
Going to this temple was a real highlight. Any spiritual person should try to go here if they are visiting nearby. Beautiful scenery and atmosphere

Highlighting the largest Bronze Statue of Buddha in Japan, this Temple has an impressive aura of power. Less imposing are the Golden Buddha's either side. Constructed of timber this is one of the largest wooden structures in the world.

I loved this temple more than any I visited in Japan. Moving experience on a grand scale. The grounds are also surrounded by the tame deer that Nara is famous for.

The architecture of the shrine built entirely out of wood is amazing. The Buddha statue is huge and worth a visit.

The temple is Absolutley Worth a visit, we went on a rainy day and it was great! We spent about half an hour inside the temple before it got too crowded. If you plan on going, go early.
Temple is inside Nara Park so you can visit it after having your fill of playing with the deers The 3 Buddhas inside are simply spectacular and a sight to behold

This place is big. You get here by walking through the South Gate. There’s a somewhat steep price for admittance, but it’s well worth it. I’ve never seen a wooden building so big before. This also has the giant Buddha inside that you can see up close if you pay.
The enormity of this temple must be experienced. We happened upon a drumming performance that was so great. Truly a must on your travels in Japan.

Beautiful temple well worth the entry fee. It's busy but it doesn't really detract from the experience. Photography is allowed inside and there is a hole you can crawl through inside for good luck. Lots of information in English to explain what is what.

It is a very busy area around the temple but a worthwhile visit. The temple, it's entrance gates and square and the buddha are huge and their are smaller temples and things to view in the surrounds. Very interesting

Nice place to visit for a wee walk and quiet reflection.easy to get to from Kyoto grounds full of wild deer, that you can pet and photograph.
Far too many people but this is a must see attraction. The size, age, atmosphere is mind-blowing. Get there early before the crowds

Been to Japan several times but never visited Todai-Ji until now. Boy have I missed out! Sitting in Nara park is this gem of a shrine, with it tons of deers roaming around making it even more joyous. The sheer size of the shrine and figures are hard to grasp. I appreciate the
The sheer size of the temple is a sight to behold! One could only imagine the effort put into the construction.
Gorgeous huge Buddha in the largest wooden building in the world does not disappoint. Go early to avoid the rush and chaos of the crowds.

This place is amazing, it’s huge. Largest wooden structure in the world. Huge Buddha. Very large crowds but this is a must place to see!

Awesome temple, with dramatic entrance and grounds; it has an enormous statue of the Buddha which is central to its mission. A must visit while in Nara.
The 800 yr old Buddha within the temple is magnificent! Definitely must see. The temple grounds are well kept and beautiful.

Easy access from the train station. Just get the bus day pass. 600 yen entrance and I recommend the audio talk which explains the statues and grounds etc. A very old monument rich in history, the biggest wooden structure in the world! Just a good visit really- not too big!

Very large and impressive Eden temple which contains many statues including a giant Buddha. Quite a long walk to reach it and there are hundreds of free roaming deer in the park. These look cute and can be very friendly.

It is a whole package tour. Great temple, with beautiful park, also with pond, deers, and also pigeons. Me and my family are very satisfied
Felt so much as ease seeing this temple in Nara. The temple was of a wooden structure and was pretty well maintained. Can definitely see the Chinese influence and was awed by the Giant Buddha

Really amazing place with beautiful statues of buddha and others. Whole place is really great and I recommend to visit this place.

the budha statue is amazing and there are other nice statues, it's definitely wirth the train ride from Kyoto

The bronze Budda is impressive, if it's the biggest one or not doesn't really matter. Beautiful, made the trip to Nara worth it. Loved the other statues as well, but for me the most awesome part is the wooden structure of the temple.

It's hard to describe the scale of the temple and Buddha. It's truly something that should be seen in person as pictures don't do it justice. Gets very busy as there are several tour buses that stop here.
The biggeat wood builduing in the world that houses one of the biggest buddhas in Japan, beautiful gardens and deers all over the property

The temple is very old with giant statue of Buddha. nicely maintained. garden is beautiful and cover a large area. Large number of Deer wandering through the garden is an added attraction.
A Must-have while in Nara. The building is huge - which makes the crowds not disappear but much less noticeable.

This was an interesting temple. It's very large, but there isn't a whole lot to see inside other than the large Budda. It was still worth the few $ we spent to visit however.

After being in Kyoto you kind of get over all the temples but this is quite spectacular. Very joyful

We got there after it closed so were unable to see the giant Buddha, but it was still a great place to visit!
Todaiji Temple is one of the most impressive and important temples in all Japan. It's a must when you come to my home town, Nara.

...beside the deers of course. The giant Buddha’s are big, of course too. The place closes at 5, if you stay until then you will get the chance to make photos without people, but you will need to be “inside” since they put curtains in the main door.

You will learn a lot about Japan getting in the temple. All rituals are unique. The history of the temple is amazing. It is a half day tour at least!

It takes a lot to impress me but this place does. The grandeur of the building overwhelms while peaceful. You might think you've seen all of the temples you need to see but you're wrong. This is a must.

We first visited this temple in 2010, and then came back with our two boys ages 5 and 7...9 years later. Its one of our favorites and so impressive, our boys even loved it and were amazed at the large Buddha, and crawled through the pillar!

Largest wooden structure, housing largest bronze statue of Buddha. Over 1300 years old. Reasonably priced entry fee considering the significance of the site. Deer roaming freely in park near site is an added bonus.

We were on the fence whether the 1200 yen admission for two of us would be worth it, but it was. Pictures don't do the Great Buddha justice. It is dizzingly tall and just towers over you.

Different from other Shrines and Temples in Japan, this place really felt like a special place. It's worth the time to walk from the Nara train station to the temple and do the entire round of the place.
Todai-ji temple is one of the most amazing places in Nara! The wooden building is simply huge as well as the statues inside it. Also, it's a place full of peace! If you go to Nara, don't skip it.

Can be quite busy as it's one of the main attractions. Lovely approach through the park with all of the deer.
We enjoyed our visit here. The huge Buddha was unique and beautiful. Its worth a visit to experience this place. Wasn't too busy the day we went.

Fantastic temple experience. We received a free guided tour in English from a lovely volunteer. Probably my favourite temple visit in Japan.

Must visit for all tourists. It costs 600 yen to visit the Buddha Hall and an extra 400 yen for the museum. Recommend coming around 4pm to view the sunset scene. Note that this place closes at 5pm though.
Been there multiple times, everytime was a greater experience than the previous. An amazing temple, a bit too crowded at times, but if you can get past that and enjoy it, it's a must see spot.

Very impressed with the building. Have to see it in you own eye. Not planned to enter initially, but was attracted by it when arrived by the entrance.
No photo could ever do justice to how amazing Todai-ji Temple is in person. It has been the highlight of our entire Japan experience.

Generally I make it a point to visit any temple/shrine in japan if I’m nearby. So during my visit to Nara park I popped by. Personally, I felt a sense of awe when arrived at the temple. It’s not the most majestic of buildings, but perhaps the surroundings blending in with the

We arrived at Todai-ji at 8:15 and there were only a few people. At 9:00, most of the tour buses arrive and it gets very crowded. The temple is very large, but you will need 20 minutes in the temple at a maximum. There are paths leading to many minor sites to visit.

We took a day off Kyōto to go to Nara and we were not disappointed. Todai-ji Temple has amazing ancient buildings with massive Buddha inside. On top you get to walk around semi-wild dears. Don’t miss it!

This is one of the must-see temples in Japan. A beautiful central Buddha, with a number of surrounding statues throughout the Temple.
Need to walk some distant through Nara Park before arriving at Nandaimon Gate of Tōdaiji and Todaiji Temple. Some souvenir shops to get great souvenirs from Nara. See deers and more deers.
Nara in general is just a charming town and the Todai-ji and its Giant Buddha are awe inspiring. Don't miss it! Extraordinary
Impressive temple and statues especially as they are made of wood. Lots of Japanese history to pick up here.

was the visit to Nara, and in particular, Toda-ji Temple. Its beautiful. The Buddha Statue, the other statues in the hall, etc - amazing! it was also fun watching people wriggling their way through Buddha's Nostril!

This temple is imposing and has some beautiful statues besides the huge gold Buddha. the grounds a beautifully manicured.
