The most famous temple in Nara, Typical japanese temple in a very nice area near Nara park. Good spot for pics but don't expect to be alone there

WOW what an amazing place. The massive statues are enormous and just brilliant to view. the work they put into these. a very interesting place and a must to visit allow a couple of hours. easy walking and good for children of all ages.
Beautiful and interesting. Temples, shrines and grounds. This should be your top priority in Nara. GO.
We came with little knowledge of the region but we were pleased we stopped by, we would recommend it to all even just to see

Nara is a lovely city and Todai-ji temple is definitely worth visiting. It can get a little crowded at times so come early.

Must visit when you step in Nara. If you don’t want to walk , you can take a bus from Nara Kintetsu station ( check with station master- direction ) and it will drop you in front of temple. Walking from station to temple should be around 15mins. Inside and Outside of temple

It is worth the walk from Nara station and moving around the deers gathering in front of the temple. The Buddha statue is awesome. Avoid holding the deer crackers in your hands as deers will rush at you.

Probably the most important and impressive shrine in Japan and is a must for tourists. The meditating Buddha gives a wonderful sense of calm and peace.

This temple is one of the highlights of a visit to Nara and should be included in your itinerary. Although it gets quite busy, there's still enough space that it doesn't feel uncomfortably crowded. Worth paying the entrance fee to see the Buddhas inside.

Very big and huge temple with a humongous campus and a very beautiful statue. Some deers are roaming around . And place was very crowded if you want to click some snaps with deers better to go to Nark park. This place you can reach by taking bus from station

Go go go. You may think it’s all a touristy hype but that’s one big wooden temple with a fairly overwhelming sized Buddha statue/ sculpture. There is an entry fee and there’s lots of people as well. Try and go very early if you can to skip the crowds..

Situated in Nara park this temple was awesome. Everything about it is on the large size and the Buddha is enormous. Lovely walk around the area and an interesting archaeological dig nearby. The deer aren't allowed in the temple, thank goodness!

A large temple in the mountains within Nara Deer Park, Todai-ji Temple is in an outstanding location. The view from the main building is simply breathtaking. We got a goshuin here - if you are a tourist in Japan, I highly recommend a goshuincho, and the goshuincho here and at
This was fantastic to visit. There was a great deal of history and sculptures to admire within this building.

This was a fun day, scenic train trip from Osaka, enjoyable walk from the station with heaps of little shops and places to eat. Sika deer everywhere leading up to the temple. It was actually fun to watch people trying to feed them. Breathtaking temple with a giant Buddha inside.

Todaiji temple is located in the Nara park, and surrounded with nature all around. What amazes me is the giany Buddha’s inside which will mesmerize you.
I was amazed. Stunning, from the statues to the building. If your in the Nara area, this is a must. The walk to the structure itself is great since the roads are full of deer.

Large Buddha figure in an huge impressive wooden temple. The building itself is worth a visit, although the large statues, partly golden, are the actually famous sight. In the nearby park, you can see and feed crowds of friendly dears.

We went to Todai-ji Temple 45 minutes before closing. There were not that many people there. The temple looks amazing from the outside. The big budah on the inside the temple is the most interesting part though. Seeing the statue and walking to it gave me that strange feeling

An absolutely beautiful temple! The whole temple is huge compared to others we visited. The grounds are lovely to. We went part of a tour guide so heard about the history of the temple. There is a small shop inside the temple that sells cute little gifts.

Well, you have to go here if you go to Nara. Todai-ji is a Buddhist temple complex in Nara and that includes the Great Buddha Hall (Daibutsuden) which houses the world's largest bronze Buddha statue. Everything...the statues, wooden structures, etc. is truly impressive.
The temple is insane, it’s so large, the Buddha inside is huge as well. If you’re in Nara this temple is a must see. Very impressive.

This is one of the must see attractions in Nara, allegedly the biggest Buddha in the world. Built in the 8th century. Needless to say all tourists visiting the town will go here at some point. Best if you can avoid the Chinese holidays

Was nice to see. But there are definitely better places in Nara to explore for nature lovers! Historical and architectural point of few I can ensure- it was a very special experience. Especially the exterior of the temple..
We’ve been to so many temples on our trip that I’m a bit Templed out but glad we came to see this. The size of the wooden building and Buddha statues are impressive!
This temple is located in the Nara park. Very impressive the big statues you can see inside the temple. If you came in Nara you can't miss this

Glad that we made an effort to come to Nara since this is really a unique place, The temple has a huge Buddha statue with the Great Buddha Hall. There are a lot of deers wonder around the temple freely. If you are afraid of deers then avoid this place.

The temple is amazing and the statues are the same but being an engineer I was impressed by the wooden structure. Entering the temple you can easily forget that it is made of wood, it's huge and well worth the visit and entrance fee.
Worth a visit to see this massive wooden temple. We went at 8am before most of the crowds but would advise going at 7:30am when it opens to get ahead of the school tours too. Well worth a look.
A must see when visiting Japan. Packed full of tourists and Japanese school kids. Be careful of the deers roaming the site as they do bite.

This was an interesting place to visit and see the largest Buddha and the other items in this venue. It is worth your time to put on your list of things to see.

Very nice temple to visit!! You can find the biggest bronze buddha here! It is impressive to see it since it is inside the temple. When you go to the gift shop, you can find a pillar. In this pillar, there is a hole with the size of the nostril of the buddha. It appears that if

The big bronze Buddah is breathtaking and you simply have to see and experience the magnitude. Really worth a trip from Osaka or Kyoto... but our recommendation is actually to stay in Nara for one night. Consider the guesthouse Naramachi!

The sheer size of this indoor Buddha is impressive, the temple is also very large to be able to accommodate this giantic Buddha. Beyond the size of the Buddha, there is nothing that would consider extraordinary.

text.wiki:
Isui-en (依水園, Isuien) is a  Japanese garden located in Nara, the old capital of Japan near Kyōto.  It has been preserved since its creation in the Meiji era, and is the only walking garden (kaiyushiki teien) in Nara. It is divided into two sections, which were originally two separate gardens, and each features a pagoda.


== History ==
The site of the western garden originally formed part of Manishu-in, a minor temple which was part of the larger temple of Kofuku-ji. The ground was bought in the 1670, during the Enpō era by Kiyosumi Michikiyo, a wealthy tanner. He restructured the gardens between 1673 and 1681 and built two houses: the Sanshu-tei and Tei-shu-Ken, as the family home.  These were built with thatched roofs. The name Sanshu-tei (“house of the three wonders”) was given by Mokuan, the large priest of the Manpuku-ji temple of the school Zen Oubaku with Uji.
The larger eastern garden dates from 1899 and was designed by Seki Tojiro, a Nara businessman. Tojiro hired for the redesign Horitoku, a garden architect from the school of Urasenke.
In 1939, the two gardens were bought and combined by Jyunsaku Nakamura, a merchant of Nara, to provide a site for the attached Neiraku Museum (寧楽美術館), which hosts a collection of traditional Japanese ceramics.


== Layout ==
The gardens cover roughly 145,000 square feet (13,500 m2).
In the central pond of the gardens, there are two islands with sculptures of a crane and tortoise. In Japanese culture these animals represent longevity.
The house of the Hyoshin-tei, along with the west pool, were designed by Kimura Seibei, another garden architect from Urasenke. It allows access of the house by using a technique called shakkei, or "borrowed landscape." The composition of the landscape incorporates the roof of the large southern door (Nandaimon) of the temple Tōdai-ji, as well as the three higher hills overhanging Nara: the mounts Wakakusa, Kasuga, and Mikasa. It is framed by the trees of the Himuro sanctuary in the south, and the Tōdai-ji temple in the north. These make the space between the garden and background seem to disappear, producing a continuity which makes the landscape blend in visual harmony. This harmony is reinforced by the absence of any artificial enclosure.
The shape of the pond represents the shape of the kanji 水 character for mizu (“water”). A central island is connected to the bank by a series of stepping stones, which were formerly used to grind the pigments used in dyeing. The garden also contains decorative stones, which were popular during the Meiji era. The water is fed by the Yosiki river, which flows adjacent to the garden.

If you are tight on time, go to yoshiki en garden next door. It's free for foreigners (show passport) instead of y900 here. It's smaller but similar.

I love Japanese gardens, so this was a must for me to visit. In your ticket, there is a guide included who walks you through the garden, tells you its history and also some information about plants, garden architecture and carps. I very much enjoyed.

The beautiful, manicured gardens are not large but are a great place to escape the crowds, sit and have a few moments of peace. They are also cool, even on a hot, steamy day. The museum is very small and does not house much of great interest. If you are on a strict budget,

Compare to the Great Buddha of Todaiji temple and over crowded photo shooting with deers in Nara park, this is the place where one can enjoy the peace and atmosphere of Zen. One can enjoy tasty ice-cream in the tea house overlooking the garden. For ones who has difficulties to
We were completely charmed by this elegant and refined garden. We learned a lot from an EGG (English Goodwill Guide) who talked about the history, design, and plants.
Very beautiful gardens within walking distance from Nara Park. Not free but worth seeing. Earlier in the morning right when the open is usually best to avoid mosquitos.

A tranquil garden close to highways and residences. Masterful creation of separate spaces, each with the sound of water and beautiful vistas. Entrance fee (about $10) also includes a small museum with a lovely collection of celadon ceramics (mostly Korean).

This was quite a nice garden, and on the way to Todaiji temple. Beautiful and peaceful but not necessarily unique or the best among Japanese gardens. Not a must see for the admission price of 900 yen, which is on the high side compared to other attractions.

We spent about an hour here after walking about 15 minutes from Nara Park. There were hardly visitor when we were there so we strolled leisurely around the garden. It was tranquil and quite beautiful. If you have an extra hour, it is worth the time to visit Isuien Garden.
Definitely worth a visit, this was one of the most beautiful settings in Japan. There were no crowds and it is a peaceful, lovely and historical garden.
More intimate than the larger public gardens. Lovely layout and planting with good borrowed landscape of the buildings in Nara park such as Nandai-mon gate, and the surrounding hills.

A beautiful and quiet Japanese garden with two ponds, nicely trimmed trees and thatched roofs buildings serving as tea houses or old rest houses. You can have a Japanese tea in the tea house while admiring the landscape sitting on tatami mats. The many maple trees make it

We were walking from Gangoji Temple to Todaiji Temple and happened to pass the entrance to this garden. We were looking for somewhere to rest in some quiet away from the crowds in Nara that day - so we popped into the garden. It was beautiful. Well landscaped and quiet. Far
This was a beautiful traditional garden in the heart of Nara. It was not very crowded because of the entrance fee. If you are a fan of gardens, then you will want to see this.

We had just visited the Temple and Buddha in Nara, which was absolutely packed with school trips. We had decided to seek out this garden. We were almost put off by the 900 yen entrance fee, but were glad we weren't. Compared to the crowds in the park and the temple, this was
Glorious 400 year old garden that is an absolute delight. The entry price is steep at 900 yen but it was the most perfect example of a Japanese garden that we saw on our trip.

We visited this garden early in the morning on our side trip to Nara. The price is a bit steep (900 yen for adults), but I think it was worth the price. The garden was absolutely stunning, and there were very few other visitors (most likely due to the steep price). If you want

Isuien is a nice Japanese Garden close to the Todai-ji Temple in Nara. There are 2 parts of the garden, one made in Edo period (17th century) and the other made in Meiji period (19th century). The entrance fee is a little bit expensive(900 yen), but it's worth visiting this

It is without doubt a beautiful garden. The attached museum is not really worth wasting time on. You can see part of it already by taking a tea in the neighbouring tea house without paying the entrance fee. There is another free garden yoshiki-en just beside it. I actually liked

Very high entrance fee as they only sell a combo ticket with the next door shocker of a museum. The gardens are nice and some decent pictures can be taken, but it is very small and not in any way worth the money.

A short distance from Todai-ji Temple is the Isuien Garden, which is often ignored by tourists in preference for the more famous temple. The gardens are incredibly peaceful and picturesque, and the staff are very helpful, with one even offering a free tour in English. If you

The entrance fee was surprisingly high (900 yen, but that day the inside museum was closed so only 810 yen, still very expensive), so my expectations rose drastically. The garden couldn't reach them because it's true that it is quite nice but I didn't feel the awe I longed for.
Nice, quiet and scenic garden but nowhere near stunning. Nothing special about this garden especially given the entrance fee required (¥820). However, it might be more scenic during late autumn.
Although there is an entrance fee, it is worth paying it. There are some volunteers who explain the history of the gardens. It is a peaceful and wonderful place.

One reviewer complained about the entrance fee. I think it's fair, and it certainly keeps the numbers down which means those that pay and enter have a relatively peaceful garden to enjoy. Wonderful colour when we were there in April, and lots of good photos taken.
It was really peaceful and relaxing, the garden is beautiful. I wish I could visit it again. Worth it!
Stopped here on the way to Nara Park and temple area. We were greeted and offered a free Guide to show us around the gardens. The area is beautifully kept and peaceful

The entrance fee to this garden is 900Yen per adult. It is not value for money and the plants and landscape there is not that great. There are sign board all over stating please do not step on the moses. Quite annoying. There is a garden next door which is free to tourist.

Don't skip this one, it was the highlight of our Nara visit to see the two gardens.It is also very quiet in there even though Tennoji was packed with people. You can sit in peace and harmony and take in the scenery. The amount of detail within the gardens is a marvel to behold-

This zen garden was fun to visit and very beautiful. We were guided around it by a volunteer who spoke surprisingly good English so were able to learn more specific reasons for its current design. I highly recommend you ask about that. It is small though and can probably be in

I was so surprised seeing how peaceful and calm Nara was, not many tourist at all BUT the scenery ommgg so beautiful it does not lose to Kyoto at all! when i first step into Isuien garden i was just mesmerised seeing how well and beautiful they maintained the garden...the autumn

It's a beautiful garden. What can I say. I visited the garden on Oct of 2015, Thursday morning. There were 4 people in the garden besides me when I visited. There was a volunteer guide who spoke English who gave me a private tour and explained to me things that I'd never

Unfortunately it was raining the day I went to see the Isuien Garden but that didn't take away from how beautiful and breathtaking this garden is. Seeing the trees turning brown, red and yellow was a beautiful sight! The walking paths give you opportunities to take perfect

Most landscape in Japan is awe-inspiring but the beauty of the Isuien is that if you visit it first thing in the morning, you might be one of the few people there and enjoy the lovely landscape in solitude. A must visit in Nara!

Less crowded than the other attractions of Nara even on a Sunday morning. Not so easy to find so ask a policeman to find the left hand turn off the main street. Very peaceful walk to get there. BTW there is wonderful free garden next door to the right. free to any non-Japanese,

This is a lovely garden to look at before you hit the big temples! There were free English speaking guides to talk to you about the history of the place, and they take your photo with your camera! About the only pics I'm in! It costs to get in, but you also get to visit the
when we visited the gardens were really quiet, most toruists only get to see the bronze buddha so this is a ideal get away from the crowds location, lovely place to rest

This garden is a hidden gem in Nara Park. It is such a beautiful garden, but there was hardly anyone there. I suppose most people visit the major attractions first. We visited this spot on our second day and were rewarded with the visit. The adjoining Neiraku Art Museum included
Quite a large garden, lots to explore, very peaceful and a good contrast to the busyness of the Toshodaiji complex.
the entire garden is superbly landscaped! great picture opportunity! lots of flowers and very serene!
A lovely garden situated just at the fringe of Nara Park. It has a nice pond and one can take lots of pictures with Todai-ji Temple as the background.

Out of all the sites we've visited, Isuien garden is my favourite. It has such a beautiful layout besides just the main garden view. Well worth also walking along all the other small paths throughout the garden. This should be on everyones list to visit in Nara! Entry fee is a

Walking distance from Toda-ji Temple, this garden is well worth a visit. Most tourists visiting nearby Today-ji bypass this in their rush. That's good news for the traveller with more time to enjoy the garden. There's a museum on site that is also well worth a visit. Local

It was so peaceful to walk in this garden with such a beautiful view that was feast for your eyes. Everything is carefully maintained but the effort was not too apparent and it gave natural feel to this place. I was there in the beginning of autumn so the leaves have started to

This was our first stop on our trip to Nara. What a lovely garden it is! There were stunning vistas, with some leaves just beginning to change. There was a lovely pond with stepping stones to one side of a small island and a stone bridge to the other side. This was a more open

Having death with the hustle bustle of the park and the Temples, entering this garden was truly a new universe. It is hard to envision yourself I. An urban landscape when at every turn there is yet another perfectly reflected tree or naturally sculpted rise. Could could have

I understand that the original garden was designed and built in the 17th Century, it was modernized in the 20th century, on several acres and the Japanese government turned it into a spectacular site, with easy to manage walks, an incredible variety of trees -- I especially

We found this little gem very enchanting and just beautiful. Way better than eg the famous Okayama garden. Isuien has it all, a pond, waterfall, tea house and more. With 3000 jpy a bit expensive especially for a family of 4. If you are not a garden fanatic , visit the free
Located Near Nara park you find this garden. Decorated in Japanese style two small ponds form the center. Quiet and peaceful to stay here for a while

This was my second time here and the garden is impeccable with fantastic landscaping. Every area was well thought out, picturesque, and breathtaking. Take the free English speaking guide tour and learn about the long rich history of this garden. The guide shared interesting

I walked 15 minutes to get here from Todaiji Temple, finished strolling around the garden in 20 minutes. The lake in the middle is the main highlight, try to go early in the morning to get good pictures when the sunlight is not so harsh. There is small traditional restaurant

If the Nara crowds at Todai-ji have worn you down, Isuien Garden is a good place to recover your tranquility. It's a beautiful garden walk, with several ponds and streams, a functioning tea house, and, for an added bonus, a museum housing some very nice ceramic pieces, exquisite

Beautiful garden, a bit small and there are nicer gardens elsewhere in Japan but if you are in Nara for a day and have time then it is worth going. Next door there is another garden and is free for foreigners.

Beautiful Japanese garden at Nara.the garden is divided in two parts, and were built in two different periods - the Edo period and the Meiji era. The front garden is smaller, but very pretty and serene. The back garden is built around a large lake. Unfortunately, the art

If you love gardens, you'll like this place. I love gardens so I enjoyed the walk around the garden. However, if you are neutral to gardens like my husband, the 900Yen entrance fee is rather pricey compared to the other entrance fees we paid in Kyoto and Nara. We didn't stay

This garden offers a peaceful moment of rest between the visits to the temples, there are very beautiful views, great for nice pictures, you can walk around or just sit and enjoy the silence and the view. Not particularly interest in the nearby museum.

One of the gardens you can visit in Nara park. We were lucky that there are a couple of very nice Japanese elderly who offered to gave us a tour of the garden, which made us fully appreciate the design and the history of the place.

We found this place recommended in the guidebook. It was quite tricky to find, and we almost gave up at one point... We were very glad we didn't. It was our favourite spot in Nara, tranquil, spiritual and painstakingly well maintained. Not as popular as the main attractions, but
We were here on a hot day in summer. A little disappointed that there wasn't much blooming, but still worth a 30 minute walk through to get away from the world.

The best Japanese Garden we have seen in this trip, we have been to Osaka, Nara, Kobe, Kyoto, Tokyo, this Isuien Garden has all the Japanese tea Garden feature in one. It is not easy to find Isuien, it is so close to Todaiji Temple, but no signs to direct you, have to ask

Really don't understand why this garden is rated so high, there are way better gardens in the Kansai area. Maybe because we visited in June, but still, in the fall or spring other places would be prettier too. Anyways, I thought the Manyo/Shinen Botanical garden was more

This was one of the most beautiful gardens we saw on our trip - and we saw a lot of gardens! It is not a huge garden but big enough to spend maybe up to an hour wandering around. There are two large ponds, front and back with fabulous landscaping, trees, shrubs, rock features

My wife and two sons visited back in April. We spent around an hour here before going over towards Todai-Ji. The garden is beautiful and picturesque. We were fortunate enough to have a tour guide show us around (free of charge and refused to take payment!) and he was very
I had a very nice experience with volunteer tour guide Hideyuki-san. He gave a great tour and very kind person! Thanks a lot!

Isuien is located in central Nara and is divided into two parts, a front garden and a rear garden, with a number of tea houses, streams, waterfalls, and ponds scattered throughout. The front garden has a longer history, dating back to the early Edo period. The rear garden, the

This garden can be easily done in half an hour. Its very close to nara deer park so we decided to stop by. It may be small but it is stunningly beautiful. yes the 900Y fee is steep but the work that goes into this garden does make it worth it.
I wouldn't understand somebody who doesn't like this garden. Quintessential Japanese garden. Perfection.

If you want to visit a typical Japanese garden you should definitely visit Isuien Garden. The entrance fee is quite expensive with 900 Yen but worth. You can see all the tree mountains around Nara from this Garden. You should sit down for a moment and enjoy the view and the
Gardeners work hard but don't overwork the garden; weeds are kept down but the other plants are allowed to grow just a bit wild. It makes for a really lovely result.
A nice Japanese garden. Small and interesting. Not more. if you are here, do not miss it. This is not the main attraction in Nara park.

I could only give this 3 stars since it certainly is a beautiful and peaceful garden, in a land full of beautiful and peaceful gardens. Not as impressive as a place like Shukkein in Hiroshima. Full of tea houses around the lake, I would have given a higher rating if not for the

It is a private garden and has some very beautiful scenes. Great if you are a photography lover. Not sure it worth the money of 900 yen. But, it does offer a museum to watch and a locker to put your bags while you watch the park, FREE!

Not to be missed, especially if you've enjoyed some of the Kyoto gardens. Down the hill from Todaiji. In terms of must sees, I rank this just below the Kofukuji and Todaiji treasure houses (medieval Buddhist wooden sculptures) and above the Kasuga jina and certainly the Nara
This is a very cute little garden located a five minute walk from Todaji temple. You could spend thirty minutes walking around it. There is also the possibility to partake in a tea ceremony there.
Start your Nara tour from this garden. There is another garden located next to this one. Nara park and todaijji temple are just meters away from this garden

This garden is quite a long walk from the main area, but can be combined with a trip to the Todeji. We arrived at 4.30pm just in time for the last entry, but to be honest 30 minutes was enough to walk round the garden as it is small. The little museum was closed so get there
Definitely one of the most beautiful garden I have ever seen -- and Japanese gardens are beautiful in general anyway. I simply couldn't believe how amazing it is. A definite must.

I visited in April in the rain and the cherry blossoms were out. It was lovely. I would like to see it a few weeks later when the azaleas are blooming. You must see this garden and have tea in the tea house!

With Cherry Blossoms in full bloom, this traditional Japanese garden provided a lovely atmosphere for a stroll and a break from the crowds of Nara park. The beautifully delicate landscaping is interesting to explore and neat surprises are all around. Highly recommended.
trying to kill a few hours in the rain we found this little gem..take advantage of the free guides.. yes really free not a scam….you learn so much from them

I stumbled across Isuien Garden while walking through Nara on my way to Todai-ji. The entrance fee was for both the museum and the garden, and while I was not very impressed by the museum, the garden definitely made up for it! The garden was extremely serene and fairly secluded.
This is what a Japanese garden should be. It is immaculately kept and most refined and delicate, with some lovely detail at every turn. Well worth a visit.

My husband and I spent the day in Nara today which was a welcome adventure away from Kyoto (which has been quite dissapointing). We visited Isuien Garden as part of a guided free tour by a lovely man Tetsuo who works for the NPO Nara Guide Club. Even though today's temperature

Very nice garden, in Nara park. Very quiet and relaxing, to rest a bit from the crowds visiting the rest of places. The ticket is a bit expensive (900 ¥) but includes the museum with some beautiful art from XVII and XVIII century

There was only 2 other people there when I visited. The entrance was quite expensive at 900Y but this included a free guided tour (in excellent english) and the small museum next door. Wonderfully manicured garden...and great example of thatched Japanese buildings
We enjoyed exploring this traditional Japanese garden, which although in January was still quite lovely.

This garden is the quintessential, gorgeous, immaculate Japanese garden. It has everything you would want in a Japanese garden: calm, serene spots; lovely vistas; some historical structures; contemplative scenery; beautiful plants and trees; and, water features. The scale is
Entry fee is 900 yen (adults) 500 yen (teenager) for both garden and museum. It is not stressful to walk around in this medium size garden but not much flowers blooming as it is winter.

November is a great time to visit since the foliage changes color now! Excepted for one cherry tree that is blossoming in Oct-nov (also now), get to the back of the property to find it. Worthwhile noting: volunteers from the YMCA offer free guided tours. Today Mrs. Yasuko did a
A traditional Japanese style garden. Great for a pleasant stroll away from the crowds, with numerous attractive spots for photographs.
An awe inspiring garden with an awe inspiring backcloth of the mountains. Well worth setting aside time to sit, admire, walk and think.

This garden is a perfect break from the bustle of the crowds and tourists in Nara. Entry is slightly expensive but is also next to Yoshikien Garden which has free entry, so in reality you might be paying for both. Very manicured and carefully planned layout with a wonderful

Very beautiful garden, but I think it's expensive compared to other gardens. If you like nature, I'm sure you're gonna live it! I went about 4pm, so there were shadow in some places. I think it would be even better going about noon.
After the crowds of the Todaiji temple this garden provides a tranquil break. A compact location but with lovely vistas and colours

Well with a visit to be away from the crowds. The price is on the high side and the museum a waste of time. But I would happily pay again. Also I would recommend visiting in the morning as the light will be best for photos

Seems a steep price to stroll a garden path off the beaten path. Nevertheless, garden affectionatos will beat a path to this gem worth at least a nine dollar fifty cent toll. ( caveat, handicapped access highly difficult )

A most wondrous garden covered in moss paths, dotted with ponds and meandering rocky streams. A welcome respite from marauding, t-shirt nibbling deer! The fee of 900¥was a little steep, and we expected it to be larger from the description outside (we would have struggled to
Typical Japanese garden worth a visit to let your mind come to rest when you stroll through. Next to this garden there is another (free) garden which is also worth while

Not sure it is worth all the hype. Very nicely groomed, 2 ponds, but not sure what differentiates it from other gardens.

This garden itself is worth a visit to Nara. Not so easy to find, but if you have a map and GPS, it is not hard. There is an admission fee but worth it. When you enter the garden, you are presented with a stunning view already. Every few steps you take, you find a different
Do visit sanshu restaurant for lunch when you're nearby. It's abit more pricy but you get to sit back, relax and enjoy the stunning view in the hut while sipping on tea.
…where you would like to be lost for the rest of your life, - but at least reserve two or three hours for a visit, especially if you are a keen photographer

Isuen Garden is a wonderfull place to be to tank energy and enjoy nature. I loved the entrence and loved waking arround the garden and each corder has someting to show: the river, the pond, the hill and even the fine restaurant is worth see

The garden was absolutely silent and we had the whole place to ourselves, to wonder around past the streams, pond and mossy areas. A really great place to wander and enjoy the spring weather, and a great opportunity to take some photos with no other tourists in the picture.
This is one of the most beautiful garden that we have seen in Japan, not so much crowd, very peaceful, and stunning landscape. Great colors in Autumn.

Isuien Garden is absolutely beautiful, especially the rear garden, where you can see Mount Wakakusayama and part of Todaiji in the background. We were there on Saturday during cherry blossom season and we still had the garden largely to ourselves. It was so peaceful to walk

This garden is paradise. We came here after visiting the busy Tōdai-ji with thousands of other tourists right around the corner. And here - silence. We have been almost alone in this wonderful place with it's lakes and beautiful pavilions. A must see for everyone visiting Nara!

Peaceful, and lots to see in the garden. Its a good place to get away from the crowded spots in Nara. While I do feel that it is like most Japanese gardens, there are certain areas that differ from the rest such as moss gardens, places that seem like forests from fairy tales, a
Partitioned in several areas this very old garden has breathtaking spots and a nice view on the Todaiji temple. One of Nara's main attractions and not to be missed.
it's the best garden I have ever seen or step my foot into! Beautiful is a small word to describe this garden! It's an experience!

We didn't expect to see such a lovely formal garden in Nara. We were there in mid-October, and there were a few trees that had already begun to turn. It would be spectacular in mid-Nov. The adjoining museum of ancient artifacts is worth a short visit as well.

My husband now says that when he needs to think of a happy place this (and the other beautiful place place next door) are where he's thinking of.... Can not help make anyone feel like there is nothing wrong with the world! Beautiful tranquil place.

In this oasis of tranquility you're constantly surrounded by magnificent nature incl. various ponds, stone paths, pavilions and gardens, etc. Trees and flowers blossoming during Sakura left me stunned and the atmosphere was very special indeed. Close proximity to Nara Park made

Well worth a visit. My kids had fun crossing the little bridges and walking on the stones over the streams. Beautiful, serene garden.
I had expected to be bigger but when you walk around you will love it. Just relax next to the tea house and enjoy the view. the entry fee is 650 including entry to the museum.

For nature lovers and get the chance to see a real Japanese garden. Very pretty and close to it there another one, smaller, and free. I went to the botanic garden too and well not worth a visit. The Isuien is much better.

Beautiful gardens with a tea room serving some food and drinks. Like most of Nara, it's peaceful with relatively few tourists. The autumn foliage is some of the best I've seen so far and no crowds of people taking selfies!
As good as a garden can be, a must see for everyone traveling Nara.
A very beautiful place. Would love to spend more time here.
What a beautiful garden!! A peaceful place away from the noise and the crowd in the center of Nara.

Very friendly, I received a great walking tour of the garden.

Best sight in Nara! Beautiful garden.
Nice and peaceful place... one gentleman touring around with you was a plus to this place!!! So kind, mindful and wise

text.wiki:
Isonokami Shrine (石上神宮, Isonokami-jingū, also Isonokami-futsu-no-mitama-jinja (石上布都御魂神社), Furu-ōmyojin (布留大明神) etc.) is a Shinto shrine located in the hills of Furu in Tenri, Nara prefecture, Japan. It is one of the oldest extant Shinto shrines in Japan and has housed several significant artifacts.
Isonokami shrine was highly regarded in the ancient era, and frequented by many members of the Imperial Family. It played a pivotal role in Japan's early history, especially during the 3rd to 5th centuries.
The shrine is at the northern end of the Yamanobe no michi, the oldest road in Japan.


== History ==
It is unknown which kami was initially worshipped at Isonokami shrine. Isonokami Shrine was supposedly built in the 7th year of Emperor Sujin's reign, or the 91 BC. However, there is little record of Sujin's existence or identity, and therefore the claim is deemed legendary. The construction of a structure that can be identified as a Shinto shrine in the Isonokami area probably dates two or three centuries later.  Despite this, it is not unlikely that the Isonokami area was considered a sacred site during that time, as archeological digs have found many ritual objects, and Isonokami worship was already firmly established when they were adopted by the Yamato leaders in the 4th century.
Early records show that the shrine was an emerging center of Yamato power, flavored with a military overtone. Archeological evidences shows that around the 4th century, Yamato kings and nobility constructed more and more palaces and buildings in the shrine's vicinity.  Prior to this, the Yamato leaders identified with kami worshipped at Mount Miwa, but may have turned to Isonokami for its martial implications.  Myths written in the Nihon Shoki clearly attempt to link the Yamato court to Isonokami shrine.  According to the Nihon Shoki, Emperor Suinin's eldest son, Prince Inishiki ordered a thousand swords made and was placed in charge of Isonokami's treasures.  He then founded the Mononobe clan, who patronized the shrine for many generations.  Indeed, many of the state's iron weaponry were kept in the shrine's storehouses.  When the Mononobe clan collapsed, it was reformed as the Isonokami clan.
The shrine became the object of Imperial patronage during the early Heian period.  In 965, Emperor Murakami ordered that Imperial messengers be sent to report important events to the guardian kami of Japan. These heihaku were initially presented to 16 shrines including the Isonokami Shrine.From 1871 through 1946, the Isonokami Shrine was officially designated one of the Kanpei-taisha (官幣大社), meaning that it stood in the first rank of government supported shrines.


== Architecture ==

Isonokami shrine is surrounded by Cryptomeria (sugi), and is known for its quiet solemnity. A waka poem from the Man'yōshū anthology mentions Isonokami shrine, surrounded by holy cedar trees.
The current site of Isonokami shrine may have been the site of an earlier religious structure, the Izumo-taisha. This is suspected because of a secondary shrine to Izumo-takeo found near the main shrine, but on higher ground.  Since secondary shrines are never built higher than the principal shrine, some have concluded that it was an older structure that stood before the current one.
The honden, or main hall, is built in the nagare-zukuri style.


== Enshrined ==
The main enshrined dedication is to Futsu-no-mitama (布都御魂), the kami of a legendary sword (futsu-no-mitama-no-tsurugi) that was given to by Takemikazuchi in Kumano and used by Emperor Jimmu, the first Emperor of Japan.  However, the sword itself is hidden in Isonokami shrine, but the second sword is visible in Kashima Shrine, Ibaraki.


== Artifacts ==

The Nanatsusaya-no-Tachi, a seven-branched sword, is housed in Isonokami shrine. It was given to the Yamato king by the crown prince of Baekje, a kingdom on the Korean Peninsula. The sword has been kept in Isonokami shrine since ancient times, perhaps as early as the 4th century when it was received from Baekje. It was rediscovered in 1873, and its gold inlaid inscription has proven to be a valuable historical resource. The sword is currently not available for public viewing.
The Totsuka-no-Tsurugi, a legendary sword, is also said to be kept at Isonokami shrine. According to the Kojiki, the sword was used by the god Susanoo to slay the Yamata-no-Orochi, a giant serpent with eight heads and eight tails. Priests at the shrine do not allow anyone to see or inspect the sword.
Ten treasures brought by Amenohiboko are thought to be housed in Isonokami shrine. According to the Nihon Shoki, Amenohiboko was a prince from Korea who settled in Japan. The ten treasures he brought are known as the Tokusa-no-Kandakara, and they are as follows:

Okitsu-kagami (A mirror)
Hetsu-kagami (A mirror)
Yatsuka-no-tsurugi (A sword)
Iku-tama (A jewel)
Makarukaheshi-tama (A jewel)
Taru-tama (A jewel)
Chikaheshi-no-tama (A jewel)
Orochi-no-hire (A type of long scarf worn by women)
Hachi-no-hire (A type of long scarf worn by women)
Kusagusa-no-mono-no-hire (A type of long scarf worn by women)


== National Treasures ==


=== National Treasures of Japan ===
The haiden, or hall of worship, with irimoya style roofing, Kamakura period
The haiden at the Izumo Takeo secondary shrine
The Nanatsusaya-no-Tachi


=== Important Cultural Properties ===
The rōmon, or main gate
Two iron shields from the Kofun period
Several pieces of breastplate armor
Several unearthed artifacts (magatama, necklaces, ring-pommel sabers, etc)


=== Others ===
Ornate red ō-yoroi
Black lacquered kabuto, various helms
Kokitsunemaru, an ōdachi forged by Sanjō Munechika

text.wiki:
Nara (奈良市, Nara-shi, Japanese: [naꜜɾa]) is the capital city of Nara Prefecture, Japan. 
As of 1 April 2019, Nara has an estimated population of 359,666, making it the largest city in Nara Prefecture and sixth-largest in the Kansai region of Honshu. Nara is a core city located in the northern part of Nara Prefecture bordering the Kyoto Prefecture. 
Nara was the capital of Japan during the Nara period from 710 to 794 as the seat of the Emperor before the capital was moved to Kyoto. Nara is home to eight temples, shrines, and ruins, specifically Tōdai-ji, Saidai-ji, Kōfuku-ji, Kasuga Shrine, Gangō-ji, Yakushi-ji, Tōshōdai-ji, and the Heijō Palace, together with Kasugayama Primeval Forest, collectively form the Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 


== Etymology ==
By the Heian period, a variety of different characters had been used to represent the name Nara: 乃楽, 乃羅, 平, 平城, 名良, 奈良, 奈羅, 常, 那良, 那楽, 那羅, 楢, 諾良, 諾楽, 寧, 寧楽 and 儺羅.
A number of theories for the origin of the name "Nara" have been proposed, and some of the better-known ones are listed here. The second theory in the list, from the notable folklorist Kunio Yanagita (1875-1962), is most widely accepted at present.

The Nihon Shoki (The Chronicles of Japan, the second oldest book of classical Japanese history) suggests that "Nara" was derived from narasu (to flatten, to level). According to this account, in September in the tenth year of Emperor Sujin, "leading selected soldiers (the rebels) went forward, climbed Nara-yama (hills lying to the north of Heijō-kyō) and put them in order. Now the imperial forces gathered and flattened trees and plants. Therefore the mountain is called Nara-yama." Though the narrative itself is regarded as a folk etymology and few researchers regard it as historical, this is the oldest surviving suggestion, and is linguistically similar to the following theory by Yanagita.
"Flat land" theory (currently most widely accepted): In his 1936 study of placenames, the author Kunio Yanagita states that "the topographical feature of an area of relatively gentle gradient on the side of a mountain, which is called taira in eastern Japan and hae in the south of Kyushu, is called naru in the Chūgoku region and Shikoku (central Japan). This word gives rise to the verb narasu, adverb narashi, and adjective narushi." This is supported by entries in a dialect dictionary for nouns referring to flat areas: naru (found in Aida District, Okayama Prefecture and Ketaka District, Tottori Prefecture) and naro (found in Kōchi Prefecture); and also by an adjective narui which is not standard Japanese, but is found all across central Japan, with meanings of "gentle", "gently sloping", or "easy". Yanagita further comments that the way in which the fact that so many of these placenames are written using the character 平 ("flat"), or other characters in which it is an element, demonstrates the validity of this theory. Citing a 1795 document, Inaba-shi (因幡志) from the province of Inaba, the eastern part of modern Tottori, as indicating the reading naruji for the word 平地 (standard reading heichi, meaning "level/flat ground/land/country, a plain"), Yanagita suggests that naruji would have been used as a common noun there until the modern period. Of course, the fact that historically "Nara" was also written 平 or 平城 as above is further support for this theory.
The idea that Nara is derived from 楢 nara (Japanese for "oak, deciduous Quercus spp.") is the next most common opinion. This idea was suggested by a linguist, Yoshida Togo. This noun for the plant can be seen as early as in Man'yōshū (7-8th century) and Harima-no-kuni Fudoki (715). The latter book states the place name Narahara in Harima (around present-day Kasai)　derives from this nara tree, which might support Yoshida's theory. Note that the name of the nearby city of Kashihara (literally "live oak plain") contains a semantically similar morpheme (Japanese 橿 kashi "live oak, evergreen Quercus spp.").
Nara could be a loan word from Korean nara (나라 : country, nation, kingdom). This idea was put forward by a linguist Matsuoka Shizuo. Not much about the Old Korean language is known today, and the first written attestation of a word ancestral to Modern Korean nara is as late as the 15th century, such as in Yongbieocheonga (1447),  Wolinseokbo (月印釋譜. 1459), or Beophwagyeongeonhae (法華經諺解. 1463), and there is no evidence that proves the word already existed as far back as the 7th century. These 15th-century books used narah (나랗), an old form of nara in Korean, and its older form might be reconstructed *narak. American  linguist Christopher I. Beckwith infers the Korean narak derives from the late Middle Old Chinese 壌 (*nrak, earth), from early *narak, and has no connection with Goguryoic and Japanese na. (See also the next theory.) Kusuhara et al. also points out this hypothesis cannot account for the fact there are many places named Nara, Naru and Naro besides this Nara.
There is the idea that Nara is akin to Tungusic na. In some Tungusic languages such as Orok (and likely Goguryeo language), na means earth, land or the like. Some have speculated about a connection between these Tungusic words and Old Japanese nawi, an archaic and somewhat obscure word that appears in the verb phrases nawi furu and nawi yoru ('an earthquake occurs, to have an earthquake').The "Flat land" theory is adopted by Nihon Kokugo Daijiten (the largest dictionary of Japanese language), various dictionaries for place names, history books on Nara and the like today, and it is regarded as the most likely.


== History ==


=== Pre-Nara/Origins ===
There are a number of kofun in Nara, including Gosashi Kofun, Hishiage Kofun (ヒシアゲ古墳), Horaisan Kofun (宝来山古墳), Konabe Kofun (コナベ古墳), Saki Ishizukayama Kofun (佐紀石塚山古墳), Saki Misasagiyama Kofun (佐紀陵山古墳), and Uwanabe Kofun (ウワナベ古墳).
By decree of an edict on March 11, 708 AD, Empress Genmei ordered the court to relocate to the new capital, Nara. Once known as Heijō or Heijō-kyō, the city was established as Japan's first permanent capital in 710 CE; it was the seat of government until 784 CE, albeit with five year interruption, lasting from 741-5 CE. Heijō, as the ‘penultimate court’, however, was abandoned by the order of Emperor Kammu in 784 CE in favor of the temporary site of Nagaoka, and then Heian-kyō (Kyoto) which retained the status of capital for 1,100 years, until the Meiji Emperor made the final move to Edo in 1869 CE. This first relocation was due to the court's transformation from an imperial nobility to a force of metropolitan elites and new technique of dynastic shedding which had refashioned the relationship between court, nobility, and country. Moreover, the ancient capital lent its name to Nara period.As a reactionary expression to the political centralization of China, the city of Nara (Heijō) was modeled after the Tang capital at Chang’an. Nara was laid out on a grid—which was based upon the Handen system—whereby the city was divided by four great roads. Likewise, according to Chinese cosmology, the ruler's place was fixed like the pole star. By dominating the capital, the ruler brought heaven to earth. Thus, the south facing palace centered at the north, bisected the ancient city, instituting ‘Right Capital’ and ‘Left Capital’ zones. As Nara came to be the epicenter of Buddhist church and drawing pilgrimage site, the city plan incorporated various pre-Heijō and Heijō period temples, of which the Yakushiji and the Todaiji still stand.
Gallery
		


=== Politics ===
A number of scholars have characterized the Nara period as a time of penal and administrative legal order. The Taihō Code called for the establishment of administrative sects underneath the central government, and modeled many of the codes from the Chinese Tang dynasty. The code eventually disbanded, but its contents were largely preserved in the Yōrō Code of 718.Occupants of the throne during the period gradually shifted their focus from military preparation, to religious rites and institutions, in an attempt to strengthen their divine authority over the population.


=== Religion and Temples ===
Nanto RokushūWith the establishment of the new capital, Asuka-dera, the temple of the Soga clan, was relocated within Nara. The Emperor Shōmu ordered the construction of Tōdai-ji Temple (largest wooden building in the world) and the world's largest bronze Buddha statue. The temples of Nara, known collectively as the Nanto Shichi Daiji, remained spiritually significant even beyond the move of the political capital to Heian-kyō in 794, thus giving Nara a synonym of Nanto (南都 "The southern Capital").
On December 2, 724 AD, in order to increase the visual “magnificence” of the city, an edict was ordered by the government for the noblemen and the wealthy to renovate the roofs, pillars, and walls of their homes, although at that time this was unfeasible.Sightseeing in Nara city became popular in the Edo period, during which several visitor's maps of Nara were widely published. During the Meiji Period, the Kofukuji Temple lost some land and its monks were converted into Shinto priests, due to Buddhism being associated with the old shogunate.
Gallery
		
		
		
		
		


=== Modern Nara ===
Even though Nara was the capital of Japan from 710 to 794, it was not designated a city until 1 February, 1898. Nara city has developed from a town of commerce in the Edo and Meiji periods to a modern tourist city, due to its large number of historical temples, landmarks and national monuments. Nara was added to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in December 1998. The architecture of some shops, ryokans and art galleries has been adapted from traditional merchant houses.Nara holds traditional festivals every year, including the Neri-Kuyo Eshiki, a spring festival held in Todaiji temple for over 1,000 years; and the Kemari Festival, in which people wear costumes ranging across 700 years  and play traditional games).In 1909, Tatsuno Kingo designed the Nara Hotel, whose architecture combines  modern elements with traditional Japanese style.


== Geography ==
The city of Nara lies in the northern end of Nara Prefecture, directly bordering Kyoto Prefecture to its north.  The city is 22.22 kilometres (13.81 mi) from North to South, from East to West. As a result of the latest merger, effective April 1, 2005, that combined the villages of Tsuge and Tsukigase with the city of Nara, the city now borders Mie Prefecture directly to its east. The total area is 276.84 square kilometres (106.89 square miles).Nara city, as well as several important settlements (such as Kashihara, Yamatokōriyama, Tenri, Yamatotakada, Sakurai and Goze), are located in the Nara Basin. This makes it the most densely-populated region of Nara Prefecture.The downtown of Nara is on the east side of the ancient Heijō Palace site, occupying the northern part of what was called the Gekyō (外京), literally the outer capital area. Many of the public offices (e.g. the Municipal office, the Nara Prefectural government, the Nara Police headquarters, etc.) are located on Nijō-ōji (二条大路), while Nara branch offices of major nationwide banks are on Sanjō-ōji (三条大路), with both avenues running east–west.
The highest point in the city is at the peak of Kaigahira-yama at an altitude of 822.0 m (2,696.85 ft) (Tsugehayama-cho district), and the lowest is in Ikeda-cho district, with an altitude of 56.4 m (185.04 ft).
Nara Basin
Murō-Akame-Aoyama Quasi-National Park
Yamato-Aogaki Quasi-National Park
Kasugayama Primeval Forest
Sarusawa Pond (猿沢池)
Mount Wakakusa


=== Climate ===
The climate of Nara Prefecture is generally temperate, although there are notable differences between the north-western basin area and the rest of the prefecture which is more mountainous.
The basin area climate has an inland characteristic, as represented in the higher daily temperature variance, and the difference between summer and winter temperatures. Winter temperatures average approximately 3 to 5 °C (37 to 41 °F), and from 25 to 28 °C (77 to 82 °F) in the summer with highest readings reaching close to 35 °C (95 °F). There has not been a single year since 1990 with more than 10 days of snowfall recorded by Nara Local Meteorological Observatory.
The climate in the rest of the prefecture is that of higher elevations especially in the south, with  −5 °C (23 °F) being the extreme minimum in winter. Heavy rainfall is often observed in summer. The annual accumulated rainfall totals as much as 3,000 to 5,000 mm (118.11 to 196.85 in), which is among the heaviest in Japan and indeed in the world outside the equatorial zone.
Spring and fall temperatures are temperate and comfortable. The mountainous region of Yoshino has been long popular for viewing cherry blossoms in the spring. In autumn, the southern mountains are also a popular destination for viewing fall foliage.


== Cityscape ==


== Demographics ==
As of April 1, 2017, the city has an estimated population of 359,666 and a population density of 1,300 persons per km2. There were 160,242 households residing in Nara. The highest concentration of both households and population, respectively about 46,000 and 125,000, is found along the newer bedtown districts, along the Kintetsu line connecting to Osaka.
There were about 3,000 registered foreigners in the city, of which Koreans and Chinese are the two largest groups with about 1,200 and 800 people respectively.

== Deer in Nara ==
According to the legendary history of Kasuga Shrine, the god Takemikazuchi arrived in Nara on a white deer to guard the newly built capital of Heijō-kyō. Since then, the deer have been regarded as heavenly animals, protecting the city and the country.Tame sika deer (also known as spotted deer or Japanese deer) roam through the town, especially in Nara Park. In 2015, there were more than 1,200 sika deer in Nara. Snack vendors sell sika senbei (deer crackers) to visitors so they can feed the deer. Some deer have learned to bow in order to receive senbei from people.
Gallery
		
		
		


== Education ==
As of 2005, there are 16 high schools and 6 universities located in the city of Nara.


=== Universities ===

Nara Women's University is one of only two national women's universities in Japan. Nara Institute of Science and Technology is a graduate research university specializing in biological, information, and materials sciences.


=== Primary and secondary education ===


==== Public schools ====
Public elementary and junior high schools are operated by the city of Nara.
Public high schools are operated by the Nara Prefecture.


==== Private schools ====
Private high schools in Nara include the Tōdaiji Gakuen, a private school founded by the temple in 1926.


== Transportation ==

The main central station of Nara is Kintetsu Nara Station with JR Nara station some 500m west and much closer to Shin-Omiya station.


=== Rail ===
West Japan Railway Company
Kansai Main Line (Yamatoji Line): Narayama Station - Nara Station
Sakurai Line (Manyō-Mahoroba Line): Nara Station - Kyōbate Station - Obitoke Station
Kintetsu Railway
Nara Line: Tomio Station - Gakuen-mae Station - Ayameike Station - Yamato-Saidaiji Station - Shin-Ōmiya Station - Kintetsu Nara Station
Kyoto Line: Takanohara Station - Heijō Station - Yamato-Saidaiji Station
Kashihara Line: Yamato-Saidaiji Station - Amagatsuji Station - Nishinokyō Station
Keihanna Line: Gakken Nara-Tomigaoka Station

I really loved their sparkling sake and a sakura flower yeast fermented sake.

text.wiki:
Nara (奈良市, Nara-shi, Japanese: [naꜜɾa]) is the capital city of Nara Prefecture, Japan. 
As of 1 April 2019, Nara has an estimated population of 359,666, making it the largest city in Nara Prefecture and sixth-largest in the Kansai region of Honshu. Nara is a core city located in the northern part of Nara Prefecture bordering the Kyoto Prefecture. 
Nara was the capital of Japan during the Nara period from 710 to 794 as the seat of the Emperor before the capital was moved to Kyoto. Nara is home to eight temples, shrines, and ruins, specifically Tōdai-ji, Saidai-ji, Kōfuku-ji, Kasuga Shrine, Gangō-ji, Yakushi-ji, Tōshōdai-ji, and the Heijō Palace, together with Kasugayama Primeval Forest, collectively form the Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 


== Etymology ==
By the Heian period, a variety of different characters had been used to represent the name Nara: 乃楽, 乃羅, 平, 平城, 名良, 奈良, 奈羅, 常, 那良, 那楽, 那羅, 楢, 諾良, 諾楽, 寧, 寧楽 and 儺羅.
A number of theories for the origin of the name "Nara" have been proposed, and some of the better-known ones are listed here. The second theory in the list, from the notable folklorist Kunio Yanagita (1875-1962), is most widely accepted at present.

The Nihon Shoki (The Chronicles of Japan, the second oldest book of classical Japanese history) suggests that "Nara" was derived from narasu (to flatten, to level). According to this account, in September in the tenth year of Emperor Sujin, "leading selected soldiers (the rebels) went forward, climbed Nara-yama (hills lying to the north of Heijō-kyō) and put them in order. Now the imperial forces gathered and flattened trees and plants. Therefore the mountain is called Nara-yama." Though the narrative itself is regarded as a folk etymology and few researchers regard it as historical, this is the oldest surviving suggestion, and is linguistically similar to the following theory by Yanagita.
"Flat land" theory (currently most widely accepted): In his 1936 study of placenames, the author Kunio Yanagita states that "the topographical feature of an area of relatively gentle gradient on the side of a mountain, which is called taira in eastern Japan and hae in the south of Kyushu, is called naru in the Chūgoku region and Shikoku (central Japan). This word gives rise to the verb narasu, adverb narashi, and adjective narushi." This is supported by entries in a dialect dictionary for nouns referring to flat areas: naru (found in Aida District, Okayama Prefecture and Ketaka District, Tottori Prefecture) and naro (found in Kōchi Prefecture); and also by an adjective narui which is not standard Japanese, but is found all across central Japan, with meanings of "gentle", "gently sloping", or "easy". Yanagita further comments that the way in which the fact that so many of these placenames are written using the character 平 ("flat"), or other characters in which it is an element, demonstrates the validity of this theory. Citing a 1795 document, Inaba-shi (因幡志) from the province of Inaba, the eastern part of modern Tottori, as indicating the reading naruji for the word 平地 (standard reading heichi, meaning "level/flat ground/land/country, a plain"), Yanagita suggests that naruji would have been used as a common noun there until the modern period. Of course, the fact that historically "Nara" was also written 平 or 平城 as above is further support for this theory.
The idea that Nara is derived from 楢 nara (Japanese for "oak, deciduous Quercus spp.") is the next most common opinion. This idea was suggested by a linguist, Yoshida Togo. This noun for the plant can be seen as early as in Man'yōshū (7-8th century) and Harima-no-kuni Fudoki (715). The latter book states the place name Narahara in Harima (around present-day Kasai)　derives from this nara tree, which might support Yoshida's theory. Note that the name of the nearby city of Kashihara (literally "live oak plain") contains a semantically similar morpheme (Japanese 橿 kashi "live oak, evergreen Quercus spp.").
Nara could be a loan word from Korean nara (나라 : country, nation, kingdom). This idea was put forward by a linguist Matsuoka Shizuo. Not much about the Old Korean language is known today, and the first written attestation of a word ancestral to Modern Korean nara is as late as the 15th century, such as in Yongbieocheonga (1447),  Wolinseokbo (月印釋譜. 1459), or Beophwagyeongeonhae (法華經諺解. 1463), and there is no evidence that proves the word already existed as far back as the 7th century. These 15th-century books used narah (나랗), an old form of nara in Korean, and its older form might be reconstructed *narak. American  linguist Christopher I. Beckwith infers the Korean narak derives from the late Middle Old Chinese 壌 (*nrak, earth), from early *narak, and has no connection with Goguryoic and Japanese na. (See also the next theory.) Kusuhara et al. also points out this hypothesis cannot account for the fact there are many places named Nara, Naru and Naro besides this Nara.
There is the idea that Nara is akin to Tungusic na. In some Tungusic languages such as Orok (and likely Goguryeo language), na means earth, land or the like. Some have speculated about a connection between these Tungusic words and Old Japanese nawi, an archaic and somewhat obscure word that appears in the verb phrases nawi furu and nawi yoru ('an earthquake occurs, to have an earthquake').The "Flat land" theory is adopted by Nihon Kokugo Daijiten (the largest dictionary of Japanese language), various dictionaries for place names, history books on Nara and the like today, and it is regarded as the most likely.


== History ==


=== Pre-Nara/Origins ===
There are a number of kofun in Nara, including Gosashi Kofun, Hishiage Kofun (ヒシアゲ古墳), Horaisan Kofun (宝来山古墳), Konabe Kofun (コナベ古墳), Saki Ishizukayama Kofun (佐紀石塚山古墳), Saki Misasagiyama Kofun (佐紀陵山古墳), and Uwanabe Kofun (ウワナベ古墳).
By decree of an edict on March 11, 708 AD, Empress Genmei ordered the court to relocate to the new capital, Nara. Once known as Heijō or Heijō-kyō, the city was established as Japan's first permanent capital in 710 CE; it was the seat of government until 784 CE, albeit with five year interruption, lasting from 741-5 CE. Heijō, as the ‘penultimate court’, however, was abandoned by the order of Emperor Kammu in 784 CE in favor of the temporary site of Nagaoka, and then Heian-kyō (Kyoto) which retained the status of capital for 1,100 years, until the Meiji Emperor made the final move to Edo in 1869 CE. This first relocation was due to the court's transformation from an imperial nobility to a force of metropolitan elites and new technique of dynastic shedding which had refashioned the relationship between court, nobility, and country. Moreover, the ancient capital lent its name to Nara period.As a reactionary expression to the political centralization of China, the city of Nara (Heijō) was modeled after the Tang capital at Chang’an. Nara was laid out on a grid—which was based upon the Handen system—whereby the city was divided by four great roads. Likewise, according to Chinese cosmology, the ruler's place was fixed like the pole star. By dominating the capital, the ruler brought heaven to earth. Thus, the south facing palace centered at the north, bisected the ancient city, instituting ‘Right Capital’ and ‘Left Capital’ zones. As Nara came to be the epicenter of Buddhist church and drawing pilgrimage site, the city plan incorporated various pre-Heijō and Heijō period temples, of which the Yakushiji and the Todaiji still stand.
Gallery
		


=== Politics ===
A number of scholars have characterized the Nara period as a time of penal and administrative legal order. The Taihō Code called for the establishment of administrative sects underneath the central government, and modeled many of the codes from the Chinese Tang dynasty. The code eventually disbanded, but its contents were largely preserved in the Yōrō Code of 718.Occupants of the throne during the period gradually shifted their focus from military preparation, to religious rites and institutions, in an attempt to strengthen their divine authority over the population.


=== Religion and Temples ===
Nanto RokushūWith the establishment of the new capital, Asuka-dera, the temple of the Soga clan, was relocated within Nara. The Emperor Shōmu ordered the construction of Tōdai-ji Temple (largest wooden building in the world) and the world's largest bronze Buddha statue. The temples of Nara, known collectively as the Nanto Shichi Daiji, remained spiritually significant even beyond the move of the political capital to Heian-kyō in 794, thus giving Nara a synonym of Nanto (南都 "The southern Capital").
On December 2, 724 AD, in order to increase the visual “magnificence” of the city, an edict was ordered by the government for the noblemen and the wealthy to renovate the roofs, pillars, and walls of their homes, although at that time this was unfeasible.Sightseeing in Nara city became popular in the Edo period, during which several visitor's maps of Nara were widely published. During the Meiji Period, the Kofukuji Temple lost some land and its monks were converted into Shinto priests, due to Buddhism being associated with the old shogunate.
Gallery
		
		
		
		
		


=== Modern Nara ===
Even though Nara was the capital of Japan from 710 to 794, it was not designated a city until 1 February, 1898. Nara city has developed from a town of commerce in the Edo and Meiji periods to a modern tourist city, due to its large number of historical temples, landmarks and national monuments. Nara was added to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in December 1998. The architecture of some shops, ryokans and art galleries has been adapted from traditional merchant houses.Nara holds traditional festivals every year, including the Neri-Kuyo Eshiki, a spring festival held in Todaiji temple for over 1,000 years; and the Kemari Festival, in which people wear costumes ranging across 700 years  and play traditional games).In 1909, Tatsuno Kingo designed the Nara Hotel, whose architecture combines  modern elements with traditional Japanese style.


== Geography ==
The city of Nara lies in the northern end of Nara Prefecture, directly bordering Kyoto Prefecture to its north.  The city is 22.22 kilometres (13.81 mi) from North to South, from East to West. As a result of the latest merger, effective April 1, 2005, that combined the villages of Tsuge and Tsukigase with the city of Nara, the city now borders Mie Prefecture directly to its east. The total area is 276.84 square kilometres (106.89 square miles).Nara city, as well as several important settlements (such as Kashihara, Yamatokōriyama, Tenri, Yamatotakada, Sakurai and Goze), are located in the Nara Basin. This makes it the most densely-populated region of Nara Prefecture.The downtown of Nara is on the east side of the ancient Heijō Palace site, occupying the northern part of what was called the Gekyō (外京), literally the outer capital area. Many of the public offices (e.g. the Municipal office, the Nara Prefectural government, the Nara Police headquarters, etc.) are located on Nijō-ōji (二条大路), while Nara branch offices of major nationwide banks are on Sanjō-ōji (三条大路), with both avenues running east–west.
The highest point in the city is at the peak of Kaigahira-yama at an altitude of 822.0 m (2,696.85 ft) (Tsugehayama-cho district), and the lowest is in Ikeda-cho district, with an altitude of 56.4 m (185.04 ft).
Nara Basin
Murō-Akame-Aoyama Quasi-National Park
Yamato-Aogaki Quasi-National Park
Kasugayama Primeval Forest
Sarusawa Pond (猿沢池)
Mount Wakakusa


=== Climate ===
The climate of Nara Prefecture is generally temperate, although there are notable differences between the north-western basin area and the rest of the prefecture which is more mountainous.
The basin area climate has an inland characteristic, as represented in the higher daily temperature variance, and the difference between summer and winter temperatures. Winter temperatures average approximately 3 to 5 °C (37 to 41 °F), and from 25 to 28 °C (77 to 82 °F) in the summer with highest readings reaching close to 35 °C (95 °F). There has not been a single year since 1990 with more than 10 days of snowfall recorded by Nara Local Meteorological Observatory.
The climate in the rest of the prefecture is that of higher elevations especially in the south, with  −5 °C (23 °F) being the extreme minimum in winter. Heavy rainfall is often observed in summer. The annual accumulated rainfall totals as much as 3,000 to 5,000 mm (118.11 to 196.85 in), which is among the heaviest in Japan and indeed in the world outside the equatorial zone.
Spring and fall temperatures are temperate and comfortable. The mountainous region of Yoshino has been long popular for viewing cherry blossoms in the spring. In autumn, the southern mountains are also a popular destination for viewing fall foliage.


== Cityscape ==


== Demographics ==
As of April 1, 2017, the city has an estimated population of 359,666 and a population density of 1,300 persons per km2. There were 160,242 households residing in Nara. The highest concentration of both households and population, respectively about 46,000 and 125,000, is found along the newer bedtown districts, along the Kintetsu line connecting to Osaka.
There were about 3,000 registered foreigners in the city, of which Koreans and Chinese are the two largest groups with about 1,200 and 800 people respectively.


== Landmarks and culture ==


=== Buddhist temples ===

== Deer in Nara ==
According to the legendary history of Kasuga Shrine, the god Takemikazuchi arrived in Nara on a white deer to guard the newly built capital of Heijō-kyō. Since then, the deer have been regarded as heavenly animals, protecting the city and the country.Tame sika deer (also known as spotted deer or Japanese deer) roam through the town, especially in Nara Park. In 2015, there were more than 1,200 sika deer in Nara. Snack vendors sell sika senbei (deer crackers) to visitors so they can feed the deer. Some deer have learned to bow in order to receive senbei from people.
Gallery
		
		
		


== Education ==
As of 2005, there are 16 high schools and 6 universities located in the city of Nara.


=== Universities ===

Nara Women's University is one of only two national women's universities in Japan. Nara Institute of Science and Technology is a graduate research university specializing in biological, information, and materials sciences.


=== Primary and secondary education ===


==== Public schools ====
Public elementary and junior high schools are operated by the city of Nara.
Public high schools are operated by the Nara Prefecture.


==== Private schools ====
Private high schools in Nara include the Tōdaiji Gakuen, a private school founded by the temple in 1926.


== Transportation ==

The main central station of Nara is Kintetsu Nara Station with JR Nara station some 500m west and much closer to Shin-Omiya station.


=== Rail ===
West Japan Railway Company

Kashihara Line: Yamato-Saidaiji Station - Amagatsuji Station - Nishinokyō Station

text.quote: Photography exhibits & a gift shop in a glass-walled space designed in harmony with the environment.
trip: Located slightly away from the main sights, this photography museum hosts temporary exhibitions throughout the year. At the time of my visit it was showing two interesting exhibitions: Irie Taikichi's "Flowers" showing some of his photographs of flowers from around Nara, and

It's a bit of a walk from the main sites, but well worth it. There were two excellent exhibits and the building itself is contemplative and beautifully done. There was also a bird exhibit possibly the work of club members. It was a thoroughly enjoyable experience.

Friends who live nearby delight in taking us to see this photography museum. Now, photography museums are fairly rare, and ones done right (not too cramped or too artsy) are very hard to find. This is one of them. The permanent collection gives some refreshingly new insights

We had a bit of a walk from the station, but a pleasant one, through rice fields and bamboo groves, with pleasant wayside shrines, coffee shops and handicraft boutiques. When we got to the photography museum, though, it didn't disappoint. A very pleasant lady sold us tickets

Some of the appeal of this museum was probably lost on me as I'm not particularly knowledgeable on photography and have no idea who Irie Taikichi is, however, it was still enjoyable and was a very different experience than anywhere else I visited in Nara. The photos were good
