text.wiki:
Ningen Isu (Japanese: 人間椅子, Hepburn: Ningen'isu, lit. "The Human Chair") is a Japanese heavy metal band from Hirosaki, formed in 1987 by Shinji Wajima (guitars and vocal) and Ken-ichi Suzuki (bass and vocal). They took their name from the 1924 short story of the same name by Edogawa Rampo.


== History ==


=== 1970s – 1980s ===
Both natives of Hirosaki, Wajima and Suzuki first became acquainted with one another while attending a concert in a local music salon. They eventually became close friends when in 1981, they both entered Hirosaki High School. Their friendship would further develop through frequent exchanges of music-records. It was around this time that Suzuki first exposed Wajima to the music of Kiss. Wajima himself was listening to the music of The Beatles, King Crimson, Deep Purple, and Led Zeppelin at the time, while Suzuki favored Kiss, Saxon and Judas Priest. Suzuki was impressed by Wajima's talent for songwriting and wrote a song called "Demon", while Wajima wrote a song called "Tetsugōshi Mokushi-roku" (Apocalypse of Iron Grill), which was not received well by the music salon but which Suzuki liked nonetheless. Two years later, Wajima and Suzuki joined Shine Shine Dan ('dead dead group'), a band formed by members of the salon, with whom they played hard rock songs at music festivals.
In 1985, after entering different universities (Wajima would study Buddhism at Komazawa University while Suzuki studied Russian literature at Sophia University), they formed a hard rock band, whose name was changed to Ningen'isu in 1987, the year when drummer Noriyoshi Kamidate joined the band. They first gained public attention in 1989 through a performance of their song Injū (Beast In The Shadows) on the Japanese Television program "Ikasu Band Tengoku" (which roughly translates to "cool band heaven"), a newly enitiated TV-band-contest that first aired on TBS Television during the same year. Their uniquely heavy sound, technical skill, and lyrics full of literary references took the judges by surprise.


=== 1990 – 2004 ===
In 1990, they released their first album "Ningen Isu", followed two years later by "Ōgon no Yoake", after which Kamidate left the band. They kept heavy sound and lyrics full of literature.
Drummer Masuhiro Goto would support the recording of their fourth album "Rashōmon" in 1993. In 1995 and 1996, Iwao Tsuchiya served as the band's drummer but was replaced by Goto as a permanent member until his leaving in 2003.
In 2004, the current drummer Nobu Nakajima joined. Wajima, Suzuki, and Nakajima once lived in a neighborhood in the district Koenji, Tokyo, which is famous for its subculture, music and free atmosphere.


=== 2004 – 2020 ===
Ningen Isu has seen a significant increase in popularity in recent years. They spent years being little known outside Japan; the sales of their CDs didn't go well, but they gradually gained popularity.
The band played at the Ozzfest 2013, hosted by Ozzy Osbourne, which they as Black Sabbath fans felt honored by. And after that, they have got more and more fans.
In 2019, their record "Shin Seinen" reached rank 14 in the Oricon music charts, their highest chart position of so far. 
Published on May 14, 2019, their song "Heartless Scat" on YouTube reached 1.5 million views on July 3, 2019. "Heartless Scat" has since achieved 6.6 million views, as of August 31, 2020.
The band performed as their first world tour in Berlin, Bochum, and London in February 2020. 


== Musical style ==
The band often writes about Japanese classical literature, for example: Edogawa Rampo, Dazai Osamu, Akutagawa Ryunosuke, Tanizaki Jun-ichiro, Mishima Yukio and also Edgar Allan Poe, H. P. Lovecraft, Friedrich Nietzsche, Georges Bataille and so on. They often take up topics such as hell, Buddhism, the universe, samurai and gambling. Wajima and Suzuki have a local accent called the "Tsugaru dialect", which adds a unique and heavy atmosphere and rhythm to their songs. They, especially Wajima, often use difficult and old Japanese (words used in Edo period to Showa period, often hard to understand even for Japanese people). They often wear Kimono and traditional underwear Fundoshi on stage.


== Influences ==
Ningen Isu was strongly influenced by Black Sabbath. Other influences include UFO, Led Zeppelin, Kiss, Budgie, King Crimson, and similar artists. The play style of Wajima's guitar is influenced by guitarists such as Robert Fripp, Tony Iommi, Jimmy Page, Ace Frehley, Michael Schenker, and also the sound of Tsugaru-jamisen. Suzuki loves Kiss and paints his face white and moves like Gene Simmons. Suzuki has a high opinion of Nakajima's eight beat.


== Members ==


=== Current members ===
Shinji Wajima / Wazzy (和嶋慎治; born 25 December 1965) – guitars, vocals, theremin, main lyrics, composer (1987–present)His costume has motifs of literary master of Meiji era. He loves the Beatles, blues and Japanese old-style pop song. So the sound he makes is melodious. He often uses the original effectors which he makes by himself. One of them called "Shocker"(the enemy of Kamen Rider Series) make fuzzy unique and mysterious sound. He sometimes uses theremin, which adds cosmic mood. He loves Rakugo (one of the Japanese verbal entertainments) and made a song "Shinagawa Shinju". He also loves camping.  
Ken-ichi Suzuki / Suzuken (鈴木研一; born 11 March 1966) – bass, vocals, lyrics, composer (1987–present)He paints his face white and dresses like a Buddhist monk. Wears "Fundoshi" for the first time in the band, old Japanese underwear under the Kimono. In the band's early days, Suzuki often wore clothes like Nezumi-otoko, a rat man (a character of Ge-Ge-Ge no Kitaro by Shigeru Mizuki), which made them impressive. He sometimes opens events called "Nazareth" in which he plays DJ (only hard rock). He loves Neputa festival held in Hirosaki.
Nobu Nakajima / Nobu (ナカジマノブ; born 20 September 1966) – drums, vocals, lyrics, composer (2004–present)He wears Koikuchi shirt and sunglasses and looks like a Japanese gangster. He sometimes uses "Dora" (kind of Japanese gong). His powerful character and play make him called "Aniki", which means big brother. He is a big fan of Hideshi Hino and composed a song "Jigoku Kozo"(which means "a boy of hell", which is a comic written by Hino). He collects a lot of things, for example sneakers, dam cards, comics and so on.


=== Former members ===
Noriyoshi Kamidate – drums (1987–1992)
Masuhiro Goto – drums, vocals (1996–2003) as a support member (1993–1995)
Iwao Tsuchiya – drums, vocals (1995–1996)

text.wiki:
Namba (難波, Nanba, IPA: [namba]) is a district of Osaka, Japan. It is located in Chūō and Naniwa wards. Namba is regarded as the center of so-called Minami ("South") area of Osaka. Its name is one of variations on the former name of Osaka, Naniwa.  Namba is best known as the city's main south-central railway terminus: JR, Kintetsu, Nankai, Hanshin, and three Osaka Metro subway lines have stations there.
Some of the most famous images of Osaka, including the Glico Man and the Kani Doraku Crab, are located around the Dōtonbori canal in Namba.  Namba is also known as an entertainment district, and hosts many of the city's most popular bars, restaurants, nightclubs, arcades, and pachinko parlors.  The area is also known for shopping, with the Takashimaya department store (for older styles) and the sprawling underground Namba City shopping mall (for newer styles).
Namba Parks is a new development consisting of a high office building, called "Parks Tower," and a 120-tenant shopping mall with rooftop garden.  Various kinds of restaurants (Japanese, Korean, Italian, etc.) are located on the 6th floor, and shops on the 2nd to 5th floors.  Parks Garden features enough greenery to help visitors forget that they're in the middle of the city.  There is also an amphitheater for live shows, as well as space for small personal vegetable gardens and wagon shops.
NMB48 bases in Namba.


== Railway stations ==

text.wiki:
Tōdai-ji (東大寺, Eastern Great Temple) is a Buddhist temple complex that was once one of the powerful Seven Great Temples, located in the city of Nara, Japan. Though it was originally founded in the year 738 CE, Todai-ji was not opened until the year 752 CE. Its Great Buddha Hall (大仏殿 Daibutsuden) houses the world's largest bronze statue of the Buddha Vairocana, known in Japanese as Daibutsu (大仏). The temple also serves as the Japanese headquarters of the Kegon school of Buddhism. The temple is a listed UNESCO World Heritage Site as one of the "Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara", together with seven other sites including temples, shrines and places in the city of Nara.


== History ==


=== Origins ===

The beginning of building a temple where the Kinshōsen-ji complex sits today can be dated to 728 CE, when Emperor Shōmu established Kinshōsen-ji (金鐘山寺) as an appeasement for Prince Motoi (ja:基王), his first son with his Fujiwara clan consort Kōmyōshi. Prince Motoi died a year after his birth.
During the Tenpyō era, Japan suffered from a series of disasters and epidemics. It was after experiencing these problems that Emperor Shōmu issued an edict in 741 to promote the construction of provincial temples throughout the nation. Later in 743 during the Tenpyō era the Emperor commissioned the Daibutsu to be built in 743. Tōdai-ji (still Kinshōsen-ji at the time) was appointed as the provincial temple of Yamato Province and the head of all the provincial temples. With the alleged coup d'état by Nagaya in 729, a major outbreak of smallpox around 735–737, worsened by several consecutive years of poor crops, followed by a rebellion led by Fujiwara no Hirotsugu in 740, the country was in a chaotic situation. Emperor Shōmu had been forced to move the capital four times, indicating a certain level of instability during this period.


=== Role in early Japanese Buddhism ===
According to legend, the monk Gyōki went to Ise Grand Shrine to reconcile Shinto with Buddhism. He spent seven days and nights reciting sutras until the oracle declared Vairocana Buddha compatible with worship of the sun goddess Amaterasu.
Under the Ritsuryō system of government in the Nara period, Buddhism was heavily regulated by the state through the Sōgō (僧綱, Office of Priestly Affairs). During this time, Tōdai-ji served as the central administrative temple for the provincial temples and for the six Buddhist schools in Japan at the time: the Hossō, Kegon, Jōjitsu, Sanron, Ritsu and Kusha. Letters dating from this time also show that all six Buddhist schools had offices at Tōdai-ji, complete with administrators, shrines and their own library.

Japanese Buddhism during this time still maintained the lineage of the Vinaya and all officially licensed monks were required to take their ordination under the Vinaya at Tōdai-ji.  In 754 CE, ordination was given by Ganjin, who arrived in Japan after traveling over 12 years and six attempts of crossing the sea from China, to Empress Kōken, former Emperor Shōmu and others. Later Buddhist monks, including Kūkai and Saichō received their ordination here as well. During Kūkai's administration of the Sōgō, additional ordination ceremonies were added to Tōdai-ji, including the ordination of the Bodhisattva Precepts from the Brahma Net Sutra and the esoteric Precepts, or Samaya, from Kukai's own newly established Shingon school of Buddhism. Kūkai added an Abhiseka Hall to use for initiating monks of the six Nara schools into the esoteric teachings. by 829 CE.


=== Decline ===
As the center of power in Japanese Buddhism shifted away from Nara to Mount Hiei and the Tendai sect, and when the capital of Japan moved to Kamakura, Tōdai-ji's role in maintaining authority declined. In later generations, the Vinaya lineage also died out, despite repeated attempts to revive it; thus no more ordination ceremonies take place at Tōdai-ji.


== Architecture ==


=== Initial construction ===

In 743, Emperor Shōmu issued a law stating that the people should become directly involved with the establishment of new Buddhist temples throughout Japan. The Emperor believed that such piety would inspire Buddha to protect his country from further disaster. Gyōki, with his pupils, traveled the provinces asking for donations. According to records kept by Tōdai-ji, more than 2,600,000 people in total helped construct the Great Buddha and its Hall; contributing rice, wood, metal, cloth, or labor; with 350,000 working directly on the statue's construction. The 16 m (52 ft) high statue was built through eight castings over three years, the head and neck being cast together as a separate element. The making of the statue was started first in Shigaraki. After enduring multiple fires and earthquakes, the construction was eventually resumed in Nara in 745, and the Buddha was finally completed in 751. A year later, in 752, the eye-opening ceremony was held with an attendance of 10,000 monks and 4,000 dancers to celebrate the completion of the Buddha. The Indian priest Bodhisena performed the eye-opening for Emperor Shōmu. The project cost Japan greatly, as the statue used much of Japan's bronze and relied entirely on imported gold.  48 lacquered cinnabar pillars, 1.5 m in diameter and 30 m long, support the blue tiled roof of the Daibutsu-den.Maps that include some of the original structures of Todai-ji are rare, though some still exist today. Some of these structures include, the two pagodas, the library, lecture hall, refectory, and the monk's quarters located behind the main hall. Todai-ji functioned not only as a place of worship and Buddhist practice, but as a place of higher learning and study. Much of what contemporaries now know about the original layout of the temple comes from the writings of monks who lived and studied there.
The original complex contained two 100 m pagodas, making them some of the tallest structures at the time. They were located on either side of the complex, one on the western (西塔) and one on the eastern side (東塔). The pagodas themselves were surrounded by a walled courtyard with four gates. These were destroyed by an earthquake. One of the sōrin finials survived and is standing at the spot where one of the pagodas used to stand.
The Shōsōin was its storehouse, and now contains many artifacts from the Tenpyō period of Japanese history.


=== Reconstructions post-Nara Period ===

 
The Great Buddha Hall (Daibutsuden) has been rebuilt twice after fire. The current building was finished in 1709, and although immense—57 metres (187 ft) long, 50 metres (160 ft) wide and 49 metres (161 ft) high—it is actually 30% smaller than its predecessor, being reduced from 11 to 7 bays wide due to lack of funds. Until 1998, it was the world's largest wooden building. It has been surpassed by modern structures, such as the Japanese baseball stadium 'Odate Jukai Dome', amongst others. The Great Buddha statue has been recast several times for various reasons, including earthquake damage. The current hands of the statue were made in the Momoyama Period (1568–1615), and the head was made in the Edo period (1615–1867).
The existing Nandaimon (Great South Gate) was constructed at the end of the 12th century based on Daibutsuyō style, after the original gate was destroyed by a typhoon during the Heian period. The dancing figures of the Nio, the two 8.5-metre-tall (28 ft) guardians at the Nandaimon, were built at around the same time by Unkei, Kaikei and their workshop members. The Nio are an A-un pair known as Ungyo, which by tradition has a facial expression with a closed mouth, and Agyo, which has an open mouthed expression. The two figures were closely evaluated and extensively restored by a team of art conservators between 1988 and 1993. Until then, these sculptures had never before been moved from the niches in which they were originally installed. This complex preservation project, costing $4.7 million, involved a restoration team of 15 experts from the National Treasure Repairing Institute in Kyoto.


=== Dimensions of the Daibutsu ===
The temple gives the following dimensions for the statue:
Height: 14.98 m (49 ft 2 in)
Face: 5.33 m (17 ft 6 in)
Eyes: 1.02 m (3 ft 4 in)
Nose: 0.5 m (1 ft 8 in)
Ears: 2.54 m (8 ft 4 in)The statue's shoulders are 28 meters across and there are 960 six curls atop its head.  The Birushana Buddha's golden halo is 27 m (87 ft) in diameter with 16 images each 2.4 m (8 ft) tall.Recently, using x-rays, a human tooth, along with pearls, mirrors, swords, and jewels were discovered inside of 
the knee of the Great Buddha; these are believed to be the relics of Emperor Shomu.The statue weighs 500 tonnes (550 short tons).


== Temple precincts and gardens ==
 
Various buildings of the Tōdai-ji have been incorporated within the overall aesthetic intention of the gardens' design.  Adjacent villas are today considered part of Tōdai-ji.  Some of these structures are now open to the public.
Over the centuries, the buildings and gardens have evolved together as to become an integral part of an organic and living temple community.
The Tōdai-ji Culture Center opened on October 10, 2011, comprising a museum to exhibit the many sculptures and other treasures enshrined in the various temple halls, along with a library and research centre, storage facility, and auditorium.


== Japanese national treasures at Todai-ji ==

The architectural master-works are classified as:


== Major historical events ==

728: Kinshōsen-ji, the forerunner of Tōdai-ji, is established as a gesture of appeasement for the troubled spirit of Prince Motoi.
741: Emperor Shōmu calls for nationwide establishment of provincial temples, and Kinshōsen-ji appointed as the head provincial temple of Yamato.
743: The Emperor commands that a very large Buddha image statue shall be built—the Daibutsu or Great Buddha—and initial work is begun at Shigaraki-no-miya.
745: The capital returns to Heijō-kyō, construction of the Great Buddha resumes in Nara. Usage of the name Tōdai-ji appears on record.
752: The Eye-opening Ceremony celebrating the completion of the Great Buddha held.
855: The head of the great statue of the Buddha Vairocana suddenly fell to the ground; and gifts from the pious throughout the empire were collected to create another, more well-seated head for the restored Daibutsu.


== In popular culture ==
Matsuo Bashō refers to the Great Buddha statue in a haiku (1689-1670):
初雪や /  いつ大仏 /  の柱立.
"First snow!/ When Buddha’s great statue/ pillar-erection"
And,
"First snow and / there stands the great Buddha / a pillar of strength"Tōdai-ji has been used as a location in several Japanese films and television dramas. It was also used in the 1950s John Wayne movie The Barbarian and the Geisha when Nandaimon, the Great South Gate, doubled as a city's gates.
On May 20, 1994, the international music festival The Great Music Experience was held at Tōdai-ji, supported by UNESCO. Performers included the Tokyo New Philharmonic Orchestra, X Japan, INXS, Jon Bon Jovi, Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan, Tomoyasu Hotei, Roger Taylor, classic Japanese drummers, and a Buddhist monk choir. This event, organized by British producer Tony Hollingsworth, was simultaneously broadcast in 55 countries on May 22 and 23, 1994.
The 2007 animation series Mononoke (モノノ怪), which is a spin-off of the 2006 horror anthology series Ayakashi: Samurai Horror Tales, references the Tōdai-ji, particularly the treasure room Shōsōin, in Episodes 8 and 9.


== International Outreach ==
Following the April 2019 fire that damaged the spire of another UNESCO World Heritage Site, the Cathedral of Notre Dame in Paris, Japanese authorities declared plans to expand fire prevention measures at several historic locations including Todai-ji in Nara, partly by hiring new, younger employees in a context where temple and shrine staff are aging.  Custodians of Todaiji temple also installed a donation box, stating “Let’s Rebuild Notre Dame Cathedral”, in the hallway behind the Great Buddha statue.  In June 2019, a sign next to the box, in Japanese and English, explained why Todai-ji, as headquarters of the Kegon sect of Buddhism, was soliciting funds in this way. The English version declared, “Todai-ji temple has been reconstructed every time it burned down by big fires thanks to the significant effort of many people.  We sincerely express our deepest sympathy for the tragedy that hit the Notre-Dame de Paris. Going beyond the creed, we would like to ask everyone for your support to reconstruct the cathedral.”

Amazing to see the big Buddha and the Golden Buddah. The wild deer were mangy. The park is big enough not to feel crowded.

The great Buddha hall was incredible, very historic and just nice to watch. You will also see many deers from Nara park

Beautiful temple! Seeing the giant Buddha was a wonderful experience. Be warned though, it will be SUPER packed!

This temple is huge and then you walk in and see the Big Buddha, impressive. Loved hearing the facts regarding this temple from our tour guide. I thought the deer were kinda annoying, they were everywhere.

An inspiring site with the enormous Buddha and beautiful temple buildings. A must see in Nara. It’s only an hour from Kyoto by train which runs frequently.

you can visit temple from 7:30 to 17:00. you must pay entrance fee for visiting inside the temple but you can visit and take great photo in outside of temple free.

Going to this temple was a real highlight. Any spiritual person should try to go here if they are visiting nearby. Beautiful scenery and atmosphere

The enormity of this temple must be experienced. We happened upon a drumming performance that was so great. Truly a must on your travels in Japan.

Gorgeous huge Buddha in the largest wooden building in the world does not disappoint. Go early to avoid the rush and chaos of the crowds.

The 800 yr old Buddha within the temple is magnificent! Definitely must see. The temple grounds are well kept and beautiful.

We visited on a weekday, while there were perhaps not as many tourists as I expected, this was more than made up for by school children of all ages on field trips. Todai-ji also pales in comparison to Kinkakuji and similar Kyoto attractions. If you've been to those then the main

This is a must see if you’re in Osaka, Kyoto or Nara. It is one of the most impressive temples in terms of its size. An imposing wooden structure housing the worlds largest bronze Buddha statue. Not to be missed!

Easy access from the train station. Just get the bus day pass. 600 yen entrance and I recommend the audio talk which explains the statues and grounds etc. A very old monument rich in history, the biggest wooden structure in the world! Just a good visit really- not too big!

Very large and impressive Eden temple which contains many statues including a giant Buddha. Quite a long walk to reach it and there are hundreds of free roaming deer in the park. These look cute and can be very friendly.

I’m not Buddhist hence probably unable to appreciate the magnificence of the statue. Though impressive in itself. The history is probably more impressive than the look of actual structure as there are many similar such monuments around the world. It’s still a beautiful walk in

This is the oldest and largest wooden structure surviving and looking at the massive joints, one cannot but marvel at the skills of the builders. The Budhha is magnificent as well as the accompanying Bodhistva and other figures.

In my short stint in Japan, I visited temples and shrines in Osaka, Kyoto and Nara. I found Nara to be the best of the three cities because it’s not wrapped up by concrete all around. In addition, another peculiarities of the city which I really liked are the deers; there are

Lovely temple, beautiful vibes, lots of tourists but you still can find a quiet corner and enjoy the visit. Buddha Vairocana is one of the largest statues of Buddha in the world, the weight is 380 tons.

It was built by an emperor more than a thousand years ago. He used so much bronze, that all of Japan's bronze went into this Buddha statue. There is so much bronze, you can get from level 1 smithing to 100 in runescape just by making bronze swords. I got my 10th goshuin here.

My wife and I were here on a Gate1 tour, Optional Excursion to Nara Park. We enjoyed the Nara Park, and seeing the temple was just an additional bonus. I think it is the biggest wooden building, and I think the bronze Buddha statue is the biggest in the world. Very awesome
It is a whole package tour. Great temple, with beautiful park, also with pond, deers, and also pigeons. Me and my family are very satisfied
Felt so much as ease seeing this temple in Nara. The temple was of a wooden structure and was pretty well maintained. Can definitely see the Chinese influence and was awed by the Giant Buddha
The largest wooden building and the largest bronze statue of Buddha in the world. An impressive structure from outside and a meditative atmosphere within.
Really amazing place with beautiful statues of buddha and others. Whole place is really great and I recommend to visit this place.

We visited this temple on April 9. You have the choice of two entrance fees. One only for the main hall with the Buddha and an other one for the main hall and the museum. We did not visit the museum. This place can be very crowded at times.

I personally enjoyed visiting this temple and it's one of my favourite. There is desciption in english and mandarin for tourist to understand more about the place. Worth the price. The Buddha statue in the Great Hall is mesmerizing.

You cannot miss this temple if you're visiting Nara. Impressive statues of Buddha (in fact is the biggest bronze statue of Buddha in the world) and his guardians are completing this beautiful construction. The deers walking free through the surroundings makes a great atmosphere.

Definitely a world heritage site, the sheer size of the buddha and its accompanying solid-gold backdrop make for a neat thing to see in person. Walking about an entirely wooden structure of such magnitude built so long ago (far before any machine help) is also impressive. It's
This great big Buddha statue is amazing to see -- one of the largest of its kind. There are very few signs in English but you are allowed to take photos inside the Temple.
the budha statue is amazing and there are other nice statues, it's definitely wirth the train ride from Kyoto

Very easy access from Nara Park and definitely worth a visit. It is one of the more expensive temples we had visited in Japan, at 1000 yen per person but still very reasonable for the experience! A really impressive wooden structure, housing impressive statues of Buddhist

Visited here while in Nara for the day. Very impressive building - especially when you realize it was built 1300 years ago. Worth a visit and a walk around. Costs ¥600/pp to enter but worth it. Large buddha is also interesting.

Something that should be on your to do list while in Nara. There are plenty of deers in the lead up to the temple as well as tourist shops. You can get a bus there from the train station that stops at different key sites. A very impressive structure to see while spending your

The bronze Budda is impressive, if it's the biggest one or not doesn't really matter. Beautiful, made the trip to Nara worth it. Loved the other statues as well, but for me the most awesome part is the wooden structure of the temple.

For those people that said previously this is the biggest buddah in the world, they've obviously never been to Thailand (Big Buddah Phuket). The one there atop a mountain is visible from space and makes this temples look insignificant. That said the buddah here is beautiful.

It is one of those touristy places that one just have to see at least once. It has great cultural and historical importance. Dimensions of the main hall, which is also the biggest wooden building in the world, are breathtaking. It pays if you choose your timing for a visit

Really very beautiful. The cherry blossoms were falling while we were here as well. As at every shrine, there were charms to buy, but they were very specific to this shrine - a lot of deer souvenirs
This place is really worth getting an admission ticket and going inside. There is a giant wooden statue of Buddha inside the main hall that is unlike anything else. Really worth a visit.

The temple is extremely impressive, as might be expected of the largest wooden building in the world. With the cherry blossoms and blue skies, it feels quintessentially Japanese. The Buddha inside is huge. The place is big enough not to be ruined by the crowds. A must see.

Oh my gosh! This Buddha is so huge it's almost impossible to believe. The size and scale of the original temple is breath taking. We were there during sakurai season and the cherry trees all in bloom was absolutely gorgeous. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes as there is a lot

This is the site of the world's biggest Buddha and it is well worth the time and effort to visit. Large crowds as you would imagine, flock to this attraction and I am sure no one walks away disappointed. Really worth a visit and one not to miss if in this part of Japan.

It's hard to describe the scale of the temple and Buddha. It's truly something that should be seen in person as pictures don't do it justice. Gets very busy as there are several tour buses that stop here.
The biggeat wood builduing in the world that houses one of the biggest buddhas in Japan, beautiful gardens and deers all over the property

One of must visit places in Nara. Catch bus from train station. A couple minutes of walk to the temple entrance. Beautiful Japanese monument.
It is a must see whether you do a day tour from Osaka or Kyoto. The area is busy but even with the large number of tourist there is plenty of space for everyone. Lots of school tours in April.

This place is massive. The gate has two impressive wooden figures on each side. Then the main gallery is home of one of Japan’s biggest Buddha statues. It gets really crowded but due to the size of everything is hard to miss any detail.

Lovely temple, great as an addition to the Nara deer park visit. It wasn't too crowded so we were able to see everything and take some lovely pictures. Don't forget to try and go through the column on the right hand side of the temple!

The outer gate to the temple complex is impressive with the two guardians at either side - Giants! After that you pay and enter the complex and the temple itself stands out. Once you get inside, you realize how large the bronze statues of Buddha is.
The temple is very old with giant statue of Buddha. nicely maintained. garden is beautiful and cover a large area. Large number of Deer wandering through the garden is an added attraction.
A Must-have while in Nara. The building is huge - which makes the crowds not disappear but much less noticeable.

After being in Kyoto you kind of get over all the temples but this is quite spectacular. Very joyful

Paid to see the giant Buddha and it was worth it. Enormous temple, as it would be to encase a giant Buddha! Awesome sight and low cost entry. Cherry blossom too.
This is probably the biggest statue of Buddha I've seen. It truly is a sight to be desired and not to be missed. A lovely peaceful place. A must do in my opinion.
A huge and impressive Buddha statue! One of the biggest wooden buddha statues in the world. An interesting place !
We got there after it closed so were unable to see the giant Buddha, but it was still a great place to visit!
Todaiji Temple is one of the most impressive and important temples in all Japan. It's a must when you come to my home town, Nara.

...beside the deers of course. The giant Buddha’s are big, of course too. The place closes at 5, if you stay until then you will get the chance to make photos without people, but you will need to be “inside” since they put curtains in the main door.
The Buddha statue is huge and magnificent. However, not much is explained in english. Hence, it might make sense to rent audio guide.
You will learn a lot about Japan getting in the temple. All rituals are unique. The history of the temple is amazing. It is a half day tour at least!

The temple is the biggest wood construction and Buddha statue in bronze in the world. Combined with the visit of the deer park makes it worth the day trip to Nara which is 90 minutes away from Kyoto. Entry cost is minimal 600 for the temple and a 1,000 if you also want to visit

It takes a lot to impress me but this place does. The grandeur of the building overwhelms while peaceful. You might think you've seen all of the temples you need to see but you're wrong. This is a must.

Take your time to discover this place. It has many things to offer beyond being the largest wooden temple such as a chance to test your ability to reach nirvana, many wonderful buildings and small replicas of the temple as it changed over the years.

We first visited this temple in 2010, and then came back with our two boys ages 5 and 7...9 years later. Its one of our favorites and so impressive, our boys even loved it and were amazed at the large Buddha, and crawled through the pillar!

Largest wooden structure, housing largest bronze statue of Buddha. Over 1300 years old. Reasonably priced entry fee considering the significance of the site. Deer roaming freely in park near site is an added bonus.

The temple architecture itself is stunning. The statues of Buddha and Bodhisattva Avalokitesvara, sitting peacefully right at the hall facing main entrance, really caught attentions - enormous and holy. The beauty of craftsmanship as well as facial expression bring true peace
It’s really a massive place. We payed the 600 yen each to tour inside. Grab yourself an English speaking guide to understAnd what you’re looking at.

So this is just another temple. *yawn*. They all look pretty much the same but this one has a giant Budda inside it. $10 will get you in to see it. To be honest unless you absolutely must see the giant Budda for yourself I'd take the $10 and go buy lunch. Other than the
We were on the fence whether the 1200 yen admission for two of us would be worth it, but it was. Pictures don't do the Great Buddha justice. It is dizzingly tall and just towers over you.

This temple was built in 710 - 792 AD. It is Vairocana Budddha, meaning Buddha that shines throughout the world like the sun. It serves as both a place of worship/prayer for peace and affluence on earth.

When i saw the picture on google it looks like a regular temple, but in reality its a huge complex. there are also wooden imitation of how the temple got bigger over years and how it looked in the past. the buddha statue is quite unique. Lovely place

Different from other Shrines and Temples in Japan, this place really felt like a special place. It's worth the time to walk from the Nara train station to the temple and do the entire round of the place.
Todai-ji temple is one of the most amazing places in Nara! The wooden building is simply huge as well as the statues inside it. Also, it's a place full of peace! If you go to Nara, don't skip it.

Near the Nara Park is the Todai-ji temple. The Great Buddha is extremely impressive as you enter the temple. There are also a number of other Buddha's there. The entire building doesn't take too long to go through, as you walk around the sites there is no opportunity to get
Can be quite busy as it's one of the main attractions. Lovely approach through the park with all of the deer.
We enjoyed our visit here. The huge Buddha was unique and beautiful. Its worth a visit to experience this place. Wasn't too busy the day we went.

Fantastic temple experience. We received a free guided tour in English from a lovely volunteer. Probably my favourite temple visit in Japan.

Must visit for all tourists. It costs 600 yen to visit the Buddha Hall and an extra 400 yen for the museum. Recommend coming around 4pm to view the sunset scene. Note that this place closes at 5pm though.
Been there multiple times, everytime was a greater experience than the previous. An amazing temple, a bit too crowded at times, but if you can get past that and enjoy it, it's a must see spot.

Todaiji temple could be reach by using a Bus or by walking from the Kintetsu Nara Station. We chose to walk towards the temple. As we walk, we already started encountering deer roaming around the area, and even on the roads! There are a lot of deer cookie vendor scattered in the

If you're wondering which temple to see near Osaka since there are so many to choose from, I'd definitely choose Todai-ji. Why? Because the trip from Osaka is easy by train, and once you're there it's a casual walk to the temple via the Nara park. Most importantly, especially
Very impressed with the building. Have to see it in you own eye. Not planned to enter initially, but was attracted by it when arrived by the entrance.
No photo could ever do justice to how amazing Todai-ji Temple is in person. It has been the highlight of our entire Japan experience.

Generally I make it a point to visit any temple/shrine in japan if I’m nearby. So during my visit to Nara park I popped by. Personally, I felt a sense of awe when arrived at the temple. It’s not the most majestic of buildings, but perhaps the surroundings blending in with the

We arrived at Todai-ji at 8:15 and there were only a few people. At 9:00, most of the tour buses arrive and it gets very crowded. The temple is very large, but you will need 20 minutes in the temple at a maximum. There are paths leading to many minor sites to visit.

We took a day off Kyōto to go to Nara and we were not disappointed. Todai-ji Temple has amazing ancient buildings with massive Buddha inside. On top you get to walk around semi-wild dears. Don’t miss it!

I will definitely be in the minority here, but the Giant Buddha of Todai-ji Temple did absolutely nothing for me. Perhaps it was the crowds, perhaps it was the exhausting summer heat, perhaps it was the darkness inside the temple itself - all I know is I wasn't impressed at all
The Toda ji Zen temple is a wonder by itself. The statue is just wonderful. The temple is just jaw dropping Never seem something so large. .
Biggest Buddha I've ever seen!! Unfortunately it's covered by a big wooden building so you can't really see it from the outside but I guess the want to preserve it or something 🤔🤔🤔

Todaji Temple is, quite simply, spectacular. The temple building is HUGE and the statues it houses are incredible in both size and beauty. In my opinion, if you only see one thing in Nara, this has to be it.
This is one of the must-see temples in Japan. A beautiful central Buddha, with a number of surrounding statues throughout the Temple.
Need to walk some distant through Nara Park before arriving at Nandaimon Gate of Tōdaiji and Todaiji Temple. Some souvenir shops to get great souvenirs from Nara. See deers and more deers.
Nara in general is just a charming town and the Todai-ji and its Giant Buddha are awe inspiring. Don't miss it! Extraordinary
Impressive temple and statues especially as they are made of wood. Lots of Japanese history to pick up here.

It takes you an auspicious time for Calm and Serene in mind to visit this holy place. You will enjoy the Deers that push their heads against you for crackers or pieces of bread. Be careful of them to take the paper tissues or plastic wrappers of sandwich from your holding

The structure is massive and quite an architectural achievement during its time. The Buddha is monstrous in size. Nice walk through the Nara park with all the deer walking around looking for food from the visitors.

was the visit to Nara, and in particular, Toda-ji Temple. Its beautiful. The Buddha Statue, the other statues in the hall, etc - amazing! it was also fun watching people wriggling their way through Buddha's Nostril!

Took the train from Kyoto to Nara and walked up to the temple. Big grounds and full of tourists and school groups when we were there We had a short 10 minute introduction to it by one of the volunteer guides at the entrance. Obviously the main attraction is the big Buddha but

It’s amazing, doesn’t even look real, it was an amazing sight. There’s the whole history behind why it was made and why the hand was done like that etc. We went at an extremely busy time unfortunately so we followed the crowd and didn’t have much time to take in the full view.
This temple is imposing and has some beautiful statues besides the huge gold Buddha. the grounds a beautifully manicured.

The most famous temple in Nara, Typical japanese temple in a very nice area near Nara park. Good spot for pics but don't expect to be alone there

WOW what an amazing place. The massive statues are enormous and just brilliant to view. the work they put into these. a very interesting place and a must to visit allow a couple of hours. easy walking and good for children of all ages.
Beautiful and interesting. Temples, shrines and grounds. This should be your top priority in Nara. GO.
We came with little knowledge of the region but we were pleased we stopped by, we would recommend it to all even just to see

Nara is a lovely city and Todai-ji temple is definitely worth visiting. It can get a little crowded at times so come early.

Our main goal for Nara was really just the deers. I just htough we could drop by the temple and take a look see. It was a really good experience since it was our first temple experience in Japan. There were stamps that you can collect at each temple you go to and this was out

Must visit when you step in Nara. If you don’t want to walk , you can take a bus from Nara Kintetsu station ( check with station master- direction ) and it will drop you in front of temple. Walking from station to temple should be around 15mins. Inside and Outside of temple

It is worth the walk from Nara station and moving around the deers gathering in front of the temple. The Buddha statue is awesome. Avoid holding the deer crackers in your hands as deers will rush at you.

Todai-ji is a balance of temple and tourist attraction but is well worth it. While the main hall is worth seeing for the Daibatsu, venture further up the mountain to the see some amazing views of Nara.

Probably the most important and impressive shrine in Japan and is a must for tourists. The meditating Buddha gives a wonderful sense of calm and peace.

This temple is one of the highlights of a visit to Nara and should be included in your itinerary. Although it gets quite busy, there's still enough space that it doesn't feel uncomfortably crowded. Worth paying the entrance fee to see the Buddhas inside.

Very big and huge temple with a humongous campus and a very beautiful statue. Some deers are roaming around . And place was very crowded if you want to click some snaps with deers better to go to Nark park. This place you can reach by taking bus from station
At this temple there is much more to see than in most temples in Japan. The temple is impressive and inside you can find more large statues. Access with a wheelchair is probably very hard.

Go go go. You may think it’s all a touristy hype but that’s one big wooden temple with a fairly overwhelming sized Buddha statue/ sculpture. There is an entry fee and there’s lots of people as well. Try and go very early if you can to skip the crowds..

Situated in Nara park this temple was awesome. Everything about it is on the large size and the Buddha is enormous. Lovely walk around the area and an interesting archaeological dig nearby. The deer aren't allowed in the temple, thank goodness!

This was fantastic to visit. There was a great deal of history and sculptures to admire within this building.

This was a fun day, scenic train trip from Osaka, enjoyable walk from the station with heaps of little shops and places to eat. Sika deer everywhere leading up to the temple. It was actually fun to watch people trying to feed them. Breathtaking temple with a giant Buddha inside.

Todaiji temple is located in the Nara park, and surrounded with nature all around. What amazes me is the giany Buddha’s inside which will mesmerize you.
I was amazed. Stunning, from the statues to the building. If your in the Nara area, this is a must. The walk to the structure itself is great since the roads are full of deer.

Large Buddha figure in an huge impressive wooden temple. The building itself is worth a visit, although the large statues, partly golden, are the actually famous sight. In the nearby park, you can see and feed crowds of friendly dears.

We went to Todai-ji Temple 45 minutes before closing. There were not that many people there. The temple looks amazing from the outside. The big budah on the inside the temple is the most interesting part though. Seeing the statue and walking to it gave me that strange feeling

The temple is insane, it’s so large, the Buddha inside is huge as well. If you’re in Nara this temple is a must see. Very impressive.

Was nice to see. But there are definitely better places in Nara to explore for nature lovers! Historical and architectural point of few I can ensure- it was a very special experience. Especially the exterior of the temple..
We’ve been to so many temples on our trip that I’m a bit Templed out but glad we came to see this. The size of the wooden building and Buddha statues are impressive!
This temple is located in the Nara park. Very impressive the big statues you can see inside the temple. If you came in Nara you can't miss this

A must see when visiting Japan. Packed full of tourists and Japanese school kids. Be careful of the deers roaming the site as they do bite.

This was an interesting place to visit and see the largest Buddha and the other items in this venue. It is worth your time to put on your list of things to see.

Very nice temple to visit!! You can find the biggest bronze buddha here! It is impressive to see it since it is inside the temple. When you go to the gift shop, you can find a pillar. In this pillar, there is a hole with the size of the nostril of the buddha. It appears that if

Great Japanese architecture and its history. Constructed with timber and iron. It’s beautiful and a must see when you visit the Nara deer park. A small fee apply.

text.wiki:
The Ikoma Cable Line (生駒鋼索線, Ikoma kōsaku sen), referred to as Ikoma Cable (生駒ケーブル, Ikoma kēburu), is a cable railway line owned and operated by the Kintetsu Railway, a Japanese major private railway. The line connects Toriimae to Ikomasanjo, all of which are within Ikoma, Nara, Japan.


== Basic data ==
Lines and distances:
Hōzanji Line: Toriimae - Hōzanji, 0.9 km (0.6 mi)
Sanjō Line: Hōzanji - Ikoma-Sanjō, 1.1 km (0.7 mi)
Gauge: 1,067 mm (3 ft 6 in)
Stations: 5
Double track line: Toriimae — Hōzanji
Quadruple at the passing loop
Vertical interval:
Hōzanji Line: 146 m (479 ft)
Sanjō Line: 322 m (1,056 ft)


== Overview ==
The Ikoma Cable Line is actually made up of two different lines; Hōzanji Line (宝山寺線, Hōzanji-sen) between Toriimae and Hōzanji, Sanjō Line (山上線, Sanjō-sen) between Hōzanji and Ikoma-Sanjō. The Hōzanji Line is the oldest commercially operated funicular in Japan, opened in 1918. It runs to Hōzan-ji, a Shingon Buddhist temple. Sanjō Line climbs up Mount Ikoma, reaching Ikoma Sanjo Amusement Park.
The Hōzanji Line is the only double-track funicular in the country. However, the two tracks are treated as different lines, called Hōzanji Line 1 (宝山寺1号線, Hōzanji Ichi-gō-sen) and Hōzanji Line 2 (宝山寺2号線, Hōzanji Ni-gō-sen). Normally, only Hōzanji Line 1 and Sanjō Line are used. Hōzanji Line 2 is operated in holiday seasons, and for safety inspections of the Line 1. Since the Hōzanji Line runs along a fairly urbanized area, it also functions as a commuter line. However, the line does not accept PiTaPa, a smart card ticketing system, nor Surutto Kansai, a prepaid magnetic card ticketing system.


== Rolling stocks ==
Hōzanji Line 1 used classical 1928 cars until 2000, when they were replaced by the current fancy-decorated cars. Since then, bulldog-faced "Bull" and calico cat-faced "Mike" serve the line, both officially being Type Ko 11. Sanjō Line uses organ-like "Do-Re-Mi", cake-decorated "Sweet", both officially Type Ko 15. Hōzanji Line 2 uses ordinary-shaped Type Ko 3 cars, nicknamed "Yume-Ikoma".

		
		
		


== Stations ==
All stations are in Ikoma, Nara Prefecture. For distances and connections, see the route diagram.

Hōzanji Line 1 and 2
Toriimae (鳥居前)
Hōzanji (宝山寺)
Sanjō Line (D: Direct trains stop, operated seasonally)
Hōzanji D
Umeyashiki (梅屋敷)
Kasumigaoka (霞ヶ丘)
Ikoma-Sanjō D (生駒山上)


== See also ==
Cable car
Funicular railway
List of funicular railways
List of railway lines in Japan
Mt. Ikoma
